DOC.HEAD: Suspect Died From Police Bullets; Murder Weapon Identified
DOC.TEXT: The man suspected of killing a family of four and setting their bodies on fire Christmas weekend died from police gunfire rather than a self-inflicted wound, according to autopsy results released Thursday. Michael Kinge, also known as Anthony Turner, died Wednesday morning in a shootout with state police when they tried to arrest him at his Dryden apartment. Police opened fire on Kinge when he turned toward them and fired the shotgun he had been holding under his chin. It hadn't been immediately clear whether Kinge, 33, died from his own or police bullets. State Police Capt. Carl Shaver said the Tompkins County medical examiner found that Kinge died as a result of police bullets. The shot he fired grazed the left side of his face but wasn't fatal, Shaver said. A coroner's investigation ruled the death ``justifiable homicide,'' Shaver said. ``The medical examiners believed he was turning to fire at police and his gun accidentally discharged,'' Shaver said. Kinge would have been charged with the Dec. 22 killings of Dolores and Warren A. Harris and their two children, 15-year-old Shelby and 11-year-old Marc. The Harrises were each bound hand and foot, shot in the back of the head, and then doused with gasoline and set afire. Robbery is believed to be the motive, and police traced Kinge through descriptions of a man who used credit cards stolen from the family home. Police said that a sawed-off rifle found in the suspect's apartment had been positively identified as the weapon used to kill the family. Kinge's mother, 54-year-old Shirley Kinge, has been charged with four counts of second-degree murder, one count of arson and one count of possessing stolen property in the Harris case.

DOC.HEAD: Johns Hopkins To Begin Random Drug Testing of Doctor
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital will be randomly tested for alcohol and drugs under a policy initiated by the physicians themselves, the hospital said Thursday. Hopkins was believed to be the first hospital in the country to adopt such a policy for physicians. Dr. Hamilton Moses III, the hospital's vice president for medical affairs, said the policy will take effect in July. Twenty percent to 50 percent of the 750 doctors who are up for reappointment then would be randomly selected for tests to determine if they have used alcohol, tranquilizers, cocaine or other drugs, he said. ``We don't know the precise number and we've not actually devised the precise protocol that we will be using, but we expect to screen somewhere between a quarter and a half of the medical staff every other year,'' Moses said. Under the policy, doctors who test positive for drugs or alcohol would be tested a second time. After a second positive test, they would be evaluated and, if necessary, sent for rehabilitation, hospital spokeswoman Joann Rodgers said. ``Only...if the doctor is not successfully rehabilitated would he be dismissed or removed from the staff,'' Moses said. ``Objections to our plan have been raised,'' Moses said. ``Not every person perceives there is a need to do it and not everyone on the staff believes it's appropriate to be this heavy-handed.'' Officials with the American Hospital Association and American Medical Association said they were unaware of any hospital instituting such a policy for doctors. ``There are hospitals who do testing on employees, and it is common to have `for cause' kinds of drug tests, but no one here is aware of a regular community or acute care hospital'' that tests physicians, said Mary Babich, spokewoman for the American Hospital Association. The American Medical Association's policy on drug testing of doctors is under review, a spokesman said Thursday. Non-clinical faculty at Hopkins who don't care directly for patients are exempt from random testing. Testing for them and others in the school of medicine is under review, Rodgers said. Doctors and other hospital workers, such as nurses and technicians, are subject to a three-year-old policy that requires tests if supervisors believe an employee's work has been impaired by drugs or alcohol, Rodgers said. All physicians involved in direct patient care, most of whom are up for reappointment after two years, will be tested every two years, Rodgers said. ``Everybody eventually will be tested probably within the two-year time period. After that, everybody will be tested each time they come up for credentialing or renewal,'' she said. Hopkins has a medical staff of 1,500.

DOC.HEAD: Little Jack Horner's Having Its Last Laughs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: With the wrecking ball just off stage left, the curtain is going down on Little Jack Horner Jokes and Magic, home for half a century to pranksters, clowns and vaudevillian wannabees. Little Jack Horner's regulars say they are losing an informal clubhouse, and that Boston is losing a little bit of its heart. ``People come in here not just to shop,'' said owner Fred Lezburg. ``We've got second- and third-generation customers who remember coming here as kids.'' And of course there are the characters. ``We get a lot of them,'' Lezburg says. There are those who wander in to check out the pranks designed for an ``adult audience'' or the groups of giggling young women who come in on their lunch break looking for just the right prop for a bachelorette party. But Lezburg says the clowns, who are ``not the biggest spenders but regular and fun,'' will probably end up the hardest hit. They'll have to look elsewhere for their oversized scissors, rubber noses and other crowd-pleasers. Gone, too, will be the inflatable Wayne Newton dolls, whoopie cushions and exploding cigars. Say goodbye to the rubber chickens and counterfeit cockroaches, things that squirt and pop out of cans. Say goodbye, as a matter of fact, to an entire block of one of Boston's most colorful little streets, which runs down the hill from the state capitol building. The building's owner wants to put a new face on the street, tear down the building and put up an office tower. Also caught up in the change will be Bromfield Street's Hat Cleaning and Shine, where a customer could get a good shine for a buck or so, and where they'd even put new heels on your shoes if you wanted to wait a few minutes. Also affected are a flower shop and a jeweler specializing in pawn. ``They want a bigger, better, higher building,'' said Lezburg, a ``reformed accountant'' who took over the business nearly five years ago. ``And I guess we don't fit into the picture.'' The picture in downtown Boston has changed a lot in recent years. Rundown blocks are revitalized while the fabled strip joints and back alley bars of the nearby ``Combat Zone'' fade slowly from the scene. And, as often is the case, the mom-and-pop stores that dotted narrow streets are giving way to bigger stores and office buildings. ``This street has become a dead end,'' Lezburg said Wednesday. ``And it's too bad because this is a place that a lot of people look to as being the high point of their day.'' Starting today, the prices on Lezburg's stock were going to be slashed. When the sky-high shelves lined with rubber likenesses of everyone from Ronald Reagan to horror movie character Freddie Krueger are cleared, the city will have only one joke store on which to rely, Jack's Joke Shop. Founded in 1922, it claims to be the nation's oldest active joke shop. ``I'm quite sure that down the line people will come into my shop and ask, `Where did Little Jack Horner's go?''' said Harold Bengin, who took over Jack's Joke Shop from his father-in-law. ``And sadly I'll have to say `They've gone out of business.' It's tough for the little guy in today's economy.'' Until about two weeks ago, Lezburg had been trying to find a place to relocate. But he's paying about $20 a square foot on Bromfield Street and prices like that have gone the way of his hard-to-find $200 Planet of the Apes mask. And besides, Lezburg has gone through this before and isn't convinced it wouldn't happen again. In 1986, he was forced out of Little Jack Horner's original site around the corner near Boston Common to make way for a condominium project. ``This is the kind of store that lends itself to laughter and I'm trying to keep that up on the outside,'' Lezburg said. ``But on the inside I'm not doing as well. I put my heart into this thing and I'm coming up empty and disappointed, terribly disappointed.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Negotiates From Comfortable Home in Prison Compound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela endured harsh treatment for many years and remains a prisoner, but now he lives in a large, comfortable home and meets government ministers to discuss the end of white rule. Mandela, often described as the world's most famous prisoner, occupies a white ranch-style house with a swimming pool at the Victor Verster Prison, which is set among the vineyards of the Winterberg Mountains. He and President F.W. de Klerk have become the critical figures in efforts for a peaceful resolution of South Africa's long racial conflict. In a speech Feb. 2, de Klerk promised to free Mandela, 71, and legalized the African National Congress and more than 60 other banned groups fighting South Africa's policy of racial separation, or apartheid. Government ministers visit Mandela regularly to prepare for talks on ending white rule and sharing power with blacks. Many blacks call Mandela the ``father of the nation,'' and he has assumed almost mythical status as a leader and a man. Many countrymen see him as the ultimate president and even the white-led government appears to deal with him as an equal. The government that has imprisoned him for more than 27 years now hopes Mandela will help solve the nation's problems by acting as a mediator between the administration and its opponents. Mandela, one of South Africa's first black lawyers, was arrested and jailed in 1962. Two years later, he was convicted of leading the ANC sabotage campaign against the government and sentenced to life in prison. Living at Victor Verster Prison is much different from the privations Mandela suffered at the notorious prison on Robben Island off Cape Town. People who have visited him say his house has three bedrooms, a study, medical examination room and swimming pool, and is surrounded by red and yellow flowers. A deputy prison commander occupied the house before it was assigned to Mandela about a year ago. He rises daily at 3:30 a.m. and exercises for two hours, including lifting weights, skipping rope and doing push-ups, according to press reports. After that, he spends most of the day studying, reading a stream of newspapers and periodicals, and following the news on radio and television. A small staff of white guards prepares his food and attends to his needs, the reports say. The house is under heavy security, surrounded by razor wire and watchtowers. Regular visits are permitted, and Mandela uses the mail and a prison fax machine to communicate with colleagues and friends at home and abroad. More than half South Africa's 37 million people were born while he was in prison. No one but guards and visitors has seen or heard him in that time. Supporters, and even some opponents, praise Mandela for his courage and dedication during nearly three decades in prison. ``He's certainly a leader of stature,'' said Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen, who has been meeting with Mandela. The Rev. Allan Boesak, an anti-apartheid leader of mixed race who met Mandela for the first time Tuesday, called him a great man waiting to lead the nation. ``A man of superior intelligence, a great strategist,'' was the way Boesak described him. People who have seen Mandela say he is remarkably lacking in bitterness about the hard years of breaking stone and building roads on Robben Island. Men jailed with him said he fought for prisoner rights and refused to be cowed by the authorities. A recent biography by a long-time friend said Mandela suffered greatly from loneliness and sometimes despaired. ``The worst part of imprisonment is being locked up by yourself,'' Mandela was quoted as saying. ``You come face-to-face with time and there is nothing more terrifying than to be alone with sheer time.'' What Mandela plans for South Africa when he is free remains unclear, and visitors and other sources disagree about it. Boesak said Mandela had not changed his principles, including the desire for a one-man, one-vote democracy with no special status for any group. Other reports claim Mandela is a pragmatist who accepts that white rule must end gradually, with many safeguards for minorities. Close friends and aides often refuse to talk about Mandela and the future, saying he alone can answer those questions.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Gov't Denies Allegations of Torture, Fundamentalist Leanings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In power seven months, Sudan's National Salvation Revolution has done little to revive a collapsing economy or end a debilitating civil war that has killed hundreds of thousands and threatens more with starvation. The war is getting worse. Despite optimistic official talk of an approaching military victory, 11 southern towns have fallen to rebels in recent weeks, and the south's largest city, Juba, is teetering under siege. The Sudan People's Liberation Army led by a renegade colonel, John Garang, launched its rebellion against the Moslem-dominated government in 1983, demanding economic and political autonomy for the predominantly Christian and animist in the country's southern half. Seven years of war have aggravated conditions in Sudan, Africa's largest country. What was once considered a potential breadbasket is an economic basket case after 34 years of independence. Sudan still can't make payments on foreign debts of more than $13 billion. It has been ineligible for loans from the International Monetary Fund since 1986 and is in arrears to the World Bank and most of its Western and Arab creditors. Meanwhile, Sudanese wonder whether their nation will become an Islamic state, reviving laws that sever thieves' hands and lash people who drink alcohol. Sudanese intellectuals and foreign diplomats say the young officers of the 15-member ruling junta _ most are in their 30s _ apparently yield major decisions to a 40-member council, or majlis in traditional Islam, dominated by the fundamentalist National Islamic Front. They say Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, the leader of the junta, vacillates between radical front members and more moderate forces. The brigadiers justified overthrowing Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi's civilian regime June 30 by pointing out that multiparty democracy had failed to end the long war or save the shattered economy. Their most visible accomplishment has been a spruce-up job on Khartoum, the capital. Run-down roundabouts and squares have been prettied up with flowers and gleaming tiles. Streets are cleaned regularly, although potholes remain. Shop facades are painted white, with bright green shutters. ``On the outside, things look changed,'' said a Sudanese woman who, like many in el-Bashir's Sudan, refused to speak for attribution. ``The streets are clean. The squares have flowers. The shops are newly painted. ``But the shelves are bare, so even if you have money, you can't buy anything.'' The shop-painting gives an insight into the state of the country today. The choice of green, usually considered the color of Islam, fueled rumors that most junta members sympathize with the National Islamic Front. Disbanding the front and other political parties and trade unions was among the junta's first acts. On Wednesday, el-Bashir said he would soon announce the formation of a one-party system that would be open to all Sudanese. The front and other political parties remain banned, but diplomats say it's clear that supporters of the Islamic Front are in control. One diplomat said his embassy learned that el-Bashir had planned on Jan. 1 _ independent Sudan's 34th anniversary _ to declare an Islamic state. He planned to restore harshly interpreted Islamic laws, or Sharia, originally imposed in 1983 by former military strongman Gafaar Nimeiri but now largely ignored, the diplomat said. The diplomat said el-Bashir was dissuaded from the move by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Sudan's powerful northern neighbor, on a quick New Year's Eve visit to Khartoum. The government's public position is that even if Sharia were enforced, non-Islamic regions could exempt themselves, unlike the practice under Nimeiri. His insistence on nationwide Sharia exacerbated the rebellion that had begun several months earlier, and its existence as the basic law continues to fuel the battle between the mainly non-Moslem, black southerners and the Arab Moslem-dominated administration. The southern civil war still costs the economy $1 million a day while causing famine that has killed hundreds of thousands and threatens as many more. El-Bashir recently spoke of approaching victory over the enemy of 30,000 trained bush fighters and 20,000 irregulars, who have fared no worse than a standoff for seven years. The war recently intensified after a lull last year, which allowed relief to be ferried to desperate civilians but also permitted rearming by both sides. Peace talks are suspended indefinitely. Such developments, largely because of both sides' intransigence, have triggered protests from the United States, Egypt and other European and Arab allies of Sudan. Allegations by the London-based Amnesty International and others of human rights abuses also have elicited complaints from aid-giving countries of the West. The government denies the charges, but diplomats in Khartoum say one of the major decisions the el-Bashir government left to the Islamic majlis was the handling of political prisoners. It approved torture, diplomats allege. The junta has cowed the opposition. After sentencing a doctor to death for leading a strike by physicians _ a sentence el-Bashir reportedly commuted later _ threats of labor action are no longer heard. Especially intimidated have been the trade unions and professional organizations whose strikes and civil unrest brought down three previous Sudanese governments.

DOC.HEAD: Hey FAT _ Your Tag is Showing!
DOC.TEXT: FAT tags are showing in Georgia, and it's going to cost those who want to shed the label. Some drivers issued license plates with the prefix FAT are complaining about driving around with the word bolted to the tail end of the family wheels. Officials say there's one way to get rid of FAT: a replacement plate, which costs $2 to $8. About 900 of the plates, from FAT101 to FAT999, have been distributed in the Athens area as Georgia changes its license plate design this year. ``I had one lady who said she was literally sick over it because she's overweight and she had such a hangup about it anyway, and having to go out with a tag that says `FAT' on her car would be just horrible,'' said Nancy Denson, Clarke County tax commissioner and license tag agent. She said about 50 people have complained. Maj. David Camp of the Clarke County Police Department said a dozen FAT plates have been reported as somehow ``lost'' or ``stolen.'' Falsely reporting such a thing is illegal, he said, but added that prosecution would be unlikely in this case. Clint Moye, director of the state Revenue Department's motor vehicle division, said FAT may join about 100 other letter combinations already blacklisted _ but not until a new plate is issued again in 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Red Army Landing at West Point
DOC.TEXT: A red shadow is being cast on West Point cadets this week. Ten cadets and two officers from the Soviet Union's Red Army on Wednesday began a seven-day visit to the U.S. Military Academy. Next month, American cadets are to visit Moscow's Supreme Soviet Military Academy. Each Soviet cadet was assigned to ``shadow'' an American counterpart through classes, calisthenics, marches, meals and even in sleep, according to military spokesman Ray Aalbue. ``We've even put extra beds in the barracks,'' Aalbue said. The hope is that the Soviets will get a glimpse of a democracy's military ethics and how the U.S. Army operates. The two Soviet officers will meet academy officials and observe the cadets. West Point already has students from 34 other countries. The Soviet exchange was proposed by Gen. Dmitri Grinkevish, the chief of staff of Soviet Ground Forces, when he visited West Point last year to observe training.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Porn Crackdown; Arrests for Stealing Magazines from U.S. Army
DOC.TEXT: In the country's most sweeping crackdown on illegal pornography, police have seized more than 200,000 adult sex magazines worth $7.3 million and arrested at least 18 people, prosecutors said today. More than 20,000 of the magazines were copies of Playboy, Penthouse and Hustler stolen from a U.S. Army base in Seoul, prosecutors said. The magazines are not available legally in South Korea, but are sold to U.S. forces through base outlets. Blackmarket copies sell for $22 to $30 apiece. The Seoul District Prosecutors Office said that among Korean-produced materials in the seizure were 50,000 comic books depicting explicit sex, 15,000 magazines with erotic pictures and text, 10,000 pornographic books, and 5,000 sex gadgets and stimulants. Nah Myong-su, 49, and Ahn Dok-jun, 41, who helped run the warehouse for the U.S. 8th Army in Seoul, were charged with larceny and illegally handing over to third parties copies of magazines pilfered from the warehouse since 1983. Prosecutor Cho Chung-ung said charges against other people were for producing and marketing obscene publications and sex gadgets and illegally dealing in pornographic materials. He said the investigation into organized criminal rings which specialize in underground sex was continuing. On Wednesday, prosecutors announced the arrest of nine people including a department store president, a film star and a runner-up in the Miss Korea pageant for allegedly using illegal drugs in sex orgies. South Korea is a conservative homogeneous society with old-fashioned values of family, marriage and centuries-old traditions. Many Koreans are deeply concerned that their country's increasing affluence and new Western-style consumerism are tearing at the social fabric. The government has stepped up efforts in the past year to weed out illicit drugs, pornography and prostitution. Arrests have been made, but such activities continue to thrive.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leaders Blaze New, Competitive Role For Party
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leadership has blazed the way to a brave new world of Soviet politics, where it will be forced to compete with other parties and people will directly choose the nation's leader for the first time. ``There will be a multiparty system. There will be a normal democracy,'' is how Communist Party member Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a noted eye surgeon, approvingly summed up a three-day meeting of the party's Central Committee, which voted Wednesday to end the party's legal monopoly on power. The decisions won't assume force of law until they are adopted by the Soviet legislative system, a process that could begin next week. They are the boldest steps yet in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to get the party he heads out of the day-to-day business of running the country and provide greater freedom for political action. A Central Committee source said the platform approved Wednesday calls for a president elected by the people instead of the Congress of People's Deputies or another legislative body _ a revolutionary transformation for Soviet politics. That would allow Gorbachev to bypass the Moscow bureaucracy and take his case directly to the people. ``The party does not assume full government authority,'' Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov told a news conference called to explain the new platform, which was to be published later. ``Its role is to be a political leader with no particular role to be included in the constitution.'' Following the lead of its fraternal parties in Eastern Europe, the Soviet party will propose repeal of its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power, Lukyanov said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher praised the vote as a great decision but added there was ``a lot still to be done.'' President Bush made no direct reference to the vote but credited Gorbachev for ``handling some extraordinarily complicated internal problems ... with a certain restraint and finesse that I think demonstrates a real commitment to peaceful change.'' Gorbachev has been struggling for nearly five years to transform the Soviet Union into a modern democracy, to save the badly ailing economy and to keep the union from dissolving under the weight of nationalist upheaval. His new proposals are unlikely to bring about the rapid collapse of Communist power. Unlike Eastern Europe, where alternative political groups have been at least marginally active for years and sprang quickly into genuine opposition parties during last year's peaceful revolutions, the Soviet Union has no nationwide alternative to the Communists. The party also holds uncounted financial resources and controls much of the nation's press, from Pravda, the party's flagship daily, to small-circulation tabloids printed for reindeer herders in Siberia. It has long held veto power on appointments to important jobs on every level. The vast majority of Soviets now living have never known anything but Communist Party rule, established after the 1917 revolution swept the czar from power. Voters are unlikely to immediately oust the Communists from control except in a few regions such as the independence-minded Baltic republics, where there are strong local political movements. ``We Communists are not going to surrender our positions. Just like any party in the world, we shall be waging a struggle for our rights,'' Politburo member Vitaly I. Vorotnikov told a group of Brazilian legislators in remarks reported by the official Tass news agency. Fellow Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, a close Gorbachev ally, told the news conference he hopes new parties will share the socialist ideal. But he said the adopted platform calls for banning only groups that condone ethnic strife or violent overthrow of the government. The actual constitutional change must be approved by the Supreme Soviet legislature, which opens its next session on Wednesday, and by the Congress, which is to meet this spring but could be called into special session. At its last meeting in December, the Congress heeded Gorbachev's plea for delay and blocked an effort by reformers to strike the Communists' leading role from the constitution. The issue achieved greater urgency after Lithuania's Communists broke with Moscow later that month and formed a new party. Gorbachev dropped his public opposition to alternative political parties just three weeks ago, so it was a surprise when he proposed Monday that the possibility should be put into law. Gorbachev packed the meeting of the 249-member Central Committee with more than 700 other officials, many of them progressives who took the floor to demand radical reform. In two votes, first by the Central Committee and then by the entire assembly, there was only one ``no'' vote _ maverick Communist Boris N. Yeltsin, who had favored an even more radical program demanding a virtual apology by the party for decades of totalitarian rule, the Central Committee source said. The committee also agreed to advance the start of the next party Congress from October to June. For the first time, delegates to the Congress, the most powerful party body, will be elected by the nation's 20 million Communists. Previously they were approved by the leadership, thus ensuring the status quo. Congress then will elect a new Central Committee and could either choose the party leader _ now Gorbachev _ or allow the rank-and-file to choose, Yakovlev said. The Central Committee is considered by reformers to be the bastion of conservatives wary of Gorbachev's reform program and the Congress would offer Gorbachev another chance to reform the committee to his liking. The committee scolded Lithuania's Communist Party for declaring independence from Moscow and backed a small group of Lithuanian Communists who remain loyal to the Kremlin. Lithuanian officials said the break was a precursor to secession by the Baltic republic and said it was necessary for them to prevent defeat in local elections Feb. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Army Taking Back 14 Combat Medals
DOC.TEXT: The Army, in an embarrassing admission, is taking back Combat Infantryman Badges from 14 wounded soldiers who were mistakenly granted the coveted awards within days of their involvement in the Panama invasion. Some of the awards were incorrectly bestowed because the wounded men were still under sedation when the medals were pinned to their pillows and couldn't be queried about their duties during Operation Just Cause, according to Army spokesman Maj. Joe Padilla. Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army chief of staff, awarded the medals during a visit to two military hospitals in San Antonio, Texas, on Dec. 22. The chief of staff awarded 186 medals _ such as Combat Infantry Badges and Purple Hearts _ during his time at the hospitals, Padilla said. ``There were 14 non-infantry soldiers awarded the CIB in Operation Just Cause. However, the awards have since been withdrawn and the affected soldiers notified,'' Padilla said. Although the awards apparently were given with some haste and without the usual review, the spokesman said the decision was not made to grant the medals just for publicity's sake. ``This was not a photo op for Gen. Vuono,'' Padilla said. ``This was an honest mistake.'' ``It was thought to be an opportunity for the men to be decorated by the chief of staff of the Army. ... It was an effort to distinguish those soldiers thought to be deserving, and allow those who were wounded to wake up with the award on their pillow,'' Padilla said. A pool of reporters was permitted to accompany Vuono to Wilford Hall Medical Center for the presentation of medals to just three soldiers. The general also visited nearby Brooke Army Medical Center. The Combat Infantryman Badge is granted only to officers or enlisted personnel with specific infantry specialties who have ``satisfactorily performed their duty'' in an infantry unit while it has engaged in combat, Padilla said. The Purple Heart is awarded to members of the armed forces wounded or killed in action. A formal review of the CIB awards found 14 were incorrectly given to soldiers who weren't infantrymen or did not have infantry specialties, Padilla said. The badges had been granted to men who were military policemen, artillery soldiers, communications specialists, truck drivers and specialists in psychological operations, the spokesman said. ``The soldiers that were incorrectly awarded the CIB were part of the initial 236 wounded soldiers evacuated out of Panama during the first 48 hours of Operation Just Cause,'' Padilla said. ``Because of time constraints, the personnel records weren't available to verify the eligibility of each soldier,'' he said. ``A decision was made to give the wounded soldiers the benefit of the doubt regarding the award of the CIB pending a final review of eligibility. It was during this review that the incorrectly awarded CIBs were discovered.'' The spokesman said he didn't think a soldier would be disappointed when he awoke and found he wasn't eligible. ``Every soldier knows what awards they're eligible for. They would know immediately that was a mistake,'' he said. The medals have been the source of some controversy in recent weeks because the women who came under fire in Panama will be ineligible for the award, since they are barred under Army policy from serving in infantry units. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has demanded that women who came under fire during Operation Just Cause be granted the medal despite the restriction. The three-inch badges portray a silver rifle on a blue background, emblazoned with a wreath.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Fasts to Dramatize War Against Drugs
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Bobbi Blok's voice is barely above a whisper as she tries to explain why she hasn't eaten any food in more than five weeks. She appears somewhat disoriented and apologizes for allowing her thoughts to wander and being unable to express herself clearly. Blok, 36, views her fast _ from Jan. 1 to Feb. 14 _ as her share of the war against drugs. ``The problems facing children and the family in the country (are) at a crisis situation, and drugs are the reason,'' says Blok, executive director of a child advocacy group, the Washington Child Development Center. ``Something has got to be done.'' Blok is drinking only a glass of grape juice in the morning and water through the rest of the day. The purpose of the fast is twofold _ to bring about a local and national drug summit and to get the government to increase funding to battle the drug problem at the social level, not in law enforcement. Blok plans to end her fast on Valentine's Day because she believes ``this country has a heart.'' She said she is grateful she was ``cleansing herself'' when Washington Mayor Marion Barry was arrested for possession of cocaine on Jan. 18. Blok, a senior campaign aide for Barry in 1986, said she never saw Barry use drugs. He did, however, have the symptoms of a drug user, she said. ``I made it clear to the mayor that I felt he needed help,'' she said. ``It was three days before Christmas. Here was the mayor _ a friend _ who needed help, and rather than confronting him I had been accepting his less-than-adequate explanations of his activities.'' Barry had ``all the classic forms of denial'' in that ``he was saying one thing and doing another. He had his priorities distorted, and I blame drugs,'' she added. So far, her hunger strike has not brought about the government policy changes she seeks. But Blok says she remains undaunted and doesn't believe she has starved herself for nothing. ``I'm losing my stamina, but in terms of my resolve and my commitment, it's never been stronger,'' she said in an interview Tuesday. ``I feel like there's a reason I'm doing this, if only to even strengthen my belief in knowing that an individual has the power to deal with the problems that face our society. ``I do not feel as if I've been ignored ... I realize that I'm risking my life _ that can't be denied _ but I've gotten to the point where I can't sit still and watch our elected officials deny that there is a drug epidemic.'' She has asked her physician not to tell her how much weight she has lost, and she is undergoing a blood test at least once a week. Blok said she started the fast after learning of a drug-related killing at an unlicensed child care center. A few days later, while she was working as a substitute at a day care center she overheard 3-year-old children talking about drugs, the police and guns. ``I have to believe that people care about this,'' Blok said. ``I also believe that our president cares, but what good is reading his lips if there's no substance to what he says? Something has got to be done about this drug situation ... the real victims of the drug war are our children.''

DOC.HEAD: Baggage Problems, Delays Plague Airlines, But Complaints Down
DOC.TEXT: An epidemic of delays and baggage problems are plaguing the nation's airlines but they're getting fewer complaints, according to a government report. On-time performance for December dipped to 70.2 percent from the 78 percent reported in November, the Transportation Department Air Travel Consumer Report said Wednesday. The worst previous showing was in January 1988 when 69.2 percent of flights were reported on time. The department blamed heavy holiday travel and severe winter weather in some parts of the country for service disruptions at the nation's largest airports. Delays due to mechanical problems are not included in the report. Mishandled baggage complaints filed against the carriers nearly doubled, from 6.99 per 1,000 passengers in November to 12.78 per 1,000 passengers in December. It was the worst month since the department began reporting airline performance two years ago. Complaints for 1989 totalled 12,403, which was about half the number received in 1988. Continuing the downward trend, December complaints totalled 749, down 33 percent from the 1,125 logged in November and the lowest since December 1989 when there were 733.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Group Says Congress Moving Toward the Center
With PM-Lists
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sens. Bill Armstrong of Colorado, Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming received the top 100 score from the American Conservative Union in its rating of the first session of the 101st Congress. They 100 scores meant those three toed the conservative line on two dozen votes in 1989 covering defense, foreign policy, taxation, spending and social issues. The higher the rating given by the ACU, the closer the lawmaker voted along the conservative path. There were also eight 100s among House members, all of them Republicans: Reps. Phil Crane of Illinois, Bill Dannemeyer of Calif., Jim Hansen of Utah., Wally Herger of California, John Hiler of Indiana, John Kasich of Ohio, Clarence Miller of Ohio and Don Ritter of Pennsylvania. Democrats Patrick Leahy of Vermont and Spark Matsunaga of Hawaii had the only zeros in the Senate. Matsunaga missed seven of the 24 votes because of health problems. Twelve senators _ all Democrats _ had ratings below 10: Alan Cranston of California, Christopher Dodd of Connecticut, Paul Sarbanes and Barbara Mikulski of Maryland, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, Jim Sasser of Tennessee and Brock Adams of Washington. The ACU said Wednesday that as a whole, Congress is moving toward the center, with the Senate becoming somewhat more conservative and the House slightly more liberal. The House has 257 Democrats and 175 Republicans. There are three vacancies. The Senate has 55 Democrats and 45 Republicans. ``Comparing this year's charts with those from the last few years, we find a slight shift toward the center by both parties in both houses,'' ACU Executive Director Daniel L. Casey said. ``It's probably too early to say whether this is a result of a kinder and gentler Bush congressional relations policy, or more reflective of a fundamental shift in the nationwide political climate,'' he said. The average rating of the Senate in 1989 was 46 percent, compared with 43 percent in 1988 and 40 percent in 1987. The average rating of the House was 43 percent in 1989, compared with 44 percent in 1988 and 37 percent in 1987. The ACU, founded in 1964, says it is the nation's oldest conservative lobbying group.

Here is the American Conservative Union's ranking of members of the House on a scale of zero to 100 for 1989. A 100 is the highest conservative ranking. Each member was graded on key recorded votes in areas of defense, foreign policy, taxation, spending and social issues. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Crown Publishing Dead at 88
DOC.TEXT: Nat Wartels, chairman of Crown Publishers and considered the richest person in U.S. book publishing, died Wednesday of pneumonia in a hospital. He was 88. Wartels built Crown into a successful company by buying publishers' surplus books for as little as five or 10 cents a book, then reselling them to bookstores for their bargain bins. The New York native graduated from Columbia University, then earned a degree from the Wharton School of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania. He entered the book remainder business in 1933 and began publishing books under the Crown name. He sold it to Random House for an undisclosed amount of money in 1988. Even before the sale to Random House, Wartels was widely considered the wealthiest person in U.S. book publishing. Wartels would not disclose his personal wealth, but in 1981 acknowledged that Crown's revenues made it one of the three or four largest publishers in the United States. Crown was just a part of his business empire. Other companies included Outlet Book Co., still the nation's leading remainder house; Publishers Central Bureau, the direct-mail company; and Living Language record courses. Wartels is survived by two nephews and two nieces.

DOC.HEAD: END ACU RATINGS LIST _ 3 Takes
Disagreement Despite Near-Unanimous Soviet Party Vote
With PM-Soviet-Party Bjt
DOC.TEXT: During the Communist Party Central Committee that saw the party relinquish its constitutional monopoly on power, Soviet leaders engaged in impassioned debate about their country's future. Here are some key quotes:

``The party will only be able to fulfill the mission of political vanguard if it drastically restructures itself, masters the art of political work in the present-day conditions and succeeds in cooperating with all forces committed to perestroika.'' _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
``This plenum is the last chance for the party.... This is also Gorbachev's last chance. Either he acts or he loses us.'' _ Moscow parliamentarian and reformer Boris Yeltsin, who cast the only vote against Gorbachev's platform, apparently because it was not radical enough.
``We cannot rule out the emergence of new parties. But we communists are not going to surrender our positions.'' _ Politburo member Vitaly I. Vorotnikov.
``All unanimously think it has become obsolete. It has no meaning.'' _ Central Committee member Vladimir P. Anishchev, responding to a question about the Communist Party's future.
Gorbachev's program ``is leading to a point where the party as such is falling by the political wayside.'' _ Valentin K. Mesyats, old-guard party boss of the Moscow region.
``It is too late to discuss whether the country needs a multi-party system or not. It is a fait accompli.'' _ Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov.
``It has become fashionable to blame all our disasters on the past. But what we are facing now is not the result of yesterday's stagnation but of perestroika.'' _ Vladimir Brovikov, Soviet ambassador to Poland.
``Without having devised a transition plan or new methods of party work in the economic sector, we began to callously reject everything from the past, including much that could still be useful.'' _ Yegor K. Ligachev, leading orthodox Politburo member.
``We must move with the tide, must move with the people, and not be left behind by events.'' _ Gennadi I. Gerasimov, Foreign Ministry spokesman.
``We are still hostages to a few dozen dogmatic members of the Central Committee who represent no one.'' _ Aleksandr S. Tsipko, former central committee adviser writing in a recent issue of Moscow News.
``It has been destroyed by the will of peoples who wished no longer to tolerate coercion.'' _ Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, rejecting assertions that liberalization was to blame for the toppling of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Whites More Interested in Stuart, Barry Cases
DOC.TEXT: Non-white Americans were more interested than whites in Boston's Charles Stuart murder case, the arrest of Washington Mayor Marion Barry and the McMartin child abuse acquittal, according to a survey of interest in the news. Among all people, white and non-white, the crash of an Avianca Airlines plane on Long Island topped the monthly interest index of the Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press. News of the crash of the Colombian airliner, in which more than 70 people died, was followed closely by 33 percent of those surveyed. Among non-whites, however, 31 percent paid close attention to the Avianca crash, compared with 44 percent for the story of Stuart, who took his life amid allegations that he had murdered his wife and tried to blame it on a black man. Twenty-seven percent of whites followed the Stuart story closely, and that case was more interesting to women than to men by 34 percent to 23 percent. Overall, the case was second in interest with 29 percent, followed by 28 percent for Barry's arrest on a drug charge and 27 percent for the acquittal of the owners of the McMartin day care center in California. Since the survey of 1,245 adults is subject to a 3 percent error, the Stuart, Barry and McMartin stories were virtually tied. Among non-whites, the arrest of Washington's black mayor on a drug charge attracted the close interest of 41 percent, compared with 26 percent for whites. The McMartin story also held more interest for non-whites than for whites, 36 percent to 26 percent. News of Nelson Mandela's impending release from jail in South Africa was of close interest to 26 percent of non-whites, compared with only 9 percent of whites. ``However, since that story erupted in the midst of interviewing for the February index, there are too few respondents who were asked to rate their attention to South Africa to enable a reliable test of the significance of the racial difference in interest,'' Times Mirror said. The center said there have only been 11 stories, since it started the surveys in 1986, in which news interest has been affected by race. Others included the letter bombings of federal judges, elections of black political leaders and racial violence in Virginia Beach, Va. The study also said 22 percent of Americans followed the Super Bowl professional football game very closely and six out of 10 watched it on television. Four out of 10 watched President Bush's State of the Union address. Forty percent of those surveyed could identify Barry as Washington's mayor; 56 percent knew Mandela was an imprisoned black leader in South Africa. Times Mirror is a Los Angeles-based media company that publishes the Los Angeles Times, Newsday and New York Newsday, the Baltimore Sun newspapers, The Hartford Courant, National Journal and Broadcasting magazine, among other journals. It also engages in broadcasting and cable television, book publishing and specialized information and training businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants to Set Limits on FHA Borrowers
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration wants Congress to set some time limits on how long a borrower can remain a customer of the Farmers Home Administration. Under the administration's 1990 farm bill proposals sent to Capitol Hill this week, direct FmHA farm operating loans would be limited to seven years. If the borrower also had a bank loan guaranteed by the agency, that could add another 10 years of eligibility, making an effective limit of 17 years. ``There's no time limit now,'' FmHA spokeswoman Marlyn Aycock said Wednesday. ``No limit on the number of loans or on how many times you can come back for another loan.'' The borrowing deadlines are part of an overall package of reforms the administration wants Congress to approve for FmHA, an Agriculture Department agency which for many years has been known as the government's lender of last resort. Only those who have been denied loans by banks and other commercial institutions are eligible for FmHA financing. The proposal calls for a continued swing by the agency to guaranteed loans and away from direct FmHA financing, a trend that has prevailed for some years. Direct loans reached the billion-dollar level in 1982 and then peaked at $4.7 billion in fiscal 1985. For the last two years, FmHA direct farm operating loans have been around $900 million annually. The Bush budget proposed for the 1991 fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1 includes $500 million for direct loans. The administration also wants to restrict FmHA direct operating loans to existing borrowers and to beginners who would become operators for the first time. Those could not have more than $100,000 in loans outstanding at any one time, compared with the current limit of $200,000. Meanwhile, FmHA guaranteed loan availability has risen from a negligible level in the early 1980s, to $2.15 billion in 1988 and $2.6 billion in 1989. The administration also is seeking curbs on abuses under the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987, including $250,000 limits on debt write-downs and write-offs. There are no such limits now, and some borrowers have had million-dollar write-offs. At a news conference announcing the administration proposals, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the FmHA ``has tilted toward the grant side'' in recent years. ``We've gone a long way from its original purposed of being a source of credit of last resort for farmers, and you've got a whole variety of ways that have made it very nearly a grant program in many of it attributes,'' he said. ``The result of that is that it has cost the department and the American taxpayer a great deal of money.'' The proposal for FmHA also would tighten the direct farm ownership loan program by limiting new loans to ``socially disadvantaged applicants'' and impose a $150,000 loan limit. According to the proposal, the 1987 credit act ``gave special emphasis to members of socially disadvantaged groups'' _ generally racial and ethnic minorities _ to provide an opportunity for them to buy farmland in the FmHA's inventory of farms taken over from previous borrowers. Loan guarantees for those wishing to buy farms would be targeted to beginning farmers and those who wish to expand family holdings.

One of the Agriculture Department's biggest annual surveys wil begin next week to see how farmers did financially in 1989. Charles Caudill, head of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service, said the sixth annual Farm Costs and Returns Survey will begin Feb. 12 and run through March 30. The agency is the department's primary gatherer of statistics used to compute farm income and expenses, assets, cash flow, costs of production and other factors affecting the financial trends and general well-being of U.S. agriculture. About 26,000 farms and ranches will be visited by local interviewers. ``This survey goes directly to the source, farmers themselves, to develop an accurate picture of the diverse financial conditions in agriculture,'' Caudill said. ``The cost-of-production data help farm policy-makers understand the costs of farming and ranching.'' Other information will help researchers analyze the financial situation in the farm sector, how it's changing and where problems are located, he said. Results of the survey will be published by USDA beginning this summer. Caudill said responses to survey questionnaires are confidential, and all the forms are destroyed after the information is fed into computers and sent to agency headquarters in Washington.

Payments to rice farmers who participated in the Agriculture Department's 1989 crop program total about $475 million. Officials said about $225 million of the total in ``deficiency payments'' was paid in advance to rice producers upon request when they signed up in the program last year. The department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service said the deficiency payment is based on the difference between the established target price and the higher of the national average price support rate or the national market price average received by producers in August through December. For 1989, the payment will be $3.56 per 100 pounds, the difference between last year's target of $10.80 and the market average of $7.24.

DOC.HEAD: `Do it Simple,' IRS Chief Advises Congress
DOC.TEXT: The landmark 1986 tax overhaul is forcing Americans to pay billions of dollars of taxes they had been evading, but the law is getting low marks for simplification. Despite attempts at making things simpler, says Fred T. Goldberg Jr., commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, the law is ``imposing an unacceptable burden on taxpayers and our system of tax administration.'' He advised a new watchword: ``Do it simple.'' Rep. Bill Archer of Texas, senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, told a hearing Wednesday that as a lawyer and 17-year member of the panel, he has always prided himself on doing his own tax return. ``Last year I could not do it,'' he said. For the most part, however, witnesses praised the impact of the new law, the most thorough overhaul of the income tax since it was enacte in 1913. Goldberg ticked off several benefits: _The requirement that all children 4 and older (since reduced to 2 and older) have Social Security numbers has brought in more than $2 billion. The requirement saw 7 million children dropped as dependents on tax returns. Research ``reflects the fact that those `dependents' never existed in the first place,'' Goldberg said. _Repeal or reduction of several deductions ``generated billions of dollars in compliance revenues by removing the `opportunity' to overstate itemized deductions.'' These changes caused more than 8 million taxpayers to stop itemizing and resulted in tax increases for many, despite the new law's reduction in tax rates. _``Tax Reform '86 brought an end to the mass marketing of abusive tax shelters,'' Goldberg said. An estimated $10 billion of partnership losses reported on 1987 returns were disallowed by the IRS because of new rules. While the Bush administration was endorsing further simplification, it also was repeating President Bush's call for restoring a special break for capital gains _ a move that many experts say could bring even more complexity. Under the 1986 law, capital gains, which are profits from the sale of stock and other investments, are fully taxed at the same rates applying to wages. One of Bush's top priorities is restoring that break, on grounds it is needed to increase investment. Kenneth W. Gideon, assistant secretary of the treasury for tax policy, told the committee that despite gloomy predictions at the time the law was passed, ``there is no clear evidence that the 1986 act affected the level of investment'' one way or another. ``The predicted short-run decrease in aggregate equipment investment has apparently failed to materialize,'' Gideon said. For whatever reason, he added, ``such investment has actually experienced a post-1986-act surge as a result of technology-driven increases and expenditures on office, computing and accounting machinery, and an increased growth in output demanded by other sectors of the economy.'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the committee, said deficit reduction is needed to improve the economy, rather than enactment of special tax breaks. Among other judgments on the 1986 act: _``The tradeoff of certain credits and deductions for lower statutory rates has ... had a positive effect on economic growth,'' said Harry Sullivan, senior vice president of the Food Marketing Institute, speaking for a coalition that includes 100 of the Fortune 500 corporations. _While praising the law for removing 6 million lower-income people from the tax rolls, William Lucy, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said its passage led many states into ill-advised tax cuts, resulting in reduced services for citizens. _Representatives of the aerospace and petroleum industries said the law has put their businesses at a disadvantage.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Carrying Miners Crashes
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian helicopter crashed Wednesday afternoon near a glacier, killing at least six people and injuring two others, authorities said. The Skyline Exploration helicopter went down near Shakes Glacier on the Stikine River 15 miles northeast of this town on the southeast panhandle near the Canadian border, firefighters said. The two injured were flown to a hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, said Wrangell General Hospital administrator John Vowell. Both were in stable condition. None of the victims' identities were released. Some of those aboard were believed to be Canadian miners from an Alaskan gold mine. There are no roads into the area and little information about the crash was immediately available. Its cause was unknown. Wrangell Fire Chief Tim Buness said he was unsure where the helicopter was headed when it went down. The bodies were not expected to be removed from the crash site until sometime Thursday, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Sanctions May End in a Year
DOC.TEXT: A top administration official says South Africa is likely to make enough progress in easing oppression against blacks over the next year to permit the lifting of U.S. sanctions against that country. The sanctions issue was revived last week after South African President Frederick W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the country's main opposition group and said imprisoned anti-apartheid militant Nelson Mandela would be freed soon. President Bush has said only that de Klerk's statement warrants a review of the sanctions policy but offered no predictions as to when they might be lifted. Congress has spelled out five conditions for removing the sanctions and has given the administration discretionary authority to lift them if South Africa meets four of the conditions. That step would be automatic if all five are satisfied. The senior administration official, speaking to reporters on Wednesday, noted members of Congress have argued strenuously against any early end to the sanctions. He said, until the time is ripe, ``We don't dare lift the sanctions.'' The official, insisting on anonymity, said that by legalizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups, the South African government already has satisfied one of the conditions set by Congress. He added he expected South African compliance on three of the remaining four conditions: government agreement to engage in good faith negotiations on the country's political future, the lifting of the state of emergency and the release of political prisoners. The fifth condition requires substantial progress toward the dismantling of South Africa's apartheid system. The official acknowledged there may be some ambiguity as to South African compliance with the conditions. He said there may be disagreement, for example, over who is a political prisoner. The sanctions were approved in 1986 over President Reagan's veto. Reagan argued approval of sanctions would lead to a loss of the U.S. ability to influence South Africa to ease its segregationist policies. The sanctions include a ban on new investment in South Africa, a prohibition on the import of certain South African products and the cancellation of landing rights for South African airlines. The official noted the administration has invited both de Klerk and Mandela to visit the United States and he also raised the possibility that a senior U.S. official may stop in South Africa as part of tour of the general region. He suggested such a visit could coincide with the ceremonies on March 21 formalizing Namibian independence from South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say Even Recalled Child Safety Seats Better Than None
DOC.TEXT: Child car seats should be used even if they have problems that call for recalls, according to witnesses from the government, juvenile products manufacturers and safety groups. At a hearing prompted by a Center for Auto Safety report alleging lax government policing of child restraint devices, National Highway Traffic Safety Administrator Jerry R. Curry vowed to examine government programs to test and recall faulty safety seats, saying he is ``not pleased'' with the results. But Curry and other witnesses told a Senate consumer subcommittee Wednesday that misuse and nonuse of child safety seats in automobiles is a bigger threat to safety than any flaws that have been found in the seats. Government surveys show use of child safety restraints has increased from 15 percent to 81 percent in the last decade, Curry said. But he added about 40 percent of youngsters are improperly restrained or not secured at all. Since 1981, the agency has tested 200 seat models, with some resulting in test failures that have led to the recall of six million seats, Curry said. He acknowledged only 5.4 percent of those actually have been brought into compliance, but said many of the flaws are minor and even those that failed tests can provide some protection. ``I am not pleased with the way it's gone, with the percentage of recalls,'' Curry told the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation consumer subcommittee. On Tuesday, the agency warned owners of Strolee GT-3000 convertible child seats manufactured in 1987 and 1988 they do not comply with federal standards when installed to face the rear of the car. Also, some Strolee Model 609 and 610 seats developed cracks which could cut or pinch the child, the government said, although tests show they still offer sufficient restraint in accidents. Curry said the manufacturer is no longer in business, so no recall program was possible. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., the subcommittee chairman, noted NHTSA waited until the eve of the hearing to release the warnings even though tests were conducted on the Strolee seats several years ago. Curry said the matter went through the normal review process and he decided to release the information out of concern for safety even though it might appear he was trying to impress the committee. ``Use the child restraint you have because any child restraint is better than no child restraint,'' advised auto safety advocate Clarence Ditlow, whose report last month on faulty seats prompted the hearing. The report by the Center for Auto Safety was criticized by the government, the juvenile products industry and some other safety groups because it might discourage parents from using the seats. Ditlow's report said half the 27 million car seats that may be in use had been the subject of recalls or had failed government tests but were not investigated. Philip W. Haseltine of the American Coalition for Traffic Safety said current recall rates are unacceptable but parents should continue to use noncomplying seats until they can be replaced or repaired.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Fear Replay of Exxon Valdez Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: An old nickname came back to haunt this stretch of Southern California sand on Wednesday. The community of 186,000 was known as ``Oil City'' 70 years ago when groves of oil derricks stood along the shore where surfers and sunbathers now gather by the hundreds of thousands. The acrid smell of oil filled the air again Wednesday after a rupture in one of the tanker American Trader's holds poured up to 250,000 gallons of Alaskan crude into the sea just off the beach. The accident brought local residents down to the city's pier late Wednesday as word of the spill spread. Several gazed warily out to the yellow lights of the tanker, moored in blackness offshore, and expressed concerns about a replay of the destruction wrought in Alaska's Prince William Sound when the tanker Exxon Valdez spilled more than 11 million gallons there last year. ``I think it's horrible. I don't think the boat should be this close to shore. I never thought anything like this would happen in Huntington Beach,'' said 15-year-old Mike Root. ``I'm just afraid it's going to happen like it happened in Alaska.'' Several motorists pulled into a parking lot near the pier to ask beach officers what was happening. Some complained about the smell they said reached northward along the shore. ``It was so bad it almost choked you,'' Huntington Beach resident Ken Williams said. ``You think of what happened in Alaska,'' said Pete Horne of Newport Beach. ``To see that on the news and see the black waves covering the shore ... and here it happened so close to shore.'' Huntington Beach has in recent years become one of Southern California's most popular areas for surfers and sunbathers. As the crowds arrived, the oil derricks of old gave way to homes, condominiums and redevelopment projects. On the shore just north of the city is the Bolsa Chica wetlands wildlife area. To the south lies Huntington State Beach and the city of Newport Beach, which encompasses Newport Bay and the yacht-studded waters around Lido Isle and Balboa Island. Fifteen miles farther south lie the teeming tide pools of Laguna Beach, and beyond that, the scenic beaches and bays of Dana Point, Capistrano, San Clemente and San Diego County. Coast Guard officials said the crude could foul Huntington City Beach, Huntington State Beach, Chica Bolsa State Beach and possibly the wetlands. ``I think it's a tragedy,'' said city Beach Supervisor Scott Rutherford.

DOC.HEAD: New Women Union Members Offset 1989 Losses in Male Membership
DOC.TEXT: Unions are gaining female members to help offset organized labor's large loss of male membership, the government says. The Labor Department said Wednesday about 16.95 million Americans belonged to unions last year, a decline of about 40,000 members from 1988. About 16.4 percent of the American workforce belonged to unions last year. The number of men in unions dropped by about 200,000 but female membership increased by about 160,000. The number of Hispanics and blacks belonging to unions stayed roughly the same. The Labor Department said although the number of union members has been fairly constant since 1985, total employment has increased so the percentage of workers who are in unions has declined. In 1985, 18 percent of the workforce belonged to unions. Fletcher Hudson, a labor management lawyer, said employer attitudes towards workers has continually improved in recent years and so workers have not felt the need to join unions. ``Unions have had a lot of bad press. The image is not as good as it was,'' Hudson said, adding he did not expect an immediate turn of events for unions. ``I think it's going to take a backsliding of employer attitudes and maybe some inflationary type things to make unions seem to be the answer,'' Hudson said. But Susan Cowell, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said labor activists were cheered by the steady membership level unions have maintained since they suffered major setbacks of the early 1980s. ``The fact that it's stabilized is a positive sign. What we need to do now is start moving again,'' she said. Labor analysts partially attributed gains in female membership to an increase in the number of women entering the workforce. In addition, the service sector of the economy _ traditionally an area employing large numbers of women _ has been expanding while the male-dominated manufacturing sector has lost jobs. Markley Roberts, an economist with the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO, said women and minorities are a key to rejuvenating the American labor movement. Union officials said women see organized labor as a way to overcome pay discrepancies that still exist. ``Women are still getting the short end in many cases, and they know that,'' Ms. Cowell said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Probe Flies By Venus on Jupiter Trip
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo space probe, heading for Jupiter on a six-year roundabout journey, will fly past the planet Venus late Friday and early Saturday and gain momentum for the second leg of the trip _ back toward Earth. NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said Galileo will be 10,028 miles above Venus' cloud tops when it makes its closest approach at 9:59 p.m. Pacific time, Friday. Although the space probe's instruments will be recording information about Venus _ Earth's closest planetary neighbor _ the data won't be played back for scientists until October. Galileo was launched last October 18 from the cargo bay of the space shuttle Atlantis. After passing Venus and gaining slingshot momentum from that flyby, the $1.5 billion probe loops back and will come within 620 miles of Earth in December. With that added second push, Galileo once more will head out into deep space and return in 1992, coming as close as 200 miles of Earth before it starts out for Jupiter where it will arrive in December 1995. There, a robot will separate from the main spacecraft and plunge through the gaseous atmosphere of the solar system's largest planet. Galileo itself will orbit the planet for two years taking scientific measurements. Galileo carries a 49-pound nuclear generator to provide electricity to power the craft's instruments. Similar generators have been used on other deep space probes, including Voyager, which last year sent back photographs as it passed Neptune, at that point the planet farthest from the Earth.

DOC.HEAD: After Suspension, Bloch May be Fired
DOC.TEXT: The State Department wants to fire Felix S. Bloch, the career diplomat who is suspected of spying for the Soviet Union. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Wednesday that, as an interim step, the department was ordering Bloch's immediate suspension and was stripping him of his salary, estimated at $80,000 a year. The diplomat, who was placed on administrative leave with pay last June, has 30 days to answer the charges and submit any information to show why he should be restored to duty. His legal troubles began after he was reportedly videotaped passing a suitcase to a Soviet agent in Paris. Bloch could not be reached by telephone Wednesday and his attorney declined comment on the State Department action. In the past, Bloch repeatedly has passed up chances to deny the allegations, saying instead the government has not been able to bring charges, much less prove them. Boucher refused to provide details of the action taken Wednesday, citing legal considerations. Bloch, an urbane diplomat who has spent more than 30 years in the foreign service, has not been formally prosecuted but there have been unofficial reports that the Justice Department believes its case against him is not strong enough to seek an indictment. Asked why the State Department was taking action against Bloch when the Justice Department has yet to press charges against him, an official said the burden of proof for suspending an employee is less stringent than the requirements for a prosecution. The disclosure that he was a suspect touched off a frenzied media pursuit of Bloch during his long walks last summer to and from his Washington apartment. A round-the-clock FBI vigil of Bloch's apartment building was called off or sharply curtailed in December. Bloch was suspended on the basis of a government regulation authorizing the head of an agency to remove any employee without pay when the action is considered necessary in the interests of national security. Bloch had been the No. 2 official of the U.S. Embassy in Vienna for much of the Reagan administration before taking up an assignment in Washington. Electronic surveillance is said to have picked up Bloch telling his wife that he had accepted payments from the Soviets. A former Viennese prostitute has told a federal grand jury that Bloch spent roughly $10,000 a year for her services over seven years _ an amount investigators cannot find withdrawn from Bloch's acknowledged bank accounts. Meanwhile, the State Department declined comment on a report in Common Cause Magazine that Bloch has not undergone a security clearance since August 1973 despite a requirement that such reviews take place every five years. Two years ago, the General Accounting Office, a congressional watchdog agency, issued a report alleging 8,929 of the State Department's long-term employees in sensitive positions were not reinvestigated within the five-year limit.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Faces Ethics Committee Amid Fresh Disclosures
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Closed committee meeting begins 3 p.m. EST; lead not expected
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger faces Ethics Committee questions about his financial dealings amid new disclosures that he received $1.3 million in unsecured, low-interest loans from a bank where his cousin is a vice president. The committee has been investigating charges that Durenberger laundered speaking fees through a book contract, used lobbyists to pay for personal trips and improperly charged the Senate for his stays in his Minneapolis condominium. Durenberger, one of seven senators being investigated by the Ethics Committee, was summoned to appear before the panel this afternoon. The Star Tribune of Minneapolis on Wednesday published a list of 23 loans that the Commercial State Bank of St. Paul, Minn., made to the senator over the past decade at interest rates as much as 6.5 points below prime lending rates. A Durenberger aide said Wednesday the list was accurate. The largest of the loans, a two-month loan in 1988 worth $484,332, was not listed on Durenberger's annual financial disclosure form, in apparent violation of Senate rules. Durenberger's cousin, Jack, is a vice president in the commercial lending section of the Commercial State Bank, where he has worked since 1954. But Durenberger and bank officials denied he received any preferential treatment. Bank officials said the loans were justified by the senator's financial stability and large savings accounts, and that other borrowers have received similar terms. ``I never asked for any special consideration from the bank and don't believe I was ever extended any,'' Durenberger said in a statement issued to the newspaper. He declined to be interviewed Wednesday. An aide later said: ``This is a mischaracterization of a banking relationship. This is another example of taking a normal situation and blowing it out of proportion.'' Durenberger obtained 20 unsecured loans totaling $1.27 million from 1979 to 1988, including 12 at interest rates less than the prevailing prime lending rate, according to the list. Banks usually charge one or two points more than the prime rate for consumer loans. ``Banks don't do a large amount of unsecured lending unless a person has a pretty substantial financial statement and the person is liquid,'' said Michael Pint, a Minnesota bank owner and former state banking commissioner. Three other loans totaling $65,646 were secured, including two car loans and a $38,400 mortgage. The Star Tribune calculated the total value of the 23 loans at $927,078, because some of the unsecured loans were renewed and the unpaid balances were consolidated into new loans. Durenberger's 1988 financial disclosure report listed three loans from Commercial State Bank, but missing from the form is the short-term loan the senator got in June 1988 to obtain financing on a suburban Washington townhouse. The disclosure form contains instructions calling for information on any loan in excess of $10,000 owed to any single creditor at any point during the year. Aides said they could not explain why the loan was not listed. The Star Tribune also said Durenberger failed to disclose two loans totaling $25,000 in 1983. Durenberger's cousin ``had absolutely no involvement in any of the loan transactions for the senator,'' Carrie Collins, the senator's press secretary, told The Associated Press. Durenberger kept as much as $80,000 in accounts at the bank, said the bank's president, Robert Kastner. The bank stopped lending to him at below-prime rates in 1983 after he moved his money into higher-earning certificates of deposit. ``We felt comfortable with the fact that the senator or a non-senator would pay us back on the loans,'' said the bank president, Richard Kastner. The bank has made similar loans to other customers, including one who has a $2 million unsecured line of credit, the bank's lending limit, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,516.24, up 214.37 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Junior Government Minister Branded As An Idiot By Judge
DOC.TEXT: A judge called a junior government minister ``idiotic'' for grabbing a 6-year-old girl who was picking flowers in his yard and taking her into his house for a scolding. The girl's father pleaded guilty Wednesday to punching Minister of State for Employment Timothy Eggar, but Judge Keith McHale told him: ``I sympathize with you entirely in feeling irritation that your daughter had been interfered with in the way she was.'' Prosecutor Jeremy Carter-Manning told the Croydon Crown Court in south London that Eggar grabbed the girl by the scruff of the neck and led her and her friend into his house for a lecture. Her father later went to Eggar's home, butted the minister with his head and then punched him in the face, breaking two teeth, Carter-Manning said. The judge said he believed ``a grown man seeing a child stealing flowers would know better than to take a small girl into his house. It was a stupid, idiotic and provocative thing to do and Mr. Eggar should have known better.'' The father, who was not named in court because McHale ruled the girl should not be identified, was given a suspended 21-day prison sentence and ordered to pay $490 to repair Eggar's teeth and replace clothes ruined in the fight. Eggar, 38, works for Employment Secretary Michael Howard, a member of Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government.

DOC.HEAD: Offshore Spill Brings Memories of Santa Barbara Spill Nearly 20 Years Ago
With AM-Offshore Spill
DOC.TEXT: Wednesday's oil spill off Huntington Beach recalled the Santa Barbara spill 21 years ago that blackened the California coast and helped spawn the environmental movement. The Jan. 28, 1969, blowout of an improperly cased well on an offshore drilling platform operated by Union Oil Co. of California spewed more than 3.25 million gallons of oil over 800 square miles of water, according to the California Coastal Commission. The spill covered 100 miles of coastline and beaches with a thick, tarry black goo, smothering thousands of birds, fish and other sea life, the commission said. The commission, marking the disaster's 20th anniversary last year, said it ``helped trigger a new age of environmental awareness.'' A spokesman for Union _ now Unocal Corp. _ has disputed those figures, contending that only 30 miles of coastline were affected by a spill of no more than 840,000 gallons. The Western States Petroleum Association, however, has said at least 2.1 million gallons spilled. Unocal, which paid about $16 million in settlements in of spill-related lawsuits, also disputed claims that oil still leaks from the spill site. It said the leakage is the result of natural oil seepage from the sea floor. Oil companies still drill for oil off Santa Barbara. The petroleum association said last year that the environment has recovered from the Santa Barbara accident, which spurred the oil industry to institute safer technology and tougher controls for oil drilling and production.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Ask Baker to Hang Tough on Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: A bi-partisan group of lawmakers says Congress will continue to support the Afghan rebels and oppose any transitional government that includes Soviet-backed leaders The eight lawmakers, including Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., sent the message to Secretary of State James A. Baker III as he was in Moscow for a meeting with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The letter said there is strong support in Congress for the longstanding U.S. policy towards Afghanistan. Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said the message was designed to caution Baker that Congress would view with ``alarm and dismay'' any effort to allow the government of Najibullah to remain in Kabul. Baker intends to raise the issue of the 11-year war in Afghanistan in his meetings with Shevardnaze. Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan in 1988, but fighting has continued between the Soviet-support government of Najibullah and the U.S.-backed rebels who receive equipment through Pakistan.
