The members of Congress said in a letter dated Feb. 6 they are committed to ``a continuation of lethal and nonlethal U.S. assistance until it is clear that Najibullah and his close associates ... have been removed from office.'' They said they support ``a political process and outcome in Afghanistan which represents true self-determination for the Afghan people.'' ``We believe America should not support a so-called `transitional solution' in Afghanistan involving Najibullah any more than we should have endorsed similar solutions in EAstern Europe,'' they said. They said the Soviet leadership must ``understand fully that a continuation of their massive airlift to prop up their proxy regime in Kabul will not succeed in wearing out American patience and cause us to agree to a political situation which abandons the brave people and sound principles that we have stood for in Afghanistan for over a decade.'' Others signing the letter were House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, Republican Reps. Henry Hyde of Illinois, Don Ritter of Pennsylvania and Bill McCollum of Florida and Rep. Charles Wilson, D-Texas. In an interview earlier in the week, Humphrey was critical of the CIA's handling of Afghanistan. Much of the covert aid for the Afghan rebels is channeled through the CIA and the security agency in Pakistan. ``It's pathetic,'' he said of the situation in Afghanistan. Specifically, he said the CIA was not playing a large enough role in planning the rebels' strategy and planning the war against the Najibullah forces.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Swiftly Passes Panama Aid Package
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Money could soon begin flowing to Panama thanks to a $42 million aid package that Congress hastily passed in a bipartisan effort to help the country rebuild its shattered economy. The measure, which won approval from both the House and Senate on separate voice votes Wednesday, was sent to President Bush for signing. The administration supported the package as the first installment in aid requests for Panama that officials say will total $1 billion. The money will be used for job programs, public works, housing and police training in the country that was invaded by U.S. troops on Dec. 20. ``It's timely,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``We do have a new dawn emerging in Panama.'' Rep. Dante FAscell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said the administration intends to ask for an additional $500 million supplemental package for Panama shortly. Bernard Aronson, the assistant secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was to testify before a Senate committee today on the Bush requests for aid to Panama and El Salvador. The Panama package included $10 million to help Eastern European countries as they prepare for elections. But Bush would have to certify countries were committed to democratic, multiparty elections before money was freed. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., said the administration must notify Congress within 48 hours of spending the money in Eastern Europe. There was little opposition to the Panama package, with most members saying the United States has a duty to help the U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara. ``This is a reasonable but appropriate commitment on the part of the United States,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., citing the high unemployment and credit problem Panama faces. Several House members, however, raised concerns about Panama's bank secrecy laws which they say have allowed drug traffickers to launder money. ``Put Panama on notice: No more aid until they get rid of their bank secrecy laws which have allowed drug barons to launder profits,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. The legislation requires Panama to report by April 15 on efforts under way to stop banks from any involvement in drug trafficking. Others objected to the way the Bush administration took money from aid to Somalia and Sudan for the Panama package and said they want to see that African aid restored. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., called the move ``robbing the poor to help the poor.'' The bill also includes trade and investment opportunities for Panama administration officials estimate are worth $500 million. The bill would: _Give Panama benefits under the Caribbean Basin Initiative, the Generalized System of Preferences, the Overseas Private Investment Corp., and the U.S. sugar quota programs. Panama was cut off from trade and investment programs with the United States when former President Reagan imposed sanctions o the country two years ago. _Certifies Panama is taking steps to cooperate to fight drugs. _Provides $12.5 million in cash and another $10 million in guarantees to rebuild the Panama City's Chorillo neighborhood, where fires in the wake of the invasion left 10,000 people homeless. _Allocates $7 million for emergency public works and jobs programs; $5.5 million to help agencies of the new government of President Guillermo Endara prepare budgets, and reorganize and train workers; $5 million to help looted businesses reopen their doors; and $2 million to begin training a new police force and start up a new judiciary. The House also passed a resolution, 389-26, commending Bush for his handling of the invasion and expressing sadness over the loss of 23 U.S. lives.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Forces Plan Swift Action on Job Discrimination Bill
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights forces, stung by setbacks in the Supreme Court, plan action within days in the House and Senate on legislation designed to protect women and minorities against bias on the job. ``I give my full support to this landmark legislation, which would restore a measure of hope to those who have suffered discrimination in the American workplace,'' Coretta Scott King told a news conference Wednesday. She and the Rev. Edmund L. Browning, presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, joined lawmakers in calling for approval of the bill, which has bipartisan sponsorship in both houses. The measure marks the first counterattack by congressional liberals and civil rights forces following a series of Supreme Court rulings last year. A newly solidified conservative court majority limited affirmative action and narrowed the scope of anti-bias laws. Hearings in the House and the Senate are set to begin within days. Chief Senate sponsor Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said approval at the committee level might be possible within three months. The Bush administration has said there is no urgent need for legislation to overturn the court's rulings, promising to monitor the impact on job discrimination cases currently before the courts. But the Justice Department said Wednesday it would propose its own bills designed to counter two of the Supreme Court decisions. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said one of the decisions was the so-called Patterson case, in which the court held that an often-used civil rights statute _ dating from the Civil War era _ does not bar racial harassment on the job. Thornburgh also pointed to the case of Lorance versus AT&T Technologies Inc. in which the court ruled that in some cases discriminatory seniority programs must be challenged at the time they are adopted, even if the victims were not employees at the time. Thornburgh said, however, the administration would oppose an effort to overturn three other Supreme Court decisions which he said were ``rooted in the court's opposition to racial quotas, which we share.'' Kennedy told the news conference the Supreme Court rulings ``mark an abrupt and unfortunate departure from its historic vigilance in protecting civil rights. The fabric of justice has been torn.'' Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., the chief House sponsor, said he hoped Bush would sign the bill. Sen. Jim Jeffords, R-Vt., urged Republicans to back the bill, saying the high court is closing the door on civil rights at a time ``when prison doors in South Africa are swinging open. I am ashamed and I am embarrassed.'' The bill would: _Bar harassment or firing of employees based on racial bias. The court invalidated a lawsuit brought by a North Carolina credit union worker, Brenda Patterson, who claimed she was the victim of racial harassment on the job. The high court said Ms. Patterson could not use an 1866 law to press her claim, ruling the statute barred only hiring discrimination, not harassment once a person was on the job. _Force employers to show that any practice with proven discriminatory impact was prompted by business necessity. The court ruled that the burden of proof belongs with workers who allege they are the victims of bias. _Make clear that it is always illegal to use race, ethnicity, gender or religion as a motivating factor in employment decisions. The Supreme Court ruling on that subject was vague enough to confuse lower courts. _Make more permanent court-approved affirmative action plans designed to remedy discrimination. The court made it easier for white men to challenge such plans years after they are put into effect. _Ease the deadlines for workers who sue over allegedly biased seniority systems. The court ruled that the time for filing such lawsuits is determined by when a seniority plan is adopted, not when an individual worker is affected. _Assure victims of intentional discrimination the right to sue for monetary damages.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Sharpen Attack on Bush's Defense Plans
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are honing their attack on President Bush's proposed Pentagon budget, but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says the spending cuts they seek would do ``great damage'' to defense priorities. Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were among several administration officials who defended Bush's $1.23 trillion budget for 1991 on Capitol Hill Wednesday. But some members of Congress were not happy with what they heard. Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., was joined by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., also a panel member, in demanding more details on the agriculture budget. Noting that Bush's budget proposed $1.5 billion in cuts in commodity payments to farmers, Dole told Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, ``It would be helpful to have your specific recommendations where we are going to find the $1.5 billion.'' Yeutter told Dole that he would be happy to negotiate the subsidies, but in ``a less public setting.'' Budget director Richard Darman, meanwhile, told reporters that ``Eventually, there will be negotiations'' on the budget. During a break in a hearing by the House Appropriations Committee, Darman predicted that the momentum for talks would not develop until congressional Democrats had a chance to clarify their own budget plans. The budget director described members of Congress as ``frozen in place'' by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security payroll taxes by $62 billion and by expectations that there will be a large ``peace dividend,'' as a result of a diminished communist military threat. He predicted that savings in defense spending would not be much more than $4 billion. Meanwhile, Cheney and Powell told the House Budget Committee that Bush's $303.3 billion defense budget _ 2 percent below the amount needed to keep pace with inflation _ reflected the lessened tensions with the Soviet Union but a continuing respect for a powerful rival. ``The Soviet Union is the only nation in the world still capable of destroying us,'' Cheney said. Most Democrats on the panel balked, however, arguing that military spending will have to be slashed further. Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said he believed the Pentagon's budget would be cut $7 billion to $10 billion below what was needed to keep pace with inflation. That would leave defense spending below $300 billion. ``Where we're headed is obviously to a number higher than what's been recommended here,'' Panetta said, referring to the size of the defense cuts. Cheney responded that the cuts suggested by Panetta would do ``great damage to those priorities we have.'' Appearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee, the top U.S. military officer in Europe said he would prefer to see a higher limit on the number of U.S. troops in Central Europe than the 195,000 that Bush has proposed. Calling that figure ``an absolute bottom line,'' Gen. John R. Galvin said he had urged Bush to seek a higher figure because ``we have to look at the full array of reasons why we have the force deployed.'' Elsewhere, Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, chided a Senate Appropriations subcommittee for approving less money last year than the president had requested for such programs as Head Start, AIDS research and prevention and the homeless. In testimony submitted to the subcommittee, Sullivan said, ``This year you will hear from me loud and clear. I will fight for every dollar in our budget. I hope this year we can get more action and fewer words.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush heard accolades for California's adult literacy campaign by a father who now reads to his children and a man who's reading his Bible for the first time. ``I think it's wonderful what you've done,'' Mrs. Bush told organizers and tutors. She spent an hour Wednesday at the Los Angeles County Library in suburban Montebello, 10 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. ``Now I can write a letter to my wife,'' said Chris Norton, 26, of Downey. ``I've come a long way in this program. ... Now, I can read the newspaper.'' ``I'm not sure reading the newspaper is so great,'' Mrs. Bush quipped. A young father of two, Gary Coyne, said a tutor taught him to read, enabling hm to get his general contractor's license. He now reads to his children. Robert Neria, 52, of Commerce, said that he called the library's literacy hotline number because he wanted to read the Bible. ``Now, I say thank you Jesus,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former heavyweight champion Muhammad Ali was on his way home from a visit with a teen-ager suffering from cancer when he found himself in the middle of a disturbance. At least that's what police thought. Officers responding to a report of a street disturbance found Ali surrounded by a crowd, police said Wednesday. ``They found it was just a group of juveniles talking to a celebrity,'' Capt. Eugene Kyle said. Floyd Bass, groundskeeper of Ali's estate near Berrien Springs, Mich., said after Ali visited the girl's home on Tuesday night he decided to mingle with youngsters in the neighborhood. The officers asked Ali if he would make one more visit _ to the police station. As a practical joke, Cpl. John Collins brought Ali into the station in handcuffs, claiming he had arrested the ex-fighter. After everyone had a good laugh, the officers lined up for autographs and photographs.

Jacqueline Onassis and the Wampanoag Indians were nearing an agreement to end a 10-year struggle over beachfront property on Martha's Vineyard, officials said. Under the agreement, the Indians would sell Onassis the land in return for money and another tract, said a clerk in Dukes County probate court. According to Wampanoag legend, Chief Moshup and his wife, Squant, are buried in the disputed land, a stretch of 264 feet of coastal property. Paul Sulla, a Boston lawyer who represents some of the Indians, said Wednesday an agreement had been reached between ``95 percent of the parties.'' He declined to specify the terms of the agreement, which would have to be approved by the court. Onassis' 380-acre private estate surrounds the property. Onassis, the widow of President Kennedy, bought a 17 percent interest in the land in 1980 from a Wampanoag family. The Indians retained a right of access to the site.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for actor Lloyd Bridges say celebrities may not pitch products so easily after his settlement of a lawsuit alleging he misrepresented an investment in television ads. A judge's ruling on a pretrial motion and a similar ruling by a judge in a related case indicated celebrities could be held liable for misrepresentations when endorsing a product or service. ``The fact that a celebrity is merely reading a script may no longer be an excuse,'' said Dan Formeller, an attorney for Bridges. Wednesday's settlement concluded a lawsuit that also pitted actor George Hamilton and a Detroit advertising agency against investors allegedly bilked by two Michigan-based mortgage companies, A.J. Obie & Associates and its parent, Diamond Mortgage Inc. Bridges was a television spokesman for Obie, and Hamilton represented Diamond in the early 1980s. Both companies were liquidated after declaring bankruptcy in 1986; two of their executives were sentenced to prison in 1988 on fraud charges. The 11 investors lost hundreds of thousands of dollars and will be getting a portion of their money back, said lawyer Stephanie Canwit, whose firm represented the plaintiffs. Bridges, a star of movies and the 1960s television series ``Sea Hunt,'' was not available for comment, his lawyers said.

Comedian Red Skelton was called as a prosecution witness in an art fraud trial, but he had kind words for the defendants _ and one-liners for jurors. Skelton testified that he was satisfied with Center Art Gallery's marketing of reproductions of his works. The gallery and owner William Mett and director Marvin Wiseman are charged with 104 counts of mail and wire fraud. They are accused of misrepresenting the involvement of surrealist Salvador Dali and celebrity artists Tony Curtis, Anthony Quinn and Skelton in reproductions. On the witness stand Tuesday, Skelton gave his age as 77. ``I would have been 78, but we spent a year on Maui,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Riccardo cq.
DOC.TEXT: Philadelphia Orchestra conductor Riccardo Muti told a lawyers' group he was happy to use his podium to speak out against nuclear arms. Muti, the orchestra's music director for 10 years, received the 1990 Peace Award by the Lawyers Alliance for Nuclear Arms Control. ``We musicians are not in an ivory tower somewhere, just being entertaining,'' Muti said Wednedsay. Muti has been criticized for his public stance on nuclear weapons. ``Some people were angry for my not having asked permission, since I am the director of a major orchestra. But I did not need to ask anyone's permission when the survival of the planet is at stake,'' Muti said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Blasts White House for Inaction on Federal Polluters
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, criticized by environmentalists for his response on global warming, faces new attacks on two other environmental issues _ protecting wetlands and cleaning up pollution on federal lands. The National Governors Association released a report Wednesday accusing the Bush administration of hamstringing the Environmental Protection Agency in attempts to pursue federal agencies that are violating pollution laws. ``The nation's chief environmental watchdog is forced to sit by as basic environmental statutes and regulations are routinely ignored at federally owned facilities,'' said the report. It said state authorities often are thwarted from action against federal sites ``by claims of national security.'' The report by an NGA task force cited a Justice Department policy which bars civil suits or enforcement actions against another federal agency on behalf of the EPA. Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus, co-chairman of the task force, said Bush could resolve the problem ``by one phone call'' to the EPA and the Justice Department. ``If you make a mess you clean it up. We're saying that goes for the federal government as well as private citizens,'' the Democratic governor said. Andrus said Bush recognizes that there is widespread pollution on federal lands _ ranging from military bases to western grazing land held by the Interior Department _ but is proposing too little money to clean it up. The EPA lists 1,268 federal facilities for priority cleanup efforts and that number is expected to grow. For many years, federal facilities ``have been among the worst violators'' of federal pollution laws, said the governors' report. Meanwhile, environmentalists charged Bush was retreating from a pledge to protect the nation's wetlands. They accused the administration of softening a policy position aimed at assuring that developers who exploit wetlands compensate for any environmental loss. The criticism was prompted by a final agreement between the EPA and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers that outlines the procedures a developer must take and what compensation must be provided to develop a wetland area. Environmentalists hailed the position when it was tentatively agreed to last November. But the document was revised during negotiations within the administration in recent weeks and environmentalists said the final version would allow developers in some cases to exploit wetlands without compensating for the environmental loss. Kathryn Fuller, president of the World Wildlife Fund and the Conservation Foundation, said the revised agreement casts doubt on Bush's promise to protect wetlands in the country. The Bush administration ``backed off from a strong (position) and has created one that is riddled with loopholes,'' said Robert Irvin of the National Wildlife Federation. The interagency agreement was negotiated for weeks by a number of federal agencies, including the EPA, Transportation Department, Energy Department and Corps of Engineers and White House chief of staff John Sununu. The White House was lobbied vigorously by oil companies and members of the Alaska congressional delegation who argued that the original wetlands agreement might preclude drilling in vast areas of the state's North Slope tundra. EPA Administrator William Reilly reportedly argued for generally keeping the original document. The EPA announced a final decision without comment. White House spokesmen have denied the revised document represents a change in the president's commitment to protecting wetlands. The Energy Department characterized the changes as providing needed flexibility to assure the development of petroleum and gas resources while protecting against further net loss of wetlands.

DOC.HEAD: Political Change Only Meets One Demand of Suffering Populace
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The decision of Communist leaders to give up their monopoly on power has met only one demand of citizens, who are hostages to an economy that is slipping from chaos to catastrophe. The move Wednesday by the party's policy-making Central Committee attacks the most visible targets: middle-level party officials who have long been under pressure from Mikhail S. Gorbachev and now feel heat from below. But it will take some time to change the Stalinist structure and centrally orchestrated decision-making mechanism that put those officials in power and allowed the economy to sink slowly into disarray. The changes will depend on Gorbachev's success in attracting new people who are honest, innovative and able to gain the people's confidence. Gorbachev is gambling he can find the right people in the Communist Party and keep them there. His risk is that the apparatus now apparently on its way out has so damaged the party's credibility that the people he needs will turn to alternative movements and parties given the green light by the Central Committee decision. Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, Gorbachev's most powerful adviser in the party's ruling body, told a news conference Wednesday the Central Committee meeting represented a ``crucial and historic'' moment for the Soviet Union. The shaky economy Gorbachev inherited when he came to power in 1985 _ characterized by a huge budget deficit, inflation, a worthless currency and shortages of consumer goods _ plunged into serious crisis last year. President Gorbachev, addressing the Central Committee on Monday, said the crisis had not reached bottom and the key economic questions now involved personnel. In relieving food shortages, he said, ``the crux of the matter now is the position of our cadre at the center and localities,'' and he indicated changes at the top also were coming. ``It is necessary to realign forces in the upper echelons of power in order to give more dynamism to perestroika processes and ensure more firmly their irreversibility,'' he said. Next week, the Supreme Soviet parliament will consider laws on ownership of land and other property, taxation and other issues. Although the laws have been discussed for months, they remain vaguely worded and could be liberally interpreted by local officials if the leadership wants it that way. In the weeks before the Central Committee meeting, people in a few large cities took their frustrations out on local leaders. Popular protests caused party officials accused of abusing their power to quit in four large cities of the Volga region, the Ural Mountains and the Ukraine. The officials were accused of using their authority to obtain goods and services unavailable to the masses, who must spend hours in lines trying to obtain consumer goods Westerners take for granted. Vitaly Korotich, a popular reformist editor, told thousands of people who gathered near the Kremlin on Sunday that they should not have to live so poorly in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Communist Parties' Loss of Power
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the space of eight months, the hallowed and powerful role of old-line Communist parties in East Europe has eroded steadily. Here is a chronology of how their power has waned: June 10, 1989 _ Under pressure from reformers, the Hungarian Communist Party and opposition groups agree to negotiate a multiparty system. On Oct. 7, the Communist Party formally disbands, reconstitutes itself as the Hungarian Socialist Party and says it aspires to democratic ideals. Nov. 29 _ Czechoslovakia's parliament deletes the leading role of the Communist Party from the constitution. Dec. 1 _ East Germany's parliament removes a constitutional provision guaranteeing the party's leading role. Dec. 29 _ Poland's parliament eliminates a clause in the constitution that gave a leading role to the Communist Party. Jan. 12 _ Romania's interim president, Ion Iliescu, declares the Communist Party outlawed. The order is rescinded later, but leading officials in the revolutionary government say the former ruling party is now completely irrelevant. Jan. 15 _ Bulgaria's parliament votes to abolish the guaranteed leading role of the Communist Party. Wednesday _ The Soviet Communist Party's policy-making Central Committee decides to recommend an end to the constitutional provision that guarantees the party supremacy in political life.

DOC.HEAD: Prolific Songsmith, Oscar Winner Dies
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Oscar-winning songwriter Jimmy Van Heusen, who wrote such tunes as ``All the Way,'' ``Love and Marriage'' and ``High Hopes,'' was remembered upon his death as one of pop music's most important composers. Van Heusen died of a stroke Tuesday night at his desert home east of Los Angeles, according to a spokesman at the Riverside County Coroner's Office. He was 77. Van Heusen collaborated with such lyricists as Johnny Mercer, Johnny Burke, Eddie DeLange and most notably, Sammy Cahn. He also wrote for Bing Crosby and Frank Sinatra. ``Jimmy Van Heusen was an architect of melody,'' Cahn said Wednesday. ``When we were writing together, if I would ask him to add even a grace note to the song, he would sit down and write a whole new melody.'' Van Heusen won Academy Awards with Cahn for ``All the Way'' in 1957; ``High Hopes'' in 1959; and ``Call Me Irresponsible'' in 1963. ``High Hopes'' was chosen as the official song for John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign. He and Johnny Burke also won an Oscar for ``Swingin' on a Star'' in 1944. ``He was one of the most important composers of American pop music,'' Cahn said. ``He was considered a composer's composer.'' The son of a building contractor who played the cornet, Van Heusen was born Edward Chester Babcock on Jan. 26, 1913, in Syracuse, N.Y. He adopted the name Van Heusen from the shirt maker's billboard advertisement. In 1928, he was expelled from Central High School in Syracuse for singing his own composition, entitled, ``My Canary Has Circles Under Its Eyes.'' His next-door neighbor in Syracuse was composer Harold Arlen. When Arlen went to Hollywood in 1933, he asked his brother Jerry Arlen and Van Heusen to take over his writing duties at New York City's Cotton Club in Harlem. He wrote ``Harlem Hospitality.'' The tune and the show for it flopped, but Van Heusen hung on in New York, operating a freight elevator and plugging tunes until he got a hit when Crosby recorded ``It's the Dreamer in Me'' in 1938. By 1940, he was one of Tin Pan Alley's most successful composers, with 60 songs published in just one season. Hollywood beckoned, and he joined with Burke for a songwriting team that became known as the Gold Dust Twins. Among the words and music they churned out were the daffy tunes for the Bob Hope and Crosby ``Road'' pictures. He wrote ``Swingin' on a Star,'' for Crosby's movie ``Going My Way.'' The tune ``Love and Marriage'' won a 1955 Emmy and has been introduced to a new generation of television viewers as the theme song for ``Married ... With Children.'' During the summer of 1942, Van Heusen toured West Coast Army camps with Crosby, sometimes serving as Crosby's pilot. In 1955, Van Heusen teamed with Cahn and produced a string of motion picture scores that became hits. They also scored the 1965 Broadway musical, ``Skyscraper,'' including ``Everybody has a Right to Be Wrong.'' Cahn and Van Heusen also wrote numerous hit songs for Sinatra, including ``All the Way,'' and the title songs of the albums ``Come Fly With Me,'' ``Only the Lonely,'' ``Come Dance With Me'' and ``September of My Years.'' Van Heusen was one of 10 songwriters elected to the Songwriters Hall of Fame when it was founded in 1971. The gregarious Van Heusen loved entertaining, parties, and the single life. ``I dig chicks, booze, music and Sinatra _ in that order,'' he told an interviewer in the 1960s. Cahn called Van Heusen ``one of the world's greatest swingers.'' Van Heusen remained a bachelor until September 1969, when he married Bobbe Brock. He is survived by his wife. Private services are scheduled Friday at Desert Memorial Park in Cathedral City.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rise, Dollar Unchanged in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged and erased morning losses Thursday afternoon, while the dollar ended higher against the yen. The dollar closed unchanged from its opening at 145.50 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's 145.10-yen finish. It ranged between 145.40 yen and 145.62 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 214.37 points, or 0.57 percent, ending the day at 37,516.24. It had lost 364.96 points the previous day. The index reversed the early downswing in the late afternoon session as foreign securities companies conducted index-linked buyings, dealers said. In currency dealings, the West German mark rose against the dollar and the yen, traders said. The market was dominated by position adjustments _ some investors were selling the mark for profit-taking following the West German currency's overnight surge on overseas markets, while others were selling the dollar to buy back the mark, they said. The mark, rather than the dollar, has been the focus of trading recently, because reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are expected to benefit the West German economy, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``The yen is less attractive amid uncertainties over the election and speculation on yet another discount rate hike,'' Kanai said. The mark benefited as investors grew confident in the outcome of the three-day Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting that started Monday. Communist Party leaders Wednesday accepted a proposal by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to give up their monopoly on power.

DOC.HEAD: Military Gov't To Free All Political Prisoners, Releases 19 Activists
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The country's military rulers marked the fourth anniversary of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier's fall by freeing 19 jailed opposition activists and promising to release all other political prisoners. But opponents said the action Wednesday did not mean democracy was on the way. ``I consider I have left a small jail for a bigger one,'' Evans Paul, one of the released activists, said in an interview broadcast by Radio Antilles. ``The whole country is a prison.'' The amnesty measure comes less than three weeks after the government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril declared a state of siege, arrested many activists and sent several opposition leaders into exile. Several of those released Wednesday were beaten while in prison, including three who suffered serious head and body injuries, fellow activists said. Four were jailed last year and most of the others were believed to have been arrested in a state of siege last month. In a televised speech Wednesday night, Avril announced a ``general amnesty of all those implicated in crimes against national security.'' He urged Haitians ``to respect the rules of the democratic game,'' which he also promised to do. The amnesty came exactly four years after ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier's 1986 flight to exile in France following a popular uprising, ending a 29-year family dynasty in the impoverished Carribean nation. The government declared the day a paid national holiday. A decree read on government TV after the speech said the amnesty covered all political prisoners jailed since Avril seized power in September 1988, ousting Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy. Haitians around the world used the anniversary to protest and demand the ouster of Avril. There were demonstrations on the West Indies islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique, and in Miami, Montreal and Paris. Four of those freed, three physicians and one artist, were jailed after Avril imposed a state of siege Jan. 20. They were released with head injuries, broken ribs and bruises, their families said. Following the state of siege, more than 50 opposition activists and militants were arrested and beaten, according to family members and friends. Seven others were exiled. Avril lifted the declaration after international outcry. The other four men released are leaders of radical anti-government groups and had been jailed since late last year. They were Jean Auguste Mesyeux, Marino Etienne, Frantz Patrick Beauchard and Paul. Paul said they were ``victims of arbitrary arrests'' and would sue. Mesyeux, Paul, and Etienne were arrested Nov. 1 and accused of possessing arms and explosives and of plotting to kill Avril. The sight of their battered faces on state TV a day after their arrest set off a storm of protests and strikes. Beauchard, a former sergeant who helped bring Avril to power, was arrested Dec. 13 and accused of conspiring with Mesyeux, Paul and Etienne. He was expelled from the army in late 1988 after Avril accused him of plotting a counter-coup. Press releases from the men's organizations said three suffered serious injuries. They said Paul ``may remain paralyzed'' on one side of his body, that Etienne ``may lose his right eye'' and has a broken ear drum and that Mesyeux suffers from back pain and has problems walking due to pain on the bottom of his feet. The three went on a 27-day hunger strike during their imprisonment. Avril promised when he was brought to power in a soldier's revolt that, unlike Namphy's regime, his government would respect human rights. But rights groups have denounced it for abuses. A former close adviser to the Duvalier regime, Avril has promised general elections for October but most organizations refuse to participate and many leaders are jailed or in exile. The last time Haiti attempted free elections, in November 1987, thugs protected by soldiers murdered at least 34 voters and the balloting was canceled. Robert Duval, president of the League of Former Political Prisoners, said recently that about 75 percent of the 340 murders in Haiti last year were committed by soldiers. Duval has been hiding since Jan. 20. In the French Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, more than 2,000 people waving blue and red Haitian flags marched in downtown Pointe-a-Pitre Wednesday chanting ``Avril murderer get out!'' In Miami, more than 1,000 Haitians held a candlelight rally on a street in the city's Little Haiti sector seeking Pope John Paul II's support for the overthrow of Avril. Among those in the crowd was conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray, who was banished in January.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
More Than 290,000 Gallons of Oil Spills From Tanker off Southern Cal Beach
DOC.TEXT: A tanker's hull was gashed and hundreds of thousands of gallons of heavy Alaskan crude oil spewed from the ship Wednesday two miles off a popular Southern California beach, officials said. Early reports indicated that more than 290,000 gallons of North Slope crude spilled from the fully loaded 811-foot American Trader, according to Coast Guard Rear Adm. William Kime. Hours after the 4:35 p.m. accident, the leading edge of the 1{-mile long oil slick was headed toward several recreational beaches and a wildlife estuary surrounding the Huntington Beach Harbor, Coast Guard officials said. ``Those wetlands and wildlife preserves are so very precious,'' said Dorothy Green, president of Heal the Bay, a local environmental group. The Coast Guard initially reported the tanker had struck a submerged pipeline, but Huntington Beach spokesman Dave Kelly said the ship was punctured by its own anchor. As the ship was docking, the anchor swung back into the bow, breaching the forward compartment, Kelly said. Coast Guard Cmdr. Scott Porter, assistant chief of marine safety, couldn't confirm Kelly's report. A diver found a 3-foot hole in the bottom of the tanker's No. 1 forward compartment, which holds more than 1 million gallons of crude, Coast Guard Capt. James Card told reporters late Wednesday. No other damage was found. The tanker's captain, who was not identified, would be tested for alcohol and drug use as a routine part of the investigation, Card said. Coast Guard officials expected the oil would foul Huntington City Beach, Huntington State Beach and Chica Bolsa State Beach. An environmentally sensitive marsh behind Chica Bolsa clearly is threatened, Porter said. ``At this time of the year ... what we know is that the currents would carry it in toward the beach, toward the northwest,'' Porter said. The spilled crude was the same kind as the oil that fouled Alaska's Prince William Sound last year when more than 10 million gallons spilled from the Exxon Valdez in the nation's worst oil spill, Porter said. ``About all we saw was the discolored surface of the water a mile and a half offshore,'' said Huntington Beach City Lifeguard Greg Crow. ``Then it got dark and we couldn't see anything more.'' Porter characterized the incident as a ``major spill,'' and said the Coast Guard's Pacific Area Strike Team had been activated and was en route from its base in San Francisco. Cleanup crews from the Coast Guard, the Orange County Harbor Patrol and county Fire Department and a private contractor went to the scene, officials said. Oil containment booms were set around the tanker, and there was minimal leakage from the tanker about three hours after the accident, officials said. An emergency response team of local, state and federal officials was being convened by telephone to discuss the emergency, said Kime, commander of the 11th Coast Guard district. The American Trader was leased by British Petroleum Oil Shipping Co. USA, said Joe Braderich, manager of the firm's Los Angeles field office. It is operated by American Trading Transportation Co. Inc. of New York City. The tanker was on a final approach maneuver in about 80 feet of water to hook up with a mooring buoy when it struck something, Braderich said. After the tanker is secured to the buoy, the crew usually connects to a pipeline hauled up from the ocean bottom to pump its cargo ashore, he added. The ship's draft when fully loaded is about 40 feet, said American Trading President Sanford Schmidt. The tanker was carrying about 500,000 barrels, or 21 million gallons, in its 10 hull tanks, said Schmidt. The compartment that was breached carries about 25,000 barrels, or about 1,050,000 gallons. Any spill over 100,000 gallons is considered major, Kime said. British Petroleum has assumed responsibility for the spill, the admiral said. The spill occurred just off Huntington Beach, a city about 30 miles south of Los Angeles long popular with Southern California surfers and sunbathers and often the scene for movies and television shows featuring surfing. A city police helicopter crew estimated the slick from the spill was about 300 feet wide and 1{ miles long, said city lifeguard Capt. William Richardson. It stretched from the ship to an area north of the pier, a distance of about 12 blocks. The mooring buoy serves as an offloading point for an oil terminal 30 miles north of Huntington Beach when the spill occurred, Richardson said. Navigation charts show several submerged pipelines in the area, including a pipeline used by tankers to unload fuel oil for a Southern California Edison power plant at Huntington Beach, Beals said. Southern California Edison spokesman Keith Sheldon said the utility's pipeline was unaffected by the incident.

DOC.HEAD: US Students Master Few Subjects
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 10th graf, ``The study xxx to delete questionable reference to highest score and give examples of questions and answers ^By TAMARA HENRY
DOC.TEXT: Question: If you call a person who speaks two languages bilingual, what do you call a person who speaks one language? An American, says Rep. George Sangmeister, D-Ill. He is introducing legislation today that authorizes $58 million in federal funds over five years and matching grants to states for instruction in foreign studies, language and geography. ``We live in an increasingly global society. We can no longer afford a generation of children uneducated and uninterested in the world outside the United States,'' said Sangmeister. ``We must spark that interest and ability early so that our students become proficient in foreign language by high school or college.'' Sangmeister's sentiments have become a familiar chorus among educators, politicians, businessmen and even President Bush. All are concerned with the flood of reports that focus on what American students don't know. Experts estimate 30 million Americans are functionally illiterate and as many as 2 million students leave school with deficient basic skills each year. To address the problems, Bush in his State of the Union address listed key education goals that include making American students first in the world by the year 2000 in science and math, and ensuring that children leave grades four, eight and 12 having mastered English, mathematics, science, history and geography. Still, the Nation's Report Card continues to release negative reports. In its first study of geography education, the National Assessment of Educational Progress _ popularly known as the Nation's Report Card _ said Wednesday most students demonstrated a limited understanding of the characteristics of the planet Earth and the relationships between people and their environment. The study found the 12th graders tested responded correctly, on average, to only 57 percent of the geography test questions overall. However, there were wide differences depending on how difficult the question was. For example, 87 percent of the 3,000 seniors tested could locate Canada on a world map and 85 percent could locate the Soviet Union. But only 33 percent could ``identify the order of the oceans, moving west to east from Africa.'' The results are disturbing because students need an understanding of other countries and cultures to master other subjects, said Gilbert Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society. Students cannot understand discussions of ``A Tale of Two Cities'' in English class if they don't know the relationship between London and Paris, or the significance of the English Channel, Grosvenor said. While learning percentages in mathematics or lessons of census shifts in civics, students could predict the growth rate of religious sects or the impact of immigration, he said. Delaware Gov. Michael Castle said regional and national geographical know-how plays a role in many jobs. ``Consider a taxi driver who cannot read a map or a fire truck driver who doesn't know the fastest way across town,'' he said. Sangmeister sad a lack of knowledge of foreign languages has a similar effect on world trade and other jobs. He noted 80 percent of all goods face foreign competition abroad and four out of five new jobs are created as a result of foreign trade. However, only 18 percent of the states require geography to graduate and only 17 percent of public elementary schools offer any form of language instruction. Japanese high schools require six years of foreign languages, compared with one to two years in the United States. The International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement reports that in a 1988 study of science achievement in 17 countries, America's 10-year-olds ranked eighth and 14-year-olds ranked 14th. Just 40 percent of American 13-year-olds could solve a two-step math problem, compared with 72 percent of the South Korean students. The writing and reading NAEP reports found merely ``subtle changes in reading performance at the national level'' since the first assessment in 1971 but no improvement in an already low writing performance.

DOC.HEAD: Corruption Under Honecker Detailed By Prosecutors
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker kept a private stash of $60 million into which the former East German Communist leader dipped to make special purchases, such as a watch once owned by Vladimir I. Lenin, prosecutors said. The country's deputy chief prosecutor, Lothar Reuter, on Wednesday read an astonishing list of the extravagances and corrupt activities allegedly committed by Communist Party officials during Honecker's 18-year rule. He said that during 40 years of Communist rule, corruption was rampant but that prosecutors still have not uncovered all the details. Honecker's private account on any given day contained about $60 million, Reuter said, most of it supplied by a former official accused of arranging illegal arms exports. Honecker once used $454,000 from such an account to buy a the Lenin pocket watch, Reuter alleged. The former leader, ousted Oct. 18 in a peaceful popular revolt, also apparently had his generous side. Sometimes just before Christmas, he would ``bless the people'' by arranging purchases of bananas, nearly non-existent in East Germany. Reuter charged that at such moments, Honecker was trying to play ``Santa Claus of the nation'' being bilked by Communist officials. He said leading officers of the state security service were stealing Western currency sent through the mail to East German citizens from West German friends and relatives. In the last three years alone, more than $4 million was pilfered in this fashion, he alleged. Honecker, 77, and a number of his lieutenants are awaiting trial on a broad range of charges, from high treason to human rights violations to misuse of public funds. The former leader was arrested last week and sent to prison. But he was released a day later after doctors determined he was too frail to withstand detention. Authorities announced Wednesday that Honecker will be indicted for high treason in March and tried before the country's supreme court. He could face life in prison if convicted. Many of Honecker's former lieutenants are in jail and also will stand trial, such as ex-premier Willi Stoph, ousted economics chief Guenther Mittag and fired security chief Erich Mielke. Reuter said Honecker and other Communists who have been interrogated for criminal acts seem to show little remorse. ``Most of the accused have either a slight sense of guilt or none at all,'' Reuter told reporters. ``By and large they are not ready to assume responsibility for the immense squandering of public wealth.'' Reuter said Honecker's private accounts were kept filled with Western currency by Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski, East Germany's former chief foreign trader who has fled the country. Schalck-Golodkowski has been accused of overseeing an illegal weapons depot to export arms and earn Western currency for East Germany's leaders. Police found 24,760 machine pistols, 1,398 automatic rifles, 1,691 revolvers, six bazookas, 502 hand grenades and a vast number of bullets when they raided the depot in December, the official ADN news agency said Wednesday. Mielke once had a mansion built for $606,000, but never used it, said Reuter. Nonetheless, Mielke kept the house supplied with power and it was looked after daily, according to Reuter. A total of $134,000 was paid annually to heat Stoph's private greenhouses, said Reuter. He also told of top Communist Party officials who would help themselves to videocassette recorders and other expensive electronic goods seized by customs authorities. Reuter said prosecutors across East Germany have been overwhelmed with work on the corruption cases. He did not reveal how many arrests have been made or say how many trials might be held. ``There are hundreds of cases like this across the country,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Commander Says U.S. Should Stop Paying for Philippine Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 prev with one graf, now bgng: The Bush xxx to clarify amount paid
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the U.S. Pacific Command told Congress Wednesday that the United States should stop paying compensation to the Philippines for two American bases. Adm. Huntington Hardisty said he remains ``cautiously optimistic'' that the U.S. and Filipino governments can work out an agreement on Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station before their leases expire next year. Philippines President Corazon Aquino, who put down a coup attempt against her government in December, is facing renewed pressure from top government officials not to extend the rights on the bases. Hardisty said the United States has contingency plans to move American forces in case U.S.-Philippines negotiations fail, but the bases are ideal for the U.S. effort in the Pacific. ``There is no single location or combination of locations that can replace what we now have in the Philippines in terms of cost, strategic positioning and operational efficiency,'' Hardisty told the House Armed Services Committee. The Bush administration is requesting $200 million in fiscal 1990 in payment to the Philippines, but Congress is not expected to approve more than $160 million, and Hardisty said that was too much. ``I feel we're maxed out on compensation,'' he told the committee. ``In my opinion, neither the Congress nor the administration should vote for compensation. We've got to be innovative and look at other ways other than paying rent.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Childhood Seizure Medicine May Lower IQ
DOC.TEXT: A study today warns doctors against giving phenobarbital to babies who suffer convulsions during high fevers because the medicine, taken by tens of thousands of children, doesn't prevent seizures and may lower IQs. ``There might be an unusual child for whom this (treatment) would still be of benefit,'' said Dr. Deborah G. Hirtz. ``It should not be used in most cases.'' Phenobarbital is the drug of choice given to infants with so-called febrile seizures. An estimated 130,000 American babies a year suffer at least one such seizure and up to 40,000 are given the drug to prevent the convulsions from recurring, said Dr. Jonas H. Ellenberg, a statisician at the National Institute of Neurological Disordered and Stroke and co-author of the study with Hirtz. Hirtz said there has been growing concern about the possible hazards of phenobarbital, an anticonvulsant long used for treating epilepsy. ``In this trial, we wanted to ask the question of whether there were specific cognitive and behavioral side effects in young children treated for febrile seizures,'' she said. ``The major outcome variable was the IQ test at the end of treatment. We did find that there was a difference between children who had been given phenobarbital and those given placebo.'' After two years of treatment, the IQs of those taking phenobarbital were 8 points lower than those who had taken dummy pills. Six months after they went off the drug, their IQs were still 5 points lower. Hirtz said further study is in progress to see if the youngster's IQs eventually catch up. She said that while a difference of a few points shows up on tests, it's too small to be noticed in an individual child. The study was directed by Dr. Jacqueline R. Farwell of the University of Washington. It was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. The study was conducted on 217 children who ranged from age 8 months to 3 years and had experienced at least one febrile seizure. They were randomly assigned to take phenobarbital or placebos. Forty-six percent taking placebos and 38 percent getting phenobarbital had at least one more seizure during the two years of treatment. This difference was not statistically meaningful. The study did not address the use of the drug to treat epilepsy. But Dr. W. Edwin Dodson, a member of the board of the Epilepsy Foundation of America, urged parents not to suddenly discontinue their children's use of phenobarbital because a sudden withdrawal could trigger seizures that are harder to control.

DOC.HEAD: House Calls For Requiring Double Hulls On Tankers In U.S. Waters
DOC.TEXT: The House is trying to ensure that legislation on oil spill liability require double hulls and double bottoms on tankers calling on U.S. ports. The House on Wednesday approved, 376-37, a non-binding resolution instructing negotiators to keep the provision in the bill that comes out of talks between the House and Senate. The provision is part of the bill passed the House, but not in the Senate version. The House-Senate conference committee is expected to begin work immediately on a compromise bill that both houses can approve before the March 24 anniversary of the Exxon-Valdez tanker spill in Prince William Sound, Alaska. The vote on the resolution came before Wednesday's major oil spill off a Southern California beach. A tanker off Huntington Beach, Calif., struck an object under water, spewing thousands of gallons of Alaska crude oil from the American Trader. Initial reports were that as much as 250,000 gallons of crude oil spilled, making it the nation's worst oil spill since the Valdez. The hull issue is viewed as the stickiest problem among the differences between the two bills. The legislation, which has taken 14 years to get this far in Congress, is a comprehensive package of regulations laying out how oil spill clean-ups should be managed and financed. The hull-bottom provision of the House bill requires tankers carrying oil and hazardous materials to be retrofitted with double bottoms within seven years of enactment and double hulls within 15 years. New tankers would have to be built with double hulls and double bottoms. The Senate version calls for a study to determine if any other technology would be an even better protection to the environment in case of a tanker accident.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Secretary Pledges More Enforcement
DOC.TEXT: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole says she will toughen enforcement of child labor laws and seek higher fines for offenders. The secretary said in a statement Wednesday the department would review possible fines and would ``seek to take penalties to the highest level permissible under the law.'' Labor shortages in some areas in the future may put pressure on employers to hire young people, and she said ``we want to make sure that employers follow the law to provide safe and rewarding work experiences.'' Mrs. Dole said she directed Bill Brooks, assistant secretary for employment standards, to ``develop a plan for targeted enforcement against egregious offenders'' and to recommend other changes. In a speech to the department's Child Labor Advisory Committee, Brooks said, ``Child labor violations uncovered by the Department of Labor have more tha doubled since 1982,'' although tougher enforcement may explain some of the increase. But ``labor shortages in certain areas have made it harder for businesses to find enough workers and some have responded by violating child labor laws,'' he said in the remarks made available by the department. Brooks said the department would, among other things: _Step up efforts to increase public awareness of the law. _Seek more injunctions against illegal acts. _Propose better regulations for jobs which pose particular hazards for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds. Generally, those under 14 may work only in specific jobs exempt from the law. The law and department regulations govern hours during which people under 16 may work and restrict employment in hazardous occupations for those under 18. Different standards apply for farm labor.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Federal Judge Sues For Full Pay
DOC.TEXT: Former federal judge Walter L. Nixon Jr., arguing the Senate impeachment procedures under which he was removed from the bench were unconstitutional, wants a federal court to restore his judicial pay and benefits. Nixon's lawyers this week said mediation was unlikely to resolve his lawsuit which challenges the Senate vote Nov. 3 to remove him from office. A federal jury convicted Nixon in 1986 of lying to a federal grand jury when he denied discussing a marijuana case with a district attorney. The Senate vote stripped him of his title of U.S. district judge and $89,500 salary. The lawsuit asserts Nixon's conviction is unconstitutional because it was based on a trial before a committee of 12 senators, rather than the full Senate. The Senate impeachment rule and a resolution setting up the committee are unconstitutional, the lawsuit says. The Senate voted 89-9 to convict Nixon of lying to the grand jury when he denied discussing the marijuana case with the prosecutor. Senators also voted 78-19 to convict him of lying to a federal grand jury when he said he had nothing to do with the marijuana case and had never tried to influence its outcome. Nixon's lawsuit against the U.S. government is assigned to U.S. District Court Judge Louis Oberdorfer, with both sides to submit a pre-trial schedule to Oberdorfer by March 8. The lawsuit was filed Nov. 20. On Jan. 22, Oberdorfer said lawyers for the government and Nixon should discuss referring the dispute for mediation on some or all of the issues in the case. But David Stewart, one of Nixon's lawyers, said Tuesday that ``this is a constitutional issue, not a commercial dispute,'' indicating that Stewart doesn't regard mediation as appropriate in the case. Nixon served 20 months of a five-year prison term for perjury and was released from a halfway house 18 days after the Senate removed him from office. Nixon, 61, of Ocean Springs, Miss., is fighting a legal battle to resume practicing law. His law license has been suspended.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sentenced for Forcing Adopted Daughter to Live in Treehouse
DOC.TEXT: A woman was sentenced to one year in jail for forcing her daughter to live in a backyard treehouse for two weeks last summer. Valerie E. Payne, 40 of Spring Hill, was sentenced Wednesday in Johnson County District Court, where she pleaded guilty last month to a misdemeanor charge of child endangerment. Ms. Payne admitted she forced her 9-year-old adopted daughter to live on the 15-foot-high wooden platform as a form of punishment. The platform, built into the tree, was covered by a shower curtain. Ms. Payne's attorney, Vernon Lewis, asked that she be placed on probation. He said she had difficulty dealing with her daughter's emotional problems and was sorry for what had happened. But Judge Earle Jones denied the probation request. He allowed Ms. Payne to remain free on bond until a Feb. 22 hearing before a parole board of county judges. Those judges will decide whether Ms. Payne serves her sentence. The girl has been in foster care since July. Lewis said Ms. Payne's three other adopted children still live at home.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Pledges Backing for Disability Legislation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush stands fully behind proposed legislation to guarantee the rights of disabled Americans, an administration spokesman told conservative lawmakers who claim the bill could wreck the economy. ``It is not a bill that has been lightly considered,'' Equal Employment Opportunity Commissioner Evan J. Kemp Jr. told the Republican Study Committee Task Force on Competitiveness. ``It does have the backing of the executive branch and both houses of Congress,'' Kemp testified Wednesday before the group of Republican House members reviewing the Americans With Disabilities Act. Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, and chairman of the task force, said he and his colleagues were concerned that the act ``may be moving too quickly through Congress to explore the impact it will have on our businesses, on our judicial system and on our nation's productivity as a whole.'' Kemp said more than 8 million disabled Americans could be brought into the work force through the employment-protection provisions of the law, saving the government $300 billion in welfare and other payments. Those workers would also make the country more productive and competitive by easing projected labor shortages, he said. The bill is also intended to ensure that the nation's 43 million disabled people have full access to shops, restaurants, lodging and other public accommodations. The ADA passed the Senate in September on a 76-8 vote. The bill has since cleared one of the four House committees with jurisdiction and is expected to be passed by the full chamber this year.
DOC.HEAD: IRS Gets Names of Parents Owing Child Support
DOC.TEXT: The names of 2.6 million parents who owe child support have been given to the Internal Revenue Service so any federal income tax refunds they are due can be used to pay their obligations, officials said. Last year, nearly $452 million was collected by garnishing federal income tax refunds under the program. Parents subject to garnishing are those who owe $500 or more in child support, or who owe at least $150 in child support and have children receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children assistance. The program is considered a cost-effective way to make sure children are getting the support they are due, said Eunice Thomas, acting director of the Office of Child Support Enforcement in the Department of Health and Human Services. Under the program, it costs an average of $4.54 per case to collect an average of $654 for non-AFDC cases and an average of $562 for AFDC cases, she said. The program, enacted by Congress, was begun in 1981 for AFDC families and expanded in 1984 to other families.
DOC.HEAD: Fines Planned for False Social Security Assertions
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is proposing stiff fines for private group that imply in their advertising or solicitations that their services are sanctioned by Social Security or Medicare programs. The Department of Health and Human Services proposed the regulation Wednesday in response to the many complaints it has received about such false assertions. The proposal would cover misuse of the terms ``Social Security,'' ``Social Security Account,'' ``Social Security Administration,'' ``Social Security System,'' ``Medicare,'' and ``Health Care Financing Administration,'' or the letters ``SSA'' or ``HCFA.'' Use of any symbols or emblems associated with either the Social Security Administration or the Health Care Financing Administration also would be a violation. Under the proposed regulation, which is subject to a time for public comment before being adopted, the department could impose a civil fines of up to $25,000 per violation for a misleading TV or radio broadcast and up to $5,000 for violations occurring in print advertising.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomat: Soviets Balking At Pullout of Troops From Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: A Czechoslovak diplomat said today that the Kremlin is balking at a swift pullout of the estimated 75,000 Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia, citing difficulties in absorbing the returning soldiers. Soviet and Czechoslovak officials resumed negotiations today in Moscow on the pullout, which the new Prague government wants completed by the end of the year. Antonin Murgas, a spokesman for the Czechoslovak Embassy in Moscow, said the Soviets have argued that the deadline is impossible to meet for humanitarian reasons. He said the Soviet side contends such a pullout cannot begin until 1991 because there are not currently enough schools and homes in the Soviet Union for the families of the officers stationed in Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist government, led by President Vaclav Havel, declared void two 1968 agreements with Moscow that legalized the troops' deployment. The government, which replaced hard-line Communists after a peaceful revolution in November, not only demands all the troops out by the end of the year but wants half of the force out by May. Unlike Hungary, where initial talks on a Soviet troop withdrawal took place last week, Czechoslovakia considers the matter of Soviet troop withdrawal separate from Vienna talks on arms reduction in Europe. The Soviet forces in both countries are viewed as occupiers who crushed movements for democracy, in Hungary in 1956 and in Czechoslovakia in 1968. The demands from Prague and Budapest for a Soviet troop pullout have increased pressure on Moscow for a radical cutback in central Europe, under discussion at the Vienna talks. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Moscow today for talks on the U.S. proposal to cut Soviet and American troops in all of Europe to 225,000 on each side, with a limit of 195,000 in central Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead in Britain's Second Storm In Less Than Two Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Packing 80 mph winds, Britain's second major storm in two weeks felled trees, disrupted transportation and brought rains that flooded homes and farmland. Police said the storm claimed two lives. The Atlantic storm hit Wednesday, lashing coastal towns and cities with southwesterly winds and disrupting ferry sailings in the English Channel. The winds and rain continued early today. Flooding shut down 25 miles of the A48 freeway in western England today, Gloucestershire police said. British Rail said rail links between Perth and Dundee in Scotland and two routes in Wales were closed today because of flooding, fallen trees or damaged overhead power pickup lines on electrified sections of track. Police said a man died Wednesday when a tree blown over by the wind crushed his car near Andover, 60 miles southwest of London. A repairman trying to restore power to homes without electricity because of storm damage near Warminster, 95 miles west of London, was also killed Wednesday when he was struck by a car. Police said at least three people were injured in the storm. The strong winds brought down power lines in southern England, blacking out the small town of Fleet, 35 miles southwest of London, and 2,000 homes in surrounding countryside. ``Wales and the West Country are particularly badly hit with flooding and very high winds making conditions absolutely unbearable,'' a spokesman for the Automobile Association said. Weather forecasting organizations have been scrupulous about predicting storms since an October 1987 nighttime storm that took much of southern England by surprise, killing 20 people. A Defense Ministry investigation said the Meteorological Office failed to give adequate warning of that storm because its scientists put too much trust in the predictions of an out-of-date computer. A storm that struck Europe on Jan. 25 killed 47 people in Britain and caused $1.7 billion in damage. Forecasters said the high winds are caused by cold air moving down from the arctic, hitting unseasonably warm air surrounding Britain in the Atlantic, creating the very dramatic low pressure that fuels the winds.

DOC.HEAD: China Defends Human Rights Record, Criticizes State Department
DOC.TEXT: China today declared it would not accept ``wanton attacks'' on its human rights record by the United States and said a State Department report on the issue would ``do further serious harm to Sino-U.S. relations.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua, at a weekly briefing, also dismissed as ``utterly groundless'' charges of widespread human rights violations by the U.S.-based human rights organization Asia Watch. The annual State Department human rights report has yet to be released, but congressional sources in Washington say it harshly criticizes China. It reportedly chronicles the continued political use of executions, suppression of labor rights, slave labor camps in western China and religious persecution of Catholics and Buddhists. Jin said he had not seen the report but ``we are resolutely opposed to the imposition of one's own values on others by any country and interference in China's internal affairs under the pretext of human rights.'' He added: ``Should the U.S. State Department insist on its wanton attacks against China in its human rights report, which is based on rumors and which is to be released soon, it will certainly do further serious harm to Sino-U.S. relations and will arouse greater indignation from the Chinese people.'' He said the Asia Watch report released Wednesday, which accuses China of continued arrests and secret executions of people involved in the crushed pro-democracy movement, was ``utterly groundless and with ulterior motives.'' ``The Chinese government attaches importance to human rights,'' he said, and ``the fact that some individuals are dealt with according to law because they have breached the criminal law is just for the purpose of protecting the human rights of the broad masses.'' He said the Chinese government has stated that participants of the pro-democracy demonstations last spring who did not violate criminal law would not be prosecuted. The Asia Watch report said tens of thousands of dissenters are languishing in Chinese jails. Many are denied access to lawyers and are subject to physical and mental torture, it said. The report criticized President Bush for moving to improve relations with China while human rights violations remain pervasive.
