DOC.HEAD: Actress Buys Into Town That Doesn't Want to Lose Past
LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: Actress Kim Basinger, who bought a third of this north Georgia town for $20 million last month, has said she wants to preserve its old-time character and won't tear down even a barn. But then, nobody tears down much here. Old barns still contain forgotten buckboards and horse-drawn plows from the days before the boll weevil ate up the cotton. The blacksmith shop, where the village smithy hasn't sung for decades, still stands, and the forges and carriage-making equipment are still there. At the Braselton Store, Cedelia Hosch gives a hearty turn on the cash register crank, and as the numbers of the sale pop up, the cash drawer yawns open leisurely. A little sign flips from ``barter'' to ``credit'' to ``cash.'' A fading federal poster on the wall notes that the minimum wage is $1.90 an hour. The store used to be the town bank, and the small round safe hasn't been moved out. It's not for show. It's the way Braselton is. Basinger, who starred in ``Batman'' and grew up in nearby Athens, hasn't said specifically what she and her co-investors want to do with the land bought from the Braselton clan. The 1,728-acre purchase, of which about 1,000 acres is in town, includes a 600-acre industrial park with utilities; a few residences; some land ripe for development; and most of downtown, which consists mainly of a complex of Braselton family stores, founded in 1887. In the connecting warren of a hardware and building supply shop, a furniture store, a grocery and a department store, a drug store and what used to be the bank, you can buy it all _ from beans to bullets to a brass bed. ``They used to say they had everything here, `from the cradle to the grave,''' said Mrs. Hosch, a lifelong resident of the area and 24-year Braselton employee. ``And they did. They sold cradles and they sold caskets.'' The mayor is a Braselton as was the one before him, and all but one councilman has Braselton family ties. The sale does not affect the town government or services such as water and sewer systems. The council will keep its control on zoning matters. Unlike much of small-town America, Braselton is not dying out. It contains a Mitsubishi plant, a winery and a tool factory. People are moving into the region, not out. The population has stayed steady at about 500, but more than 5,000 people live within five miles. Braselton has freeway access, is about 45 minutes north of Atlanta and land prices are on the rise. Residential developments are springing up and crime is low. There is only one cop and one stoplight. Parking is no problem. Herbert ``Kit'' Braselton, who runs the hardware store, said the 24 stockholders in the family holdings decided nine years ago to sell. From his roll-top desk, he pointed to boxes of offers they had received over they years. Most, he said, wanted to pay for it over 20 or 30 years. ``But the heirs are getting up in age, most of them are past 75,'' he said, describing himself as a ``young buck'' who turns 70 this month. ``We were hunting a cash deal.'' He said the heirs also had the community in mind. Miss Basinger ``promised to do well by the town and I think she will.'' Mayor Henry Edward Braselton, who operates the grocery store, said he hoped the town's history would be preserved. During the Depression, when cash was scarce, the Braselton family printed its own to pay field hands and store workers. It was good only at the family stores, and samples of it are in a frame on the wall near the old cash register. A bittersweet collection of yellowing pictures and newspaper clippings on the wall traces the town's progress. There is a 1956 letter and two $1 bills from a man who said ``I want this letter and these two one-dawler bills to go to the head manager ... '' to atone for a 10-cent toy he shoplifted there on Christmas Eve 1917. Miss Basinger has mentioned a possible recording and film studio, and Mayor Braselton said it may bring in some tourists. ``It's easier to pick Yankees than it is to pick cotton,'' he said as he relaxed in a rocker in the family furniture store. ``You can't stop progress. We could have built Braselton into an island and watched progress build up around us,'' he said. ``But I think we did the right thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Time Element Becomes Crucial in Hazelwood Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Testimony Set to Resume 1:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A critical time element was vigorously disputed as lawyers tried to answer how many hours Capt. Joseph Hazelwood spent drinking liquor before he took command of the Exxon Valdez on its fateful voyage. A Coast Guard officer's wife testified she saw Hazelwood order a vodka on the rocks at a Valdez bar about 1:45 p.m. on March 23. The skipper's lawyers contend he didn't get to the bar until 4 p.m. He boarded the Exxon Valdez about 8:30 that night and the ship ran aground just after midnight, causing the worst oil spill in U.S. history. Janice Delozier, whose husband, Mark, was one of the first Coast Guard officers to board the Exxon Valdez after it ran aground, insisted Hazelwood was the man she saw at the Pipeline Club and later recognized in a newspaper photo. ``My immediate reaction was, `Wow, I saw him,''' she testified. She had told FBI and Coast Guard investigators she had gone to the club for coffee during her lunch hour when Hazelwood arrived and ordered vodka on the rocks. Defense attorney Michael Chalos attacked her account, noting that her husband was standing by and prompting her during her interview, which was recorded. She also acknowledged she had listened to the tape before testifying Wednesday to ensure that her testimony was consistent. She said she waited 10 days to come forward with her story because she feared people might find her involvement ``fishy'' given her husband's role in the case. ``I didn't want anything to do with it,'' said the woman who spoke rapidly in a thick Southern accent. ``And then there were the ever-present questions, `What were you doing in a bar?''' She said she doubted people would believe she had gone there for coffee. She portrayed the bar as a town gathering place where men's and women's darts' teams staged competitions. Chalos and Mrs. Delozier clashed when he asked how come she didn't discuss her recollection with the barmaid who she said waited on Hazelwood. ``There's no `how come' involved,'' snapped Mrs. Delozier. ``I'm not the town crier.'' She said another woman was at the bar that day but she didn't consult with her, either, because ``she's not the kind of young lady I hang out with.'' Chalos asked if it ever occurred to Mrs. Delozier she might be mistaken in identifying Hazelwood. ``It has occurred to me, sir,'' she said. Asked if she tried to verify her identification, she said, ``I didn't feel I had to.'' ``But if you had doubts?'' Chalos asked before the woman cut him off. ``When did I say I had doubts? I knew who I saw 100 percent,'' she said. ``I wouldn't be sitting here under oath if I had those doubts.'' The attorney noted that in an interview with a state police investigator last week she placed Hazelwood in the bar between 12:30 and 1:30 p.m. She said she was confused by the passage of time since the event. She was followed to the witness stand by Gretchen Dunkin, an administrative assistant at the Alaska Maritime Agency in Valdez, who said she saw Hazelwood leave for lunch with his shipmates at 12:30 p.m. and later encountered him at the Pipeline Club at about 4 p.m. She said Hazelwood's demeanor was unchanged from earlier in the day. ``He seemed to be relaxed,'' she said. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is accused of a felony second-degree criminal mischief charge and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. The prosecution contends Hazelwood's drunkenness contributed to the accident, which spilled more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound, killing thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of shore. In a legal setback for the defense, Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone allowed as evidence recordings of Hazelwood's comments to the Coast Guard after he called to say: ``We are aground and leaking some oil.'' The defense had argued Hazelwood's statements were exempt from use in a state court under federal law.

DOC.HEAD: Copter Crashes Near Glacier, Killing at Least Six People
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian helicopter crashed near Shakes Glacier, killing at least six people and injuring two others, authorities said. The Huey UH-1, owned by Northern Mountain Logging Co., based in Prince George, British Columbia, went down Wednesday afternoon about 15 miles northeast of Wrangell, said Debbie Avila, a dispatcher with the Alaska State Patrol office in Ketchikan. There are no roads into the area along the Stikine River and little information about the crash was immediately available. State troopers and investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board were to search the crash scene at daylight to recover the bodies of the six people, Avila said. The two injured were flown late Wednesday to a Vancouver General Hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, said John Vowell, Wrangell General Hospital administrator. He said they both were in stable condition. An emergency room nurse said early this morning the two were expected to arrive by daylight. None of the victims' identities was released. Some aboard were believed to be Canadian ore miners from the Johnny Mountain gold mine, just on the Alaska side of the border. Wrangell Fire Chief Tim Buness said he was unsure where the helicopter was headed when it went down.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Gov't Made Millions in Smuggling Of Illegal Aliens
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the government of ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega made millions of dollars helping illegal aliens enter the United States, the new immigration director said. ``We knew there was corruption, but we never imagined all the levels of corruption,'' said the official, Jose Chen Barria. Chen said aliens from the Dominican Republic, Ecuador and Peru obtained falsified documents to enter Panama, then went to Guatemala, Mexico and the United States. He said more than 45,000 people _ including 11,196 Ecuadorians, 10,502 Peruvians, 9,241 Dominicans and 7,405 Nicaraguans _ were smuggled into Panama in 1989. He had no figures on how many people entered the United States this way. The profits from this operation were enormous, he said. ``Smuggling Chinese brought in nearly $200 million in five years. Between November 1985 and 1989, 20,537 Chinese entered the country, paying an average of $5,000 each, Chen said. ``The business of smuggling Chinese into Panama could have generated between $50 million to $60 million.'' From 1985 to 1989, 10,020 Chinese left Panama, some of them with false documents going to the United States, he said. Noriega was toppled in a Dec. 21 invasion by the United States, which said it was protecting Americans in Panama and wanted to bring Noriega to trial on U.S. drug trafficking charges. The former director of immigration and naturalization, Belgica de Castillo, has been detained by authorities of the new government of President Guillermo Endara.

DOC.HEAD: INS Launches `Blitz' to Detain Central Americans in Texas
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has reversed a recent decision to ease the detention of Central Americans seeking asylum in the United States and said it hopes to stanch an increased flow of illegal aliens. Only those able to prove they are fleeing a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' will be allowed to stay, Gene McNary, commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, announced Wednesday. He said an additional $11 million will be spent to bring in extra Border Patrol agents and immigration officials to stem the flow of new asylum-seekers along the Mexican border in Texas. To save money, the INS last month lowered the population at the 347-acre detention center at Bayview to less than 700 by freeing asylum-seekers on their own recognizance to travel elsewhere in the United States while their cases were decided. ``Since that time, I'm convinced that because of the gradual increase in people coming across the border that we need to put on a blitz,'' McNary said. ``We're not going to allow border crashing.'' He said asylum-seekers no longer would be released. Six large tents, such as those used for state fairs, have been erected, raising the camp's capacity to 2,500. McNary said the INS will build tents for 10,000 if needed. The Bayview camp held 998 detainees Wednesday, mostly Central Americans. Another 632 people were detained at five other INS centers in southern Texas. A year ago the INS reduced the time it took to make asylum decisions to just one day when it was overwhelmed with more than 500 applications for political asylum every day. Because most of the asylum requests were denied and those denied were put in deportation proceedings, the number seeking refuge dropped to fewer than 10 a day. At one point, the Bayview camp's population topped 2,400. But the detention of aliens from countries other than Mexico in October rose to 829 alone in the McAllen area of southern Texas. By January, the figure had risen to 1,860, mostly Central Americans, said INS spokesman Duke Austin. Refugee advocates have speculated that a return of tensions, especially in El Salvador and Nicaragua, are responsible for the recent increase in immigrants from that region. Asylum is granted to those able to show they are fleeing a country because of political and not economic reasons. INS officials say most Central Americans come to the United States to find work, and therefore do not qualify. McNary told local officials there wouldn't be a repeat of the situation early last year when hundreds of Central Americans were camping in makeshift tents and in condemned buildings. A group called the Rio Grande Defense Committee protested the new INS policy. ``Last year, these tents became a symbol of injustice, of summary asylum denials and coercive, illegal conditions of confinement,'' the group said in a leaflet handed out during McNary's visit.

DOC.HEAD: Hunter Captured After Four Years on Lam
DOC.TEXT: A bounty hunter who himself was hunted for nearly four years after escaping from a courthouse is back behind bars, awaiting trial on weapons and other charges. George John Koufos, a police buff who couldn't become an officer because he had a lengthy criminal record, taunted his pursuers and used several aliases as he stayed on the lam, authorities said. ``Three years I waited for this man,'' said the main pursuer, Anthony R. Strus, an agent for the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. He called Koufos ``a master of deceit'' who within the past year even worked as a prison guard as he lived in Boston and Connecticut and shared an apartment in Connecticut with a state Highway Department officer. After his escape in March 1986, Koufos once called federal agents to complain about wanted fliers posted in the New York City neighborhood where he was staying with his girlfriend, Strus said. He said Koufos also told the agents he saw Strus enter a delicatessen across the street. The bounty hunter was finally hunted down Saturday in Ellington, Conn. Connecticut state police had learned Koufos was trying to set up another bounty hunting operation under the alias of John Michael Doyle. It was unclear how they obtained the information. On Wednesday, the 6-foot-1, 300-pound Koufos appeared in U.S. District Court here, bound in ankle and wrist shackles. He pleaded innocent to a six-count indictment charging him with failing to disclose a previous conviction and using fake Drug Enforcement Administration credentials while buying guns. A grand jury returned the indictment in August. U.S. District Judge John Bissell ordered him to remain in federal custody, and set trial for April 2. Koufos also faces weapons charges in the New York City borough of Brooklyn and in Hartford, Conn., and is accused of impersonating a federal agent in Brooklyn and in Boston, Strus said. Strus said Koufos has used the names John Kou, George Koufopoulos, Loannis Koufo, and most recently, Doyle. Strus said the most reliable birth date for the Brooklyn-born defendant is Feb. 9, 1955. Koufos had a nearly 20-year criminal record of larceny, forgery, assault and possession of stolen property, preventing him from becoming a police officer, said Lawrence McElynn, a DEA agent in Washington, D.C. So instead, Koufos got into the business of hunting down defendants who skip bail. ``He seems to be the kind of fellow who is attracted to police work,'' McElynn said. He acquired police techniques through a bounty hunter's frequent contact with law enforcement authorities, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Kevin McCarthy in Newark. In 1984, a judge in Bridgeport, Conn., sentenced Koufos to five years in prison for an insurance scam. But he was out in months after persuading the DEA he could work as an informant, court records show. ``He'll have you convinced that you're his brother if that's what he wants to convince you of,'' said Stamford, Conn., police Detective James Van Allen, who investigated the insurance case. Soon after, Koufos and the DEA agent assigned to him became partners in pursuing fugitives, authorities said. They were charged in Elizabeth in 1985 with abducting the girlfriend of a bail jumper they were seeking. Charges against the agent were eventually dismissed and are pending against Koufos. Around that time, authorities lodged the weapons charges in Newark. But Koufos disappeared. In March 1986, Strus and other agents arrested Koufos in New York City. While awaiting a hearing at a federal courthouse on the case, he was left alone for a moment in a locked room. Koufos picked the lock and was free. His attorney, Tonianne Bongiovanni, said Koufos fled because of threats that if he went to prison, inmates would be told of his cooperation. ``He was fearful he would never come out alive,'' she said. Ms. Bongiovanni said that Koufos knew his arrest in Connecticut was imminent and decided not to flee.

DOC.HEAD: New Restrictions On Chinese Students Going Overseas to Study
DOC.TEXT: Chinese seeking to study overseas at their own expense will have to first work for several years in China or pay a large fee to the government, a pro-Beijing newspaper reported today. The new restrictions come from the State Education Commission and take effect Saturday, the Chinese-language Ta Kung Pao said in an article from Beijing that quoted unnamed sources. Under the order, university and college graduates will have to ``serve'' China for three to five years before being allowed to study overseas at their own expense, the report said. It did not say precisely what type of work was expected. In addition, Chinese still in school will be allowed to apply to study overseas only after repaying the government for public money already spent on their education. Fees will range from 1,500 yuan ($318) per school year for students at professional training colleges to 6,000 yuan ($1,271) per school year for Chinese studying for a doctorate. The average annual urban wage in China is about $255. The newspaper said the money would be returned to students if they come back to China within eight years of going abroad. In explaining the reason for the new regulations, the article said only that they were drafted in the spirit of discussions held by the six-member Politburo Standing Committee of the ruling Communist Party. Fear of students not returning home, particularly after the brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last year, is one reason for China's more stringent rules on study overseas. The government also is concerned that too many students are returning home with ``anti-socialist'' ideas that could undermine the Communist revolution. Sources in the education bureaucracy in Beijing had earlier told The Associated Press of regulations being circulated internally to bar anyone under 30 years of age or with less than five years of work experience from obtaining official sponsorship to study overseas. Other measures have made it more difficult for students to take tests for study abroad and to obtain passports without official sponsorship.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Could Act Next Week on Use of Mercury in Paint
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials are considering a ban on mercury in paint after a 4-year-old boy became severely disabled after inhaling it in his home. ``We think there is a potential for exposure and a potential for risk,'' said Dr. Ruth Etzel, a pediatrician at the government's Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. She said the agency is considering a recommendation to ban the use of mercury in paints to prevent bacterial growth and mildew. A decision could come as early as next week, she said. The concern is heightened by the fact that mercury need not be added to paint because safer alternatives are available, she said. ``If there is a preventable source of exposure to mercury, we ought to try to prevent exposure,'' Etzel said. The Environmental Protection Agency also has launched an urgent investigation, said Dr. Renate Kimbrough, of the EPA in Washington, D.C. ``We are trying to get, as rapidly as possible, as much information together as we can.'' The case that triggered the investigation occurred last summer in Detroit. The boy developed severe neurological problems and became unable to walk. The condition is called acrodynia, or ``pink disease.'' He was hospitalized until just before Christmas, said David Wade, a toxicologist with the Michigan Department of Agriculture, which regulates mercury as a pesticide. It's not known whether the boy would recover fully, Wade said. ``It's going to be a long recovery,'' Wade said. ``There is a lot of physical therapy that will be involved.'' An investigation showed the paint contained levels of phenyl mercuric acetate higher than the law allows, Wade said. The boy's family has sued the paint's manufacturer, the Mercury Paint Co. of Detroit. ``The issue is whether anything in the paint harmed the child, which we don't believe it did,'' said Charles Soberman, president of Mercury Paint. ``It's not a question of a formulation. When you have one alleged incident in the 70-year history of a company, that hardly creates an imminent health hazard, in our opinion.'' Pink disease was relatively common from the 1920s through the 1940s, Etzel said. It disappeared when scientists found it was caused by a widely used teething powder containing mercury. She said it is possible, however, that the disease is occurring more frequently than doctors realize but is being misdiagnosed. ``Many younger physicians have never seen a case,'' Etzel said. It produces a rash similar to those caused by rheumatic fever, an ailment called Kawasaki disease and even measles, she said. Doctors unfamiliar with pink disease might be diagnosing it as one of these, she said. The Michigan health department issued an advisory in October warning consumers not to use paints with high levels of mercury. In January, the department asked the EPA to review the evidence on mercury exposure and consider banning its use in paint. ``We have initiated a review,'' said Tina Levine, a toxicologist at the EPA. ``It has a very high priority.'' The concern is not only for children who might be exposed but for other groups, such as painters, she said. She noted that the Detroit case was unusual because it involved paint in which the levels of mercury were about three times higher than allowed, about 300 parts per million. Dr. Charles Cubbage of the Michigan Department of Agriculture said that levels of mercury exposure that might be safe for one child could cause pink disease in another. ``It's what we call an idiosyncratic disease,'' he said. ``If you have a group of children exposed to the same level of mercury, they won't all get it.''

DOC.HEAD: Principal: Caps Are For Dunces
DOC.TEXT: Schools have tried banning beepers, jewelry and short skirts. Now, a principal has gone one better. He ordered his students to polish up their image by yanking the gold caps from their teeth. ``You can't go to Wall Street with gold teeth or excessive gold jewelry,'' Principal Frank Mickens told a student assembly Wednesday. ``You can be a drug dealer, you can be a prostitute, you can be a pimp.'' When the freshman assembly at Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn rumbled with protest, Mickens said students who don't want to comply can transfer to another school. ``In dealing with black and Hispanic young people, I teach them they have to be beyond reproach, people have to look at them and immediately know they are dealing with a good young person,'' said Mickens, who is black. The order furthers a trend in which schools have banned electronic beepers _ which students have been used for communicating with drug dealers _ and pricey clothes and jewelry, in order to promote education over conspicuous consumption and to prevent the students being victimized by thieves. Three years ago, Mickens banned excessive gold jewelry. Short skirts, personal tape players and shearling coats also were forbidden. The school, once regarded as one of New York's worst, is in a section of the Bedford-Stuyvesant area stricken with crime and drugs. Now, 70 percent of the seniors continue with their education after graduation. Obah-David Ward, president of the school's Parent, Teacher, and Community Association, said parents support Mickens, who is ``setting kids in the right direction.'' ``Our students are placing the accent on the wrong thing: The gold here and the gold there, the right shoes, the right dress. We want the emphasis to be on education,'' Ward said. The caps, a fad first started by drug dealers wanting to flash their wealth, cost between $40 and $100, and are more popular with boys than girls. Erskine Tillery, a 16-year-old sophomore with two gold caps on his front teeth, said he would follow the order because he probably would be safer from gold thieves. ``People will shoot you if they don't come out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Colon Cancer Victims Could Be Saved by New Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Details of a major new study showing that a veterinary drug is the first medicine to save the lives of people with advanced operable colon cancer should presuade doctors to offer the treatment, a researcher contends. Dr. Charles G. Moertel of the Mayo Clinic estimates that routine use of this approach for all potential patients could save about 5,000 lives annually. Doctors from the National Cancer Institute sent letters to doctors outlining the findings last fall, but the first in-depth account of the research appears in today's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. ``The data in this large trial are just overwhelmingly convincing,'' said Moertel, who directed the study. The treatment uses levamisole, which is ordinarily given to de-worm farm animals, and the standard cancer medicine fluorouracil. When tested on 1,296 colon cancer patients, it reduced cancer recurrence by 41 percent, and it lowered the death rate by one-third. In October, the cancer institute wrote letters to about 35,000 doctors describing the findings of this and a smaller, earlier study that was published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology. However, some doctors remained skeptical. ``With publication in a prestigious journal, they will review this information and decide it is worth trying,'' predicted Dr. Michael Friedman, chief of the cancer institute's therapy evaluation program. Levamisole is not commercially available in the United States for human use. However, since May the cancer institute has distributed it without cost to physicians who wanted to use it for colon cancer. Moertel said that about one-third of potential patients are getting it this way. Another one-third with advanced operable colon cancer are enrolled in experimental drug studies, and some of them are also receiving levamisole as well as other medicines. Moertel said some doctors are probably not using the medicine because of the extra paper work necessary to obtain it for patients, while others were reluctant to adopt the therapy until they saw detailed results. Last week, the Oncologic Drugs Advisory Committee of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration unanimously recommended that Janssen Pharmaceutica Inc. be given permission to sell the medicine for routine use. Eva Kemper, an FDA spokeswoman, said Wednesday that final approval should come within a month or so. Of the 110,000 Americans diagnosed with colon cancer annually, about 22,000 have stage C disease. Their cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes but can still be removed surgically. Moertel said that 95 percent of stage C patients should receive the two-drug combination. ``At the present time, with the known rate of occurrence of C stage colon cancer, this could translate into saving about 5,000 lives annually who would now die of recurrent colon cancer,'' he said. Studies are also under way to see if the treatment saves the lives of people with less advanced colon cancer that has spread into the wall of the colon but not invaded lymph nodes.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Rain Hit Cascades; Midwest, East Expect Record Warmth
DOC.TEXT: Coastal rain and high-altitude snow east of the Cascade Mountains continued in Oregon and Washington today as another Gulf of Alaska storm churned into the Pacific Northwest. A warm spell, meanwhile, lingered across most of the rest of the nation, with temperatures in the Southeast averaging up to 16 degrees above normal. Record readings were expected today in parts of the Midwest and much of the East. Arctic air was due today in the northern Rockies and Friday in the Northern Rockies. All major passes across the Washington Cascades were expected to reopen today after being closed due to heavy snow and high avalanche danger. Snoqualmie Pass, Stevens Pass and White Pass were closed Wednesday evening, virtually cutting off road travel between eastern and western Washington, the state Department of Transportation said. The Spokane, Wash., area received about 3.5 inches of snow by late Wednesday. Winter storm watches were posted for late today across eastern Washington state and northern Idaho. More snow was expected in most of Idaho, and in the mountains of Arizona, New Mexico, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming and Montana. The weekend forecast calls for the Plains to turn warmer and the Southwest to remain sunny. The mid-Atlantic states anticipate rain or snow. Colder air was expected in the Gulf states, Great Lakes, Mississippi Valley and Northeast. The rain and snow in the Northwest was predicted to last through the weekend. Alaska's deadly cold ended its second week with a low of 57 below recorded at Tanana. Fort Kent, Maine, registered the coldest temperature Wednesday in the lower 48 states with minus 9 degrees. Philadelphia's high of 59 degrees on Wednesday broke the 106-year-old mark of 58. Other new records established for Feb. 7 included: 45 degrees in Neguanee, Mich.; 51 in Williamsport, Pa.; 55 in Harrisburg, Pa., and Newark, N.J.; 57 in Baltimore; 59 in Atlantic City, N.J.; 67 in Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; and 69 in Concordia, Kans. Concordia's usual high for the date is 39 degrees. Wednesday's high temperature for the nation was 85 at Fort Myers, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Barr, Cosby, Abdul Lead `People's Choice' Nominations
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr, Bill Cosby and Tom Cruise were among nominees picked in a public opinion poll for the 16th annual ``The People's Choice Awards.'' ``Batman'' and ``Dead Poet's Society'' were among nominees in the movie categories, while ``Cheers'' and ``Life Goes On'' were among the shows winning nominations in the television categories. The winners, to be announced during a March 11 telecast on CBS, were determined by a poll conducted by the Gallup Organization and announced late Tuesday. Here is a list of the top three vote-getters for each of the 20 categories. Some categories have more than three vote-getters because of ties. Favorite female television performer: Roseanne Barr, Candice Bergen, Phylicia Rashad. Favorite male television performer: Bill Cosby, Ted Danson, Tom Selleck. Favorite young television performer: Neil Patrick Harris, Keshia Knight-Pulliam, Fred Savage. Favorite television comedy series: ``Cheers,'' ``The Cosby Show,'' ``Roseanne.'' Favorite television dramatic series: ``China Beach,'' ``Knots Landing,'' ``L.A. Law,'' ``thirtysomething.'' Favorite male performer in a television series: Richard Chamberlain, Neil Patrick Harris, Craig T. Nelson. Favorite female performer in a new television series: Stephanie Beacham, Corinne Bohrer, Jamie Lee Curtis, Ann Jillian. Favorite new television comedy series: ``Coach,'' ``Doogie Howser,'' ``Major Dad.'' Favorite new television dramatic series: ``Life Goes On,'' ``Quantum Leap,'' ``Rescue 911,'' ``Young Riders.'' Favorite late night talk show host: Johnny Carson, Arsenio Hall, David Letterman. Favorite motion picture: ``Batman,'' ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' ``Look Who's Talking,'' ``Steel Magnolias.'' DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Ban On Contraception Blamed For Pediatric AIDS Epidemic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 4th pvs, `He did ... the disease.' to ADD health official saying more than 700 children with virus. Picks up 5th pvs, Doctors blame ...' ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu's ban on contraception is being blamed for Romania's epidemic of AIDS among children, most of whom contracted the deadly disease through blood transfusions to treat malnourishment. Government officials say AIDS was a state secret under the ousted Communist dictator and they now are publicizing the problem to gain international help to fight the disease. Health Minister Dan Enachescu said Wednesday that Romania has about 74 confirmed cases of AIDS, including 50 children. About 600 Romanians carry the human immunodeficiency virus, _ HIV _ which causes AIDS, he said. He did not say how many people were tested for the virus or how many had died of the disease. Earlier Wednesday, Dr. Jonathan Mann, the head of AIDS programs for the World Health Organization, said more than 700 children in Romania were infected with the virus. He said in a U.S. television interview that an emergency WHO medical team sent to Romania is still trying to ``figure out exactly how this has happened and, particularly, what steps must be taken immediately to stop this now.'' Doctors blame Romania's outbreak of pediatric AIDS on contaminated blood transfusions and the constant reuse of needles at hospitals. Elsewhere in the world, most children with AIDS have contracted it from their mothers while in the womb. Disposable needles have been in short supply in Romania and foreign governments and charities are now pledging to sent several million disposable hypodermic syringes. Enachescu said that because of Ceausescu's ban on contraception, there are 14,000 abandoned children in Romania. Many were given small blood transfusions to treat malnourishment, and the transfusions proved to be a main source of passing on the AIDS virus, he said. Enachescu said the Health Ministry had only halted such transfusions on Jan. 5. But he said that in some orphanages and hospitals in Bucharest, the Black Sea port of Constanza and the Danube port of Giurgi ``there is between 15 and 50 percent'' of children who have the AIDS virus. Other towns have reported no cases and a nationwide survey must be conducted for a more complete picture of the epidemic, Enachescu said. Dr. Jacques Lebas, president of the Paris-based humanitarian organization Doctors of the World, said Monday that the outbreak was the first known AIDS epidemic to involve mainly children and that an initial screening of 1,025 children up to 3 years old in several hospitals and orphanages found 367 with the HIV virus. AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. A person can carry the HIV virus for years without having AIDS, but in almost all cases it leads to the disease. There is no known cure for AIDS. Enachescu said the government was completing a national program for the treatment and control of the disease. Ceausescu, who was toppled in a bloody popular revolution and executed on Christmas Day, banned contraception because he wanted continuous population growth. Enachescu said Romania has enough equipment to test blood in Bucharest for AIDS for the next two months, but needs more equipment as well as disposable needles. Britain announced Wednesday that it was sending a million syringes to help fight the epidemic. AmeriCares, the U.S.-based medical relief organization, also said it would send a million syringes. Dr. Alex Gromyko, a Soviet based in Copenhagen and an expert on the medical aspects of AIDS, said: ``It's enormous what has to be done to get an adequate idea'' of the extent of the problem. He said the first case of AIDS in Romania was reported in 1985, but until October 1989 only 10 cases were reported. Last month, Dr. Ludovic Paun of the Infectious Diseases Department at Bucharest's Victor Babes Hospital said 69 people treated there had developed AIDS since 1985, including 53 young children. He said 33 of the 45 AIDS fatalities so far had been children 3 years old or younger.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Indict 20 Alleged Mobsters
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors believe they've cracked open an underworld crime syndicate with the indictments of 20 alleged mobsters in the slayings of three bookmakers who wouldn't pay the mob's ``street taxes.'' ``Obviously, this was a powerful group of individuals,'' said acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson, citing what he said was their willingness to kill and their many years of operating the rackets. The government said those indicted by a federal grand jury were engaged in illegal gambling, high-interest loans and the collection of street taxes _ fees to the syndicate for the privilege of running criminal activities. Several are accused of using murder and extortion as enforcement tactics. Prosecutors called the indictments a rare solution of underworld murders. Those indicted, Raphaelson said, operated as the Joseph Ferriola street crew, a segment of Chicago's crime syndicate _ a notorious group of gangsters harking back to the days of Al Capone. The prosecutor refused to say how many street crews are believed to operate in Chicago, how big a role the Ferriola crew played in the mob or whether the indictments were expected to reduce crime in the city. Rocco Infelise, 67, of suburban River Forest, who allegedly became boss after Ferriola's death last year, is charged racketeering, conspiracy to commit murder, illegal gambling and tax cheating. Also charged with racketeering is Salvatore DeLaurentis, 52, of suburban Inverness. The FBI said Infelise and DeLaurentis were arrested Wednesday at O'Hare International Airport when they arrived from Florida. Of the 18 other defendants, all but one had been arrested. The government is seeking forfeiture of the homes of Infelise and DeLaurentis and $3.7 million in proceeds from alleged racketeering activities. Some of defendants also are accused of conspiring to bribe public officials in Illinois to protect the street crew and of planning to bribe officials in Wisconsin. Raphaelson said there isn't any indication the Wisconsin plans were realized or that any Wisconsin officials knew about the plan. According to the indictment, Anthony Reitinger was fatally shot in Chicago in 1975, Robert Plummer was beaten to death in the Libertyville suburb in 1982 and Hal Smith was strangled in suburban Long Grove in 1985. Veteran defense attorney Patrick Tuite noted that he represented some of the same defendants against similar charges in 1984 ``and the jury said `not guilty.''' The indictment contains 42 counts against the 20 defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Stevie Wonder Accused of Stealing `I Just Called To Say I Love You'
DOC.TEXT: Pop singer Stevie Wonder's Academy Award-winning song ``I Just Called To Say I Love You'' was written by two other people and stolen by Wonder after it was played for him, a lawyer charged. Songwriter Lloyd Chiate, 40, claims he and collaborator Lee Garrett wrote the song in the 1970s and titled it ``I Just Called To Say.'' Wonder says he wrote the song himself before the pair composed their song. Wonder, who was born Steveland Morris, is being sued in federal court for alleged copyright infringement by Chiate. ``We are going to prove to you that Mr. Morris took the song written by Mr. Chiate and Mr. Garrett for his own benefit ... and Mr. Chiate received nothing,'' attorney Herbert Dodell said Wednesday in opening statements as Wonder sat in the courtroom. But Wonder's attorney, Howard King, said the pop star wrote the song's chorus on July 16, 1976, as he returned from a visit with his mother in the San Fernando Valley, before Chiate and Garret ever met. He said Wonder completed the song in 1984 after hearing part of the soundtrack to the film ``The Woman in Red.'' King added that Garrett, who dropped out as a plaintiff in the case, has acknowledged that Wonder actually wrote the song.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Want Three-Year Contract for Selma School Superintendent
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: Public schools were ordered closed for a second day today as a racial dispute flared over white management of the mostly black school system in this 1960s battleground of the civil rights movement. On Wednesday, about 500 people chanting ``soul power'' and ``I am somebody'' marched on City Hall in support of Norward Roussell, Selma's first black superintendent. The white-dominated school board dismissed Roussell from his $80,000-a-year job last week, but reinstated him amid protests, and he returned to the job Wednesday. The six white members of the 11-member board cited an evaluation critical of Roussell's managerial skills as the basis for dismissing him. Roussell said the evaluation was unsubstantiated. Protest leaders, who want an elected board rather than the current board appointed by the white-majority City Council, said Roussell was being fired only because he is black. The marchers demanded Roussell be given a three-year contract. His contract expires in June. ``If we can't get that, we're going to be marching,'' said attorney Carlos Williams, a protest organizer. The board closed all 11 public schools in Selma's 70 percent black, 6,000-student system after scuffles broke out between white and black students Tuesday morning. Roussell met Wednesday for about two hours with principals and his central office staff and said the schools would remain closed today and until ``we are able to assure the safety and security of our students and staff.'' ``Everyone needs to cool down a bit,'' Roussell said. The closings prompted some white parents, upset with the racial turmoil, to transfer their children to Selma's two all-white private schools. ``We've run out of room in our sixth-grade classes and I've had to turn down some parents,'' said Lee Holladay, headmaster at Meadowview Christian School. He said 15 pupils have enrolled at the school since Tuesday. About 170 parents attended an informal discussion Wednesday night at Selma High School. ``I think it's important to note that 80 percent of the students in the community want to be in school,'' said one parent, Diane Crisman. ``If 20 percent want to boycott, let them, but keep them off school property.'' State Sen. Hank Sanders, meanwhile, said Wednesday he would use ``any means necessary'' to respond personally to what he described as police abuse of his wife, Rose, during a protest Monday over Roussell's firing. Mrs. Sanders, wearing a neck brace, with one arm in a sling, spoke from a wheelchair at a hospital Wednesday, saying she was hurt when she was carried bodily from Mayor Joe Smitherman's office by police after a melee there. She and three other blacks were charged with misdemeanors. J.L. Chestnut, one of Mrs. Sanders' law partners, filed a complaint alleging that her civil rights were violated.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: He'll `Never Walk the Streets Again'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with boy celebrating, quotes, editing to conform, clarify that boy is now 8 years old; picks up 10th graf, `Ms. Harlow, who ...' Note contents; Lloyde cq
DOC.TEXT: A boy who was raped, mutilated and left for dead jumped into his mother's arms and yelled, ``Success!'' after he found out a former mental patient was convicted in the attack, the woman said. The boy remained in his second-grade class Wednesday and was picked up by his parents after the conviction of Earl Kenneth Shriner. Under state sentencing guidelines, Shriner, who had a long history of violence toward young people, could be ordered imprisoned 99\ years. But Pierce County prosecutors said they would ask Superior Court Judge Thomas R. Sauriol to go beyond that range. ``We want to see that he never walks the streets again,'' said deputy prosecutor James Roche. Shriner faces sentencing March 26 for raping the then-7-year-old boy, cutting off his penis and leaving him for dead in woods near their south Tacoma homes. Shriner looked frightened when the jury returned the verdict. He gulped and bit his lower lip as the guilty announcements were read: guilty of first-degree attempted murder, two counts of first-degree rape and first-degree assault. Lloyde Alton, Shriner's court-appointed attorney, said he would seek a new trial. Ms. Harlow said she, the boy's father, Lowell, and friends celebrated at her house by dancing to the music of Black Sabbath and AC-DC shaking gold pompons and shouting ``Rah! Rah! Rah! Guilty! Guilty! Guilty!'' ``He jumped into my arms and said, `We got it! Success!''' she said. ``I was happy,'' the 8-year-old boy told the Morning News Tribune as he got ready for bed. ``I'm glad that he's in jail now, and I sat down and watched TV.'' The attack May 20 created an uproar in the state about sex predators. The Legislature is close to enacting legislation calling for longer sentences, civil commitment and registration of sex offenders. The law was drafted by a governor's task force on which the boy's mother had served. Ms. Harlow, who has testified before the Legislature, said she looked forward to the continued recovery of her son. ``Praise God it's over and it went like we were told,'' she said. A trust fund established with donations has financed extensive corrective surgery for the boy, but he faces more operations when he approaches adulthood. Deputy prosecutor Barbara Corey-Boulet said the extensive publicity, which complicated jury selection and resulted in heavy courtroom security, would help focus attention on other sex crime victims, especially girls who internalize their fears. ``Their cases don't get the attention they deserve. Here you have a horrible, visible injury,'' Corey-Boulet said. ``I think the legislative furor will help other victims.'' Jury forewoman Susan Barker, 30, said the attempted murder charge was the main issue in nearly five hours of deliberations that began Tuesday. The judge told jurors that to convict Shriner of attempted murder, they had to agree that Shriner intended to kill the boy. Another juror, Timothy Jacobson, said the grim nature of the case took its toll during deliberations. ``I know some of them had trouble sleeping,'' he said. ``I know I had trouble one or two nights getting my mind quieted down.'' Shriner has a 24-year history of violent attacks on young people. He has been confined at Rainier School for the retarded; Western State Hospital, a mental institution, and the Washington Corrections Center, but the jury was barred from hearing of his background. Neighbors found the boy, naked, bloody, covered with mud and practically incoherent, soon after the attack. A fellow jail inmate testified that Shriner admited mutilating the boy. Dolores Shriner, the defendant's mother, cried when she heard the verdict. On leaving the courtroom, she said, ``How would you feel if you were his mother?''

DOC.HEAD: Winn Convicted In Wealthy Woman's Disappearance
DOC.TEXT: A bankrupt Florida attorney who prosecutors say blamed a multimillionaire for his financial woes was convicted by a federal jury in the 1988 disappearance of the man's wife. The jury found Newton Alfred Winn, 65, guilty of one count each of conspiracy to kidnap, extortion and perjury Wednesday after about 3{ hours of deliberation. Winn was charged with extortion and lying to a federal grand jury about his knowledge of the disappearance of Annie Laurie Hearin on July 26, 1988. He also was accused of conspiracy in having a ransom letter mailed from Atlanta. No one has been charged with actually abducting the 74-year-old woman, whose search is still active. Winn, who faces sentencing April 13, sat impassively as the jurors were polled. ``I think we deserve the verdict,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney James Tucker said. ``The proof was there.'' In his closing arguments, Tucker said that Winn was ``a desperate man,'' who carried out the kidnapping conspiracy only days before his law office in St. Petersburg, Fla., was to be shut down. Defense attorneys said the government has the wrong man. John Collette, one of Winn's attorneys, said an appeal is likely. When asked if he had a statement after the verdict, Winn held out his hands in a questioning manner and said, ``What is there to say?'' The government claimed that Winn blamed Robert Hearin for his financial losses in School Pictures of Mississippi, Inc., in which Hearin was a primary stockholder and former chairman. Prosecutors said the business deal led Winn to his bankruptcy and the loss of his law office. Found at the Hearin home was a spattering of blood on the front door and another ransom note demanding that Hearin reimburse 12 people, including Winn, for losses they suffered in deals with School Pictures. Mrs. Hearin hasn't been seen since she disappeared from her Jackson home following a bridge party with friends. Doctors have said the woman had a health problem that required daily medication. ``The investigation into whatever happened to my mother is continuing, and on that basis, I am pleased with the result reached today,'' Robert Hearin Jr. said after the verdict was read. On hand for jury instructions and final arguments were two key government witnesses: Don Ward, who once worked for Winn; and Marilyn Taylor, who describes herself as a one-time lover of the defendant and who has testified that she mailed Aug. 11, 1988, a letter which prosecutors say was a ransom note. Defense Attorney Ed Marger told the jury that the conspiracy could have been created by Taylor and Ward or by Hearin's children ``to get some money that they didn't get at this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Clark Ends Campaign for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Steve Clark bowed out of the race for Arkansas governor after authorities told him they were investigating erroneous expense claims he filed with the state. Clark read a brief statement Wednesday announcing his withdrawal as a candidate for the Democratic nomination, but said he would not leave office as the state's attorney general, a post he has held for 12 years. Clark, 42, wouldn't answer questions, but his statement claimed innocence of any deliberate wrongdoing. On Tuesday, Prosecutor Chris Piazza officially notified Clark that state police and auditors were looking into his expenses. Earlier news reports said people claimed by Clark as fellow diners on state expense forms actually never ate with him. Clark said last week he was repaying the state nearly $4,000 that had gone unreported because of sloppy bookkeeping. He said he had tried to reconstruct his use of a state-issued Visa card 60 to 90 days after the fact. News reports said the expense-claim errors exceed $4,000 and may surpass $8,000. ``After much reflection and discussion with my family and friends, I have reached the conclusion that the mistakes in my expense records and subsequent news coverage about those mistakes have virtually destroyed my ability to run an efficient and effective campaign for governor,'' Clark said. ``I therefore must, with profound regret, withdraw as a candidate for governor,'' he said. ``As I complete the remainder of my term as attorney general, I pledge to serve the people of Arkansas with honor and dignity.'' Clark said last week: ``It was an honest mistake but I made a mistake. I'm sorry and I apologize.'' Col. Tommy Goodwin, state police director, said three state police officers have been assigned to the Legislative Audit staff to determine if any criminal activity occurred.

DOC.HEAD: China Says No Change In Communist Monopoly Of Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with TV report, reaction from foreign ministry. Pickup 6th graf, `Under the...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party, rejecting the reforms undoing Communist rule in the former Soviet empire, said today that it has no intention of surrendering its monopoly on power and claimed overwhelming popular support. A strongly worded editorial in the party's official People's Daily made no mention of the Soviet Communist Party's decision Wednesday to end its constitutional guarantee of leadership. But the commentary was an obvious response to Soviet and Eastern European moves toward multiparty political systems. It branded Western democracies as playthings of the rich. The nationally televised evening news today reported at length but without commentary on the Soviet Communist Party meeting. However, it made only passing mention at the end of the four-minute report of the decision to abolish the party's leading role and instead quoted Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders as defending socialism and the party. It was the first detailed report in the official media of the meeting. A Shanghai newspaper Monday ran a brief report without saying the party's leadership was in question. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jin Guihua, asked at a weekly briefing today about the Soviet decision and how it would affect Sino-Soviet relations, said only that ``this is the internal affair of the Soviet Union.'' China has taken a sharply divergent path, crushing its pro-democracy movement last spring and then launching a campaign against all dissent and criticism of the party. The People's Daily editorial said China without the party would mean turmoil and war, national division and suffering for the people. The whole nation has endorsed the ``correct leadership'' of the Communist Party, it said. Under the party, ``the Chinese people have been able to hold their heads high, withstand various invasions and pressure from imperialism and foreign forces, and safeguard the dignity of the motherland.'' ``Without the leadership of the Communist Party of China armed with Marxism, Leninism and Mao Tse-tung thought, you cannot begin to talk about building socialism in China,'' it said. The editorial concerned a party document released Wednesday urging greater cooperation with eight tiny and powerless ``democratic parties'' and promoting China's system of one-party rule with input from non-Communist parties and mass organizations. The ``elite'' who stirred up the ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' _ the official term for the pro-democracy movement of last spring _ sought to deprive the party of its leading role and establish Western-style parliamentary democracy, it said. ``Some people,'' it said, ``always think that the parliamentary democracy in the West is advantageous.'' But it claimed Western democracies were controlled by the rich and ``the broad masses of working people have never had the right to take part in the administration of state affairs. ... Those who have more money will have more freedom and have more right to talk in the democracy. Such democracy means nothing to those who do not have enough to eat.'' The editorial urged the party leadership to study the document released Wednesday, which said the democratic parties and non-Communists should get more legislative and bureaucratic positions and have a voice in policy-making. The party has a lock on all leadership positions and absolute power over policy, but the document said ``our democratic system still needs to be perfected'' and the party must listen to different opinions. The democratic parties now number about 300,000, with their ranks comprised mainly of leftist intellectuals from pre-1949 days, many now in their 80s. The Communist Party has 48 million members. All eight parties pledge allegiance to Communist Party rule, and no new parties have been recognized in the past four decades.

DOC.HEAD: Witness to Stuart Killing Alleges Police Coercion
DOC.TEXT: A woman questioned in the investigation of Carol Stuart's slaying says police offered her a vacation and relocation of her family to make her account conform to theirs, that a black man committed the crime. The Boston Globe today reported that Mary Smith said police also threatened to put her daughter in juvenile detention unless she said what they wanted to hear. ``They treated me like I was nobody,'' Smith said. ``They tried to put words in my mouth.'' Paul K. Leary, first assistant district attorney, said it would be inappropriate to comment on Smith's charges because allegations of police misconduct are being investigated by the attorney general. Charles Stuart told police a black mugger shot him and killed his pregnant wife Oct. 23 after the white couple left a childbirthing class. On Jan. 4, Stuart apparently jumped to his death after one of his brothers implicated him in the shootings. Before Stuart's death, Wiliam Bennett, a black man, was placed in a lineup and implicated in the slaying. Smith told the Globe that she saw Bennett on the night of the shooting with what looked like a silver gun. Stuart had described the assailant's weapon as a silver gun. Smith, 43, said police pressured her into making her description of the clothes worn by Bennett fit a description Stuart gave police of an assailant. The case raised racial tensions in Boston and called into question the fairness of the news media and the police. Smith is the fourth person to come forward and accuse police of misconduct in their investigation. Three teen-agers have said police coerced them into giving testimony. At one meeting, Smith said, police promised to make a deal with her if she would implicate Bennett and to re-locate her family to Springfield. ``They said if I don't answer any questions, they would put my daughter in juvenile detention,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES noun-verb agreement in lead of 2nd item.
DOC.TEXT: Michigan's House of Representatives digs the idea of an official state soil and has given the nod to sandy Kalkaska sod. House members voted 86-14 Wednesday to honor the Kalkaska soil. The bill now goes to the Senate, which approved a similar measure last April. ``I am very much aware of the fact that a lot of people might think that designating a state soil is somewhat trite, but I do think that it does serve a purpose. Without a state soil we wouldn't have a state tree, we wouldn't have a state bird, we wouldn't have anything,'' said Rep. Richard Sofio of Bessemer, the legislation's sponsor. Backers of the bill hope that Gov. James Blanchard will approve it on April 22 _ Earth Day.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Resigns; Police Wound Presidential Candidate
DOC.TEXT: The interior minister resigned and the president apologized after police wounded a presidential candidate with birdshot during a leftist campaign march in downtown Lima. Also wounded Wednesday were two congressional candidates, a supporter and one of presidential candidate Henry Pease's bodyguards. Pease, a candidate for the Marxist United Left coalition, said none was seriously hurt. President Alan Garcia accepted Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla's resignation and expressed his apologies over the shooting. The interior minister is in charge of the national police. In a letter to Garcia, Mantilla called the shooting ``without justification,'' and said it occurred when Mantilla was away from Lima on a trip to the central highlands. The Interior Ministry said one police commander had been fired and another suspended, and that it was investigating the police action. Witnesses to the shooting said the marchers tried to cross the Plaza de Armas, a large public square in front of the Government Palace that has been closed off by police for several months for security reasons. Police diverted the marchers down a side street, where the confrontation occurred. Police used tear gas, water cannons and shotguns loaded with birdshot to disperse the marchers. ``My indignation is not as a presidential candidate, but as any citizen who has suffered an abuse,'' Pease said today. ``What happened yesterday should not happen to any citizen. We are human beings, not cattle.'' He added that he considered the ``resignation of Minister Mantilla was necessary.'' The candidate favored to win the April 8 elections is novelist Mario Vargas Llosa of the center-right Democratic Front coalition. Trailing him in the polls are Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left coalition, Luis Alva Castro of the governing, center-left Aprista party, and Pease.

DOC.HEAD: Exodus From East Beirut As Christian Fighters Prepare For More Warfare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE number of deaths, casualties, new quotes. Pickup 9th graf, `A police...'
DOC.TEXT: Waves of civilians scurried out of embattled east Beirut to the city's western sector today during a relative lull in the battle by rival Christian forces for control of the country's Christian enclave. Police said the respite was used by Gen. Michel Aoun and Lebanese Forces militia chieftan Samir Geagea to add ammunition and weapons to areas under their control in devastated east Beirut and Kesrouan province. The 10-day fight for predominance in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north and northeast of Beirut has killed 373 people and wounded 1,680, by police count. Police said a lieutenant in Aoun's army was killed by a sniper's bullet in east Beirut's district of Dora today, and the St. Joseph Hospital said seven civilians wounded in the savage fighting earlier this week died. Civilians emerged from bomb shelters, and hospitals sought to replenish depleted stocks of food, fuel, water, oxygen, blood and medicines. At the museum crossing, the only open link between the mainly Christian and Moslem halves of Beirut, an exodus was under way. Hundreds of civilians emerged from the narrow alleys of the Ashrafiyeh district, scene of some of the heaviest fighting, and stumbled through the no-man's-land at the crossing. ``My life is more precious than my house,'' said George Bido, a 72-year-old grocer who left Ashrafiyeh with his wife, headed for Damascus via west Beirut. ``We collected rain water in canisters and drank it to remain alive,'' Mrs. Bido said, crying. ``I don't know if we'll ever come back.'' Other Christians flooded the gateway to purchase bread, vegetables, fruits and drinking water from dozens of Moslem vendors who parked their trucks nearby. ``I can't wait to get the bread to the family,'' said Youssef Hayek, a resident of Furn el-Shubbak. Aoun's soldiers, armed with U.S.-made, M-16 automatic rifles, did not interfere with civilians leaving Ashrafiyeh, but snipers halted traffic trying to enter Geagea's area of influence by shooting at them. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said Geagea's engineering units used rocks, cement and mines to block a 500-yard tunnel separating their positions from Aoun's lines at the Dog River valley north of Beirut. The tunnel is on the coastal highway linking the Aoun-held town of Dbaye with main bases of Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia in Kesrouan, Byblos and Batroun farther north. The move appears aimed at blocking Aoun's U.S.-made, M-48 tanks. Aoun has 20,000 army troops, but his force has been unable to quell Geagea's 6,000-member Lebanese Forces. In east Beirut, Geagea's men are entrenched in two isolated strongholds _ the western Ashrafiyeh-Karantina area next to Beirut port and Ein Rummaneh on the city's southeastern edge. Police reported sporadic sniper fire today. The police spokesman said Geagea's men were seen early in the day filling sand bags and planting additional anti-tank and anti-personnel mines along the southern slopes of the Ashrafiyeh district, which face Aoun's tanks. Both sides are believed to have enough weapons stockpiled to fight for months. The newspaper An-Nahar said the fighting might stop if Geagea accepts Aoun's offer to dismantle the militia and become a political party. Aoun told a news conference Wednesday that Geagea was trying to enforce implementation of an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the nation's 14-year-old civil war. The accord, worked out by Lebanese legislators in Taif, Saudi Arabia in October, was rejected by Aoun, appointed earlier last year to head an interim government by former President Amin Gemayel. Aoun has refused to recognize the Nov. 24 election of President Elias Hrawi to oversee implementaion of the pact. Geagea supports Hrawi but has not commented on the accord. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated political life in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Hrawi has hinted at requesting help from the Syrians, who support him, but their intervention would need advance international approval. On Tuesday, Hrawi appealed to Western nations, the Soviet Union, the United Nations and the Arab world for help in ending the fighting. The Syrian soldiers were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 to quell civil war fighting. Aoun says they violated their peacekeeping mandate by siding with the Moslems in the civil war. He has demanded that the Syrians leave the country. Last year, his forces fought artillery battles with them.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Death Threats Against Mandela Delaying His Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th graf, `Gerrit Viljoen...' to UPDATE with march in Port Elizabeth.
DOC.TEXT: Death threats against Nelson Mandela from left- and right-wing extremists are among the factors delaying the black leader's release from prison, a government minister said today. ``We want to ensure he walks out of that prison a free man and lives safely in this country as a free citizen,'' Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told a news conference. He also said the 3{-year-old state of emergency must be maintained to give police extra powers in dealing with unrest and preventing extremists from sabotaging President F.W. de Klerk's reforms. ``We would like to lift (the emergency) as soon as possible, but it's not possible now,'' Vlok said. Gerrit Viljoen, the Cabinet minister in charge of setting up negotiations with black leaders, said in an interview with the ABC news network in the United Sates that the emergency will last only a few more weeks, because the government realizes it is inhibiting normalization of the political process. In Port Elizabeth, South Africa's fifth-largest city, 50,000 to 80,000 blacks marched peacefully to a government education office to protest inadequacies in black education. A petition presented to education officials demanded the construction of new schools, reforms in university admission policies, and repeal of apartheid legislation. The Rev. Allan Boesak, a top anti-apartheid leader, said today that the 71-year-old Mandela must be released very soon or people will start questioning the government's commitment to end white minority rule. ``If the release of Mr. Mandela is not a fact within the next week or two ... the world will start to question if Mr. de Klerk is really serious,'' he told The Associated Press in an interview. The government appears to be dithering over a release date because it still hopes to persuade Mandela to take a less critical position once he is released, the clergyman said. Without giving details, Vlok said Mandela had been threatened by right-wing extremists and by hard-liners within leftist black groups unhappy over his attempts to negotiate with the white minority government. He said some of the threats were several years old. There had always been right-wing threats against Mandela, but now, Vlok said, police had received intelligence reports that Mandela was at risk from elements within his own organization, the African National Congress. The ANC has rejected such accusations by Vlok in the past. De Klerk announced major reforms Feb. 2 to try and start talks on ending white minority rule and bringing blacks into the political process. He legalized the ANC and other anti-apartheid grops and promised to free Mandela soon, but lifted only certain sections of the state of emergency. Mandela wants an immediate end to the state of emergency and the release of all political prisoners before he leaves prison, or he will question the government's commitment to reform when he is free, Boesak said. Boesak said Mandela was not delaying his release and the question of when he is freed is entirely up to the government. ``He is a prisoner of the South African government,'' Boesak said. Vlok said some elements of the state of emergency must be kept to guard against the ``higher revolutionary climate'' now facing South Africa. He specifically mentioned the need to retain regulations giving the police powers of mass arrest and mass detention, but said they would only be used in extreme circumstances. The minister said the police were fully committed to de Klerk's plans and rejected opposition Conservative Party claims that the security forces opposed sharing power with blacks and are turning against the government. Another demand of the ANC _ as a condition for possible negotiations with the government _ is the removal of army units from black townships. Deputy Defense Minister Wynand Breytenbach told journalists there were less than 800 troops assigned to black residential areas at present. These units acted only in support of police, and in some cases were welcomed by residents as a help in reducing black factional violence, Breytenbach said.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Slay Two Policemen in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants seeking independence for the Kashmir valley shot and killed two paramilitary policemen today while they were shopping for groceries in a suburb of Srinagar, the government said. Witnesses to the shooting, however, said they saw three bodies being carried away after the incident. They said the policemen were buying vegetables when they were gunned down in bursts of automatic rifle fire. The shopkeeper and a bystander were injured, they said. A government statement said two policemen of the paramilitary Border Security Force were killed and a civilian injured in the Chanpora suburb of the city by Moslem militants. The deaths raise to 81 the number of people killed in confrontations between security forces and the militants since the government launched a crackdown Jan. 20 on the Moslem movement for secession of Kashmir from India, where Hindus are in the majority. The witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said police immediately imposed a curfew in Chanpora and launched search operations for the assailants. It was not immediately known how many people were involved in the attack. Meanwhile, Jammu-Kashmir state Gov. Jagmohan appealed for peace in the valley and called on the militants to give up their campaign. ``Let us impress once again on our young brothers to see the futility of the cult of guns and understand the magnitude of all-round misery that it has caused,'' he said in a letter released by the state government. ``Let us assure them that if they abandon the path of violence, we would treat them with care and compassion,'' he said. The letter was written by Jagmohan, who uses only one name, to the father of a Moslem youth who was killed in a bomb explosion in a shopping complex on Wednesday. Kashmir, once a princely state, was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned upon becoming independent from Britain in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only state in India with a Moslem majority. A western slice of Kashmir is controlled by Pakistan along a cease-fire line where Indian and Pakistani troops face each other, sometimes at distances of only a few hundred yards. The two countries have gone to war three times, twice over Kashmir. India accuses Pakistan of fomenting the current trouble in Kashmir, a charge Pakistan routinely denies. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, but they make up only 65 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Proposes Deep Cuts in U.S.-Soviet Troops
DOC.TEXT: NATO today presented to Warsaw Pact negotiators President Bush's proposal to cut the number of American and Soviet troops stationed in central Europe to 195,000 for each side. Under revised proposals approved in Brussels two days ago, the Western alliance also called for each side to be limited to 4,700 combat aircraft within the area, plus 500 ``air defense interceptors.'' The Western proposals are expected to speed up the negotiations on conventional armed forces in Europe. Negotiators for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven Warsaw Pact countries are under pressure to reach an agreement by the end of the year. ``The 16 Western participants believe that the ... negotiations must keep pace with the political changes now sweeping the European continent,'' said a NATO statement presented to reporters by the Danish delegation to the talks. ``One area where this is most relevant is manpower.'' It said the 16 nations had reviewed their positions and now feel it is appropriate to lower the Western-proposed ceiling for U.S. and Soviet stationed manpower. ``To that end, we now propose that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union shall station more than 195,000 ground and air force personnel each within the area comprising the territory of Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Poland,'' the statement said. The troops removed should be demobilized, the statement added. West German Ambassador Ruediger Hartmann made clear that French, British and other troops stationed in the central European zone would be unaffected by such an accord. Under the Bush plan, proposed during his State of the Union address, the United States would maintain an overall limit of 225,000 soldiers in Europe, including forces in Britain and southern Europe. In May, Bush suggested an overall ceiling of 275,000 troops for both sides. The Soviet Union has about 565,000 troops stationed in Europe outside its national territory, more than 500,000 of them in the central zone. The United States has 305,000 troops in Western Europe, with 250,000 in the central zone. Hungary and Czechoslovakia have begun talks with the Soviets separate from the Vienna negotiations on removing Red Army contingents stationed on their soil for decades. Czechoslovakia wants all the 75,000 or so Soviet troops out by the end of this year. The Hungarians want the 50,000 Soviet soldiers to leave before the end of next year. The Soviets have signaled readiness to pull back their troops, but they reportedly argue they need more time to accommodate the manpower back home.

DOC.HEAD: Classmates Mourn Death of Girl With Lung Implant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to ADD that girl had given birth one month earlier; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `Those closest ...'; DELETES next-to-last graf to confomr.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN4
With PM-Lung Implant, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some couldn't find the words to tell how they are going to miss Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey, but a few at a North Lamar high school did. One of her classmates at Frank Stone High School wrote two poems after learning of her death Wednesday. The news that their classmate _ the world's first recipient of a lung implant device _ had died Wednesday at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City stunned students and faculty. Students copied poems and passed them around as they groped for consolation and understanding. ``Each of us in turn have been touched,'' one poem read. ``All of us have been treated as a best friend.'' Mimi had given birth to a son, Trenell, on Jan. 6, a month before the lung operation. Mimi's 41-year-old mother, Edith Harvey, died Jan. 31, seven days before her daughter, of what officials said were diabetes-related causes. ``It's good that she left the baby behind because that's like she's leaving behind the best part of herself,'' said one of Mimi's friends, Carolyn Hawkins. Those closest to her said Mimi added a spark to any place she went. She was vice president of the student council and played flute in the band. ``She had a great sense of humor and she had a contagious laugh,'' said Krissy Hicks, who was on the drill team with her. ``She was always telling these weird jokes that nobody understood.'' Another friend, Kathleen Norris, said Mimi was always willing to help other girls on the drill team, especially the younger ones. ``I didn't think of her just as a friend, because we all are family,'' she said. And now those who felt they were Melicia's family say they are going to chip in to help her relatives pay for her burial expenses. School officials have authorized a fund-raising ``Mimi Harvey Day'' on Friday. Eight ministers came to the school Wednesday to counsel students after word arrived of her death. Many of the school's 735 students wept unabashedly after being told she had succumbed to pneumonia despite the device that was allowing her injured lungs to rest and recover. ``We all knew of her condition, but the last thing we heard this morning was that everything was going fine,'' said Principal Tony Daugherty. ``Boy, when (news of her death) hit this morning, these kids went nuts.'' Mimi's father, Atrell Harvey II, works for the Campbell Soup Co.

DOC.HEAD: Nagasaki Officials Want Retraction of `Satanic Verses' Dedication
DOC.TEXT: Nagasaki city officials today demanded the retraction of the Japanese-language version of ``The Satanic Verses,'' which they say was dedicated to Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima without his permission. The dedication to the outspoken mayor, who was shot in the back last month by a right-wing terrorist, has ``caused us great trouble, and was done without our permission,'' a City Hall official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said a complaint in Motoshima's name had been sent to Gianna Palma, who is promoting the book in Japan. The Japanese edition will be published by Shinsensha. The mayor, still in the hospital, first learned of the dedication when he received a phone call from the Iranian Embassy, the official said. He said Palma had apologized, but added that the dedication already has been printed in the Japanese translations, which are to go on sale Saturday. Palma could not immediately be reached for comment. After Motoshima was shot Jan. 18, police said the rightist confessed to attacking the mayor because of remarks he made suggesting the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II.
