Motoshima faced death threats from rightists for more than a year after he suggested in December 1988 that Hirohito could have ended the war sooner and spared Nagasaki from the atomic bomb dropped by the United States on Aug. 9, 1945. Hirohito died of cancer on Jan. 7, 1989. The official said the dedication praised Motoshima for his courage in defending freedom of speech. Moslems claim depictions of the prophet Mohammed and his wives in ``The Satanic Verses,'' written by British author Salman Rushdie, blaspheme their religion. Rushdie went into hiding one year ago, after the late Iranian leader Ayatollah Khomeini called on him to recant or be killed by Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Lukanov Presents New Government, Minus Opposition Figures
DOC.TEXT: Premier Andrei Lukanov today presented to Parliament his new government packed with Communist academics, but he failed to persuade any members of the democratic opposition to join it. The previous government of Premier Georgi Atanasov, a holdover from the rule of ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, unexpectedly resigned Feb. 1 during the extraordinary congress of the ruling Communist Party, where Atanasov was accused of economic mismanagement and other shortcomings. ``This will be a government of national interest, which is ready to cooperate with all political forces,'' Lukanov told the National Assembly, according to Bulgarian state radio. The Communists had called for a ``government of national concord'' comprising representatives ``from all social forces'' in this Balkan country of 9 million people. But after the opposition Union of Democratic Forces repeatedly rejected the Communist Party's offer to participate in the new government, the Agrarian Party, until recently a docile ally of the Communists, said Wednesday it would no longer be part of a Communist-dominated Cabinet. That left Lukanov little choice in selecting new ministers. It was not immediately clear from the list of ministers if any of them were non-Communists. But the government, as presented to the National Assembly, did not include any known members of the Union of Democratic Forces or the Agrarian Party. Lukanov, a multilingual economist with years of diplomatic experience, was widely considered the best choice as head of government at a time of political and economic crisis. He was unanimously elected premier at a session of Parliament on Saturday, when he promised to submit an ``anti-crisis'' program to revamp the national economy on Feb. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Crash Kills 17 in Ethiopia, Including Soviet General
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter crashed in eastern Ethiopia, killing all 17 people aboard, including a Soviet general, two Ethiopian generals and four Ethiopian lawmakers, the state-run news agency said today. The helicopter slammed into the side of Gudo Bella mountain between Dire Dawa and Harrar on Wednesday, the report said. The cause of the crash was being investigated. The victims included Maj. Gen. Alexander Simonoff, a Soviet military adviser to the Ethiopian government, and his interpreter. The crash also killed Maj. Gen. Berhanu Jembere, commander of the first army in the Ogaden; Brig. Gen. Gebreyes Wolde-Hana, secretary of the governing party in eastern Harrar; Col. Kejela Gemeda, the police commander in the region; Col. Yimam Mohammed, first army operations officer; and Fikre-Mariam Asfaw, the security chief in the region. Other victims included the helicopter's crew of four, two low-ranking police officers, and four members of the regional legislature, all Ethiopians.

DOC.HEAD: Rooney, CBS to Discuss Alleged Racist Statements
DOC.TEXT: CBS called TV humorist Andy Rooney on the carpet today to explain racist remarks attributed to him in a gay magazine. Rooney, who earlier drew criticism from homosexual and lesbian groups for remarks he made in a December TV special, ``A Year With Andy Rooney: 1989,'' denied making the comments contained in an article in The Advocate. The Los Angeles-based magazine quoted Rooney as saying that ``most people are born with equal intelligence, but blacks have watered down their genes because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children.'' ``They drop out of school early, do drugs and get pregnant,'' Rooney was quoted as saying. CBS spokesman Roy Brunett said today, ``We're very concerned. Andy Rooney denies saying this, and we're planning to talk to him today. Until we meet him, we won't have anything further to say on this matter.'' ``I wouldn't be surprised if I got fired,'' Rooney told the New York Daily News on Wednesday night. But he denied making the remarks attributed to him in what he says was a conversation with the article's author, Chris Bull. Brunett said the conversation was by phone. Bull said Wednesday that the quotations were accurate. He said he had not tape-recorded the conversation, which took place several weeks ago, but took notes. ``I gave him ample opportunity immediately after he made those remarks,'' Bull said. ``I said I thought they amounted to racism. He didn't respond. He just went to another topic.'' The Advocate is a national magazine that publishes articles of interest to homosexuals. Bull said he requested the interview after learning that in December Rooney had made remarks that offended many gay people. He referred to Rooney's CBS special, in which the 69-year-old humorist said ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced,'' and then cited ``too much alcohol, too much food, homosexual unions, cigarettes.'' After gay groups protested, CBS executives met with representatives of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation to hear their concerns. In an interview Wednesday in the Washington Post, Rooney said that in hindsight he believed he should have said ``unsafe sex.'' He also denied making the remarks attributed to him in The Advocate, and in his interview with the News said he had told that magazine's writer that people with less education tend to have children who also tend to be undereducated. He said that while that tends to be true of blacks, he did not believe it was a factor of race. ``Anyone who knows me knows I'm not racist,'' he said. Benjamin Hooks, director of the NAACP, described Rooney's reported remarks to the magazine as ``ill-informed and racist.'' Mayor David Dinkins, who is black, called CBS to ``register shock,'' according to a spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Publicists Helping Mandela's Family
DOC.TEXT: Oprah Winfrey has arranged to fly members of Nelson Mandela's family to South Africa to witness the black activist's release from prison. ``This is history in the making,'' said Armstrong Williams, a vice president of B&C Associates, a High Point public relations firm, who is making his fourth trip to South Africa on business involving the Mandelas. South African President F.W. de Klerk announced Feb. 2 that Mandela would be released soon under reforms he has proposed to scale back apartheid. Mandela's family is awaiting word from Winnie Mandela, who visits her husband in prison this weekend, on when Mandela wants his children and grandchildren to arrive. Mandela wants to avoid ``his children sitting around idle for three or four days while they wait for him to be released,'' Williams said. Zenani Mandela, her husband, Prince Thumbumuzi Dlamini of Swaziland, and their three children will be escorted from Boston, where they live, to Paarl, South Africa, early next week by B&C executives Williams and Steadman Graham. Williams said Ms. Winfrey is paying the Mandelas' air fare. The talk show host's foundation, Oprah Winfrey Charitable Giving, is represented by a B&C subsidiary founded by Williams and Graham, who is Ms. Winfrey's boyfriend. The Mandela family will witness the end of Mandela's 27-year imprisonment for protesting the government's policies of apartheid, or racial segregation. Mandela, 71, was imprisoned in 1962 for protesting apartheid and in 1964 received a life sentence for treason. He is a leader of the African National Congress, which has waged a battle to bring down South Africa's white-minority government. The Mandelas have another daughter, Zindziswa, 29, who lives in Soweto.

DOC.HEAD: 9 Killed, 58 Feared Trapped in Mine Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE number of deaths, miners trapped, ventilation turned off, new quotes accusing government of neglecting safety; Picks up 7th graf, `The mine ...'
DOC.TEXT: An explosion in a mine in northern Turkey started a fire and pumped dense smoke through the tunnels, killing nine miners and trapping 58 nearly 1,000 feet underground, officials said today. There was ``no chance for the survival of those trapped'' in the explosion Wednesday night, State Minister Mehmet Yazar told reporters. The fire and spreading smoke made rescue impossible. All ventilation channels to the mine were closed to cut off air feeding the blaze, he said. Union officials blamed the accident on lax enforcement of safety standards. Crews recovered eight bodies from the mine more than 900 feet underground and one of two rescued miners later died of severe burns, said Ekrem Sami, secretary general of Maden-Is, the mineworkers union. ``It is also the end for all trapped down there, which is an inferno,'' Sami said. The tragedy began with a small fire at the Yeniceltik coal mine, in the township of Merzifon, 240 miles northeast of Ankara near the Black Sea coast. The fire set off an explosion of pit gas, largely made of methane, Sami said. The explosion in turn ignited a giant blaze. ``Tons of coal are burning there now, there is little that can be done,'' he said. Gas was smelled before the explosion, but there was not enough time for the miners to escape, he said. Sevket Yilmaz, president of Turk-Is, Turkey's largest labor union confederation, told reporters at the site: ``This is no work accident, this is murder because of neglect of safety standards.'' The semi-official Anatolia News Agency reported that this was the fourth accident in the history of the Yeniceltik mine, owned by the municipality of Merzifon and the state-owned Sugar Company. A similar explosion in 1965 killed 72 miners. In 1983, an explosion in the northern province of Zonguldak killed 102 miners. ``The state sector and the private sector are equally guilty of negligence. In all coal mines in Turkey, the conditions are primitive,'' Sami alleged. The mine accident came a day after the Labor Ministry published a report deploring the inadequacy of safety standards in coal mines in northern Turkey. The report was prepared during the course of the investigation of 26 deaths and 7,433 injuries in the pits last year. The report criticized the mines for not having fireproof uniforms or artificial breathing apparatus.

DOC.HEAD: British, French and Americans Win Japan Prize
DOC.TEXT: An American scientist known as the ``father of artificial intelligence'' and three geologists who developed the theory that the Earth's crust consists of rigid plates have won the 1990 Japan Prizes, the prize committee said today. Professor Marvin Lee Minsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will receive one of the two prizes, each worth $345,000, for developing and popularizing the concept of artificial intelligence _ or computers that reason like the human brain, the Science and Technology Foundation of Japan said. The other prize will be shared by professors William Jason Morgan of Princeton University, Dan Peter McKenzie of Britain's Cambridge University and Xavier Le Pichon of France's Ecole Normale Superieure for their work on the theory of tectonic plates. Each year the prizes are awarded in two different areas of science and technology, with this year's awards given in the fields of Earth science and the techology of integration. According to plate tectonics, the Earth's crust is made up of about 20 rigid plates that grind against each other with a velocity of several inches a year, causing earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and the formation of ridges and mountains. ``The plate theory has been used widely to study earthquakes in Japan,'' said professor Toshi Asada of Tokai University, chairman of the Earth science selection panel. ``Plate tectonics is still very useful, which is why we have awarded the prize in this area.'' Morgan first presented the plate theory in 1967, the committee said. McKenzie applied the theory to the Pacific region, showing that the ocean floor moves as one gigantic plate, while Le Pichon studied plate movement in other parts of the world, it said. The non-profit prize foundation, formed under the direction of the prime minister's office, began with a $172 million grant from Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. and the company's founder, the late Konosuke Matsushita. Since the prize began in 1985, 19 scientists in 12 fields have received awards. This year's winners are to receive their prizes in Tokyo on April 17. They were selected from among 662 people nominated by scientists and academics in Japan and around the world, the foundation said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Official Gets Rough Reception on China from House Panel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new with House committee hearing; picks up 2nd graf pvs, If there are.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A top administration official got a rough reception today as he defended the White House's China policy before a House committee, with one lawmaker saying it was ``lacking in credibility.'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger described Bush's efforts as the most likely route to long-term moderation of the Beijing regime. But the message wasn't selling well among either Democrats or Republicans. ``I think there was a tone deafness toward the values and ideals this country stands for'' in the administration's contacts with China since last June's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, said Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. ``The president has isolated himself in Congress and with the American people with a policy virtually lacking in credibility,'' said Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn. The chairman of the panel's Asia subcommittee, Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., called Eagleburger's December mission to Beijing with National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft ``one of the most misbegotten missions in contemporary American diplomacy.'' Eagleburger repeated testimony delivered a day earlier before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in which he argued that hopes for change in China rest with reformers in the country's leadership rather than the masses who demonstrated in and around Tiananmen Square. ``If there are to be changes ... they will depend in large measure for some time to come on the attitudes and activities of people within the leadership'' who believe in reform, Eagleburger told the Senate committee. ``The process of reform in China so far has been largely led from the top,'' Eagleburger added, asking for patience from lawmakers to give Bush's efforts time to bear fruit. ``The policy we are following is not one which will lead to a rapid payoff,'' Eagleburger told the senators. ``This is a long-haul situation.'' In repeated votes, Congress has rejected Bush's policy toward China as insufficiently sensitive to human rights concerns. High on the list of members' objections are two clandestine trips Eagleburger made to Beijing last year with National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft following the June 4 massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators. Many in Congress believe the administration has been too cozy with the Chinese government since the killings, and that a confidential State Department report that catalogs widespread human rights violations in China underscores their position. Referring to Bush's closeness to Chinese leaders as a former ambassador to Beijing, Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said: ``I think the president has a lingering case of clientitis,'' the affliction of diplomats who represent their host country's views more strongly than those of their own country. Humphrey also said he hoped Bush would not view the Senate's narrow vote to uphold his veto of a Chinese students' immigration bill last month as a vote of confidence in his policies. Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said Bush's opponents have no desire to ``isolate'' China, but added: ``The choice with China is not between isolation and normal relations. The choice is between good policy and bad policy.'' Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., asked whether the U.S. action might signal to the Soviet Union that it could brutally repress a pro-democracy movement in one of the Baltic states without incurring a severe U.S. response. ``I do not think that anyone should draw any conclusion that U.S. policy toward China after Tiananmen Square applies to any other case,'' Eagleburger responded. ``It is country-specific.'' Answering charges that the administration has quickly dropped many of the limited trade sanctions it imposed following the Tiananmen Square crackdown, Eagleburger said, ``the Chinese certainly don't think it's business as usual.'' Stronger sanctions, he said, would only strengthen those in the Beijing government ``who would like nothing more ... than to go back behind their wall and live as they have so many times in the past.'' Steps the administration has taken, such as allowing the shipment of U.S.-made satellites for launch on Chinese rockets and limited loans from multilateral banks, have come in response to moderating moves in China, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arms Cuts Prospects Appear to Brighten
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with report thatiet, 4th Ld-Writ talks covering more than non-nuclear arsenals; picks up 5th graf pvs, Speaking of ..., DELETING now redundant 11th graf pvs, Soviet Deputy...
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Schevardnadze for a second day today and the Soviet official reported ``some movement'' in their negotiations over weapons arsenals. Shevardnadze also said the steps taken by the Communist Party Central Committee to abolish the party's monopoly on political power would improve U.S-Soviet relations further. ``It will mean we have more elements of trust in our relationship,'' he said. The official Soviet news agency Tass quoing about 400,000 Soviet and 100,000 American soldiers under a treaty the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact are deliberating in Vienna negotiations. Baker and Shevardnadze seemed to be in an upbeat mood as they held a second round of talks at the Soviet foreign ministry. They were joined at a long negotiating table by more than a dozen aides. Baker's strategy, meanwhile, is to pursue his heavy agenda irrespective of internal Soviet developments, which he hailed in a statement Wednesday night as contributing to reform and to political pluralism. Today's meeting with Shevardnadze was expected to produce a Soviet response to Bush's troop reduction initiative. ``Overall, our response is positive, and we will discuss the details,'' Shevardnadze said. He said Baker's supplementary proposal on tanks and combat aircraft had ``some interesting elements.'' On another issue _ German unification _ Shevardnadze again referred to Soviet concerns that are rooted in the loss of 20 million people in World War II. He said they would be aired when West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher come here Saturday for talks. Shevardnadze has proposed an international referendum on the issue, while Baker has found merit in a formula advanced last week by Genscher that would keep Germany in NATO but bar Western forces from the area that is now East Germany. ``There are some elements there that deserve consideration,'' Shevardnadze said of Genscher's formula. But referring to underlying Soviet concerns, Shevardnadze added: ``Those issues will have to be addressed.'' Baker and the Soviet foreign minister exchanged some preliminary thoughts on Germany at their three-hour meeting Wednesday night. Overall, Shevardnadze said, ``It was a good, substantiative and very productive conversation on many questions.'' Baker confirmed he had presented ``some new ideas'' to reduce weapons, and said he expected a reply from Shevardnadze on Bush's proposal for troop cuts. Initially, Bush proposed ceilings of 275,000 for the United States and the Soviet Union in Europe. Prodded by more dramatic disarmament calls by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last year, Bush improved his own proposal of last June. As Baker arrived in Moscow, the Central Committee, the Soviet Communist Party's policy-making body, was concluding a historic meeting at which it endorsed Gorbachev's call for an end to the party's constitutional monopoly on power. ``This is clearly a time of great change in the Soviet Union,'' Baker said in a statement. ``They are making efforts to reform both their economic and political processes and they are emphasizing the importance of the introduction of pluralism into their political system.'' Bush, meanwhile, speaking to an audience in Omaha, Nebraska, on Wednesday refrained from passing judgment on the moves by Soviet communist leaders. ``I'm not here to anoint or try to shape the deliberations of the Central Committee proceedings in the Soviet Union,'' said Bush. But Bush reiterated his admiration for Gorbachev and his reforms, saying, ``He has handled some extraordinarily complicated internal problems ... with a certain restraint and finesse that I think demonstrates a real commitment to peaceful change.'' Baker planned a four-day stay in the Soviet capital. A meeting with Gorbachev scheduled for Friday is the anticipated climax of what was designed initially as a trip to prepare for the June summit, but has now grown into a far more important U.S.-Soviet exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Politician Gunned Down Outside Home After Cith Hall Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The deputy mayor of this port city was shot to death early today as he arrived home after a late-night City Council meeting, police said. Giovanni Trecroce, a school teacher who also served in the city hall post as a Christian Democrat, had just gotten out of his car in the nearby seaside hamlet of Cannitello, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. State television reported that Trecroce was shot twice in the head with a weapon possibly equipped with a silencer because no one reported hearing gunfire. His family told police it knew of no threats to his life and investigators were focusing on Trecroce's role as public works commissioner. Villa San Giovanni, whose ferries transport cars and trucks from the mainland across the Strait of Messina to Sicily, has been the site of several killings in recent years linked to the 'ndrangheta, the Calabrian version of the Sicilian Mafia. Several organized crime clans are believed engaged in blood feuds over drug-dealing and control of lucrative government contracts in underdeveloped Calabria, the ``toe'' of the Italian boot. Although the killing was not immediately blamed on organized crime, Trecroce's slaying was carried out in common gangland style.

DOC.HEAD: Quarreling Gotti Jurors Resume Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with deliberations resuming; PICKS UP 14th graf pvs, `Gotti's attorney ...'
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the assault trial of reputed mob boss John Gotti scolded the jury after learning members of the panel were bickering. Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin cut short the jury's deliberations Wednesday after a juror wrote a note complaining that one member of the panel had decided Gotti's guilt or innocence before the trial ever started. Gotti, known as the Dapper Don because of his expensive double-breasted suits, is accused of ordering a union leader shot in 1986. He is reputed to be boss of the Gambino mob family, the nation's most powerful criminal organization. ``I wouldn't know what's going on in there but questioning somebody's lineage or intelligence is not the way to come to grips'' with the problem, the judge said to the anonymous jury after they sent out a note Wednesday evening. ``Jury service is a give and take, as gently as possible. It's not a contest to see who can get in the most cutting, triumphant gibe at the end.'' The judge added: ``Jury duty is not only a sacrifice of time and money. Sometimes you have to sacrifice the opportunity to show how smart you are or how sharp you are.'' Defense attorneys immediately requested a mistrial because of the disagreements in the jury, but McLaughlin denied the motion. Deliberations resumed this morning. After the sequestered jury left the courtroom Wednesday, the judge read the note. It said: ``I feel we have a juror who has brought a previous bias into this room. Please advise. This juror has indicated he had some opinion on guilt or innocence before the trial started.'' The jury is deliberating assault and conspiracy charges against Gotti, 49, and Anthony Guerrieri, 61. They are accused of commissioning a gang to shoot John F. O'Connor, former vice president of a Carpenters Union local, in 1986. He was wounded in the buttocks. Prosecutors said Gotti arranged the shooting because O'Connor ordered thugs to trash a mob-run restaurant that was being built with non-union labor. Gotti's attorney, Bruce Cutler, didn't think the disagreements among the jury members were unusual. ``It's the nature of the system. We think we're in good shape,'' Cutler said. Guerrieri's attorney, Gerald Shargel, said he found no fault in the judge's action regarding the note. If convicted, Gotti could face 25 years to life in prison as a persistent felon because of convictions in 1969 and 1974. Cutler and Shargel contend Gotti is being persecuted because of his reputation.

DOC.HEAD: Recipient Dies, But Experiment to Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT to son, sted daughter; SUBS 8th graf, `Word of ...', to CORRECT school name to Frank Stone High School sted North Lamar.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN4
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl died four days after becoming the world's first recipient of an experimental lung device, leaving behind a newborn son and a grieving hometown but hope that similar implants will save lives. Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, who suffered from respiratory distress syndrome, died Wednesday of pulmonary failure, said Tim Madden, spokesman at LDS Hospital. Mimi had received an IntraVascular Oxygenator, or IVOX, in a two-hour operation Friday. The device, which works like a lung, is a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes as fine as human hair, with walls so thin that oxygen and carbon dioxide can pass through. ``There were no clinical complications from the use of the device,'' Madden said. LDS and three other medical centers have federal approval to implant the device in up to 10 patients, and Dr. J.D. Mortensen, chief developer of the IVOX for CardioPulmonics Inc. of Salt Lake City, said the implants will continue. `It will take a long time to review the mountain of data we gathered with this case. From what we know with this case, it was extremely successful,'' Mortensen said. Nevertheless, he said nine of the 10 patients who will receive the device are expected to die. Word of Mimi's death stunned classmates at Frank Stone High School in Paris, Texas. A month before Mimi died, she gave birth to a son, Trenell. Mimi's mother, Edith Harvey, 41, died Jan. 31 of diabetes-related causes. Many of the school's 735 students, who included the girl's sister and brother, wept, and eight ministers went to the school to counsel students. ``It's good that she left the baby behind because that's like she's leaving behind the best part of herself,'' said one of Mimi's friends, Carolyn Hawkins. Those closest to her said Mimi added a spark to any place she went. She was vice president of the student council and played flute in the band. ``She had a great sense of humor and she had a contagious laugh,'' said Krissy Hicks, who was on the drill team with her. ``She was always telling these weird jokes that nobody understood.'' School officials authorized a fund-raising ``Mimi Harvey Day'' on Friday to help pay burial expenses. The girl's identity and details of her condition had been kept private at her family's request until a Texas newspaper identified her and her father, Atrell Harvey II, an employee of the Campbell Soup Co. With the family's permission, Madden confirmed her identity Wednesday. The disease Mimi suffered from has a variety of causes and is characterized by an inability of the lungs to transfer oxygen to the blood. In its most severe forms it is fatal in 90-95 percent of all cases, Madden said. The IVOX, designed to give damaged lungs time to rest and recover, is inserted via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the bundle of tubes and lead out of the body. One delivers oxygen to the blood; the other removes carbon dioxide. The Food and Drug Administration approved IVOX in September for temporary implantation in up to 10 people at LDS, Penn State University's Hershey Medical Center, the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor and the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center. Before Mimi died, it was unclear how long doctors intended to leave the device inside her. Madden had said any use beyond the seven days would require FDA permission. Mortensen said further implants will involve only patients with acute lung diseases, not chronic disorders such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema. ``We're just waiting for the right case, at any one of the centers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Anthony Quinn Undergoes Heart Operation
DOC.TEXT: Oscar-winning actor Anthony Quinn underwent coronary bypass surgery today. The 74-year-old actor entered Mount Sinai Hospital on Wednesday and the operation began at 9 a.m., said Kathy Benvin, his assistant. ``The doctors think he'll come out of it very well because he's in very good health,'' she said. She said Quinn had undergone tests after suffering chest pains a few weeks ago. Quinn won Academy Awards for best supporting actor in ``Viva Zapata!'' and ``Lust for Life.'' He also appeared in ``Zorba the Greek'' and ``Lawrence of Arabia'' and in recent years has toured in the musical ``Zorba.''

DOC.HEAD: Acting Chief Worries About Runaway Shelter's Future
DOC.TEXT: The sexual misconduct allegations against the founder of Covenant House, the nation's biggest shelter for runaways, has the organization's new chief worried that the children will be abandoned again. Frank Macchiarola, a former chancellor of city schools, replaced the Rev. Bruce Ritter on Wednesday, saying he was sure allegations of sexual misconduct against the Roman Catholic priest were false but took their toll nevertheless. ``We're all sad,'' Macchiarola said. ``This is not an easy time for us.'' His chief task, he said, is to convince the public that the shelter's mission must not be abandoned. Today, full-page advertisements for Covenant House appeared in New York Newsday and the Daily News, urging contributors to continue supporting its work. The ad does not mention Ritter or the controversy. ``We need help. There's no question about that. There is a sense in the organization of loss, of hurt, of feeling that if this doesn't go right for them they will be abandoned once more,'' Macchiarola said. ``Basically, our rules are sound but all of this is going to force us to be careful again and to look again at the things we've done.'' Macchiarola, 48, took over for Ritter because four past residents of Covenant House have said Ritter had sex with them when they were distressed teen-agers. The church is investigating at least some of the allegations. ``In Covenant House, we of necessity must do things that are at risk,'' Macchiarola said. ``A more conventional approach to that would mean that we would close the door. Covenant House goes out into the street on youngsters. ... We don't wait for them to come to us.'' Ritter was told Tuesday to step down as director of Covenant House, which has become the nation's largest shelter program for runaway youngsters since he began it in 1968 with two abandoned tenements in New YORK City. WABC-TV reported Wednesday that a total of seven individuals had filed complaints with authorities. The district attorney's office would not comment on the report. Ritter, 62, has characterized as ``garbage'' accusations by four men that he carried on sexual relationships after they came to Covenant House for help. Macchiarola said the Covenant House board, of which he is a member, has never discussed the possibility that Ritter would not return. The New York Post said Wednesday that Ritter's fourth accuser, Paul Johnson, 33, came forward after it reported Dec. 12 on allegations against the priest by an ex-prostitute, Kevin Kite. Kite, whose allegations against Ritter were the first to be made public, accused him of giving money, housing and gifts in exchange for sex. Franciscan church officials said they were investigating Ritter, and the district attorney's office was looking into Covenant House's use of funds and its giving false identification to at least one youth. Macchiarola acknowledged that donations had decreased since the controversy began. ``We're not doing as well as we would have done had this not happened,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Tear Gas Against Black Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th pvs, `Several journalists...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with police claiming journalists aided protesters. Pickup 8th, `Moss Mashishi...'
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas today to disperse about 2,000 blacks who tried to protest an English cricket team touring the country in violation of an international sports boycott of South Africa. At least six people were arrested, police said. Later, riot police with batons broke up a second protest by about 100 black youths outside a downtown office building housing the British Consulate. The protesters were chased through the streets, even though a British diplomat had asked police to let them stay. The first confrontation occurred when police ordered demonstrators to disembark after they had boarded mini-bus taxis that were to take them from the black township of Alexandra to the nearby Wanderers stadium, where the Englishmen began a five-day test match against South Africa's national team. A judge had refused to grant a permit for a protest outside the stadium. According to police, the crowd ``dispersed peacefully'' after tear gas was used. A local anti-apartheid group, the Alexandra Civic Organization, claimed some protesters were beaten and said the township was in chaos. Police said six activists from Alexandra were arrested on suspicion of stealing vehicles to take protesters to the stadium. Police said eight journalists covering the confrontation were briefly detained at a local police station when they refused to obey an order to leave the area. Police claimed some journalists were providing transportation to protesters trying to get to the stadium. Moss Mashishi, a protest organizer, claimed 30 people were injured. He said police had set up roadblocks at exits from Alexandra and were searching outgoing cars. A few hours later, about 100 black youths, some carrying flags of the African National Congress geurrilla movement, gathered at a pedestrian mall outside the the British Consulate. Riot police allowed the youths to remain for about an hour, then declared the gathering illegal and chased some of the protesters along the mall and into the streets. On Wednesday, a magistrate rejected an application by protest organizers to hold a demonstration at the stadium, saying there was no appropriate space for a protest. Scores of protesters nonetheless reached the stadium today but were moved away by police after chanting slogans denouncing the English players. Capt. Eugene Opperman, a police spokesman, said officers warned the blacks who had boarded the minibuses in Alexandra that their protest would be illegal. ``When they disembarked from the buses, they started singing and dancing'' and refused to disperse until the tear gas was used, Opperman said. At the Wanderers stadium, located in a wealthy residential area, a newly formed organization called Freedom in Sport bought tickets for scores of blacks to watch the opening of the five-day match, the first international competition for South Africa's national team in three years. Ahmed Mangera, one of the leaders of the campaign against the tour, said a group of black spectators knew nothing about cricket and were being paid to attend. The members of the English team, led by former England captain Mike Gatting, expect to be barred from official international competition for five years for breaking the International Cricket Conference's ban on sporting contacts with South Africa. There have been unconfirmed press reports that the English players are receiving $160,000 each for the tour, with Gatting getting $320,000. Most international sports organizations boycott South Africa because of its policy of apartheid, under which the country's 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs and are ruled by a government run by the 5 million whites.

DOC.HEAD: Handicapped Teen Found Hundreds of Miles Away
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old girl who has suffered memory lapses since a sports accident a year ago was found safe here today, eight days after she disappeared from her Wisconsin hometown hundreds of miles away. Michelle Ebeling of Janesville, Wis., was picked up along an interstate highway around dawn by a truck driver who took her to a truck stop and called authorities, police said. Sheriff's officials notified Miss Ebeling's family, ending the search that included more than a 1,000 volunteers. She had no idea of how she got to North Carolina, said her father, Tim Ebeling. ``We're absolutely elated and thankful. We all cried like fools,'' said Miss Ebeling's aunt, Ellie Bickel. ``We all talked to her and reassured her that we loved her very much.'' The high school senior apparently wandered away last Wednesday while waiting for a bus at Craig High School. The girl was an honors student and athlete before an injury during track practice last April left her partially paralyzed, with short-term memory loss and tunnel vision. Her family said she could remember the past and recognize family and friends, but often would forget a request made 10 minutes before. Her therapy included carrying a book to write down what she needed to remember. Volunteers in the Janesville area mounted a ground and air search over the weekend. The family offered a $10,000 reward and distributed about 60,000 leaflets across the country. When she was found, the girl was wearing a long coat, not the high school letter jacket she had on when she disappeared, and carried no identification. Leah Booe, a sheriff's dispatcher, said the trucker thought it was unusual for a young woman to be walking along the road at that hour and offered a ride. Richard Jorgensen, principal at her high school, said the eight days of searching had affected everyone in the comunity of 51,000. He said a homecoming celebration will be held when Michelle returns. ``It's been a week of deep concern caring frustration and just a matter of not knowing what you can do and wanting to do something,'' he said. Mrs. Bickel said the girl's parents would fly to North Carolina and return with their daughter on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: 80 Moslem Fundamentalist Detainees Freed
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors Thursday ordered the release of 80 Moslem fundamentalists detained for nearly two months on charges of illegal possession of weapons and anti-government activities. Abdel-Aziz Mokhtar, the city's chief prosecutor, cited lack of evidence as the reason. The charges against the detainees, all university students, stemmed from a battle Dec. 11 between police and more than 300 Moslem militants who tried to march from a mosque to the city center in an anti-government demonstration. The clash left 10 policemen and 30 militants wounded, many by bullets. Assiut, 238 miles south of Cairo, has been a center of fundamentalist agitation in recent years. At least 500 people were arrested soon after the demonstration. All were gradually released except the 80, who were remanded to custody by government prosecutors investigating the case. The detainees were charged with resisting authorities, illegal possession of arms and explosives, and unlawful assembly. About 10 other Moslem militants remain in jail in connection with a clash last month with police during a demonstration outside a mosque. One militant was killed, reportedly by police gunfire.

DOC.HEAD: British, Argentine Officials Open Talks on Falklands
DOC.TEXT: British and Argentine officials opened two days of talks Thursday on issues related to the disputed Falkland Islands, a step toward restoring full diplomatic ties, embassy spokesmen said. An Argentine Embassy official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Argentina would ask Britain to drop the 150-mile military ``protection zone'' around the Falklands, which Argentina calls the Malvinas Islands. The zone has been enforced since Argentina invaded the South Atlantic islands in 1982. The Argentine soldiers were driven off by British troops after a 74-day war. Britain now requires Argentine military ships to request and receive British permission before entering the zone. The talks Thursday were held at the Argentine ambassador's residence in central Madrid. On Friday, the talks will move across the street to the British Embassy. A British Embassy spokesman said details of the meetings were not expected to be made public. The talks serve as a preliminary step to high-level meetings in Madrid on Feb. 14-15 that will be aimed at restoring full diplomatic relations. Argentina has claimed the islands since declaring independence from Spain in 1816. British claims to the islands are based on effective occupation since 1833. Relations between the two countries have improved considerably since October, when two days of talks in Madrid ended with the restoration of consular relations and an agreement to move toward normal diplomatic and economic relations. Since then, Argentina has allowed British vessels and planes to operate freely in Argentine territory, and Britain has lifted a restriction on the navigation of Argentine merchant ships in the 150-mile military protection zone around the Falklands. Britain's five-man delegation at this week's talks was led by Adrian Beamish, the Foreign Office's assistant undersecretary of state for the Americas. The Argentine side was headed by Jose Maria Otegui, director-general for the Malvinas.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Foreign Minister Arrives to Resume Ties
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli foreign minister, Moshe Arens, arrived in Prague on Thursday for a three-day visit to mark the resumption of diplomatic ties with Czechoslovakia. Except for Romania, all East bloc countries followed Moscow in breaking diplomatic relations with Israel in 1967 following the Middle East War, when Israel captured the West Bank and Gaza Strip from Egypt and Jordan. Now that Eastern European countries are breaking away from Moscow, they are eager to restore diplomatic ties with the Jewish state. Arens is expected to sign an agreement on resuming relations with his Czechoslovak counterpart, Jiri Dienstbier. After Israel was established in 1948, Czechoslovakia was one of its earliest and most enthusiastic backers, training Israeli air force pilots and supplying weapons for its fight against the Arabs. In later years, like the other East bloc Communist countries under the sway of Moscow, Czechoslovakia gave far more support to the Arabs. Vaclav Havel, who became Czechoslovakia's president after the pro-democracy movement that drove out the hard-line Communist leadership, has said he recognizes the right of the Palestinians to their own state, while understanding the anxiety of Israel based on ``years of painful experience.'' Havel has offered to mediate in talks between Israel and the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Seoul And Washington Negotiating to Alter Combined Command System
DOC.TEXT: South Korean officials are negotiating with the United States to change the countries' combined military command system to give Seoul more control over its armed forces, officials said Thursday. South Korea's 600,000-member military currently is under the operational control of the top U.S. commander in the country under a combined forces command system adopted in 1978. U.S. and South Korean officials defend the system as an effective measure to jointly cope with a possible North Korean invasion, but Korean radicals see it as an example of U.S. infringement upon the sovereignty of South Korea. Radicals have attacked U.S. facilities to protest the system. South Korean Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon, meeting reporters Thursday, said the combined command system must be maintained in wartime. He said the new arrangement under discussion may give South Korea more power to control its military in peace time. ``That way, we can resolve the dispute without demaging the basic structure of the combined command system,'' one Korean reporter quoted Lee as saying. Officials at the Defense Ministry said the change will be further discussed when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney visits Seoul on Feb. 14-17.

DOC.HEAD: List of Worst U.S. Oil Spills
With AM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of 10 of the worst oil spills in U.S. history, according to Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin, which has kept records since 1976. 1. March 24, 1989, Exxon Valdez, Prince William Sound, Alaska, 10.92 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 2. Nov. 1, 1979, Burmah Agate tanker, Galveston Bay, Texas, up to 10.7 million gallons of oil burned or spilled when two ships collided. 3. Dec. 15, 1976, Argo Merchant tanker, Massachusetts' southeast coast, 7.6 million gallons of crude spilled when the ship ran aground. 4. Nov. 6, 1985, exploratory well, Ranger, Texas, 6.3 million gallons of oil spilled after a blowout. 5. Jan. 2, 1988, Ashland Oil Co., above-ground storage tank, Jefferson Borough, Pa., 3.8 million gallons of oil spilled when a tank ruptured. 6. July 30, 1984, Alvenus tanker, Cameron, La., 2.8 million gallons of oil spilled after a ship ran aground. 7. Oct. 31, 1984, Puerto Rican tanker, San Francisco, 2 million gallons of oil spilled when a ship caught fire following an explosion. 8. Aug. 18, 1984, Triangle Oil Corp., above-ground storage tank, Jacksonville, Fla., 2.5 million gallons of oil burned after lightning sparked a fire. 9. Nov. 22, 1980, Georgia tanker, Pilottown, La., 1.3 million gallons of oil spilled after an anchor chain caused a ship to leak. 10. March 31, 1982, Arkas tanker, Montz, La., 1.47 million gallons of oil burned and spilled after a ship collision and fire.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson Sister Begins `Journey of Hope'
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Say, sister of Terry Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon, is launching a ``journey of peace, reconciliation and hope'' to Europe and the Middle East in efforts to free her brother. ``In Terry's last videotape in October 1988, he asked that the United States use its influence in a positive, not a negative way. I intend to make that same appeal to all of those who may have influence in this hostage situation,'' she said. Say will meet Friday with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to begin her mission. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was seized March 16, 1985. Seventeen other Western hostages _ seven Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman _ are being held in Lebanon. ``I want to appeal for an end to the suffering of all people in the Middle East, including these innocent hostages,'' said Say, of Cadiz, Ky. During the tour, Say and AP executives will meet with Pope John Paul II in Rome; the archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, in London; the European Parliament's Committee on Human Rights in Strasbourg, France; and the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva, Switzerland. They also will meet UNESCO Director General Federico Mayor in Paris and Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa in Damascus. The group also hopes to meet with Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat. Say said efforts to meet with Iranian officials received no response. Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual head of Hezbollah, the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem movement in Lebanon, declined to meet with the group outside Lebanon. Anderson is being held by a group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, generally believed to be one of several groups operating under the umbrella of Hezbollah. The AP delegation includes photographer Donald Mell, who was with Anderson when he was kidnapped in Beirut, and Larry Heinzerling, who has been serving as a special assistant to AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi on the Anderson case. Boccardi said of the tour: ``The approach of the fifth anniversary of Terry's captivity carries with it the clear message that there is no point in continuing his cruel ordeal. ``Our group will try to convey publicly what we have tried to convey privately, that is, that in the name of humanity it is time for Terry Anderson to be allowed to come home.'' Public and private efforts throughout the world, involving scores of governments, organizations and individuals, have failed to obtain Anderson's freedom. Most visible in these efforts has been Anderson's sister, who has campaigned tirelessly on her brother's behalf. The Associated Press has supported Mrs. Say's efforts, and pressed its own efforts to win Anderson's release. Say said church groups in Buffalo and Batavia, N.Y., plan to organize a nationwide fast and prayer through March 16 ``for an end to the suffering of the people of the Middle East.'' Anderson graduated from Batavia High School. The Buffalo Area Metropolitan Ministries called on Americans to select a day or days of fasting and prayer in support of the hostages, culminating in a 24-hour fast beginning the evening of March 15.

DOC.HEAD: Army Takes Back Mistakenly Awarded Combat Decorations
DOC.TEXT: The Army, which hurriedly awarded 186 decorations to hospitalized soldiers two days after the Panama invasion, has taken back 14 Combat Infantryman Badges from men found to be ineligible. The badges were pinned to the pillows of men who were under sedation and couldn't be asked what they did in the operation, said Army spokesman Maj. Joe Padilla. It turned out 14 were not in the infantry. The three-inch badges, which portray a silver rifle on a blue background emblazoned with a wreath, are awarded only to soldiers with infantry specialties. Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army chief of staff, handed out the awards during a visit to two military hospitals in San Antonio, Texas, on Dec. 22. The infantry badges have been the source of some controversy in recent weeks. Women who came under fire in Panama are ineligible since they are barred from serving in infantry units, but Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has demanded that such women be granted the badges anyway. As for the mistakenly awarded badges, which were given quickly and without the usual review, Padilla said the problem did not stem from a quest for publicity. ``This was not a photo op for Gen. Vuono. This was an honest mistake.'' ``It was thought to be an opportunity for the men to be decorated by the chief of staff of the Army. ... It was an effort to distinguish those soldiers thought to be deserving, and allow those who were wounded to wake up with the award on their pillow,'' Padilla said. Most of Vuono's hospital visit was off-limits to reporters, and only a small group was permitted to accompany the general to Wilford Hall Medical Center for the presentation of medals to three soldiers. The general also visited nearby Brooke Army Medical Center. The Combat Infantryman Badge is granted only to officers or enlisted personnel with infantry specialties who have ``satisfactorily performed their duty'' in an infantry unit while engaged in combat, Padilla said. The incorrectly awarded badges were given to men who were military policemen, artillery soldiers, communications specialists, truck drivers or specialists in psychological operations, the spokesman said. The spokesman said he didn't think the soldiers would be disappointed. ``Every soldier knows what awards they're eligible for. They would know immediately that was a mistake,'' he said. The Army declined to provide the names of the soldiers involved.

DOC.HEAD: Young Teacher Arrested in Love Triangle
DOC.TEXT: A young woman teacher shot and killed her lover's wife, then kept a date with him for drinks at a motel and sex in her car, police said. The man said he discovered his wife's body when he returned home. Carolyn Warmus, a 26-year-old computer science teacher, was indicted on murder charges and freed on $250,000 bail this week in what police said was a lover's triangle. Ms. Warmus was charged in the slaying a year ago of Betty Jeanne Solomon, shot nine times at her home in Greenburgh. Police said Ms. Warmus had been romantically involved with Mrs. Solomon's husband, Paul, for nearly a year. Ms. Warmus and Solomon, a 39-year-old elementary school teacher, had at one time worked at the same school, in Greenburgh. Police have said Mrs. Solomon was killed between 7 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. Ms. Warmus told police she met Solomon about 7:30 that night at a Holiday Inn in Yonkers and that they had drinks before having sex in her car, authorities said. Ms. Warmus, who knew Mrs. Solomon and had been a dinner guest of the couple's, told police she had called Solomon at his home that afternoon and that they talked for 45 minutes before making a date to meet at a bar. ``We had a few drinks and spoke about many things,'' police quoted her as saying. ``While we were in the car Paul stated to me that he wanted me to be happy, we are best friends.'' Solomon said he discovered his wife's body when he returned home. Police said Solomon was their original suspect but that their year-long investigation pointed them to Ms. Warmus. Law enforcement sources said Ms. Warmus was treated at a hospital in New York for a psychotic episode in August, but declined to discuss details. A private detective, Gabe Laura, said Warmus tried to buy a gun and silencer six months before she allegedly killed her lover's wife, the New York Post reported today. Warmus allegedly obtained a .25-caliber handgun and a handmade silencer from New York private eye Vincent Parco, Laura's former partner. Parco is cooperating with authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Government Asks for Wage-Price Freeze, Ban on Strikes
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said Thursday the economy is ``falling apart'' and his government will resign unless Parliament bans strikes and imposes a wage-price freeze for two years. The plan that Finance Minister Kjell-Olof Feldt outlined in Parliament also would put a two-year freeze on local taxes, rents and stock dividends. Some opposition legislators accused Carlsson's Social Democrats of declaring economic martial law and advocating a planned economy when Eastern Europe is abandoning that approach. A vote is expected next week on the plan, which is designed to curb rapidly rising wages and annual inflation of 8.6 percent, twice the West European average. Carlsson's minority government needs the support of at least one opposition party to pass each of its proposals. Both conservatives and liberals have indicated they would support a tax freeze, and the Communists said they would go along with freezing prices, rents and stock earnings. ``If Parliament rejects our demands, the government cannot stay on,'' Carlsson told a news conference. ``We will not administer an economy that is falling apart.'' His plan would suspend a 50-year-old agreement under which powerful unions and employers' associations negotiate wages quietly, without government intervention. Collective bargaining is a pillar of the Swedish welfare system, which has eliminated poverty and guaranteed health care and education for everyone. The Swedish mix of socialism and capitalism became a model for the industrial welfare state. ``What was known as the Swedish Model is, on the whole, gone, and this is just another sign,'' bank economist Nils Lundgren said on Swedish radio. Strikes would be prohibited for the duration of the plan, through 1991, and a striker could be fined 5,000 kronor, about $800. To help curb absenteeism and cheating on sick leave, the government would stop paying salaries for the first two weeks of illness, shifting the burden to the employer. Under current rules, the government pays sick leave from the first day. ``What we propose is without doubt an austere policy,'' Feldt said. ``It also means an important deviation from the Swedish Model of free wage negotiations, but it is necessary.'' Carlsson said: ``To make the wage freeze work, it must be combined with a strike freeze. If the Riksdag (Parliament) takes the package to pieces, the package is meaningless.'' Approval of the plan would preempt a strike by 110,000 municipal employees called for Wednesday that would halt public transportation, public health services and day-care in major cities. Banks have been closed for 11 days, since 62,000 employees were locked out after a deadlock in wage negotiations. People are strapped for cash, the stock market is virtually inoperative and some companies soon may be unable to pay salaries and bills. ``If this merry-go-round isn't stopped, it could lead to anarchy on the labor market,'' Feldt said. He compared the labor strife with Britain's ``winter of discontent'' in 1979, when strikes caused a conservative backlash that put Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in power. Sweden's largest union, known as LO, expressed guarded approval of the plan. Union president Stig Malm, a member of the Social Democratic leadership, said many members would be unhappy about the wage freeze but expressed hope the package as a whole would win ``great understanding.'' Sture Nord of TCO, a white-collar union, declared in disagreement: ``We cannot accept limits of trade unions' rights.'' Carlsson told the news conference Sweden was pricing itself out of the European market through rising production costs. ``We had hoped the trade unions and employers' organizations would agree on a lower cost development to increase competitive strength and reduce inflation,'' he said. ``They did not.'' In Parliament, Feldt said: ``Sweden is rushing into a cost crisis, and that cannot be permitted.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Magistrate Denies Defense Request For Document Inventory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `The trial ...' UPDATE with judge saying March 5 start date is unrealistic, prosecution and defense estimate of preparation time.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge refused today to give up jurisdiction in the drug trafficking case against Manuel Noriega, rejecting defense efforts to have the fallen dictator moved to a neutral country. ``I don't find that under the Geneva Convention I must divest myself of jurisdiction,'' said U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler, the trial judge. William Bryson, U.S. deputy solicitor general, had argued the government's case that the judge does have jurisdiction. ``Yes, we have agreed to treat General Noriega as a prisoner of war,'' Bryson said. But he said the Geneva Convention clearly authorizes Noriega's prosecution in a U.S. civilian court. Defense attorney Frank Rubino strongly dissented, saying the government was trying to read the Geneva Convention to justify an illegal invasion and the detention of Noriega. ``Your honor is going to decide whether we are going to strictly observe the Geneva convention, or whether we are going to push it aside a little bit so we can bring General Noriega to trial,'' Rubino said. Rubino said he was not asking the judge to dismiss the indictment but to acknowledge he had no jurisdiction over Noriega except to send him back to Panama or a willing third country. Rubino said the United States could then try ``fair and square'' to get him back by extradition. The comments came during a status conference on the indictment. Both sides agree the judge must also decide soon what procedures will be used to give the defendants classified documents they say are essential to the defense. The hearing saw the first gathering in court of all six defendants brought here to face charges in the February 1988 drug trafficking case: Noriega, Brian Alden Davidow, Luis del Cid, Luis Saldarriaga, Daniel Miranda, and Eduardo Pardo. An attorney for Davidow, 28, asked for a separate trial for his client. In the motion, defense attorney Richard Sharpstein said Noriega's presence ``is similar to an atomic bomb, producing fallout which would kill anyone tried with him.'' Hoeveler acknowledged that the March 5 trial date was unrealistic. Rubino he would need 18 months to two years to ready his case, but prosecutors said they could start trial by the year's end. The judge did not set a new date. On Wednesday, a U.S. magistrate denied a request by Noriega's attorneys for an immediate inventory and inspection of materials seized from the dictator's homes and offices since the U.S. invasion two months ago of Panama. Defense attorneys already have gotten a promise of an inventory. But they contend the government may remove or destroy materials critical to Noriega's defense. ``The U.S. Attorney's office is dragging its feet,'' Noriega attorney Steven Kollin told Magistrate William C. Turnoff, who last month issued an order that an inventory be provided to the defense. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's Office, declined to comment on whether any potential evidence in the possession of the military had disappeared. ``We do not believe anything has been removed from inventory (in Miami),'' she said. In a separate development Wednesday, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Adminstration announced that 34 computer diskettes captured during the U.S. invasion of Panama may show how Noriega laundered drug money. The DEA has sought Hoeveler's approval of a search warrant permitting one of its agents to inspect the information on the diskettes, according to today's Miami Herald. The diskettes were reportedly discovered at the home in Panama City of Noriega business associate Carlos Wittgreen. Wittgreen was described in a DEA affidavit made public Wednesday as one of Noriega's ``prime financial advisers.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Revenue Director Charged With Preparing False Memo
DOC.TEXT: Florida's former chief tax collector wrote a phony memo in an attempt to prove she didn't order a politically motivated audit, investigators charged after examining her office typewriter ribbon. Katie Tucker, 46, was charged Wednesday with official misconduct for falsifying documents, punishable by five years in prison and a $5,000 fine. She was released on her own recognizance. The charge came one day after she resigned as state revenue director amid allegations she singled out a political opponent of her husband's for a tax audit in 1988. ``I've done no wrongdoing,'' she said. ``I wish they'd just let me get on with my life.'' Her attorney, Lorence Bielby, said Ms. Tucker would plead innocent to the misconduct charge. No court date was set. Florida Department of Law Enforcement agent John Gordy said in court papers that Ms. Tucker prepared a document purporting to show that she had asked an employee to conduct a broader tax investigation instead of singling out Donald G. Resha. Resha unsuccessfully challenged Tucker's husband, Daniel Miller, for president of the AFL-CIO in 1985. That memo was dated Dec. 21, 1988, and addressed to a former revenue department employee who handled the Resha investigation. ``I am disappointed and concerned as to why you investigated one company only,'' the memo said. ``Please do not ever again assume that I would want one company investigated when I have given you a much larger assignment.'' Gordy said the memo was probably produced by Ms. Tucker on Jan. 31 during a night visit to her office. Much of the evidence was found on a cartridge ribbon from a typewriter there, the FDLE said. Ms. Tucker has insisted while trying to save her $85,292-a-year job that she intended to order a larger tax probe of video stores like those owned by Resha and claimed she could find documents to back her up. But she never showed those documents publicly.

DOC.HEAD: Psychologists Give Troops Support To Forestall Post-Traumatic Stress Syndrome
DOC.TEXT: Fort Bragg enlisted a psychologist to help soldiers deal with their feelings about combat in Panama, in the Army's first attempt to prevent post-traumatic stress disorder before it appears. ``We called it shell shock in World War II,'' Lt. Col. Dick Bridges, an Army spokesman at the Pentagon, said Wednesday in a telephone interview. ``But we've come to understand it better and have only called it post-traumatic stress since 1980.'' Bridges said he wasn't sure if the Army provided counseling for the disorder after the invasion of Grenada in October 1983, ``but it seems to me that this is the first time that we've tried to be pro-active in trying to treat it before it happens.'' Unlike Vietnam veterans, soldiers returning from Panama were greeted by cheers and commendations, and psychologists say that could make them less likely to suffer the effects of post-traumatic stress disorder. Last week, Bragg invited some psychologists to work with soldiers and their family members who were involved with the Panama incursion, dubbed Operation Just Cause, said Maj. Doug Foster, base spokesman. The medical community at Womack Army Community Hospital worked with the psychologists to learn to recognize early symptoms of the syndrome, he said. Dr. Tom Williams, a consultant for the Post Trauma Treatment Center at Centennial Peaks Hospital in Louisville, Colo., spent five days at Fort Bragg on a volunteer basis and spoke to about 2,000 soldiers and family members. Williams said he drew on his own experiences as a Marine captain during two tours in Vietnam to help soldiers at Fort Bragg cope with their feelings after their brief combat experience. ``I'm jealous because these guys went in as a unit and came out as a unit,'' said Williams, 38. ``I didn't have that luxury. In Vietnam, nobody cared about us afterwards, either in the Defense Department or the civilian community.'' The brief duration of the fighting in Panama, which ended in the first week after the initial assault, does not prevent the possibility of emotional ill effects, he said. ``What we would not want to see is what happened after Vietnam _ high states of depression, high suicide rates, high alcoholism rates and high divorce rates,'' Williams said. ``If we were talking about an airplane crash and people who pulled bodies out and risked their lives in recovering survivors, there would be no question there would be emotional response to that,'' Williams said. ``Combatants have the same type of response because they're human beings.'' The effects of traumatic events go beyond the mind, Williams said. ``We're talking about the endocrine system _ bursts of adrenalin which our body has for our survival,'' he said. ``When adrenalin gets used up, then you have another chemical which slows down all the body processes, particularly the nervous system, thus the listlessness.'' No one seems able to escape the effects of going into battle, not even the soldiers left behind. ``The people who stayed in the rear have to realize what they did was important,'' Williams said. Understanding can ease the way for soldiers who may experience trauma from the ordeal. ``Family members must realize that experiencing combat, either firsthand or indirectly, inevitably alters the life of their loved one,'' Williams said. ``A soldier's homecoming is easier if families understand the typical emotional responses one has experienced.''

DOC.HEAD: Other Recent U.S. Oil Spills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `June 23...', to CORRECT Rhode Island spill estimate to 280,000 sted 420,000.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of some major oil spills in the United States during the past year: March 24, 1989, tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound, Alaska, spilling 10.92 million gallons of crude. June 23, 1989, tanker World Prodigy ran aground at mouth of Narragansett Bay off Newport, R.I., spilling an estimated 280,000 gallons of heating oil. June 23, 1989, tug-driven barge collided with cargo vessel in the Houston Ship Channel near La Porte, Texas, spilling an estimated 250,000 gallons of crude. June 24, 1989, Uruguayan tanker Presidente Rivera ran aground in Delaware River near Claymont, Del., spilling estimated 300,000 gallons of industrial heating oil. Jan. 1-2, 1990, pipeline linking Exxon's Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J. with a distribution terminal in Bayonne, N.J., ruptured, leaking an estimated 567,000 gallons oil heating oil into the Arthur Kill waterway between New Jersey and New York's Staten Island.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Kill Paramilitary Soldiers as Violence Continues in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants armed with automatic rifles shot and killed two unarmed paramilitary soldiers on Thursday in Srinagar, the flashpoint of a violent separatist campaign, officials said. Witnesses said a cigarette vendor also was killed in the attack, which occurred outside the vendor's kiosk in the Chanpora suburb of the city. A bystander was injured, said the witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The deaths brought to 81 the number of people killed since Jan. 20 in clashes between security forces and Moslem militants fighting for secession of the Moslem-dominated Kashmir region from Hindu-majority India. Most victims have been protesters shot while defying a curfew imposed Jan. 20 when government forces launched a crackdown. A senior police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said militants exploded bombs in a government building and a government-run bank in Srinagar's outskirts Thursday, causing severe damage. There were no casualties. The official also blamed militants for a fire that broke out in a downtown shopping center. No casualties were reported in the blaze. Security was strengthened across Srinagar after the incidents. New roadblocks were set up and more paramilitary troops were deployed on the streets, the official said. Some soldiers patrolled in trucks while others perched with machine guns on the sides of roads. A curfew that was to have begun at 6 p.m. instead took effect in the afternoon in three areas of the city after the shootings. The two paramilitary Border Security Force officers were shot with Chinese-designed AK-47 rifles from close range as they walked from their camp toward the cigarette kiosk, 100 yards from the camp's gate, said Ashok Patel, inspector-general of the Border Security Force. He said the men were unarmed and were not in uniform when attacked. It was the first reported slaying by Moslem militants of paramilitary troops. The Border Security Force, known to be a more disciplined and tougher force that the state constabulary, is normally deployed on international borders but has been increasingly used to put down the Kashmir secessionist movement. State police began preparations to counter violence Friday, the Moslem sabbath. On past sabbath days, speeches have been broadcast from mosques urging people to fight for Kashmir's independence. Gov. Jagmohan, known to be a tough administrator who ordered the Jan. 20 crackdown, on Thursday appealed for peace in Kashmir, the Himalayan valley once popular for its gardens, lakes and apple orchards. ``Let us impress once again on our young brothers to see the futility of the cult of guns and understand the magnitude of all-round misery that it has caused,'' he said in a letter released by the state government. Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses only one name, wrote the letter to the father of a Moslem youth who was killed in a bomb explosion in a shopping complex on Wednesday. Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned on gaining independence from Britain in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir state, India's only predominantly Moslem state. Sixty-four percent of the state's 5 million people are Moslems, but nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's population of 880 million. Kashmiri militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population, but now they demand independence and the status of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: US Worried About Terrorist Attacks in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The United States is deeply concerned about the possibility of a terrorist attack against Americans or U.S. installations in Europe to coincide with the upcoming 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran, the State Department said today. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher recalled that a threat advisory was issued last December and he said that threat continues. The anniversary of Iran's revolution is this Sunday. Boucher added that the United States has no specific information about the alleged terrorist operation or its target. ``If further credible or specific information on this threat develops, the department will issue additional alerts to travelers and other concerned parties,'' he said. He added that the department is encouraging travelers to Europe to exercise caution but that Americans are not being urged to cancel plans they may have to visit the continent. The statement issued last December said the concern was based partly on reports of movement of terrorists from the Middle East and the discovery of weapons shipments destined for pro-Iranian groups in Spain and Africa. At the time, officials said there were several anniversaries pending that terrorists sometimes use as occasions for carrying out violent activities. One was the still unresolved bombing of Pan Am flight 103 on Dec. 21, 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland, with a death toll of 259 aboard the craft and 11 on the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The balloon an 8-year-old Leawood, Kan., boy let loose earlier this week certainly isn't in Kansas anymore. The green balloon, tied to a note celebrating ``Happy Week,'' ended up Tuesday on Mary Ellen Pinto's front lawn in Shelton. ``My! I'm amazed,'' said Doug Harris, principal of the Leawood Elementary School. ``Most of the time they don't go any farther than across the state line into Missouri,'' he said. ``The kids will be very excited about this.'' The balloon released by Colby Raden flew the 1,000 miles from the Kansas City suburb to Shelton in about a day. Harris said the school's 480 children have released balloons for four years as part of Happy Week, a celebration at the school to brush away the winter blahs. Each balloon is accompanied by a note telling the recipient it was sent to reach out to friends ``far and near.'' Colby was impressed at his balloon's performance, especially when Harris pulled out a map and showed him where Connecticut is. ``Gosh!'' he said. ``I've sent one every year and no one has ever found my balloon. That's awesome.''

Minnesota is no longer the ``brainpower state,'' Transportation Commissioner Leonard Levine has decided after travelers panned the idea. Levine said Wednesday that the message on a tourism sign on Interstate 94 near Hudson, Wis., will be changed. The sign has welcomed travelers to ``Minnesota _ the Brainpower State'' since December. The slogan _ from a phrase used by Gov. Rudy Perpich to refer to the state's high quality of education _ has been the butt of jokes and of complaints from Minnesota legislative leaders. In addition, 63 percent of 220 motorists surveyed at the St. Croix Travel Information Center on Interstate 94 near Hudson said they wanted the original wording restored. Before it was changed, the sign read: ``Minnesota Welcomes You _ Land of 10,000 Lakes.''

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Governor Won't Run Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Secretary of ...' to UPDATE with Roberts announcing for governor.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Neil Goldschmidt says he won't seek a second term because his marriage is coming apart and that's ``certainly no time to be running for governor.'' Aides to the governor had previously denied recurring rumors of problems in his 25-year marriage. Goldschmidt and his wife, Margie, have two children, ages 20 and 17. ``I put off my decision until now hoping Margie and I could work out our differences, but it was not to be,'' the Democrat said Wednesday. ``It is going to be a rough time for our children as well as for Margie and me.'' Goldschmidt, 49, said he is separating from his wife. Secretary of State Barbara Roberts, a 53-year-old Democrat, announced today she will make a bid in November to become Oregon's first woman governor. Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer is seeking the Republican nomination. Goldschmidt is a former Portland mayor and secretary of transportation under President Carter. Goldschmidt's energy and charisma earned him high marks at first, and he has been credited with a regional economic development program, a major expansion of the prison system and an initiative devoted to helping children. But critics have accused him of not always following through on his initiatives.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's `Today' Loses To ABC Rival In Ratings
DOC.TEXT: ABC`S ``Good Morning America'' again triumphed over NBC's ``Today'' show, averaging a 4.5 rating last week against the 3.8 of ``Today,'' A.C. Nielsen Co. audience estimates showed Thursday. ``CBS This Morning'' remained a distant third with a 2.6 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ABC's victory marked the fifth consecutive week it has beaten ``Today,'' which in attempting to fend off ABC's challenge has undergone a series of changes, including the much-publiziced departure of Jane Pauley in December. Pauley, the show's co-host for 13 years, was succeeded by Deborah Norville, who had been the program's news anchor since September. The longest previous winning stretch of `Good Morning America'' over once-dominant ``Today'' occurred in October and November 1987, when ABC's show won its morning time period for six straight weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Doctor Can Be Sued Over Patient's Shooting Spree
DOC.TEXT: A psychiatrist who treated a woman who went on a 1988 shooting rampage in an elementary school, killing one child, can be sued for negligence by the woman's victims, a judge has ruled. Circuit Court Judge Donald O'Connell refused Wednesday to drop Dr. Philip Epstein from a lawsuit filed by the victims of Laurie Dann, whose shooting spree in Winnetka also wounded five other children and one neighborhood resident. Dann then took her own life. The suit, filed by the family of the slain 8-year-old, Nicky Corwin, alleges that Epstein negligently treated Dann with a drug not approved by the Food and Drug Administration and that the drug may have contributed to Dann's violent behavior. The lawsuit, which has been joined by other victims, also names Dann's parents, Norman and Edith Wasserman, as defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Son Arrested on Traffic Charges Again
DOC.TEXT: The teen-age son of Atlanta's mayor has been charged with driving without a license and improper lane changes in his second arrest in a month. Maynard H. Jackson III, 19, was charged Wednesday and released, said police spokeswoman Sandra Blount. A court date was set for Feb. 21, she said.
