After his first arrest, on Jan. 9, Mayor Maynard Jackson issued a statement saying he had given orders that his son be shown no special treatment. The mayor's office did not immediately return a call Thursday seeking comment on the second arrest. In the January case, the younger Jackson was charged with possession of less than an ounce of marijuana and following too closely after an accident in which his car struck the rear of another. He pleaded no contest to the drug charge and was fined $150. He pleaded innocent to the traffic charge and a judge found him guilty and fined him $60.

DOC.HEAD: Bird On State License Plate An Impostor, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: The little bird pictured on South Carolina's new license plates is ruffling the feathers of experts, who say it's not a Carolina wren as the plate's makers claim. ``The rendition looks more like a sparrow than a wren,'' said John Cely, a biologist at the South Carolina Department of Wildlife and Marine Resources. Cely said Carolina wrens generally are brown, have long, needle-like bills and tend to cock their tails at 90 degrees. The bird on the license plate has a short bill and straight tail. Bob Wood, president of the Columbia Audubon Society, said he is particularly offended by the ``gross shade of yellow'' selected for the bird. ``The Carolina wren is a beautiful, chocolate-colored bird, which I'm sure would have made for a pretty license,'' he said. ``I'm just so disappointed that the highway department depicted such a beautiful bird as something that's not even close.'' William H. Kay of the state highway department's administrative services division said he discussed the drawing with the artist, Glynn Keisler, after it was completed. ``I'm not sure whether she contacted the Audubon Society, and I don't know what her basis was for this,'' he said. ``But we did discuss how the tail should be shown _ whether it should be turned up or not _ but she said it only was turned up when the bird was in an excitable state.'' Kay said people should not get upset over the bird's color. ``When was the last time you saw a blue or red Palmetto tree?'' he asked, referring to two previous versions of the state's license plate. ``I've only received a few negative comments about the plate, and those have been generally about the bird's tail and color,'' Kay said. ``Aside from those, most people seem to think it's the most beautiful license plate they've seen.'' There was no comment from Ms. Keisler; she resigned from the highway department about a year ago after she finished the drawing, and is no longer listed in the Columbia telephone book. Kay said Ms. Keisler's drawing was not the only one considered. ``We also considered a drawing of a golfer,'' he said. ``But not everyone golfs, so we went with this.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Economist Sees Peril in Moynihan Plan
DOC.TEXT: Congress' chief economist said Thursday that a proposed reduction in Social Security taxes could worsen inflation while doing nothing to ease the long-range problems of the pension system. ``Because the economy is operating close to its full capacity now, a significant reduction in payroll tax rates without offsetting deficit reductions elsewhere could harm the economy's performance over the next several years,'' Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told the Senate Finance Committee. No matter what happens to the tax cut proposed by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., Reischauer said, retirement benefits for future generations will have to be financed out of the goods and services being produced at that time. ``A permanent increase in taxes or reductions in other federal programs appears to be a certainty, since the retirement of the (post-World War II) baby boom will mark the beginning of a permanent increase in the ratio of retirees to workers,'' he said. Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, also argued against a Social Security tax reduction. Darman said Moynihan's bill, if it became law, would either worsen next year's deficit by $55 billion or result in an offsetting tax increase. Raising other taxes ``would hurt the very workers Senator Moynihan's proposal is ostensibly intended to help,'' Darman said. ``Indeed, it would hurt them doubly: first, by jeopardizing their future retirement benefits and second, by taking back in new taxes what it pretended to give in the way of a tax cut.'' Darman said the Bush administration agrees with Moynihan that the government should stop using surplus Social Security taxes to make the regular federal deficit appear smaller than it is. But the answer, he said, is the administration's proposal, which, starting gradually in 1993, would require that surplus Social Security taxes be used only to pay off federal debt. Moynihan's bill apparently has picked up little support among colleagues on the tax-writing Finance Committee. No member offered an endorsement; the chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said he is opposed. Bentsen told reporters that Moynihan, one of Social Security's most ardent defenders in Congresss, deserves praise for ``tearing the mask off of this idea that we're financing the deficit with a surplus in the Social Security trust fund.'' ``But insofar as bringing about that kind of cut in revenues, there's no way we can afford to do that at the present time,'' Bentsen said. The cut proposed by Moynihan would be about $60 billion a year when fully implemented, yielding tax cuts that would be nearly $300 a year for higher-income workers. The Democratic leadership of the Senate and House are expected to take a position on Moynihan's bill within several days. The government is collecting about $1 billion a week more in Social Security taxes than it is paying in benefits. By law, that money is invested in federal securities; the surplus makes the deficit in the overall government budget look much smaller than it really is. The Social Security system is deliberately building a surplus in an effort to guarantee that ample money will be on hand to pay benefits when the big post-World War II generation begins retiring around 2010. Whether or not Social Security taxes are cut now, experts say, they will have to be raised again early in the next century. A worker now pays a 7.65 percent Social Security tax on the first $51,300 earned each year; the employer matches the payment. Moynihan's bill would repeal a rate increase that went into effect Jan. 1, restoring the rate to 7.51 percent, and cut it next year to 6.55 percent.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Telephone Fine,750
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday ordered a record $1.4 million fine against New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. for alleged improper dealings with an affiliated company and ordered them to refund about $35 million to customers. The fine against the two subsidiaries of NYNEX Corp. was the maximum allowed under current law and involved alleged $118.5 million in overcharges made to NYT and NET by Material Enterprises Co., an unregulated NYNEX affiliate NYNEX established in 1983 to provide equipment and services to the two phone companies. The action _ the largest federal penalty ever imposed on a telephone company _ was seen as a tough warning to the nation's huge regional Bell companies that the FCC is committed to regulating the multibillion-telephone industry. Critics claim the FCC cannot effectively regulate the giant hone companies, particularly if Congress bows to the phone companies' requests that they be freed from federal rules that bar them from the manufacturing, information services and long-distance businesses. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes told reporters the FCC's action demonstrates the commission's ``capability and commitment to regulate even the largest'' telephone companies. Sikes said the benefits to be derived from improved competition and diversification in the phone industry following the 1984 breakup of the Bell system must be ``accompanied by strong ratepayer and competitive safeguards. Today's action demonstrates that such safeguards actually exist, and that they are being efficiently administered and vigorously enforced.'' NYNEX has 30 days to answer the FCC's order, and company officials said they would state their case strongly. NYT and NET each were fined $709,500. NYNEX has revenues of about $12 billion annually. Richard Firestone, the FCC's chief telephone regulator, defended the size of the fine as ``the maximum penalty available under the rules.'' He said the companies were being penalized because ``We don't believe this was an inadvertent error in bookkeeping.'' NYNEX Chairman William Ferguson said the company welcomed the FCC audit so that NYNEX's arguments finally will be heard in a case that first was disclosed by the Boston Globe. But Ferguson said the FCC was incorrectly subjecting NYNEX to rules that were established in 1977 for AT&T and its affiliate, the Western Electric Co. Ferguson also maintained that NYNEX had scrupulously followed 1987 FCC bookkeeping safeguards designed to prevent cost-shifting to non-regulated affiliates and that NYNEX had agreed with New York state regulators to turn over ownership of MECO to the two phone companies. ``My overriding concern is our customers and the good faith of our customers, because certainly there has been no intention to overcharge,'' Ferguson said. New York state regulators and New York Telephone officials recently reached a settlement under which NYT would reduce a $900 million rate hike request to a $367 million cut this year and an increase of $445 million in 1991, with another $20 million to be used to make up for any overcharges by MECO. As part of the agreement, state officials would end their investigation of NYNEX and MECO. A New York judge on Tuesday rejected the settlement as being inadequate. Thursday's FCC order was based on the findings of a routine audit initiated during 1988. Firestone said audit would have taken place despite the the Boston Globe reports, but that the news stories did cause FCC auditors to shift their attack. ``The bureau audit focused on compliance with the affiliate transaction rules and policies, which are designed to protect rate-payers and competition from harmful cross-subsidies,'' the FCC said. The rules provide that when a regulated telephone company such as NYT or NET purchases supplies or services from an affiliated company, the telephone company may recover from rate-payers no more than the cost that would have been incurred in an ``arms length'' transaction. The FCC said the three companies engaged in a series of transactions between 1984 and 1988 designed to increase the overall profits of their parent company, NYNEX Corp., at rate-payer expense. The FCC said its audit revealed that NYT and NET purchased equipment, supplies and services from MECO at prices that were inflated by $118.5 million. Approximately $35 million of these inflated costs were passed along to interstate rate-payers, the FCC said. Firestone said about 97 percent of MECO's business was with NYNEX. Thursday's action will not affect local telephone rates for NYT and NET customers. Any refunds would have to be made through a reduction in the fees long-distance carriers such as AT&T pay to connect with the local telephone company networks. When the long-distance companies pay lower ``access fees,'' they must pass those savings along to customers.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Hail Communist Party Decisions; Still Skeptical About Change
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Muscovites on Thursday hailed the Communist Party's decision to end its political monopoly, but many wondered whether the party will truly allow a multiparty democracy and abandon seven decades of repressive rule. ``Everything will depend on whether people are ready to exert pressure,'' said Vladimir A. Tikhonov, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies. The congress, which is the national parliament, will pass final judgment on the proposal to remove the constitutional article giving the Communists an exclusive claim to power. Many people who crowded onto Pushkin Square, the Soviet version of Speaker's Corner in London, predicted a battle for power and threw their support behind fledgling opposition groups. As they have daily, dozens huddled in front of the offices of Moscow News, one of the most progressive Soviet newspapers, to talk politics. But on Thursday, their chats were enlivened by the three-day meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, which ended Wednesday by recommending creation of a Western-style presidency and popular elections of Communist leaders. The party daily Pravda splashed news of the Central Committee meeting on its front page Thursday, as it had done the three preceding days, but did not publish the most crucial document, the platform outlining steps toward democracy. The newspaper carried five pages of speeches at the meeting. Many people interviewed said they fear the Congress of People's Deputies will reject the party's recommendations because the congress is dominated by hard-liners. Peddlers on Pushkin Square, the home of the first McDonald's in the Soviet Union and a hotspot for political demonstrations, sold newspapers published by fledgling political groups such as the People's Front of the Baltic republic of Latvia, part of the movement for democracy that could get a boost from the Central Committee decision. One salesman sold a newspaper with two images side-by-side of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, one showing him in a trilby hat and the other an American baseball cap. People crowded three-deep to read papers tacked onto the gray stone walls of the Moscow News building. One was a 35-page document titled, ``The Mafia and Perestroika,'' and another was a transcript of a speech by populist legislator Boris N. Yeltsin. One woman, Ludmilla Frolova, wore a Yeltsin button with a picture of the maverick Communist and the slogan, ``The Mind, Conscience of the People.'' The crowds wondered whether anything would really change in a country that has fallen behind the tide of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe. ``The party started out as the initiator of perestroika but has become a braking force,'' one man said. Another man said the ``people have matured'' but the first chimed in: ``The people haven't matured yet. If they had, it would be like Romania or East Germany.'' Others said they were pinning their hopes for change on Democratic Platform, a group of Communists fighting for radical changes in the party and government. They predicted the Communist Party would become just one of many competing for power and the people's support, but they worried the party could dash opponents' efforts through its control of paper distribution and other tools of democracy. A 63-year-old woman who lived through the repressions of dictator Josef Stalin and stagnation of Leonid I. Brezhnev said she was ready to fight for democracy. ``We should boycott the elections or cross out all the names on the ballots, because they're all apparatchiks,'' said the woman, her silver teeth shining in the afternoon sun. Russians go to the polls March 4 to elect members of local governing councils, and many have expressed concern the party is not allowing progressives to run. ``This year will be a real battle,'' one man predicted. A woman said a huge rally and march by progressive groups in Moscow last Sunday was only the beginning of the battle. ``On the fourth we almost took the Kremlin. On the 25th, we will take the Kremlin,'' she said. Nationwide pro-democracy protests are planned Feb. 25.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: President Bush saluted his childhood hometown on its 350th birthday, saying it gave him a ``strong foundation and values'' as sturdy as the trees that grow there. ``I am pleased to send my warmest greetings and congratulations to the people of Greenwich as you celebrate the 350th anniversary of the founding of this beautiful town,'' Bush wrote in a letter to Greenwich First Selectman John Margenot. Bush spent his childhood in the posh New York City suburb of 60,000, and his mother, Dorothy Bush, still lives here. ``The first real appreciation my brothers, sister, and I felt for this lovely, historic town came from the abundance of great old trees that we somehow knew were there just for us to climb,'' the president wrote. ``In Greenwich, we gained a strong foundation and values that were as sturdy and true as those great sheltering trees _ values that have served and guided us throughout our lives.'' Margenot said the letter will probably be framed and displayed at Town Hall, but the final details have not been arranged. According to Bush's letter, the town was founded in July 1640 when a group of settlers purchased some land from the Indians. It was the 10th town to be established in what is now Connecticut.

Spike Lee, creator of ``Do the Right Thing,'' says he's the only filmmaker criticized for not showing drugs in his movies. Critics complained that his 1989 film dealing with race relations in New York City was unrealistic because the streets were clean and the characters weren't shown using drugs, Lee told an audience at the University of Rochester on Wednesday night. ``Drugs are not the unique domain of black people,'' Lee said. Lee said black people have to make their own movies to be in control of their own image. ``Blacks know a lot about the white world, because we're a minority living in it,'' he said. ``But whites don't know anything about black culture. What blacks does Steven Spielberg know? Quincy Jones? Michael Jackson? Maybe Prince? They aren't regular black people. ``Hollywood is a closed community and they're out of touch.''

Paul McCartney takes his concert tour to the University of California's 60,000-seat Memorial Stadium next month, and the event will mark the first time the stadium is used for a rock concert. The former Beatle last appeared in the Bay area in 1976, with his post-Beatles group, Wings, at the Cow Palace. McCartney's March 31 concert in Berkeley was announced Wednesday. McCartney is on his first North American tour in 13 years. University officials said a portion of the rental fee for the concert will be used to help Berkeley's homeless and other charities. The university has a long-standing agreement with the neighborhood to use the football stadium only for university events, but there have been exceptions, such as a few Oakland Raiders football games in the 1970s.

Rudolf Nureyev's successor as director of the Paris Opera Ballet Company was named Thursday. He's Patrick Dupond, one of France's most popular classical dancers. The Soviet-born Nureyev resigned from the post last fall because of growing dissatisfaction with his long-distance direction of the company and his many commitments outside France. Dupond, 30, was a lead dancer with the company until 1988 when he left to direct the Nancy French Ballet, leading that company to critical and commercial success. Dupond's appointment was announced by Culture Minister Jack Lang. Admired for his good looks, grace, athleticism and acting ability, Dupond is regarded as a performer's performer, inspiring leading choreographers to create compositions especially for him. Nureyev is currently starring in an American production of ``The King and I,'' playing the role of the King of Siam immortalized by Yul Brynner.

The Oak Ridge Boys, whose hits include ``Thank God For Kids,'' got a thank you themselves from the state's lawmakers. The Legislature passed a resolution Wednesday commending the country music stars for their success and for their charitable work. The four band members appeared on the House floor to accept the award, and lead singer Joe Bonsall thanked the House members. He said the band loved the state and ``always felt like we should give a little back.'' The resolution cited the band's two platinum and nine gold albums and praised their service as national spokesmen for the National Committee for Prevention of Child Abuse and the Boy Scouts of America, as well as for the Tennessee Department of Transportation's ``Adopt-A-Highway'' program. Other hits by the Oak Ridge Boys are ``Elvira'' and ``Bobby Sue.''

Soul singer James Brown, who has been in prison for more than a year, is now eligible to participate in a work-release program. A judge in Georgia altered his jail sentence on Wednesday, making him immediately eligible for a work-release program in South Carolina, where he is serving a 6{-year sentence. To qualify for the program, an inmate must be no more than two years away from a parole date. Brown, 56, was arrested in 1988, after leading police on a chase from Augusta, Ga., into South Carolina and back to Georgia. He is serving concurrent terms in each state for assault and eluding police officers. He also was convicted on weapons charges in Georgia. In South Carolina, he could have been paroled in May 1991, said South Carolina Department of Corrections spokesman Francis X. Archibald. But in Georgia, the date for parole was March 1992. Without Wednesday's order, Brown would have been eligible to enter the work-release program March 7. Once the order is received in South Carolina, Archibald said officials will ask the singer if he wants to participate at one of seven work-release centers in the state.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Home Builders,350
Builders May Face Recession
DOC.TEXT: The home-building industry may be approaching a recession because of rising interest rates, a sluggish economy and the dampening effects on loans from the savings and loan bailout law, the president of the National Association of Home Builders said Thursday. ``What looked like a flat year a month ago has taken a turn for the worse,'' Martin Perlman said at a news conference. ``We're skating on very thin ice. We may be getting terribly close to a housing recession.'' Perlman, a Houston builder, noted that mortgage interest rates returned to double-digit levels last month after dropping into the single digits in the last half of 1989 and spurring a brief rebound in housing starts. Because of the weakness in last year's construction, Home Builders chief economist David Seiders has changed the organization's forecast for housing starts from 1.44 million in 1990 to 1.38 million. But Perlman said Thursday that the rise in rates, combined with continued economic slugishness, declining consumer confidence and the difficulty in getting building loans, may force the Home Builders to lower that projection even further. Perlman urged Congress on Wednesday to change that part of the thrift bailout law that reduces the amount a savings and loan can lend to one borrower from 100 percent to 15 percent. That section and a second provision requiring thrifts to hold more of their capital in reserve have choked off funds from many builders, he said. Perlman said builders at the organization's convention in Atlanta last month told in a survey of curtailing construction projects after getting word that their S&Ls were reducing the amount of money it could lend them. ``For every 100,000 drop in housing starts, there is a loss of 176,000 jobs, $4.6 billion in wages, $1.55 billion in federal, state and local income taxes and $160 million in local property taxes,'' he said about the ripple effect. That ripple effect also extends to other industries related to housing, such as home furnishings, he said.

Telephone Companies Assessed Record Fine
