DOC.HEAD: AM-SAfrica-Jackson,0745
U.S. Civil Rights Leader Visits South African Township
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
LaserPhoto JOH8
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told hundreds of people in this impoverished black township Thursday that their struggle to win civil rights from the white-led government has inspired hope around the world. Touring Soweto on the second day of his visit to South Africa, the black U.S. civil rights leader walked down streets of ramshackle squatters' huts, stopped at a day-care center, visited the home of African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu and spoke at a meeting of township teachers. At the Orlando Home and Creche, a day-care center for Soweto children, Jackson took preschool children on his knee and posed for pictures under a banner reading, ``Welcome Baba Jesse Jackson ... We love you very, very much.'' ``Baba,'' or father, is a term of respect. Earlier, echoing speeches he made on the campaign trail during the 1988 presidential race, Jackson roared to youths gathered outside Sisulu's home: ``Keep your head high! Keep hope alive!'' Sisulu had Jackson for tea at the white-washed stucco house he returned to in October after 25 years in prison. An ANC flag fluttered on a swaying staff over the house. Outside, a crowd of 100 people sang and chanted. Jackson, emerging arm in arm with Sisulu, cheerfully joined in the dancing, then stood quietly as Sisulu led the singing of ``God Bless Africa,'' the hymn black nationalists hope will one day become South Africa's national anthem. ``You've inspired hope around the world,'' Jackson declared. ``It's so good to see you express your will to be free, and to see you determined to put hope in your heart and hope in your brains, and not dope in your veins.'' Jackson began his visit to Soweto, home to 2.5 million blacks, at the Funda cultural center on its outskirts. After greeting local dignitaries, Jackson, Sisulu and the Rev. Frank Chikane, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, attended a meeting of 2,000 township teachers. ``Right here in Soweto, every morning now, you're teaching a potential president of a new South Africa,'' Jackson said to shouts of ``Viva!'' from the audience. Later, Chikane led Jackson on a driving and walking tour that took him through some of the township's most crowded squatter areas. Scores of children gathered to shake Jackson's hand and hold onto the cuffs of his suit. A horsecart halted briefly to let Jackson and the entourage of aides and journalists pass. Jackson stopped briefly at the home of Ada Muswange, 47, who shares her tiny corrugated-metal shack with two other family members. As a kettle boiled on an iron stove, Sisulu acted as translator as Jackson chatted with her about the difficulties of keeping her family together. Jackson is on a 12-day visit to South Africa, which he said is aimed at encouraging unity among black factions and dispelling white fears. His trip to Soweto was not shown on television newscasts Thursday night, although his arrival in South Africa was covered Wednesday. The biggest daily, the Johannesburg Star, ran an editorial cartoon portraying Jackson as a song and dance man in front of a cell containing Mandela, with a director saying in the caption, ``Thank you, but we don't need any extras in this scene.'' Other newspapers carried matter-of-fact stories on inside pages on his arrival, except The Sowetan, which carried his picture and story on its front page. Walking along the muddy rows between intermittent rain showers, Jackson was asked if Soweto had changed since 1979, when he last visited. ``There are a lot more people, and there are some new houses,'' Jackson replied. ``But no one in Soweto yet has the right to vote. No one yet is empowered to help determine fairly the resources of the country. ``Even when Nelson Mandela leaves jail, he will not be free ... He will not be able to live in the community of his choice. He will not be able to send his grandchildren to the school of their choice,'' Jackson said of the ANC leader, who is expected to be freed soon from his life prison term. Mandela has said he will return to the small house he has rented in Soweto for 40 years when he is released.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Bombs Found,0398
FBI Investigates Arrest Of Georgia Man in Pennsylvania
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is investigating the discovery of homemade bombs in a Georgia businessman's car to see if he is linked to any bombings in the United States, an FBI spokesman said Thursday. Police found the bombs Sunday while searching a car being driven by Dean B. Hileman of Valdosta, Ga., where he operates S.O.S. Salvage. Police said they stopped Hileman, orginally from the Ford City area, because he was driving in the wrong direction on a one-way street in the town about 45 miles from Pittsburgh. Hileman had seven bombs in his car, several handguns, a sword, two knives and a slingshot, said Police Chief Jan Lysakowski. Hileman was charged Sunday with carrying prohibited offensive weapons and firearms without a license, driving under the influence of alcohol, and possession of a controlled substance, Lysakowski said. He was being held in lieu of $100,000 bail. FBI agent Jeff Kimball in Pittsburgh said the devices went sent to a lab at FBI headquarters to be examined to see if there is any connection with other cases under investigation. Those cases, Kimball said, include the December mail bombings that killed U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance in Birmingham, Ala., and City Councilman Robert Robinson in Savannah, Ga. ``I don't know for sure whether they will compare the evidence against those cases,'' he said. ``It's a logical assumption.'' However, Lysakowski said he has no evidence linking Hileman with the December mail bombings. ``We don't believe there is a link,'' he said. ``We have nothing to indicate that.'' The bombs in Hileman's possession, 3-inch cylinders full of black powder with fuses attached, were not the same type used in the Southeast bombings, the police chief said. In Lowndes County, Ga., Sheriff G. Robert Carter said Hileman has no criminal record in that area. Ed Hileman of Valdosta, Dean's brother, told The Valdosta Daily Times the explosives and some of the other items were used in the salvage business, and added, ``you've just got to know Dean.'' He said his brother uses the explosives to loosen beaver dams and tree stumps and ``to knock things loose so he can do his job.'' He said some of the weapons were used for protection, while others were collector's items.

DOC.HEAD: State Withdraws Appeal on Leg Amputation Case
DOC.TEXT: The state Thursday dropped its effort to force an 84-year-old woman to have a gangrenous foot amputated, but the woman's family pleaded with a judge to order her to have the lifesaving operation. Israeli liberals hailed Thursday's outcome as a victory in the right-to-die issue, because the court refrained from imposing unwanted medical treatment on Ruth Trabelsi. Offspring of Mrs. Trabelsi argued bitterly over what to do next, and Rabbi Mordechai Eliahu, spirititual leader of Jews of Middle Eastern and North African origin, said he would try to change her mind. ``From the standpoint of Jewish law, she should accept the treatment to save her life,'' Eliahu said. Doctors at Poriah Hospital in the northern Galilee town of Tiberias want Mrs. Trabelsi's right leg amputed above the knee to avoid the spread of gangrene, which set in as a complication from hardening of the arteries and blood clottings. Mrs. Trabelsi has refused to have the operation, saying she wants ``to enter the Garden of Eden with both feet.'' The Israeli Welfare Ministry took the case to court Wednesday under a 1966 law ordering the protection of citizens who may not be responsible for themselves. It withdrew its appeal Thursday after geriatric specialist Leon Spalter testified during a hearing that Mrs. Travelsi was ``lucid and fully capable of making an organized decision.'' ``If you have withdrawn the request, then I have no reason to interfere,'' Judge Oded Gershon said. This touched off a tearful courtroom argument among some of Mrs. Trabelsi's 258, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren who are divided over whether she should be forced to have the surgery. Shalom Trabelsi, the woman's youngest son, wept and tried to persuade the judge to force the operation. ``Please, the rabbis have already said she must have the operation. We are only waiting for you to say so. Please do it,'' he said Another son, Eliahu Trabelsi, disagreed. ``Our tradition says, `ask your elders.' We have to respect what our elders say.'' Haim Cohen, a retired supreme court justice and former civil rights activist, praised the outcome on Israel radio, saying it upheld past rulings ``that you do not conduct a medical operation without a patient's consent.'' Relatives pursued their argument in a shouting match at the hospital after the court session, Israel radio reported. ``We have never had such a problem before,'' Poriah's chief surgeon, Dr. Amos Mazor, said on the radio. He said he would seek advice from the Health Ministry's legal department about what to do next. Hospital director Yaacov Farbstein said in a telephone interview that without Mrs. Trabelsi's consent, her leg would be left alone. ``We cannot force her to the operating room. We will just try to treat her as best we can.'' Farbstein added that without the amputation, Mrs. Trabelsi was likely to die of spreading infection from the gangrene, but he would not estimate how long she had to live. Farbstein suggested that the delay in amputation has already complicated her condition. On Wednesday, doctors were recommending that only her foot be amputated, but they said Thursday that removal of the leg to above the knee was required.

DOC.HEAD: US Concerned About Terrorism By Pro-Iranian Militants
DOC.TEXT: The United States is concerned about the possibility of a terrorist attack against Americans or U.S. facilities somewhere in Europe this weekend by pro-Iranian militants, the State Department said Thursday. But deputy spokesman Richard Boucher had no specific information about the alleged threat and said the U.S. government was not urging Americans to cancel travel plans to Europe. Instead, travelers are encouraged to be alert to any danger, he said. Other officials said threat advisory messages have been sent in recent days to U.S. diplomatic posts in Europe and the Middle East. Boucher said the U.S. concern is linked to the 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran this Sunday. Officials have said that Iran has established a far-flung terrorist network targeted at American and West European interests, especially civil aviation. But officials said Thursday that they had no details on what type of U.S. facility might be a terrorist target this weekend. The spokesman recalled that a threat advisory was issued in December and said that threat continues. The statement issued two months ago warned of the possibility of an attack against an American or Western European target but Thursday's announcement spoke only of ``U.S. interests'' being possible targets. The December statement said the concern in December was based partly on reports of movement of terrorists from the Middle East and on the discovery of weapons shipments destined for pro-Iranian groups in Spain and Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Fear Monetary Union Could Harm West German Prosperity
DOC.TEXT: Rather than calming fears of economic collapse in East Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's advocacy of one currency for East and West Germany has created worries about continued prosperity at home. Economists and investors have reacted negatively to Kohl's proposal for swift introduction of the West German mark in East Germany, whose own mark is not convertible. Some accuse him of trying to boost his chances in the December elections. Fear that taking over the East's nearly bankrupt system would endanger the West German economy drove bond prices down Thursday for the third straight day. The mark has dropped two pfennigs against the weak U.S. dollar in two days. Kohl said Wednesday a Cabinet committee was drafting plans for union with East Germany, including a common currency. By making the strong Deutschmark the official currency of East Germany in return for free-market reforms, the worries go, Bonn would in effect be taking on the economic woes of its eastern brothers and distributing them among prosperous West Germans through higher taxes. More marks would have to be printed, adding to the money supply and forcing interest rates up. Higher rates would slow the West German investment boom that is supposed to bankroll the eastern bailout. Experts see monetary union as a necessary step toward East Germany's economic recovery and eventual integration with West Germany in a single state. Central bank president Karl Otto Poehl and others, however, feel transition to a convertible currency for East Germany must be gradual, a companion of economic reform rather than its catalyst. Providing East Germans with a currency of value before they have anything at home to buy might even make the economic imbalance between the two countries worse, economists contend. ``Without that economy being given a chance to acquire a more efficient status, currency union would just mean having bad money drag down good money,'' Liane Launhardt, a senior economist with Commerzbank in Frankfurt, told The Associated Press. She accused Kohl of ``irresponsible'' electioneering in proposing swift conversion, of ``saying what he thinks the people want to hear.'' East Germany's economic disaster has become a West German problem even without monetary union because huge numbers of East German emigres strain social services, job markets and the public's patience. Finance Minister Theo Waigel acknowledged that speedier efforts toward monetary union were intended to give East Germans confidence in their future. ``This is a signal, an appeal,'' he told reporters. ``The people of East Germany must know we are ready to take a decisive step toward the unity of Germany.'' A source in Kohl's Christian Democratic Union said the chancellor was trying to avoid further political damage from the influx of East Germans. About 340,000 moved West last year and the pace this year hovers around 2,000 a day, accelerating the economic decline in their homeland. Industrial output in East Germany and the availability of even basic goods have plummeted in recent weeks. Waigel would not predict when the Deutschmark would replace the East German currency, or what such a major step toward reunification would cost West Grmany. Helmut Geiger, president of the Savings Banks Association, said monetary union would cost ``a sizable double-digit billion-mark sum.'' Ten billion marks equals more than $6 billion. Government sources indicated privately that Kohl's administration recognizes the probable hardships for West Germans of the transition period. Sudden application of capitalist economics to East Germany would compel the closing of inefficient factories, resulting in widespread layoffs. An internal Finance Ministry paper shown to reporters predicts 1.4 million jobless in a few months, or more than 15 percent of the working population. West Germany would have to provide unemployment benefits to carry those affected through retraining and job placement, probably forcing higher taxes in a nation with 8.5 percent unemployment of its own. Economists at West Germany's leading financial institutes say conversion to a market economy must be well under way for such a plan as Kohl's to work. ``If you export a hard currency to a country that doesn't have a strong economy, then it will no longer be a hard currency,'' said Heiner Flassbeck, an economist with the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin. The financial impact on West Germany will depend primarily on the conversion rate fixed for the Deutschmark and the East German currency, which the Berlin institute believes should be at least 1 to 3. ``If West Germany takes over East Germany at a bad price, then the market value of the federal republic drops as well,'' said Reinhard Pohl, an economist with the institute. Premature introduction of the Deutschmark would encourage more spending by East Germans outside their country, which would make the economic decline worse and might force a hasty takeover by West Germany. In a report issued Wednesday, the institute said ``considerable illusions'' among people in both Germanys cloud prospects for successful monetary union.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Science-Technology World Dominance Lagging, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: The United States still leads the world in science and technology but no longer dominates as it once did, according to a National Science Foundation report released Thursday. A national weakness has developed in science and engineering education, in production of high-tech goods and in research and development funding, the report said. Mary L. Good, chairwoman of the National Science Board, a foundation group that produced the report, said cooperative action between government, industry and academia is required if the United States is to maintain its leadership position. The report said: _Growth rates have slowed in both research and development and in the training of scientists and engineers. _Science and mathematics education in U.S. schools has shown little improvement despite major reform efforts. _Fewer college and university freshmen are choosing science and mathematics fields, which means there will be fewer degrees in technical fields in the coming years. _The number of foreign students earning advanced degrees in U.S. schools continues to increase while the number of advanced degrees to Americans continues to decline. _The U.S. growth in research and development was 6 percent annually from 1975 to 1985, but slowed to 2 percent annually from 1986 to 1989. _The United States spends more on research and development than the United Kingdom, Japan, France and West Germany combined, but Japan and West Germany spend a greater portion of their gross national product on research and development than the United States. ``While the U.S. continues to be the world's foremost supplier of high-tech products, its lead is shrinking,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Slugged Senator Found Innocent By Reason Of Insanity
DOC.TEXT: The man who slugged Sen. John Glenn during a television interview was found innocent by reason of insanity Thursday and ordered to undergo treatment for ``severe mental illness.'' U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson ordered Michael Breen, 31, of Washington, to remain in an in-patient psychiatric hospital until he can prove in court that he does not pose a risk to others. In October, Breen encountered the Ohio senator at an outdoor television interview, lunged at him from the side and landed a solid right to the jaw. Aside from redness and a few days of soreness, Glenn, a 68-year-old ex-Marine, was unharmed. Defense attorney Philip Inglima acknowledged that Breen hit Glenn last Oct. 25. The altercation was taped by a television camera and broadcast nationwide. According to the criminal complaint filed against him, Breen told police he was trying to get the attention of Pope John Paul II and prevent a nuclear war. A day earlier, Breen had been detained by U.S. Capitol Police and the Secret Service after breaking through a police line and trying to reach out to Vice President Dan Quayle's motorcade, authorities said. Breen also ``had sought President Bush at the Federal Emergency Management Agency'' a week earlier, Assistant U.S. Attorney Craig Iscoe told the court. Breen was responding to instructions he received in dreams, the attorney said. At Inglima's request, the judge sealed the records containing Breen's psychiatric report, an action that moved Breen's mother to tears. Breen had been an engineer with Martin Marietta Corp. and showed no signs of mental problems until the dreams began in December 1988, according to the court record. District of Columbia police Detective Tom Johnson said Breen told him he was trying to get publicity that would attract the pope's attention and lead the pontiff to reveal a heavenly message some Roman Catholics believe has been kept secret by the Vatican for 72 years. ``The defendant stated that he wanted the notoriety of the event to get the Pope to read the Fatima message to prevent a nuclear war,'' Johnson said in a sworn statement. Breen told the detective he'd been having dreams for about 10 months in which God gave him information about ``possible future disasters,'' and that he feared the San Francisco earthquake on Oct. 17 could have triggered a nuclear war. The original charge against Breen was a felony carrying a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $10,000 fine. That charge was dropped Thursday and Breen entered his plea on a misdemeanor charge.

DOC.HEAD: Fake-Ticket Scam Derailed on NY Suburban Railway
DOC.TEXT: A corporate lawyer who lost his cool when a conducter screen his railroad pass has led to an investigation that nabbed 12 people _ including high-salaried executives _ with counterfeit tickets, police said Thursday. ``It's certainly surprising that people in those positions would risk their careers and good names to save $100 on a commutation ticket,'' said Dan Brucker, spokesman for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The names of those arrested have not been released, but Brucker said that besides the corporate attorney, one is the vice president of an insurance company and several are thought to be earning six-figure salaries. Brucker said he couldn't give out the names of those arrested because disclosure could hamper the continuing investigation. The railroad links New York City to its northern suburbs in New York state and Connecticut, including some of the most expensive towns in the region. Brucker said the average monthly ticket costs $120, and the counterfeits generally sold for half of face value. Usually, riders with passes simply flash the tickets at the conductor as he walks through the train. But on occasion, tickets are checked more closely. Brucker said that on one such day in December, ``A corporate attorney had made himself a counterfeit and he was so nervous and jittery when presenting the ticket the conductor became suspicious.'' The conductor notified police and the attorney was arrested when the train reached Grand Central Terminal. Since then, 11 others have been caught using phony monthly and weekly tickets. Metro-North police Chief Gerald Hotopp said charges range from the misdemeanors theft of services and larceny, to forgery and criminal possession of a forged instrument, felonies that carry prison terms of up to 15 years. In all but one case, the commuter spent the night in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Ready to Put Axe to Bush Budget Priorities
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats seem near a consensus that they can slice $4 billion to $7 billion or more out of President Bush's 1991 defense budget, fight off Bush-recommended cuts in some domestic programs and limit next year's deficit to $64 billion. They also believe they might be able to find a bit of start-up money for domestic initiatives in such areas as education, child care and nutrition. But even as they solidify their plans for reworking the $1.23 trillion spending plan Bush unveiled last week, Democrats are still groping for an approach to one of this year's hottest issues: whether to cut the Social Security payroll tax. Questions are also arising over whether Congress' majority party can successfully write its own budget without Republican support. An offbeat but still striking illustration of the Democrats' desire to alter Bush's budget came Thursday when Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee, brandished a mock Viking battle axe during a visit to the panel by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``I'm afraid that's the mood of what we're going to have to put up with the rest of this year, because from what I'm hearing from members themselves, Republicans and Democrats, they expect a peace dividend,'' said Murtha, a moderate Democrat. ``Peace dividend'' refers to possible savings from cutting back the military in response to a reduced from the Soviet Union and its allies. Democrats pressed their offensive on other fronts as well. At the Joint Economic Committee, Chairman Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., challenged Bush's claim of having submitted a budget that met his campaign pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``In the budget, you submitted 33 revenue changes and 20 of them raise revenue, totaling an increase of $13.9 billion,'' Hamilton told Bush's chief economic adviser, Michael Boskin. Boskin argued that there were only minor tax increases, and that most of the receipts would come from new and higher fees for government services. And on the defense front, House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., accused the administration of using strategic arms talks with the Soviets to win permission to deploy weapons Congress does not want, including nuclear missiles and a bomber such as the B-2. Such a position by the administration is ``out of sync'' with Congress' preferences, Aspin said. Liberal Democratic lawmakers have been complaining that Bush should have cut far deeper than his $303.3 billion defense proposal for next year. That figure is $7 billion higher than this year's total, but $3.2 billion below the amount that would likely be needed to stay even with inflation. Liberals would like to see defense spending drop below the $290 billion level. But moderates such as House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., say they believe the figure will end up closer to the $296 billion to $299 billion range _ $4 billion to $7 billion below Bush's proposal. Panetta's Senate counterpart, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., has talked about military spending in the $291 billion to $296 billion range. Such figures would allow Democrats to shield the Medicare program for the elderly and handicapped, retirement payments to government workers and other benefit programs from most of the $13.9 billion in cuts that Bush has proposed. ``We're looking at much less savings there,'' Panetta said Thursday. To hit the $64 billion deficit target required next year by the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law, Democrats say they will seek to raise the $21 billion Bush proposed in new tax receipts, user fees, sales of federal assets and other collections. They also say they will seek to change some of the components of that mix. Democrats believe enough room will be left in the budget for some new domestic initiatives, a list of which party leaders are drawing up. According to Panetta, that list is likely to include education, child care, nutrition, health care and housing. Little of the money for those would be included in the 1991 budget. Not everyone believes Democrats can piece together a budget of their own that can be passed by the Senate and House. ``I don't think they can make a budget serving the constituencies they want to serve without putting new taxes in, and they don't want to be the ones leading the way on that,'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, predicted Thursday. ``My guess is after internal discussions, they'll decide to request negotiations with the administration.'' Democrats also still don't know what to do about a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security payroll tax, a levy that is raising so much money that it is shrinking the official size of the overall federal deficit by about $60 billion this year. A team of top Democrats are trying to draft a unified party position on the proposal, which has one major problem: It would add $62 billion to the budget gap over the next two years. ``We're thrashing around a number of different options,'' said Panetta, a member of the group, which hopes to finish its work by late February.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Releases Panama Attack Video
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Thursday released 12 minutes of dramatic videotape of the air assault on the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Force showing cannon fire blasting the buildings. The grainy blue-gray footage, taken during the post-midnight attack on Dec. 20, looks like a Fourth of July fireworks display, with white streams of tracer bullets spraying about and white flashes of explosives bursting around the buildings. Rounds from the AC-130 gunship carrying out the assault can be seen striking roofs and blowing out windows. Fires are visible in several structures after the attack. The four-engine turboprop AC-130 aircraft is armed with three kinds of weapons _ a 105mm howitzer, a 40mm Bofors cannon and a 20mm Vulcan cannon. The tape was made as the plane hovered a few hundred feet in the air pouring fire on various targets and snipers. The tape, made from footage retrieved from the gunship's own camera monitoring system, was released following requests made by television networks. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the pictures had been censored to remove sensitive information. While most of the footage portrays the attack on the Panamanian Defense Force's headquarters known as the Comandancia, it also shows a Panamanian armored personnel carrier taking a direct hit and an attack on a barracks, where a palm tree is toppled by hits from the 105mm cannon. Pentagon officials said the AC-130 gunship was chosen for its accuracy, and its ability to avoid damage to nearby buildings and U.S. troops in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl to Try to Allay Soviet Fears As Reunification Pace Quickens
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl comments Thursday. Pickup 6th pvs, ``Kohl and...
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will tell Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev this weekend that he need not worry about Soviet security interests as the Germanys move closer to reunification, officials said Thursday. Kohl plans to fly to Moscow on Saturday to discuss German reunification with Gorbachev. On Feb. 24, Kohl heads for Camp David for similar discussions with President Bush. The United States has voiced support for German reunification as long as it occurs in an orderly way and does not threaten European stability. But the Soviets, recalling the bitter experiences of World War II, continue to express reservations about the possibility of a unified German nation. Kohl said Thursday any fears the Germans intend to create a ``Fourth Reich'' are completely unfounded. In an interview with West Germany's ZDF television network, Kohl said he is committed to making Europe stronger through the process of reunification and hopes that in economic terms, the 1990s will ``be the decade of the Europeans, and not of the Japanese.'' Kohl will be accompanied by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher when he visits the Soviet Union on a mission to allay fears of a united Germany. ``Kohl and Genscher plan to assure the Soviet leadership in personal conversations that they are serious about their repeated assurances that Moscow's security interests will be taken into account during the process of uniting both German states,'' a government source in Bonn said. Kohl and Genscher also plan to assure Gorbachev and other Soviet officials that ``no one in the West wants to use the reform process in the former East bloc to gain political power or to extend the reach of NATO eastward,'' another government source said. The sources spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. East Germany has long been the Soviet Union's most important ally, as it is the Warsaw Pact's front-line country facing West Germany. If a united Germany became a NATO member, that would move the Western alliance much closer to the Soviet Union's frontiers. NATO has about 255,000 troops in West Germany, most of them Americans. More than 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany. Since the fall pro-democracy movement that ousted the hard-line Communist leadership in East Germany, there have been increased calls for the two German states to unite. The tempo picked up rapidly this week, with Kohl calling for the two countries to share a currency, and West Germany forming a select committee, headed by Kohl, to lay the groundwork for unity. The committee Thursday called for making Berlin the capital once Germany is united. Kohl on Wednesday urged immediate talks with East Germany on establishing the West German mark as the currency for both nations. Some financial experts have warned that doing this too quickly could weaken the West German mark. West Germany's main labor federation appealed to the federal government Thursday to make major economic reforms in East Germany a condition for introducing West Germany's mark there. In other developments Thursday, two members of a new committee formed to oversee the disbanding of East Germany's secret police force said there are still about 4,000 spies operating in the force's espionage wing. They also said the ``Stasi'' secret police kept files on 6 million East German citizens, more than a third of the country. Werner Fischer and Georg Boehm gave the previously unpublished figures at a news conference. The secret police force was ordered disbanded by the government that took over after the ouster of hard-line leader Erich Honecker. Under Honecker, the secret police were used to crush dissent.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Hike Consumer Debt 6 Percent in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $4.91 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in December, pushing total consumer debt up 6 percent for the year, the Federal Reserve said Thursday. The Fed said consumer credit in December advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 percent, up from November's revised 7.8 percent increase. The November gain originally had been reported to be 7.2 percent. But consumer debt rose in both months to its highest level since last February when it increased $5.38 billion. Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages. While credit was up 6 percent for the year, it still was a modest increase, said Sandra Shaber, an econmist with the Futures Group here. Debt rose 8.5 percent in 1988 and 7.5 percent in 1987. ``Nevertheless, it shows that consumer spending continues to grow modestly,'' she said. ``It's not collapsing'' despite the sluggish economy. The category of debt that includes credit cards jumped 24.5 percent in the month that included the bulk of holiday shopping. The hike was 17.5 percent in November, the last week of which has included holiday shopping in recent years. Total credit card debt outstanding rose $4.06 billion at an annual rate in December, compared with $2.86 billion increase in November. Ms. Shaber said that while unit sales were good during the holiday season, profits for many retailers were off because of the discounts they had to offer to lure purchasers. Auto loans rose a meager 1.1 percent to $259 million at an annual rate, down from 1.9 percent in November. Auto loans posted a 4.1 percent increase in October, but sales tapered off at year's end. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate slowed to a 3.3 percent increase, to $557 million, in December after rising 10 percent in November. Mobile home debt outstanding rose 1.9 percent to $35 million in December. These debts had declined for seven consecutive months until a one month gain in September. They fell 2.3 percent in October 19.9 percent and November. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of December totaling $717.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Proposes To Warsaw Pact: 195,000 Superpower Troops On Each Side
DOC.TEXT: NATO challenged the Warsaw Pact on Thursday to accept a U.S. proposal to remove hundreds of thousands of American and Soviet soldiers from central Europe, setting a regional ceiling of 195,000 troops for each superpower. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, pitching the plan at the 23-nation Conventional Forces in Europe negotiations, called for a mutual NATO-Warsaw Pact cap of 4,700 combat aircraft for central Europe, plus 500 air defense interceptors for each side. President Bush first proposed the reduced troop levels Jan. 31. It was approved Tuesday at NATO headquarters in Brussels by a high-level NATO task force. The 195,000 Soviet and American troop ceilings were down from the level of 275,000 that Bush proposed in May. There was no Soviet or Warsaw Pact reaction Thursday to the formal NATO presentation. Initial Soviet reaction after Bush made the proposal last week was generally favorable, but Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov complained the plan did not go far enough. ``We must continue to have as our goal no foreign troops on foreign soil,'' he said. In Brussels, a senior NATO official, who demanded anonymity said the West expected a response at a meeting next week of the two alliances in Ottawa, Canada. The ``Open Skies'' gathering there is officially being held to review a plan for unarmed reconnaisance flights over rival alliance territories, a proposal designed to reduce East-West tensions. The official also said the NATO allies agreed to narrow the definition of combat helicopters to focus on those equipped with anti-tank and air-to-air guided missile capability. The NATO proposal maintains the previous limit for combat helicopters of 1,900 for each side. Officials have previously said that both NATO and the Warsaw Pact agreed on the number but not on the definition of combat helicopters. With democratic reform in the Soviet bloc putting East-West relations at their best since the late 1940s, negotiators for both sides are under pressure to reach an agreement by year's end. The Soviets are also being pressured by some of their formal military allies, which are rapidly moving toward Western-style democracy. Hungary and Czechoslovakia have begun talks with the Soviets separate from the Vienna negotiations on pulling out Red Army contingents from their countries. While the Hungarians seek withdrawal of the approximately 50,000 Soviet troops in their country by 1991, Czechoslovakia wants all of the 75,000 Soviet troops on its soil out by the end of this year. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia also have announced troop cuts of their own. There appears to be growing sentiment within NATO that the Warsaw Pact is not the threat it used to be, and that some troop reductions should begin even before formal agreement at the Vienna talks. Belgium has said recently it is studying pulling some of its troops from West Germany. ``The 16 Western participants believe that the CFE negotiations must keep pace with the political changes now sweeping the European continent,'' said a NATO statement presented to reporters. ``One area where this is most relevant is manpower. ``To that end, we now propose that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union shall station more than 195,000 ground and air force personnel each within the area comprising the territory of Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Poland,'' said the statement. The Soviet Union has an estimated 565,000 troops stationed in Europe outside its borders, with well over 500,000 of them within the central zone. There are about 305,000 U.S. troops in Western Europe, with approximately 250,000 of those stationed in the area of application, according to Western estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Eased Rules Proposed for Wireless Cable Systems
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday proposed new regulations aimed at making it easier for wireless cable television systems to compete with their wired counterparts. The commission, which is bent on improving competition in a cable TV industry beset by complaints of rate increases and poor service, voted 4-0 to consider eliminating multiple ownership restrictions on microwave radio channels used by wireless cable systems, increase permissible power output, establish new interference requirements and improve wireless cable's access to underused frequencies. Those and other proposed changes, plus streamlined applications, would help wireless cable become ``a competitive spur to (wired) cable system operators,'' the FCC said. The commission's notice inviting public comment said ``most of the rules at issue were adopted in the infancy of the various services they govern and did not anticipate the potential of a wireless cable service to compete in today's multichannel video marketplace.'' Many existing rules, the FCC said, ``are now individually inappropriate and also are inconsistent from service to service.'' The FCC also said it would consider reallocating to wireless cable some frequencies now reserved for instructional television and other private services. FCC Commissioner Sherrie Marshall said the proposed changes were part of an ``effort to create a level playing field between'' wired and wireless cable. Wireless cable uses microwave radio, instead of coaxial cable, to reach its customers. Microwave radio beams signals from one point to another, unlike ordinary over-the-air broadcasting which spreads in all directions using longer wavelengths. These microwave links must be licensed by the FCC. Wireless cable systems usually combine standard TV broadcast receiving equipment with special microwave equipment to provide non-broadcast and broadcast signals to homes, schools, apartment buildings and businesses not wired for coaxial cable. Wireless cable systems claim they can't compete effectively with wired cable systems because they lack large channel capacity and because cable TV programmers such as Home Box Office refuse to give them programs at fair prices, accusations that HBO denies. Robert L. Schmidt, president of the Wireless Cable Association, said the commission's decision was a positive step ``toward assuring that wireless cable is a viable competitor.'' But Schmidt said the commission's actions did not address ``the fundamental problem impeding the wireless cable industry _ restricted availability of fairly priced programming.'' Schmidt said he hoped some of these problems would be resolved in two inquiries into the cable TV business the FCC is expected to finish by summer. In other actions Thursday, the commission voted 4-0 to: _Propose creation of an entry-level, ``communicator class'' of amateur radio license that would not require ham operators to know Morse code. The commission said it wanted to open amateur radio to young, technically oriented people who don't want to learn Morse code. _Streamline the application process for AM radio license applications and changes. _Propose additional channels for mobile-satellite radio services.

DOC.HEAD: Bermuda Sentences Man to Die in Three Murders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Alicka and Ayeisha correct
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of murdering his girlfriend and her two young daughters is due to be executed Feb. 21, Gov. Sir Desmond Langley announced in a statement Thursday. Langley said that by setting an execution date for Leroy Alvin Dunlop, 30, the matter now could be considered by Bermuda's Committee on the Prerogative of Mercy _ the governor's five-member advisory committee on capital punishment. The last execution in this British colony in the western Atlantic was on Dec. 2, 1977, when murderers Larry Tacklyn and Buck Burrows were hanged. Bermuda, 570 miles from the North Carolina coast, has about 60,000 residents. Britain abolished capital punishment in 1965 and Bermuda retains it only in first-degree murder cases. A referendum is to be held on the issue this year. A Supreme Court jury found Dunlop guilty on Jan. 9 of slitting the throats of Florita Jackson, 29, and her two daughters, Alicka, 8, and Ayeisha, 4, on July 10, 1988. Dunlop refused legal assistance and represented himself during the trial. The prosecution introduced eyewitness testimony, but Dunlop maintained his innocence throughout. He refused to appeal, leaving his fate in the governor's hands. As Queen Elizabeth's appointed representative here, Langley can intervene at any time to commute a death sentence to life imprisonment. He last exercised that right in March 1989 when he intervened to spare the life of murderer Troy Dean Shorter.

DOC.HEAD: Quayles Kick Off Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle joined his wife Marilyn on Thursday to kick off a $400,000 campaign to raise public awareness about preventing breast cancer, stating, ``It's not solely a woman's issue.'' The Quayles and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan announced they will participate in a June 16 five-kilometer run to raise money for breast cancer research and treatment. ``As terrible as this disease is, it is treatable through early detection,'' the vice president said at a news conference. Quayle joined the effort at the urging of his wife, whose mother died of breast cancer at age 56. ``When breast cancer kills 40,000 women each year, it becomes an issue for every family, every community, and yes, the nation becomes concerned,'' Quayle said. ``The health issue affects so many Americans that it is not solely a women's issue.'' ``We are committed to make a difference,'' he said. The Quayles will be chairmen of the June 16 ``Race for the Cure'' in Washington to raise money for breast cancer research and treatment. The fund-raising goal for the event is $400,000, with the money to go for low-cost mammograms for women in Washington and to support the Susan G. Komen Foundation which funds research, education and treatment of breast cancer. Sullivan and several members of Congress as well as celebrities Lynda Carter, Loni Anderson and Larry Hagman also will join the race. The Quayles plan to produce a series of public service announcements to raise public awareness about the importance of early detection, and Mrs. Quayle said her husband will make public appearances around the country to highlight cancer detection and treatment programs.

DOC.HEAD: Soo Gets Extra Hopper Cars
DOC.TEXT: The Soo Line Railroad has leased 500 covered hopper cars from the Canadian Pacific to help meet a severe U.S. grain car shortage in the Midwest, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Martin ``Buzz'' Fitzpatrick Jr., head of the department's Office of Transportation, said the Soo Line will operate the cars under a six-month lease and that the cars will add a carrying capacity of about 16.8 million bushels of grain. Fitzpatrick said his agency joined the Soo Line in petitioning the U.S. Customs Service to allow the company to bring in Canadian cars duty-free. He said the waiver was granted. ``Without it, the cost of using the Canadian cars would have been raised to a prohibitive level,'' he said. The cars are being transferred to the Soo Line at a border crossing near Noyes, Minn., Fitzpatrick said.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Makes First Loan to China Since Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank, the biggest source of aid to the Third World, announced Thursday its first loan to China since the communist government cracked down on the movement for democracy last June. Meeting behind closed doors, representatives of the 151 governments that own the bank approved a $30 million loan for relief from earthquakes that hit northern China in October. Barber B. Conable, the American who is president of the bank, did not ask for action at this session on $780 million worth of loans he had postponed in June. President Bush later asked that the loans be held up. China and India are the largest borrowers from the bank. As of July 1, it had lent China nearly $8.7 billion. A spokesman for the Treasury, speaking anonymously, said a U.S. representative on the Board of Executive Directors supported the loan on Thursday. He said he did not know who was sitting at the session for the United States. Its official member is E. Patrick Coady, a Treasury official. Officials of the bank said none of the 22 board members opposed the loan. The approval had been foreshadowed Wednesday when Conable put it on the program for Thursday's meeting. The United States is the biggest shareholder in the bank but does not completely control its decisions. The bank occasionally grants loans despite U.S. objections. Last Friday the U.S. Export-Import Bank signed an unannounced $9.75 million loan with the China National Offshore Oil Corporation. The federal agency is expected to announce a larger loan soon. The World Bank said its loan was granted Thursday through its International Development Association, a fund for the poorest countries to which the United States makes the largest contribution. For 10 years, China will pay only interest at less than 1 percent, and then will have an additional 20 years to repay the principal. At least 29 people were killed in the earthquakes, which came shortly after the one in San Francisco. The bank said 25,000 homes were destroyed in Shanxi and Hebei provinces. It is one of the world's poorest areas, where the bank estimates the average income at $89 a year.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Increase Slowing Overall, But Not for Some
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The number of new AIDS cases in the United States rose just 9 percent in 1989 _ the slowest increase ever _ but the disease is spreading faster among heterosexuals, newborns, women and Southerners, federal AIDS specialists reported Thursday. A total of 35,238 AIDS cases were reported in 1989 by the national Centers for Disease Control, compared with 32,196 reported during 1988. That 9 percent increase is easily the slowest since the spread of AIDS began in the early 1980s. For example, AIDS was up 34 percent in 1988 and 60 percent in 1987. ``This is somewhat of a continuing trend,'' said Dr. Ruth Berkelman, chief of AIDS surveillance for the Atlanta-based CDC. ``There has been a leveling in reported cases.'' The CDC also attempts to tabulate AIDS cases according to when they were first diagnosed. In the latest 12-month period of that survey (October 1988 through September 1989) the annual increase was similarly modest, a 14 percent rise over the preceding 12 months, the CDC said. The two tabulations differ somewhat in part because of case reporting delays, revisions in the standards for reporting of AIDS cases and other factors. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome cripples the immune system's ability to ward off life-threatening infections and illnesses. It is transmitted chiefly through blood and body fluids, most often through sexual contact or contaminated drug needles. Of the 35,238 new AIDS cases reported in 1989, 56 percent occurred among homosexual and bisexual males, as has been the case in previous years, the CDC said. But those cases among gay and bisexual men were up only 8 percent over 1988 levels, while heterosexual-contact cases _ just 4 percent of the total _ were up 27 percent compared with the previous year. ``Cases diagnosed among homosexual-bisexual men continued to increase, but not as rapidly as in previous years,'' the CDC said in its weekly report. ``I think the leveling off reflects both a reduction in the number of new infections among homosexual and bisexual men, and also the introduction of some effective therapies (such as the drug AZT) in 1987, delaying the onset of AIDS itself among infected persons,'' Ms. Berkelman said. In 1989, 547 cases of AIDS transmission from mothers to newborns were reported, up 17 percent from 1988. And while females made up just 3,931 of the 35,238 cases last year, that was an increase of 11 percent over 1988; the number of male AIDS cases last year was up 9 percent from the preceding year. Other larger proportional increases occurred in the South, up 22 percent over 1988; in population areas of less than 100,000, up 35 percent; and in areas of 100,000 to 500,000 people, up 32 percent. Among the regions, the South accounted for the largest proportion of AIDS cases reported in 1989, 31 percent, compared with 30 percent in the Northeast, 24 percent in the West and 10 percent in the Midwest. And the majority of cases _ 70 percent _ occurred in cities of a million people or more. The number of new AIDS cases among hemophilia patients actually dropped 5 percent in 1989, from 339 in 1988 to 321. And the cases associated with blood transfusions dropped 14 percent, from 935 to 808. Improved screening of blood donations since the AIDS epidemic began has reduced the danger from new transfusions and from the blood products used by hemophiliacs. ``But in IV (intravenous) drug users, we have not seen such optimism,'' Ms. Berkelman said. IV drug abusers still make up the second largest group of AIDS patients, and the 7,970 such cases in 1989 marked a 5 percent increase over '88. Nationwide, the CDC has reported 117,781 cases since AIDS reporting began in 1981. Sixty percent have occurred in homosexual or bisexual men, and 21 percent have occurred among IV drug abusers, with 7 percent among patients in both categories. AIDS has killed 70,313 of the 117,781 reported patients, or 60 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Prospects for Arms Cuts in Europe Brighten
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with more on Jewish settlers, U.S. quota, arms control detail
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union made headway Thursday toward new arms control agreements, and also considered a joint condemnation of Israel's resettlement of Jewish immigrants on the West Bank. A half-dozen senior U.S. officials made no mention of the Jewish settlers in a briefing summing up more than seven hours of talks between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. However, Gennady I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said, ``It is quite possible that as a result of the Soviet-American talks a common viewpoint will be expressed on this issue, condemning Israel's attempt to resettle immigrants on someone else's occupied territory,'' ``There are no differences between the United States and us on this issue,'' he said. A heavy influx of immigrants to Israel has been caused, in part, by the lowering of Soviet emigration barriers and by limits on how many Soviet Jews the United States is willing to take in. Gerasimov said the United States had informed the Soviet delegation the annual U.S. quota would be raised to 60,000 or 70,000. Currently 50,000 Soviet Jews are permitted to enter the United States as refugees annually. In the first four months of this fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, some 21,000 were admitted. The U.S. officials, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said Baker and Shevardnadze made progress toward treaties to curb long-range nuclear weapons, ground troops, tanks and combat aircraft in Europe, and to ban production of chemical weapons. Both Shevardnadze and Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Bessmertnykh echoed the positive U.S. appraisal. ``The discussion of the disarmament problem is proceeding very well,'' Shevardnadze told Tass, the Soviet news agency. Bessmertnykh, who specializes in U.S. relations, was quoted by Tass as saying both sides had presented new ideas, narrowing the gap between their positions. Gerasimov called the discussion ``very technical'' and said it would keep U.S. and Soviet experts busy through the night sorting the proposals out. Baker offered at least one concession that would permit the Soviets to exclude from a projected ceiling some of the combat aircraft they contend are defensive. The Soviets, meanwhile, dropped their demand for a provision that would allow them to scrap a long-range missile-reduction agreement if they determined U.S. antimissile defenses in space were illegal. But the U.S. official who reported the concession acknowledged that the treaty, which President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev intend to sign at their Washington summit meeting in June, would include a common escape clause. Either side could abandon the restrictions if it concluded the treaty did not serve its national interest. The separate briefings produced evidence of discord, too. Gerasimov said the United States still flatly refuses to consider reducing naval forces. And he said the Soviets would not sign the treaty if a dispute over sea-launched cruise missiles was not resolved. The Bush administration refuses to accept limitations on the weapons carried aboard nuclear submarines and surface ships. And when Baker expressed concern to Shevardnadze about published reports the Soviets were shipping late-model MiG-29 fighter bombers to Cuba the foreign minister brushed him aside. ``They made clear they have particular commitments'' to Cuba, a U.S. official said. ``The foreign minister stated his views very vigorously.'' The surprise of the second day of talks was the Soviet disclosure of a joint approach on Jewish settlements. Only about 1 percent to 2 percent of the Jews now emigrating to Israel in record numbers are settled on the land the Arabs lost in the 1967 Six-Day war. Overall, there are 70,000 Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza compared to an estimated 1.4 million to 1.75 million Palestinian Arabs. Still, the State Department, echoing Arab complaints, has denounced the settlement of more Jews in the territories as an obstacle to peace. On the arms control front, Shevardnadze registered general approval of Bush's proposal last week to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe to a maximum of 225,000 on each side, with no more than 195,000 in Central Europe. U.S. officials said they expected a more specific reply when Baker meets with Gorbachev on Friday. The Soviet leader has advanced even broader disarmament schemes of his own. The net result of the talks so far is that the superpowers' steadily more cooperative relationship apparently will not be inhibited by the Communist Party Central Committee meeting that was concluded after Baker's arrival here from Czechoslovakia Wednesday night. In fact, Shevardnadze said, ``It will mean that we have more elements of trust in our relationship. We simply cannot afford lowering our international activity.'' Shevardnadze broke away from the Central Committee meeting on Wednesday night for a 3{-hour session with Baker, filling in the U.S. secretary of state on the changes taken at the direction of Gorbachev. DOC.HEAD: NJ State Supreme Court Reprimands Justice for DWI Arrest
DOC.TEXT: A state Supreme Court justice arrested on drunken driving charges last year has been publicly reprimanded by his colleagues. Justice Robert L. Clifford, 65, the second-ranking member of the state's highest court, pleaded guilty to driving while intoxicated and refusing to submit to a Breathalyzer test after his car was stopped by police Oct. 12. ``We believe that any judge convicted of driving while intoxicated should be publicly reprimanded,'' the Supreme Court reprimand issued Wednesday states. It noted that the high court has resisted efforts to weaken the state's drunken driving laws. ``When a judge commits such an offense,'' the statement continued, ``the public's confidence in the judiciary is inevitably affected.'' The public reprimand was made by Clifford's fellow justices as a result of a recommendation made by the Advisory Committee on Judicial Conduct. One member of the committee said Clifford should be privately admonished in a letter, but the justices said they believe they have the power to reprimand one of their own members and the offense justified it. Clifford was ``treated in this matter precisely as any citizen would have been,'' the reprimand stated. ``No favors were asked, suggested or granted. The penalty was that almost invariably imposed for a first offense.'' Clifford would not comment on the reprimand Wednesday. In addition to the reprimand from his colleagues, a lower court had ordered Clifford to pay $615 in fines and court costs, give up his license fo a year, and attend 10 sessions of the state's program for counseling and educating drunken drivers. He could have received up to 30 days in jail.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Impairs Mental Performance Only When Other Symptoms Develop
With AM-CDC--AIDS, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: AIDS impairs mental performance only in people who also display other symptoms, suggesting those who are infected with the AIDS virus but otherwise healthy can hold jobs involving public safety, scientists said Thursday. The research is significant because it indicates that testing people for the AIDS virus can't predict whether the virus already has damaged their mental abilities, said Dr. Barbara Visscher, a co-author of the study and an epidemiologist at the University of California, Los Angeles. The results, released Thursday, were published in February's issue of the journal Neurology. The findings are part of a larger study of AIDS conducted by researchers at UCLA, Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Northwestern University in Chicago and the University of Pittsburgh. People who are infected by the AIDS virus _ human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV _ normally take several years before they develop symptoms and are diagnosed as having acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``The findings suggest that people who are infected with the HIV virus, but have no symptoms of AIDS, are perfectly capable of holding down jobs demanding cognitive (mental) performance and may assume responsibility for public safety,'' the university said in a summmary of the research. The new study involved 1,580 homosexual and bisexual men who were tested from 1986 through 1988 for speed of motor skills, attention and concentration, memory, manual dexterity and language skills. The men were divided into four groups: 769 men who weren't infected, 620 who were infected but had no symptoms, 107 who became infected during the course of the study but lacked symptoms, and 84 diagnosed with AIDS symptoms. The men with AIDS were most likely to fail the various tests, including those that measured manual dexterity and rapid problem solving requiring a physical response. But the researchers found no difference between the men who weren't infected and those who were infected but hadn't developed AIDS symptoms. Many AIDS patients suffer dementia, or a loss of intellectual skill, and other signs of nervous system impairment during the final stages of the deadly disease, but there was little previous evidence on when such changes started. ``This is the first time we have been able to document continuing normal cognitive (mental) function over a long period with a very large group of HIV-infected subjects,'' said Dr. Eric Miller, director of the study at UCLA.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Honor Cardinal Who Defied Stalinist Leadership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Government and church officials paid homage Thursday to Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty, whose defiance of Stalinist leaders 40 years ago made him a symbol of the conflict between Marxism and the church. ``The trial of the primate and those sentenced with him involved illegal means and was based on falsehood,'' said Matyas Szueros, Hungary's interim president. ``His political opponents sought to defeat him by illegal means. The lesson of his example teaches us that we need to bring about such a democratic society in which differences in opinion cannot lead to show trials, repression, incarceration (and) revenge.'' Mindszenty was sentenced to life in prison on trumped-up treason charges. He died in 1975. Thousands of Roman Catholic faithful gathered in the Basilica of Esztergom, seat of the nation's Catholic primate, for a Mass celebrated jointly by Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican secretary of state, and Cardinal Laszlo Paskai of Hungary. Casaroli arrived Wednesday on a five-day visit that is to include formal restoration of the relations Communists severed 45 years ago. Hungary, a leader in Soviet bloc reforms leading to democracy, will be the second Soviet bloc country to restore full diplomatic relations with the Vatican. Poland, the native land of Pope John Paul II, did so in July. After the Mass, Szueros and the church leaders unveiled a gold-etched plaque of black marble that said: ``Here lived and fought for the freedom of the Hungarian nation and the Church until his arrest on Dec. 26, 1948, Jozsef Mindszenty, Cardinal, Prince Primate, and Archbishop of Esztergom. On the 41st anniversary of his sentencing, the city of Esztergom creates a monument to him by renaming this square.'' The square, previously dedicated to Communist heroes, is just below the towering basilica and the site of the archbishop's palace and seminary. The 19th century basilica, on a hill overlooking the Danube where an 11th century church had stood, isa visible for miles. After the Mass, those who attended walked down the steep slopes to what was now Mindszenty Square. Older men and women had tears in their eyes as they sang the national anthem together with leaders of the Hungarian church. Hungary's chief prosecutor has concluded Mindszenty's trial was purely political and the Supreme Court is reviewing it. On Wednesday, the official news agency MTI said the chief prosecutor might reopen the case, with the possibility of a retrial and formal rehabilitation. As he pulled the white silk covering from the plaque on the seminary wall, Szueros said: ``Let this occasion be a symbolic event of national reconciliation. Let Cardinal Jozsef Mindszety take his proper place in Hungary's history.'' In a message read by Casaroli during the Mass, John Paul described Mindszenty as ``an example for the Catholic world'' who dedicated himself to the church ``with great passion.'' Mindszenty was arrested in 1948 and tried the following year. He was freed during the anti-Stalinist uprising of 1956, but a Soviet invasion crushed the revolt. The cardinal took refuge in the U.S. Embassy until 1971, when he left under an agreement worked out by the Vatican and the Hungarian government. After a short stay in Rome, Mindszenty settled in Vienna, where he died May 6, 1975, at age 83. Parliament passed a law Jan. 24 that separates church and state, ending state interference in church affairs, and grants all denominations full autonomy. Separate legislation legislation is planned on the return of confiscated church assets. Under pressure from the Stalinist leadership, Hungary's Catholic church surrendered its autonomy on Aug. 30, 1950. Cardinal Paskai and Premier Miklos Nemeth formally annulled the law Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: China Can Buy Another Million Tons Of U.S. Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has been authorized to buy an additional 1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department announced Thursday. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat will be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. The subsidies have averaged from around $10 per ton, to more than $40 per ton of wheat, or in the range of 27 cents to about $1.10 per bushel. China bought 299,150 tons under EEP arrangements on Monday, leaving only 1,050 tons in the previous allocation. The subsidy announced for that deal was $10.28 per ton, or about 28 cents per bushel. Purchases of U.S. wheat for 1989-90 delivery total about 5.7 million tons, much of it without subsidies. In 1988-89, China bought nearly 8.1 million tons, all of it carrying EEP subsidies.
