DOC.HEAD: Study Says Regulators Often Go to Work for Those They Regulated
DOC.TEXT: Consumer advocates and an insurance industry group said Thursday that a study of 106 former and current state insurance commissioners showed about half of them obtained jobs with insurance companies after they left office. The study highlights ``the short period of time many commissioners served'' and ``the number of former commissioners who immediately moved to the industry after leaving office,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. The study was released by the Consumer Insurance Interest Group and the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents, which said state insurance commissioners should be prohibited from working directly or indirectly for the industry for one year after leaving office to avoid the reality or appearance of conflict of interest. The survey found that 49 percent of the former commissioners worked for insurance companies or provided legal, accounting or other professional services to the industry after leaving office. ``Their study is incomplete and does not support that sweeping conclusion,'' said Earle Palmeroy, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. ``They've made no conclusion that the regulation of individual commissioners was affected by their later work for the industry,'' said Palmeroy, the North Dakota commissioner. Palmeroy also objected to the group's inclusion of commissioners who later worked for law and accounting firms that had insurance companies as clients. Insurance commissioners are appointed or elected to state boards to regulate insurance rates, allocate insurance premium taxes and carry out other duties. ``This study doesn't contain any evidence of impropriety by insurance commissioners,'' noted Richard Yingling, president of the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents. But ``even the potential for the appearance of conflict can erode the public's confidence in state regulation of insurance,'' he added. The study tracks the employment patterns of 55 former and 51 current commissioners from the 50 states and the District of Columbia who are or have served from 1984 through 1989. Employment information was obtained for 53 of the former commissioners. Twenty-six worked for the insurance industry in some capacity; 13 went to other government positions. Nine entered other industries or practiced non-insurance related law, while five retired. The Consumer Insurance Interest Group is a coalition of three consumer advocacy organizations _ the Consumer Federation of America; Public Citizen, a Ralph-Nader founded group, and the National Insurance Consumer Organization. The National Association of Professional Insurance Agents is a trade associaiton representing 180,000 independent insurance agents who specialize in home, auto and business insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Business Executive Being Named to Civil Rights Panel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with appointment in top 2 grafs, picking up in 3rd graf pvs, Redenbaugh said
DOC.TEXT: A blind Philadelphia business executive, Russell G. Redenbaugh, who said he had personally suffered discrimination because of his disability, was appointed Thursday to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. The appointment was announced by Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., acting Senate Pro Tempore, after Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said earlier in the day that Redenbaugh had been recommended for the post. Redenbaugh said he had experienced discrimination when he applied to three business schools after his graduation from college. He said two of them turned him down because he was blind. He said they told him that even if he could get through their programs they ``could not afford to squander their scarce resources on someone who would be obviously unemployable.'' Dole said that the civil rights field has ``been focused almost exclusively on discrimination based on race, color and creed.'' He said discrimination against the disabled ``deserves far more emphasis.'' ``Russell Redenbaugh is a profile in courage and achievement who will be a tremendous addition to the commission,'' said Dole, R-Kan. The 45-year-old Redenbaugh, a nephew of Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, was injured at the age of 17 in an explosion. He went on to graduate from the University of Utah and ranked sixth in his class when he received a master of business administration degree from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. He is a partner and director of the investment management firm of Cooke & Bieler Inc. of Philadelphia and is also an author and teacher. He and his wife have four children.

DOC.HEAD: Money Laundering Called $300 Billion Annual Business
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials should attack the $300 billion business of laundering drug money with steps ranging from a banking summit to supermarket-style bar codes on $20 bills, a senator said Thursday. ``We hope that the administration will get off the dime and get moving on this,'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., told a news conference at which he released a wide-ranging report on the laundering of proceeds of drug sales. He recommended a summit between top bankers and officials of the State and Treasury departments aimed at speeding action. He also called on the Senate Banking Committee to launch an investigation of the laundering of cash missing as part of the savings and loan industry crisis. Kerry called for aggressive pursuit of information from foreign banks ``backed up by the threat of real sanctions,'' adding that officials should ``look hard'' at allowing banks to keep part of any laundered money found. Banks should be required to know their customers and real names _ not aliases _ should be required on checks, Kerry said. He said there should be federal requirements for check cashing operations such as currency exchanges. Some recovered money should be funneled into the effort to combat crime in high-intensity drug areas, he said, and money should be stamped with bar codes that would allow computerized tracking of the flow of currency. The report, based on testimony last fall before the Senate Foreign Relations and Banking Committees, quoted Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore Martoche as estimating that drug revenues total $300 billion annually, including $110 billion generated in the United States. It said much of the money laundered worldwide comes from criminal activities other than drug sales, such as loan sharking, but that narcotics represents a major portion. Laundering is not always simple, it said. For example, $100 billion in $20 bills, a denomination often used in drug transactions, would weigh 26 million pounds, the report said. ``A money laundering operation in New York shut down earlier this year required a tractor-trailer to haul away $19 million in small bills,'' it said. The report said the 1970 Bank Secrecy Act is working as a deterrent to money laundering through American financial institutions. The measure requires the institutions to report cash deposits of $10,000 or more. However, the report said that drug traffickers ``continue to use foreign banks and foreign branches of U.S. banks to launder U.S. drug profits.'' Switzerland, Canada, the Bahamas, Luxembourg, Panama and Hong Kong are among the main countries where money is laundered, the report said, adding that criminals are pushing to develop money laundering centers in a number of tiny countries, ranging from Andorra to Vanuatu. The report said the government has no policy on control of international electronic transfers of U.S. funds. ``As a consequence, money launderers retain a choice of methods to conceal their laundered funds through international wire transfers, including informal channels involving Fax machines, telex, personal computer networks and ordinary telephone instructions which do not leave the paper trail which would allow investigators to follow the flow of funds,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion, Fire Trap More Than 50 Miners in Turkey; Two Survive
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a coal mine in northern Turkey, trapping more than 50 miners inside, and officials said Thursday that they had cut off ventilation to the shaft to help extinguish the blaze because there was no hope of finding any more survivors. Two miners survived the Wednesday night blast in the state-owned Yeniceltik coal mine in Merzifon, 240 miles northeast of Ankara near the Black Sea, officials said. Rescuers also recovered eight bodies but 58 others are believed entombed in the mine, union leader Ekrem Sami said. ``It is ... the end for all trapped down there, which is an inferno,'' said Sami, secretary general of Maden-Is, the mineworkers union. ``Tons of coal are burning there now, there is little that can be done.'' The cause of the accident was not immediately determined, but union officials blamed lax safety measures at the mine for the blast, which occurred a day after the Labor Ministry said mines in the region had few safeguards. Dozens of soldiers formed a ring around the mine to prevent loved ones from getting close, the independent Hurriyet News Agency reported. Families were upset over the decision to seal the mine shaft, ruling out any possibility of rescue, the agency said. Government television showed the relatives of miners wailing and shouting at the site of the accident. Sami said a small fire set off the explosion of pit gas, largely made of methane. The blast in turn ignited a giant blaze, he said. He said one of the two rescued miners had died later of severe burns, but doctors at nearby Samsun University Hospital said the miner was still alive though in critical condition. State Minister Mehmet Yazar told reporters that all ventilation channels to the mine were closed to cut off air feeding the blaze. The ventilation was ordered cut off when it appeared dense smoke left no hope the trapped miners could survive, he said. Celalettin Cakir, manager of the mine, said in an interview with the state television that the fire was spreading and any rescue effort was impossible under the circumstances. Hurriyet quoted Hamit Ozturk, local head of the union, accusing the management that they failed to evacuate the mine in time even though they were aware of the accumulation of methane gas at the pit. Cakir denied the allegation, Hurriyet reported. Sevket Yilmaz, president of Turk-Is, Turkey's largest labor union confederation, told reporters at the site: ``This is no work accident, this is murder because of neglect of safety standards.'' The semiofficial Anatolia News Agency reported this was the fourth accident in the history of the Yeniceltik mine, owned by the municipality of Merzifon and the government-owned Sugar Co. In 1965, a similar explosion killed 72 at the same mine, the dispatch said. In 1983, there were 102 victims of an explosion in the northern province of Zonguldak. ``The state sector and the private sector are equally guilty of negligence. In all coal mines in Turkey, the conditions are primitive,'' Sami alleged. He said 800 miners worked in Yeniceltik but there were 68 miners in the shaft hit by the explosion during the evening shift. The disaster struck a day after the Labor Ministry published a report deploring the inadequacy of safety standards in Turkey's coal mines in the northern region. The report criticized the mines for not having fireproof uniforms or artificial breathing apparatus. The report was prepared during the course of the investigation of 26 deaths and 7,433 injuries in the pits last year. Officials estimate 1,000 people have lost their lives in mine accidents the past 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: State Investigating Reports of Meeting Before Priests Slain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs to UPDATE with Dodd proposal
DOC.TEXT: Reports that a group of high-ranking El Salvadoran military officers met shortly before six Jesuit priests were murdered in November are being investigated, the State Department said Thursday. Bernard Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, was subjected to tough questioning at a Senate appropriations subcommittee meeting about El Salvador's human rights record, particularly the government's handling of the investigation of the Jesuit killings. El Salvador has indicted eight members of the military, including Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides, in the slayings. Sen. Thomas Harkin, D-Iowa, asked Aronson what he knew about a reported meeting of 30 military officers in San Salvador on Nov. 15, the day before the killings. Harkin said among those reportedly attending the meeting were Benavides; the Armed Forces chief of staff, Rene Emilio Ponce; and a top intelligence official. ``I think it's being looked into,'' Aronson said, adding that the U.S. Embassy in San Salvador is helping the Salvadorans in the investigation. But Harkin called for a more pointed investigation to determine if El Salvadoran military officials might have been involved in ordering the killings. ``It seems to me the circumstantial evidence is that there was discussion and orders were given,'' Harkin said. However, Aronson said Harkin had not produced such evidence. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the panel's chairman, criticized the Reagan and Bush administrations for continuing to provide military and economic aid to El Salvador without insisting on an end to activity by right-wing death squads. Sarcastically, he said the administrations' efforts to condition aid ``would have had more teeth in it if we said we'll cut you off from the Book of the Month Club.'' But Aronson said as recently as last week that El Salvador's president, Alfredo Christiani, was warned that Congress might reduce the aid if his government did not improve its human rights. Aronson said the aid _ expected to total $315 million in fiscal 1990 _ has prevented the rebels battling the government ``from taking over El Salvador and imposing another dreary, vicious Marxist dictatorship upon a nation and a people that want to live in a democracy.'' Six Democratic senators have called for a cut-off of aid to El Salvador this year, but earlier efforts to end the assistance or make it conditional have failed in the House and Senate. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the Senate subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, took the middle ground at a Capitol Hill news conference. Dodd proposed legislation that immediately would cut military aid to El Salvador in half. If the Salvadoran government failed to pursue peace negotiations with rebel forces, all aid would be cut. Conversely, should the rebels cut off negotiations or launch an offensive, full military aid would be restored. ``If I were convinced that cutting off all aid would end the war tomorrow and preserve a democratic government, I would support that,'' Dodd said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev Speech at Conclusion of Party Meeting
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is the full text of Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's concluding remarks at the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee's plenary meeting, as reported Thursday by the official Tass news agency: To cut the long story short, I will say only a few words to sum up the major discussion that was held in the Hall of Sessions of the party Central Committee's plenums during the past three days. I think that the discussion at the plenum on the entire range of issues was adequate to the dimension and novelty of the documents and problems that we discussed. The plenum can be described in the following way: it revealed the immense concern and immense anxiety of the Central Committee and the party in general over the situation in the country and in connection with the course of perestroika processes. The plenum made a harsh, critical analysis of all perestroika processes and forecast on its basis what is to be done and in what way. This found reflection in the political guidelines that we placed at the basis of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee's platform. This is probably one more time after the work on resolutions of the 19th party conference that the entire Central Committee worked on the document in the sweat of its brow, so to say. I make the following very important conclusion: all activity, keenness and passions that emerged here _ all this reflects in one way or another the manifestation of concern about the party, about the fate of perestroika and about giving correct political guidelines for society on the part of the ruling party at this very crucial stage of perestroika. I think, comrades, that despite the diversity of views _ which was obvious at the plenum, down to opposite positions that clashed here (partially due to the lack of restraint _ this is all forgivable) _ all comrades were unanimous that a progressive document was required, a document that calls forward, rather than backward. In my opinion, this is the dominant view. I think that in some area of work there is a need to use some of the old mechanisms when new ones have not yet started working. Society should not be left rudderless and without sails, without means that are able to advance perestroika in our huge country. But the prevalent opinion _ which was endorsed in the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee's platform _ is that it is necessary to handle pressing problems along the tracks of perestroika, renewal of society and renewal of the Soviet Communist Party. This is the main thing. Now one more thing, or the reverse side of the medal, I would say. It is now not only by brain, but literally by all skin do we feel that we must act resolutely. The Central Committee, the government and the Supreme Soviet should act. I mention them not in order to give them instructions. No, we are expressing our position. The main thing is that Communists who are members of these bodies should act on the basis of this appraisal. We cannot waste any more time. It was fair to say to the party Central Committee: it is inadmissible to be late now. It is necessary to take the lead in stormy and complicated processes in order to support healthy trends, consolidate them and try to overcome or inhibit destructive trends. Communists in the government should also act. I think that comrades were right when they told party members working in the government that during the discussion of the platform at the plenum we did not hear their viewpoint. It was said that there was such a discussion at the second Congress of People's Deputies. This is no argument. It was necessary to have a discussion here as well. The more so for the government is now handling practical things, and it had what to say. It was important for the Central Committee members to check these steps and orient the entire party to support and consolidate them. Above all, to state our support for the program approved by the congress. But I think that the government will find a way to inform Central Committee members and secretaries of party committees so that they clearly and fully realize all the specifics. It is necessary to act in the Supreme Soviet from which major decisions are expected on key issues of perestroika and the improvement of the situation in the country. Communists should act vigorously and efficiently in all sectors. In general, we ought to consolidate forces by regrouping them and resolutely to advance perestroika and practical deeds. The deeper we enter perestroika and explore all its strata, the greater crystallization of positions and interests of opposing sides become. We felt its presence here as well. This is a reflection of the entire life of our society.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Surrender Stolen Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers trying to convince the government they want peace returned a helicopter they stole a year ago and said Thursday they were not responsible for threats to the national soccer team. The helicopter, stolen from the Colombian company Helicol, was left in the jungle in the northeastern state of Choco, according to a statement sent to news media Thursday by the Medellin cartel cocaine gang. It said several cocaine processing labs would be surrendered in a few days. In recent weeks, the traffickers have freed six of the 21 hostages police say they hold, turned over a ton of dynamite and halted a bombing campaign that killed 199 people in four months. Leaders of the Medellin cartel, who call themselves the Extraditables because of their vulnerability to extradition, said last month they would abandon the cocaine trade in exchange for constitutional and legal guarantees. They did not say what assurances they wanted, but most officials believe ending extradition to the United States is the main objective. President Virgilio Barco's government has sent 14 suspects to the United States for trial since it declared war on Colombia's cocaine gangs in August. Nine others await extradition. Officials said repeatedly they will never negotiate with traffickers and that cocaine barons should surrender if they want peace. Thursday's statement denied suggestions by the acting national police chief, Gen. Carlos Arturo Casadiego, that traffickers were behind threats to the national soccer team, which has qualified for the 1990 World Cup tournament in Italy. Coach Francisco Maturana said earlier this week he might keep the team out of the tournament because of threats made in a telephone call to a radio network by a group calling itself ``The Cleaning of Colombian Soccer.'' A recorded message played over the telephone claimed the group represented gamblers who had lost millions of dollars because members of team fixed games on instructions from drug traffickers. The Extraditables said some soccer figures were connected with traffickers, but the cocaine dealers would never try to destroy the sport. In Colombia's continuing war with insurgents, two guerrillas from a group that has promised to lay down its arms this month were found floating dead in a river and five rebels, six soldiers and a member of a leftist party were killed in political violence, police reported. Police said they found two members of the April 19 Movement, known as M19, in the Magdalena River near Pitalitio, 250 miles south of Bogota. An M-19 statement blamed the killings on ``ultra-right wing groups and paramilitary squads.'' Colombia's most active leftist guerrillas, the National Liberation Army, bombed the main petroleum pipeline Thursday for the fifth time this year, causing a fire and a spill of the thousands of barrels of crude oil, the state oil company Ecopetrol reported. The pipeline runs more than 400 miles from the Canon Limon oil field on the Venezuelan border to Covenas, a Caribbean port. The guerrillas have made more than 180 attacks on oil facilities since 1986. Barco's government and M19 are to sign an agreement Wednesday providing for the estimated 900 guerrillas to surrender their arms Feb. 22 in return for amnesty and the right to form a political party.

DOC.HEAD: Report Terrorist Seized in Tour Bus Attack on Israelis
DOC.TEXT: The state-owned newspaper Al-Akhbar said Friday that police arrested one of two terrorists who attacked a tour bus with machine guns and hand grenades on Feb. 3 and killed nine Israelis. On Thursday, the paper said investigators viewed videotape shot during the ambush. The tape's owner said it showed the terrorists' faces. Al-Akhbar did not identify the arrested man by name or nationality Friday nor did it give attribution for its page one story. The paper also ran an editorial attacking Israeli Trade Minister Ariel Sharon for remarks it said he made holding Egypt responsible for the attack. Police have said the attack was planned outside Egypt and a Palestinian connection is being investigated. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said Wednesday his investigators found the attack was mounted by non-Egyptians. The bus was carrying 31 Israeli tourists to Cairo from Rafah, a divided town on the border with Israel. It was ambushed 40 miles northeast of Cairo on the desert road between the capital and the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. Besides nine killed, 20 Israelis and an Egyptian tour guide were wounded. ``Al-Akhbar has learned that the Interior Ministry's security apparatus has arrested the terrorist who participated with his partner in the attack on the Israeli tourists' bus,'' the newspaper said Friday. It said Thursday one terrorist was arrested, but it was unclear whether the arrest was of a gunman or a Palestinian suspected of driving the car used by the attackers. A ministry spokesman refused comment. Al-Akhbar said the videotape was shot by Pinchas First, a wounded Israeli survivor, and ran for three minutes. It quoted the Israeli newspaper Hadashot as saying First began filming when the assault began and the video recorder kept running after he was hurt. ``I used my camera right from the start of the attack, and I'm sure that I managed to film the assailants,'' First was quoted as saying in an interview with the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot. He was quoted as saying the gunmen wore scarves over their faces, but the scarves fell off after they boarded the bus. He said he turned the tape over to Egyptian police. In its editorial on Sharon, Al-Ahram said: ``Sharon is the first to know that he is at the head of those who are responsible for the violence and extremism that are spread in the region ... ``He is the first to realize that the seed of violence was sown by him and those hawks and extremists like him.'' At the same time, editor Ibrahim Nafea attacked the Palestine Liberation Organization for issuing a condemnation of the ambush which he called ``weak and absolutely incompatible with the magnitude and horror of the accident.'' ``Terrorism benefits only the enemies of the Arabs, especially if such a crime takes place on Egyptian land,'' Nafea, a confidant of President Hosni Mubarak, wrote. Nafea's attack indicates Cairo's anger at the PLO for saying the ambush should be put in context with the death of hundreds of Palestinians at Israeli hands in the uprising in the occupied territories. Al-Ahram said Mubarak sent ``an urgent verbal message'' to PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat on Thursday about ``recent developments in the Middle East peace process'' but gave no details. Egypt is the only Arab country to have a peace treaty with Israel. The Mubarak government has been trying to broker Israeli-Palestinian talks as a first step toward Mideast peace. A police source said about 100 people, mostly Palestinians, were detained for questioning in the bus attack by late Wednesday and that police were combing Rafah, which has a large Palestinian population. Butros Ghali, minister of state for foreign affairs, appealed Thursday for Israelis to continue visiting Egypt despite the attack, saying tourism was needed to deepen relations. He spoke in an interview from Cairo broadcast on Israel radio. Ghali also called for ``a new peace process'' to encourage moderate voices in both the Arab and Israeli camps. Sharon said on Israel television Thursday the bus attack was planned by Palestinians deported from occupied territories _ ``Those who sent the killers in Egypt were people, terrorists, who were deported from Israel.'' He named no names nor did he say what their roles were.

DOC.HEAD: Runaway Home Tries to Offset Sex Allegations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add that ad also appeared in New York Times, delete reference to ads being full-page. INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `In 1968, to add comment from acting director. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `One of...'.
DOC.TEXT: Covenant House, the shelter for runaways that has been shaken by charges of sexual misconduct by its founder and president, ran newspaper advertisements Thursday urging contributors to continue their support. ``This work cannot continue without you. Please help us,'' said the ads in New York Newsday, The New York Times and the Daily News. Many earlier ads for the house featured the Rev. Bruce Ritter and included his picture. Thursday's made no reference to him. Four men have come forward to make claims of having had sexual relationships with Ritter. WABC-TV reported Wednesday that a total of seven men had formally complained to authorities about similar allegations. A spokewoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office, Colleen Roche, declined to comment on the WABC report. Ritter, who denies the allegations, was instructed to take a leave of absence during an investigation by his order, the Franciscans. Frank J. Macchiarola, a member of the board of directors and a former city schools chancellor, took over Wednesday as acting president. Covenant House has an annual budget of $87 million and operates 17 shelters with more than 2,000 beds in the United States and Canada. It is the largest shelter systems for runaways in the United States. The advertisement ``is telling people out there who are donors and have been loyal donors that we need their help and continued support,'' said a Covenant House spokesman, Bill McAndrew. ``In 1968 we took in 8 kids a night. Tonight _ 1,500,'' part of the ad said. Macchiarola said he met with some staff members and Covenant House residents Thursday. ``The general feeling is up, that we will see this thing through, though not without a sense of danger, a sense of risk,'' he said. ``One of the things the kids expressed is, `We have not had a friendship like this before, and we don't want to lose it.''' One of the four men who has accused Ritter, Paul Johnson, told WNBC-TV on Wednesday that ``I cashed something in the neighborhood of $175,000 in checks for Bruce and took the cash to him.'' When allegations of sexual and financial improprieties first surfaced in December, Covenant House produced results of an audit that it said accounted for every dollar. The investigation by the Manhattan district attorney's office is focused on Covenant House's finances and whether its officials illegally obtained false identification for one of Ritter's accusers, Kevin Lee Kite. The charities bureau of the state attorney general's office is also looking into Covenant House's finances. But its review of documents in December found no evidence of wrongdoing, said spokeswoman Leslie Gersing.

DOC.HEAD: $840,000 of Noriega Money Reported Frozen in British Banks
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Thursday ordered money in British bank accounts belonging to ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega to be frozen pending inquiries to discover whether it was derived from drug trafficking. Judge Sir Michael Hutchison granted the application by attorneys of the Crown Prosecution Service, who said the Noriega's accounts were being investigated by National Drugs Intelligence Unit officers based at Scotland Yard. The amount of money wasn't stated but the domestic Press Association news agency said it is about $840,000. The attorneys said the investigators received information from the United States before Christmas that Noriega had several bank accounts in Britain. The 1986 Drug Trafficking Offenses Act allows the examination and freezing of suspect bank accounts and confiscating all monies received by a convicted trafficker. Noriega, 51, is awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges in Miami, where a federal judge on Thursday rejected efforts by his attorneys to have him moved to a neutral country. U.S. forces invaded Panama Dec. 20 to depose Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Utah Man to Credit Union Board
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Thursday that President Bush will nominate Robert H. Swan to the National Credit Union Administration Board. Swan, 64, of Tooele, Utah, is president and chief executive of Tooele Federal Credit Union and a former Utah deputy director of finance. The personnel announcement was made here before Bush addressed an Ohio GOP dinner.

DOC.HEAD: KQED to Lose License for KQEC in San Francisco
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday upheld a review board's decision that stripped from San Francisco station KQED-TV its license to operate a UHF educational station, KQEC. The review board had ruled KQED failed to deal honestly with the commission. The FCC said it will award a new license to the Minority Television Project Inc. for a new station using KQEC facilities, provided that Minority Television Project supplies proof it has received sufficient state and federal funds. The commission said it agreed with the review board's conclusion that KQED officials ``committed serious misconduct by lacking candor about and misrepresenting the reasons that KQEC was off the air from January through May 1980.'' It said the record showed KQED's board of directors adopted a resolution authorizing the deactivation of KQEC, channel 32, ``as a means of alleviating KQED's financial problems.'' The commission said that on three occasions after the resolution was adopted, KQED told the commission the UHF station was closed ``for technical reasons associated with the replacement of switcher equipment,'' and did not disclose the board's decision. The commission said that it had warned KQED in 1975 that it considered KQED's practice of deactivating channel 32 for financial reasons contrary to the public interest. The commission said that even after it learned of the board's resolution as the result of a complaint, ``KQED attempted to characterize its action as related to the switcher replacement and not a general budgetary matter. ... Such conduct violates the fundamental duty of a licensee to deal honestly with the commission.'' Despite KQED's misconduct, the commission said it was upholding the review board's decision to renew the license of KQED-TV and KQED-FM. The board found that KQED did not commit the ``kind of pervasive misconduct that would have disqualified KQED from holding any broadcast licenses and that the loss of a single station was the appropriate sanction in view of the misconduct committed.'' KQED may continue operating KQEC for 90 days. If KQED seeks reconsideration of the FCC order or judicial review, it may continue to operate the station for 90 days following release of any reconsideration order or the completion of judicial review, whichever is later.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Flee to Moslem Area to Escape Battle; Cease-fire Called
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with cease-fire agreement, Geagea comment; picks up 11th `Police said' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI1,3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Christians fled to the relative safety of Moslem west Beirut during a lull Thursday in the deadly war for supremacy between Christian Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea. Mediators announced an agreement to end the 10 days of fighting in which hundreds have died, but Geagea said he would fight 100 years to keep Aoun from turning Lebanon's Christian enclave into a ``banana republic.'' More than half a dozen previous cease-fires have collapsed. Snipers continued firing Thursday, but their bullets seemed a small danger to people who had spent a week or more underground while shells and rockets smashed homes, hospitals, schools and power stations. ``I don't want to be there when all hell breaks loose again,'' said Hayat Labaki, 35, a secretary who left Christian east Beirut to stay with friends in the Moslem sector. ``The combatants didn't have any mercy on civilians,'' she said. ``I spent nine days in the basement, trembling and wondering whether I'd be alive when the battle ended. I don't want to die.'' She said her parents would not leave Ashrafiyeh, a stronghold of Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia, which has 6,000 regulars and an estimated 30,000 reservists. Ms. Labaki's eyes brimmed with tears as she said: ``The apartment is all my parents have. It was hit by bullets, but it's still standing. They want to stay with it.'' Then she entered west Beirut at the Museum crossing, the only open gateway in the no man's land that draws a sectarian line through the city. Many other Christians crossed to buy food and water, and hospital officials went in search of blood supplies and medicine. Civilians have mingled peacefully on both sides of the line throughout the 15-year-old sectarian civil war. Aoun and Geagea left their big guns silent Thursday in a battle that has killed at least 373 people and wounded 1,680, many of them civilians, since Jan. 30. Three mediators worked out an agreement with representatives of both sides that calls for a cease-fire, assurance that ``there is no intention to liquidate the Lebanese Forces'' and renunciation of the use of arms to resolve political differences. Geagea seemed to imperil the truce when he told reporters, as if addressing Aoun: ``General, you're mad, a liar, an utter fool in politics. You shouldn't think you can finish us off. We shall fight you 100 years. ``You've waged war on everyone in sight and on everything in the Christian area. ... Let me remind you of Hitler's and Mussolini's fate.'' They are fighting for control of the 310-square-mile enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live, but the casualties include Moslems killed or wounded by shells that strayed into west Beirut. Police said Geagea and Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but still commands the loyalty of nearly 20,000 Christian troops, were reinforcing their positions and resupplying their men with ammunition, weapons and food. They said a first lieutenant in Aoun's army was killed by a sniper in the Dora district of east Beirut, and St. Joseph hospital said seven civilians wounded earlier in the week died Thursday. Five people were reported wounded by snipers. Aoun, with a bulletproof vest under his camouflage jacket, made a morale-boosting tour of strategic hills his troops seized from the militia this week at Dbaye, north of Beirut. His Tele Liban television station showed Aoun in a dark blue beret, flanked by a dozen heavily armed bodyguards, talking to officers beside a demolished Lebanese Forces truck in Dbaye. The 54-year-old general rarely leaves his bunker beneath the shattered presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb east of Beirut. He refuses to recognize President Elias Hrawi, who fired him after being elected in November, and has refused to leave the palace. Geagea, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun and Hrawi, said in a letter to Pope John Paul II that Aoun wanted to ``silence any voice that opposed his decisions.'' Aoun rejects a Lebanese peace plan worked out last fall under Arab League mediation, which Hrawi was elected to implement. Geagea recognizes Hrawi as president, but has not taken a public position on the peace agreement. Hundreds of people fled to west Beirut from Ashrafiyeh, the militia stronghold that has seen the heaviest fighting, but most residents of districts controlled by Aoun appeared to be buying supplies and returning home. Youssef Hayek of the Furn el-Shubbak district, which Aoun controls, said, ``I can't wait to get the bread to the family,'' and headed for the dozens of trucks Moslem vendors had parked nearby. Hayek, who works in a bank, also bought as much bottled drinking water, eggs, canned meat, vegetables and fruit as his small red Renault would carry. ``I'm going back to the underground shelter,'' he said. ``We don't want to leave. We have no place to go.'' His third-floor apartment was badly damaged, Hayek said, and ``we put out a fire that was started by shrapnel.'' Aoun's soldiers did not interfere with civilians leaving Ashrafiyeh, but snipers made targets of roads leading to it and other strongholds of Geagea's militia. Hanan Saade, a housewife, led her three children across, leaving leaving behind a gutted apartment in Ashrafiyeh. ``What is left there?'' she said. ``We were all in the shelter when it happened. Shells rained on Ashrafiyeh, maybe three days ago; I don't remember. ... The apartment was gone. I couldn't even find clothes for the children.''

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Proposed on Nuclear Weapons Safeguards
DOC.TEXT: Soviet lawmakers are proposing joint hearings of the House Armed Services Committee and the defense committee of the Supreme Soviet to study ways to prevent accidental or unauthorized launches of nuclear weapons. Yevgeni Velikhov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet's defense subcommittee, suggested the unprecedneted hearings to Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., a spokesman for the U.S. office of the International Foundation for the Survival and Development of Humanity said Thursday. Velikhov is also chairman of the Moscow-based foundation, founded in 1988 to find solutions to problems in such areas as international security, the environment and human rights. Aspin said Thursday that he and his Soviet counterparts will explore the possibility of ``joint undertakings such as hearings between the two committees.'' He commented at a meeting marking the opening of a 12-day visit of members of the Soviet committee to a number of U.S. military installations. Members of the House panel made a similar inspection visit to Soviet military bases in August. ``The Supreme Soviet is struggling to become a more independent legislature,'' Aspin said. ``Anything we can do to promote democratic values in the Soviet Union is in the U.S. national interest.'' Representatives of the International Foundation said Velikhov is asking that the hearings be based on a report written by members of the group's security committee. The report, entitled, ``Reducing the Dangers of Accidental and Unauthorized Nuclear Launch and Terrorist Attack: Alternatives to a Ballistic Missile Defense System,'' has been presented to Aspin and other members of Congress and is to be made public at a news conference here Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Visit Head Start Class
With AM-Bush Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For a few minutes Thursday, the president of the United States perched on a tiny chair and talked about helicopters, stuffed animals and favorite numbers. For the kids in the Head Start class, the ``people in the picture'' had come to visit. ``What do you like best about school, huh?'' President Bush asked a little girl at the St. Aloysius Head Start Center in Columbus. ``I mean, do you like singing or do you like coloring or do you like the numbers _ which is your favorite?'' he asked. ``Two,'' she replied quietly. ``Two,'' echoed first lady Barbara Bush with a smile. ``Two is her favorite number.'' The 23 youngsters patiently fielded other questions from the president about the pre-school program and their plans for the rest of their young lives. ``Boys and girls, I'd like to introduce somebody to you, O.K.? The people in the picture _ guess what, they're in your classroom now,'' their teacher, Deborah White, announced as the Bushes made their entrance. ``Hi, Tiffany, how are you going?'' said the president, espying a nametag. ``You like this Head Start?'' Bush likes Head Start, too. Last week he asked Congress to raise its $1.4 billion budget by $500 million. It helps get disadvantaged 3-to-5-year-olds ready for school. Bush, a grandfather of 12, had no trouble keeping up his end of the conversation. Bush, who had heard the kids singing ``Where is Thumbkin'' as he entered, asked, ``Can you sing us another? ... Do you know any others or is that the only song you know?'' The teacher and two aides laughed nervously. ``How about `I'm a Little Teapot'?'' suggested Mrs. Bush, joining the youngsters in an aerobic rendition that Bush watched rigidly. He managed a subdued wave of his hand at the very end. Seated on an undersized chair, Bush pointed out his bedroom on a picture of the White House, and another room ``full of stuffed animals, when our grandchildren come. ... There must be 20 up there. I've never seen so many of them. Elephants, birds.'' Bush asked a girl he called Ebony Kwanella if she knew how to spell her name. ``I bet you don't. That's a very hard name to spell,'' said Bush. ``E-B-O-N-Y,'' she replied. ``Yeah, but how about Kwanella?'' said Bush. He got no reply. ``I know you have a helicopter,'' a child said. ``Yeah. You've ever been in a helicopter? Did you? Oh, a pretend helicopter,'' said the president. He showed them where Marine One lands on the White House lawn. ``I want to be like you,'' a boy said. ``Do you want to be president? You've got a fighting chance. You get out there and work hard and study hard. Go to your lessons and do stuff,'' advised Bush. ``How about you Lauren? ... What are your hopes and dreams?'' said Bush. The first lady spotted a boy with a rat's tail hairdo. She turned him around and said admiringly, ``You've got the most modern, wonderful hairdo! You've got a swinging hairdo!'' ``I love you,'' a girl told Bush. ``Oh, thank you,'' said Bush, hugging the girl _ and then another and a third. Finally, he insisted, ``We've got to go. You get down and go to work. Goodbye, Wanda. You guys get in here and study hard or start singing some more _ do something.'' Bush found himself left behind after Barbara made her exit. ``Your husband's leaving,'' a girl informed him. ``That's my wife,'' said the president, exiting at last to laughter.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the latest developments Thursday in Eastern Europe.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leader Boris N. Yeltsin and other activists said that in addition to renouncing its legal monopoly on power, the ruling Communist Party must eliminate its organizations in the police, courts and other institutions to end political repression and centralized control. Yeltsin said Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms failed to go far enough and recommended the formation of a second party if the Communists do not excise conservatives.
DOC.HEAD: BAKER-SOVIETS
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and U.S. Secretary of State Jame A. Baker III made progress toward treaties on nuclear, conventional and chemical weapons in more than seven hours of talks and also considered a joint condemnation of Israel's resettlement of Jewish immigrants on the West Bank.
DOC.HEAD: GERMAN REUNIFICATION
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to tell Gorbachev when they meet in Moscow beginning Saturday that Soviet fears that a unified Germany will lead to a ``Fourth Reich'' are completely unfounded. Kohl said he is committed to making Europe stronger and hopes economically, the 1990s will ``be the decade of the Europeans, and not of the Japanese.''
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY-HOLOCAUST
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister, in a letter to the president of the World Jewish Congress, recognized that East Germany's people share responsibility for the Holocaust. Modrow pledged ``material support'' for the victims of Nazi persecution.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's first all-Communist government, which will run the country until multiparty electons in May, was sworn in after Premier Andrei Lukanov failed to persuade members of the democratic opposition to join it. Previous governments have included members of the Agrarian Party, a docile ally of the Communists, and other parties later absorbed by the Communists or banned.
DOC.HEAD: HUNGARY
DOC.TEXT: President Matyas Szueros and Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican secretary of state, attended a ceremony renaming the square in front of the Esztergom basilica _ the seat of Hungary's Roman Catholic primate _ after the late Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA
DOC.TEXT: Romaina's largest opposition party said it fears the outgoing National Salvation Front will try to control the new Council of National Unity, which will run the country until elections in May, by appointing prominent former Communists.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA
DOC.TEXT: A Czechoslovak diplomat said that the Kremlin is balking at a swift pullout of the 75,000 Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia, citing difficulties in absorbing the returning soldiers.
DOC.HEAD: ELSEWHERE
DOC.TEXT: _ Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, arrived in Prague for a three-day visit to mark the resumption of diplomatic ties with Czechoslovakia. _ The first deputy mayor of Moscow, Yuri A. Belyakov, died of a heart attack during a visit to Madrid. _ In Vienna, Austria, NATO presented to Warsaw Pact negotiators President Bush's proposal to cut the number of American and Soviet troops stationed in central Europe to 195,000 for each side.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Dispute Bush Request to Delay $2.2 Billion in Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: The top two senators on the Senate Appropriations Committee are challenging the legality of a White House request to delay $2.2 billion in Pentagon expenditures this year, according to a letter released Thursday. Among the postponments President Bush is seeking are several projects that are favorites of particular members of Congress. Presidents routinely ask Congress to delay billions of dollars of planned spending each year. By law, those requests _ called deferrals _ are permissible because of unexpected contingencies or a chance to save money through better management. They can be blocked by a majority vote of either house. The requested delays, however, are not allowed for policy reasons. Yet according to the papers Bush sent lawmakers dated Feb. 6 and released Thursday, the administration justifies many of the deferrals by stating: ``This proposal reflects changes in requirements in view of promising developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.'' Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., and Sen. Mark Hatfield of Oregon, ranking Republican on the appropriations panel, wrote Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher on Wednesday asking him to review the requests. The senators wrote that some of the requests ``appear to go well beyond the permissible housekeeping deferrals.'' Bowsher is chief of the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative agency. By law, the GAO routinely examines presidential requests to delay spending. The requested deferrals include $200 million for V-22 Osprey tilt rotor aircraft manufactured in Texas and Pennsylvania; $593 million for construction and conversion of Navy ships, work that is a boon to many coastal states; and $325 million for the Coast Guard's purchase of an icebreaker. The second-ranking Republican on the appropriations panel is Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, where the icebreaker would presumably see much of its duty.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Iranians Deported from Britain
DOC.TEXT: British police on Thursday put nine Iranians on an Iran Air flight to Tehran after Home Secretary David Waddington signed deportation orders against them on the grounds of national security. The Home Office refused to give details of the complaint against the nine or publish their names. The deportations were announced Feb. 1. A Home Office spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom, said Thursday: ``The deportations were enforced for reasons of national security because their activities were not conducive to the public good.'' Britain deported two Iranian students in December. Their attorney said then that British authorities suspected them of preparing to kill Salman Rushdie, author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' the novel denounced by many Moslems as slanderous to their religion. The late Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on Feb. 14, 1989, called on Moslems to kill Rushdie because his book was blasphemous to Islam. Iranian leaders offered a $5.2 million bounty to anyone who killed Rushdie. Rushdie has been in hiding since.

DOC.HEAD: Peaceful Beach Scene Contrasts With Frantic Life-Saving Efforts
With AM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Wetsuit-clad surfers bobbed within a mile of a big oil slick Thursday while animal lovers worked frantically to save sea birds coated with dark goop. The day after the tanker American Trader dumped nearly 300,000 gallons of oil into the ocean near the community known as Surf City, the scene was peaceful. A mid-morning helicopter survey showed the mile-long slick as a giant purple blob _ an ugly ink spot on the smooth sea surface. A dozen surfers rode the waves nearby, apparently oblivious to the spill. From the air, U.S. Coast Guard vessels could be seen weaving around the American Trader. Helicopters carrying news crews buzzed above the grey and red vessel. About three dozen people gathered on the beach and stared out toward the spill, which really couldn't be seen from the shoreline. On the other side of Pacific Coast Highway, oil wells pumped just as they do every day. By midday just over a dozen oil-coated birds, six of them dead, had washed ashore, said Curt Taucher of the state Department of Fish and Game. But offshore winds threatened to shift and steer the spill toward the Bolsa Chica wildlife sanctuary. David Thompson and Mark Recktenwald, students at Orange Coast Community College, spent the afternoon walking the beach in search of oil-soaked birds. They were supplied with gloves and boxes. ``This is unfortunate that it happened,'' Thompson said. ``But we all drive cars and use heaters. You're kidding yourself if you think it's the fault of capitalists. I think it's everyone's responsibility to help clean this up.'' Thompson frequents the beach, often bodysurfing beside dolphins. He said he would return to the water as soon as it's deemed safe. Desiree White, 16, said, ``I think it really stinks. I'll wait a little while before I come back here.'' The placid beach scene contrasted with the frenzied atmosphere inside the Huntington State Beach's central life guard station, where environmentalists set up a command center to rescue wildlife. Ailing birds were cleaned with dishwashing liquid and tended under warm lamps by volunteers. ``They were completely drenched in the oil. You'd pick them up and drops would come off,'' said Christina Amato, a volunteer with the Alliance for Wildlife organization. Hundreds of people volunteered time or materials, such as boxes and towels for cleanup. Trained workers turned down some of the volunteer hopefuls, saying they needed professionals to help, said State Fish and Game biologist Esther Burkett. ``In your zeal, in your pity, you could hurt (the birds),'' she said. Marci Lowy, 24, roller skated all the way from Newport Beach to volunteer. ``It seemed like the thing to do,'' she said. Burkett said it's too early to say what toll the spill will take on birds, diving ducks and grebes. Of primary concern were endangered species living in area estuaries, such as the American brown pelican, peregrine falcon and the light-footed clapper rail. The accident recalled Huntington Beach's nickname. The community of 186,000 was known as ``Oil City'' 70 years ago when groves of oil derricks stood on the shore where surfers and sunbathers now gather by the hundreds of thousands.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Offers Resignation After Presidential Hopeful Shot
DOC.TEXT: Political leaders Thursday criticized the use of police force to break up a campaign march in which a leftist presidential candidate was shot in the leg. The interior minister offered to resign. President Alan Garcia apologized to the candidate, Henry Pease, and met with his Cabinet Thursday to discuss Wednesday's incident in downtown Lima as well as Interior Minister Agustin Mantilla's offer to step down. Mantilla, who was in charge of overseeing law enforcement, called the police action that left at least seven people wounded ``without justification.'' No statement was issued after the Cabinet meeting on whether Garcia formally accepted Mantilla's offer, and no replacement has been named, but Mantilla said his resignation was ``irrevocable.'' Radio Programas reported earlier Thursday without attribution that Garcia had accepted the resignation. Senate President Humberto Carranza, of Garcia's center-left Aprista party, said Thursday he supported Mantilla's decision to resign. ``If the interior minister cannot control his subordinates, those who are under his command, I believe that the principle of authority has been lost,'' Carranza said. Pease, running in the April 8 election as the candidate for the United Left, a coalition of Marxist parties, was wounded when police fired birdshot to disperse the coalition's march near the Government Palace where Garcia lives. Also wounded were two congressional candidates, one of Pease's bodyguards, two newspaper photographers and a number of marchers. Pease said none of those wounded was seriously injured. The government banned the use of birdshot to break up demonstrations three years ago when several people were badly injured by the pellets during a miners strike. The Interior Ministry ordered an investigation and said one police commander had been fired and another suspended. Pease said said Mantilla's resignation was ``necessary.'' ``What happened yesterday should not happen to any citizen,'' he told reporters. ``We are human beings, not cattle.'' Witnesses to Wednesday's incident said the marchers tried to cross the Plaza de Armas, a large public square in front of the Government Palace that has been closed off by police for several months to prevent a rebel attack by Shining Path extremists. Police detoured the marchers down a side street, where the confrontation occurred. Police used tear gas, water cannon and shotguns to disperse the marchers. Garcia named Mantilla to the post last May 13. Mantilla has been a close confidant of Garcia since before Garcia took office in 1985, and has served as Garcia's bodyguard and minister of the presidency. The favored candidate in the April election is novelist Mario Vargas Llosa of the center-right Democratic Front coalition. Trailing him in the polls are Alfonso Barrantes of the Socialist Left coalition, Luis Alva Castro of the Aprista party, and Pease. Garcia by law is not allowed run for a second consecutive 5-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Meets With Ethics Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT time from 90 minutes to about an hour; SUBS 11th graf: ``He has,'' to CORRECT that payments were made while Senate was ``not in session,'' sted ``in session.''
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger said Thursday that he told the Senate Ethics Committee that ``appropriate official bodies'' approved the financial dealings that sparked the panel's investigation of his conduct. ``I am comfortable in presenting my case to the Ethics Committee and letting the process take its course,'' the Minnesota Republican said after spending about an hour minutes before the committee in a closed-door meeting. ``I have accepted full responsibility for my actions, and I have acknowledged that had I to do it all over again, some decisions would be made differently.'' Durenberger had requested the meeting before new allegations surfaced on his receipt of unsecured, low-interest loans from a St. Paul bank where his cousin is a vice president. The committee is in its grand jury phase and is trying to determine whether it should proceed to the trial stage. The panel said earlier it would make no decision Thursday on how to proceed with the case. Durenberger, who is not up for re-election until 1994, has apologized to constituents for mistakes in judgment. More than 70 percent of respondents in two recent Minnesota polls said he should resign if the ethics panel finds wrongdoing. Durenberger refused to answer reporters' questions after the meeting but said in a statement that he ``sought and received approvals from the appropriate official bodies'' in regard to financial dealings that are being questioned. Durenberger previously said the Federal Election Commission approved an agreement to promote two books he wrote and that the Senate Rules and Ethics committees sanctioned reimbursements he received for stays in a Minneapolis condominium he partly owns. The ethics panel is trying to determine whether Durenberger broke Senate rules by evading outside income limits when he made promotional speeches for the books, improperly charged the Senate for the condominium stays and received improper reimbursements for trips to Boston that combined official appearances with visits to his marriage counselor. Durenberger's statement did not address the Boston trips. He has repaid the Senate $11,005 for stays in the condominium while the Senate was not in session; the repayment did not include weekend trips during Senate sessions. There were new disclosures Wednesday that Durenberger received $1.3 million in unsecured, low-interest loans from the Commercial State Bank in St. Paul. The Star Tribune of Minneapolis published a list of 23 loans the bank made to Durenberger over the past decade at interest rates as much as 6.5 points below prime. A Durenberger aide said the list was accurate. Durenberger, however, called the story a ``mischaracterization of a normal, long-standing relationship with a bank and it was a blatant distortion of the facts.'' Bob Weinholzer, Minnesota Republican Party chairman, said in an interview Thursday that informal GOP polls show ``everybody thinks we should wait until the Ethics Committee makes a final ruling'' before judging Durenberger. Weinholzer said he expected state Democrats to increase pressure for Durenberger to resign because Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich could appoint a senator from his party to serve until an election could be held. ``Last week, he told me he has absolutely no intentions of resigning unless something major comes along in an Ethics Committee report,'' Weinholzer said about Durenberger. A St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch-WCCO Poll of 767 Minnesota adults conducted from Jan. 19-25 showed 42 percent of those polled give Durenberger favorable marks for his performance in the Senate and 53 percent give him unfavorable marks. A Star Tribune-KSTP-TV Minnesota Poll of 800 adults from Jan. 17-23 found Durenberger's approval rating had plummeted from 73 percent in October to 41 percent in January. Both polls have an error margin of plus or minus 4 percentage points. This isn't the first time that Durenberger has been in hot water with the Ethics Committee. In April 1988, the committee criticized him for discussing an espionage case in public the previous year but stopped short of recommending disciplinary action. Some senators were said to have been angered by Durenberger's reported disclosure that then-CIA Director William J. Casey had in 1982 ``changed the rules'' under which allies did not spy on each other, by recruiting an Israeli military officer to spy on Israel for the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Rejects East European Reforms _ Firmly
DOC.TEXT: A leading government official said Thursday that Albania will remain unaffected by democratic reforms sweeping the Soviet bloc, but welcomes the superpowers' reduced role in Europe. ``We are continuing along our own road, which has been very different from that of the Eastern bloc countries,'' Deputy Foreign Minster Socrat Placa told The Associated Press. Albania is Europe's last bastion of Stalinism. It is rare here that officials consent to comment spontaneously and on the record to Western reporters. This small, mountainous nation between Greece and Yugoslavia is a closed society that for decades has been Europe's most conservative communist nation. The Tirana government broke with the Soviet Union in 1961 over Moscow's policy of de-Stalinization and with China in 1978 because it viewed Beijing as deviating from Marxist-Leninist tenets. Placa said Albania followed European developments with ``intense interest'' and welcomed any reductions of U.S.-led NATO and Soviet-led Warsaw Pact forces from the Continent. The two sides are making progress at talks in Vienna on cutting their conventional troop strengths. Although it takes part in few international forums and restricts entry by foreigners, Albania consistently denies being isolationist. In arguing against the isolationist label, Placa used as an example Albania's not participating in the Helsinki process of building inter-European trust and reducing the threat of military confrontation on the Continent. ``We have not been involved in international politics, for example the Helsinki process, because that did not respect the will of the nations involved _ simply the interests of the power blocs,'' he said. Albania now has diplomatic relations with 112 countries _ many of them nonaligned Third World nations, and Placa said his country was interested in ``improving our diplomatic links both with the East and West.'' Asked about Albania's relationship with the United States, Placa blamed the Americans for the lack of formal ties. ``It was not our making that we are not engaged in diplomatic relations with America. ... Really, the ball is in their court,'' he said. He did not elaborate on consistent rejections by his government of such relations with both superpowers. Placa repeated Albanian rejections of the reform process gripping much of Eastern Europe, saying ``the turmoil ... has been due to misguided socialism, bureaucracy and corruption.'' ``We do not have that here,'' he said. Despite militant rhetoric, signs have been emerging that Albania is slightly relaxing decades of dogma, as part of a cautious move away from total control of society by the ruling Communist Party. The state ATA news agency reported Sunday that a Central Committee meeting on Jan. 22-23 agreed to give state enterprises more decision-making power, permit dual candidacies and tie wages more closely to production. Such moves are sorely needed, but will not likely be nearly enough to inject competition into a rigid, centrally controlled economy that draws on an infrastructure that has changed little since the early 1950s. Albania has the lowest gross national product in Europe, estimated at $820 a year per capita by the World Bank in 1981, the last year statistics were available. It has about 3.1 million residents. Foreign business people said Albania wants badly to increase its foreign trade, currently a paltry $860,000 a year. ``The potential is there, but this country has a lot to do before it becomes an attractive prospect,'' said Kurt Felbsberger, an Italian tourism promoter on his first visit. ``The bottom line here is they don't have the money to pay for the goods they want. Bartering, which they would like to see, is an antiquated form of trade,'' said a Finnish foreign trade official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Placa told Western reporters that ``nothing stood in the way of economic cooperation'' with the rest of Europe. ``There are no obstacles to increased trade and we should not be afraid of joint ventures,'' he said, without elaborating. The moribund economy, and resulting food shortages acknowledged by ATA in its Feb. 4 report, were reported partially responsible for riots said to have occurred in the northern city of Skhoder Jan. 11 and Jan. 14. The violence reportedly was associated with anti-Communist rallies there. But Placa said such reports were ``simply fabricated propaganda,'' mainly by Yugoslav state-supervised media. Albania and Yugoslavia's federal government are at odds over the fate of 1.9 million ethnic Albanians in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo. More than 25 ethnic Albanians died there in the latest wave of unrest for more autonomy.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Cites Council Opposition to Settlements
With AM-Baker-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Thursday he was following the issue of Soviet Jews moving to Israeli-occupied lands, and cited Security Council opposition to Jewish settlements there. Arab diplomats said the problem eventually might become an issue in the council, which is charged with maintaining international peace and security. Perez de Cuellar said, in a statement read by spokesman Francois Giuliani, that he was monitoring the situation because of protests by Arabs that the influx of Soviet Jewish settlers posed a potential threat to security and efforts toward peace in the region. Israel captured the occupied territories, the West Bank and Gaza Strip, from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 war. In Los Angeles, a spokesman for the Simon Wiesenthal Center told The Associated Press about 29 Soviet Jews had settled to the West Bank. Giuliani told a daily news briefing Perez de Cuellar was mindful that the Security Council adopted a resolution in 1980 deploring the establishment of Jewish settlements in the territories. The League of Arab States has condemned expanded settlements on grounds they undermine the possibility of a Palestinian state in the territories and jeopardize peace efforts. Clovis Maksoud, U.N. representative of the league, said last week the United States should caution Israel against seeking a ``big Israel'' in the territories to accommodate ``big immigration'' from the Soviet Union. He said settlements expanded by Soviet immigration would inflame the volatile Middle East and threaten international peace and security by altering the demographics of the West Bank and Gaza.

DOC.HEAD: New York Principal Orders Students to Take Caps Off Their Teeth
DOC.TEXT: The principal of a high school in a tough neighborhood has ordered students to take off their caps. That wouldn't be unusual, except the caps are made of gold and they're on the students' teeth. Boys and Girls High School Principal Frank Mickens said removable, cosmetic gold caps send the wrong signal about minority youths. ``You can't go to Wall Street with gold teeth or excessive jewelry,'' Mickens told the freshman class during an assembly Wednesday. ``You can be a drug dealer, you can be a prostitute, you can be a pimp.'' The estimated 100 students who wear the gold caps will have until Tuesday to doff them. ``In dealing with black and Hispanic young people, I teach them they have to be beyond reproach,'' said the principal, who is black. ``People have to look at them and immediately know they are dealing with a good young person. ``We're on a campaign of self-esteem,'' he continued. ``It's my belief that once a kid feels good about himself, he won't need the gold.'' The cosmetic caps, initially popular among drug dealers, have become a status symbol; heavyweight champion Mike Tyson often appears in public wearing one. The most popular versions feature initials or an emblem etched into the gold, and can cost up to $100. Mickens' order, which brought rumbles of protest from the assembly at the 3,500-student school, is his latest fashion edict. Three years ago, he banned excessive gold jewelry from school grounds. Since then, he's banned short skirts, shearling coats and cassette players. Board of Education spokesman Bob Terte said Mickens is entitled to issue his dress-code orders. ``The determining factor is whether it's reasonable and necessary to maintain order and discipline,'' Terte said. Dress codes vary from school to school, he said. The only systemwide regulation is one barring students from wearing beepers, which are often used by drug dealers. Mickens' school, once regarded as one of New York's worst, is in the borough of Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood, an area plagued by crime and drugs. Since Mickens' arrival four years ago, there have been improvements at Boys and Girls High. Seventy percent of its seniors now go on to further education. Mickens is ``setting kids in the right direction,'' said Obah-David Ward, president of the school's Parent, Teacher, and Community Association. ``Our students are placing the accent on the wrong thing: The gold here and the gold there, the right shoes, the right dress. We want the emphasis to be on education,'' Ward said. Erskine Tillery, a 16-year-old sophomore with two gold caps on his front teeth, said he would follow the order for a more practical reason: he'll be safer from gold thieves. ``People will shoot you if they don't come out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota News Editor Named
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT name of town to Bellefonte sted Bellefont.
DOC.TEXT: Paula Froke, a newswoman in the Minneapolis bureau of The Associated Press, has been named the AP's Minnesota news editor. The appointment was announced Thursday by Minnesota Chief of Bureau Charles Hill. Ms. Froke, 29, joined the AP in Minneapolis in 1984 after temporary assignments in Boston and on the AP's national editing desk in New York. She has been Minneapolis night editor for the past four years. Ms. Froke is a graduate of Penn State and a native of Bellefonte, Pa. She succeeds Clay Haswell, who has become managing editor of the Contra Costa Times in Walnut Creek, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Female Helicopter Pilots Dodged Gunfire in Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; SUBS grafs 7-8: ``We'd heard,'' with three grafs noting interview from Panama; CORRECTS that women are not the first to get the Air Medal but are the first to get the ``V'' on the medal; minor editing
DOC.TEXT: Two female helicopter pilots rushing U.S. troops to attack zones came under heavy fire during the Panamanian invasion, the pilots said Thursday, providing new evidence of the exposure of Army women to combat during the operation. One pilot's helicopter had to be grounded after it was hit. ``At night, when you see the tracer bullets coming at you, you realize you could end up giving up your life for your country,'' said one of the women, Army Lt. Lisa Kutschera of Milwaukee. The pilots' story is a new indication of the combat-area roles women played during the attack _ roles that have sparked controversy over what military women should or shouldn't be allowed to do in the future. Kutschera, along with Warrant Officer Debra Mann, flew UH-60 ``Blackhawk'' helicopters, trying to evade enemy bullets as they ferried infantry troops to several landing zones between midnight and dawn of Dec. 20. After Mann returned from one flight, it was discovered that her helicopter had been hit by several rounds and damaged badly enough to ground it. ``We'd heard the shots but we didn't even know we had been hit,'' she said in an interview by telephone from Panama. The two women, along with a third female pilot who also faced gunfire during a supply flight the next day, have been nominated for the Air Medal. Kutschera and Mann also have been nominated to receive the additional ``V,'' designating valor, device on the medal for particular courage. They would be the first women to get the ``V.'' U.S. law bars the Navy and Air Force from placing women in combat roles. The Army attempts to follow the law with its policy of ``combat exclusion'' that prevents women from being assigned jobs directly related to combat. As the Army defines it, that is seeking out and engaging the enemy. Since Kutschera and Mann were ferrying troops in and out of battle zones by helicopter, and not piloting attack helicopters, ``they were correctly deployed,'' said Army spokeswoman Paige Eversole. The issue of women's roles in Panama first gained attention with reports that Army Capt. Linda Bray led male and female troops who exchanged fire with Panamanian Defense Forces at a kennel for police dogs. In light of reports such as Bray's, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., has called for legislation directing the Army to conduct research on lifting the combat restrictions against women. Earlier Thursday, the head of the U.S. Southern Command, headquartered in Panama, said the United States should not change its policy. ``The routine carrying of a 120-pound rucksack day in and day out on the nexus of battle between infantrymen is that which is to be avoided and that's what the current Army policy does,'' Gen. M.R. Thurman told the Senate Armed Services Committee. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate panel, noted that some women may be capable of carrying the backpack. ``It works well just like it is,'' Thurman responded. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, head of the U.S. Central Command, said most in the military would say ``we'd probably lose some fighting ability if 50 percent of all infantry units consist of females.'' The commander of the female helicopter pilots, Capt. Thomas Muir _ himself shot in the head during one of the operations in which Kutschera was flying _ said, ``I'm quite proud of them. They took a tremendous amount of fire. There were some very hot LZ'' _ landing zones. Muir said he and his unit were on a three-month rotation from a Fort Ord, Calif., aviation regiment when the U.S. operation designed to oust Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega began. The third chopper pilot, Warrant Officer Caryl Newberry, is permanently assigned to a regiment in Panama. She came under small arms fire while flying a helicopter on a supply mission on Dec. 21, Ms. Eversole said. The men in the women's units are also being recommended for Air Medals, the two women said in the interview. Muir said Kutschera took part in three out of four operations during the first day of the invasion. During the initial night-time assault, the pilots used the Army's high-tech night vision goggles to help maneuver as they picked up about 20 soldiers each and landed to put them into position for specific attacks, he said. During the first nightime movement of troops from Howard Air Force Base to the landing zone at Fort Amador, the helicopters suffered ``heavy anti-aircraft fire and small arms fire'' from Panamanian units, Muir said. The unit ``drew quite a bit of small arms hits,'' during a second operation along the coastline during which Miss Mann's chopper was hit, he said. During flights in and out of Tinajitas, northeast of Panama City, later during the day where the unit was ferrying another battalion, ``We drew extensive number of hits. The fire was quite heavy,'' Muir said. ``It seems the PDF was ready for us.'' At that point, Muir said, he suffered a hit to the head by an AK-47 round. ``It ended the day for me,'' he joked. Besides himself, another soldier was wounded during that segment of the operation, the captain said. The Panamanians were using ``machine guns and rifles, primarily AK-47s'' when the choppers approached, he said. Kutschera, who was navigating in the lead chopper for the Tinajitas movement, said she knew the group was taking a lot of fire, despite wearing the earplugs and helmet worn by chopper crews. She said the reality of the danger of the mission sunk in when she'd heard over the radio that Muir, and a gunner on another craft, had been hit. ``It really was combat. ... Flying into Tinajitas, after I'd heard Capt. Muir'd been shot in the head, I thought, people could die doing this. That was probably the scariest point for me,'' she said. ``I guess it takes a special kind of courage,'' she said of the effort. But both Mann and Kutschera said they would both gladly do it again, if they had to. ``I was doing what I was trained for,'' said Mann, 25, of Seattle. Was she frightened? ``It was in the back of my mind. We'd known at one point that an aircraft had been shot down. I was a little apprehensive.'' Kutschera said she'd given the matter some thought before enlisting. ``It's my job. Before I got in, I resolved that some day I might have to go into combat, regardless of the combat exclusion rules,'' Kutschera said. ``But getting shot at, that definitely increases your attention,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti's Military Government Publishes New Electoral Law
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Haiti's military government published on Thursday an electoral law written by an independent panel, one day after declaring a general amnesty and freeing 19 political prisoners. It includes all rules on balloting, such as the number of polling stations to be set up, who will staff them and where ballot boxes will be brought for the final tally. Under the constitution, the Electoral Council has complete control over the voting process.
