The nine-member Electoral Council, appointed by such institutions as the Roman Catholic Church, labor unions and human rights groups, has scheduled presidential elections for Oct. 28. Local elections are to be held April 29 and legislative elections on July 22. A statement from the Information Ministry said Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril's government ``published the complete text that the members of the independent Electoral Council submitted to the executive.'' Most major politicians swore to boycott elections held under Avril after a crackdown last month in which seven prominent leaders were exiled and more than 50 activists were arrested and allegedly beaten. On Wednesday night, however, the fourth anniversary of fallen dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier's flight into exile, Avril promised not to interfere in the electoral process and urged Haitians to ``respect the rules of the democratic game.'' He declared a general amnesty for 19 jailed activists ``implicated in crimes against national security.'' At least four had been held since last year. Most of the others were believed to have been arrested during a nine-day state of siege in January which followed the assassination of an army colonel. Avril lifted the state of siege on Jan. 29 and said exiled leaders could return. Most said they won't, arguing that free elections are not possible under Avril. Thugs protected by soldiers massacred at least 34 voters at polling stations in November 1987, causing cancellation of Haiti's first free general elections since independence from France in 1804. Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who took over when Duvalier fled in 1986, scheduled army-run elections in January 1988, boycotted by most voters and candidates. Leslie Manigat was declared winner, but Namphy ousted him five months later. A soldiers' revolt drove out Namphy in September 1988 and brought Avril to power in this impoverished Caribbean island. Thousands of Haitian expatriates in Miami, Montreal, Guadeloupe and Paris demonstrated Wednesday to celebrate Duvalier's ouster and demand Avril's removal.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say U.S. Sanctions Against South Africa Encouraged Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 12-13: ``Rep. Dan,'' with another sanctions opponent
DOC.TEXT: The sanctions Congress imposed against South Africa in 1986 took a stiff economic and psychological toll on the white government and helped encourage reforms, a wide spectrum of experts say. ``International trade sanctions alone have probably resulted in a $2 billion loss annually to the South African economy,'' said Stephen R. Lewis Jr., author of ``The Economics of Apartheid.'' But Lewis, president of Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., said U.S. sanctions probably had a greater psychological than quantitative impact on South Africa because Washington never played a dominant role in the country's economy. Fewer than 1 percent of all South Africans are employed by American companies. As a result of sanctions, however, the South African government ``could no longer kid itself the United States would come down on its side,'' Lewis said. Congress, he said, sent a message that U.S. opposition to apartheid was broad-based, not simply a domestic political issue driven by the black community. Still, the U.S. sanctions _ combined with an international oil boycott, other countries' restrictions and the inefficiencies of apartheid _ have devastated the economy of South Africa, a country rich in gold and minerals, several scholars said. South Africa's economy has grown at less than 2 percent in recent years, compared with about 5 percent between 1950-1970, Lewis said. There is high black unemployment, a $20 billion external debt and a loss of business confidence. ``I think sanctions were quite important,'' said Pauline Baker of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a think tank. ``They finally made an impact on whites. The economy was in irreversible decline.'' Michael Johns, an analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, agreed that sanctions have had a negative effect on South Africa. ``At this point, there has been a realization ... sanctions played a role and increased the pressure on South Africa.'' As important as sanctions in influencing South Africa, Johns said, were the ``winds of change'' blowing through Eastern Europe and other parts of the world. Conservatives were generally against sanctions. Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., a long-time opponent of sanctions, agreed that they hurt the government. But he said he opposed them because, ``I have felt for some time the people who suffered most were the blacks.'' He said positive change ``could have been brought about just as rapidly'' through creating educational, health and jobs programs for blacks. The Reagan administration, along with then-Vice President George Bush, opposed sanctions. But Assistant Secretary of State Herman J. Cohen said last year that ``sanctions have had a positive effect,'' according to a paper on sanctions prepared by the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Among other things, U.S. sanctions barred new U.S. investment, including bank loans to the South African government; prohibited the import of South African iron, steel, coal and uranium and agricultural products, including sugar; prevented the United States from exporting computers to South Africa; banned all nuclear trade and halted landings by South African Airways. ``In general, sanctions have helped persuade whites inside the country they can't conduct business as usual,'' said Steven Davis, a senior analyst at the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a group that monitors activity in South Africa. Davis said the number of American companies doing business in South Africa is about 123, down from a one-time high of 300. A top administration official said Wednesday that South Africa is likely to make enough progress in easing oppression against blacks over the next year to permit lifting of U.S. sanctions. But despite South African President F.W. de Klerk's recent loosening of some apartheid regulations, several members of Congress said it would be premature to repeal sanctions because not all conditions for their removal have been met. ``This is a time when the United States can do the most good by waiting and watching,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. As chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in 1986, Lugar supported sanctions against South Africa, leading the drive to override President Reagan's veto of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act. Apartheid remains intact despite de Klerk's steps, several lawmakers said. De Klerk legalized the African National Congress after three decades of guerrilla war against white rule, and said he would soon free Nelson Mandela, the ANC leader mprisoned in 1962. De Klerk's actions, ``important as they are, do not meet all the conditions required to build the appropriate pre-negotiations climate,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Africa subcommittee. ``Nor to they meet the conditions set down in U.S. law required to lift the American sanctions,'' he said. Wolpe's committee, along with a House Banking subcommittee, will hold hearings later this month on legislation that would prohibit banks from rescheduling any debt held by South Africa. The sanctions dictate that de Klerk release all political prisoners, end the state of emergency completely and allow all political parties to operate. President Bush said he wants to review U.S. policy toward South Africa, including the sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua's Indians Throw Support to Opposition Candidate Chamorro
DOC.TEXT: The leading opposition presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, on Thursday picked up the support of a coalition of independent Indians from Nicaragua's Caribbean coast. Leaders of Yatama, a federation of Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians whose eight-year guerrilla war with the leftist Sandinista government ended last year, shifted their support from Social Christian candidate Eric Ramirez less than three weeks before the balloting. Mrs. Chamorro, who is challenging President Daniel Ortega of the ruling Sandinistas, signed a pact with the Indians calling for local autonomy, ``ethno-development'' and reconstruction of ``communities devastated by Sandinista repression and natural disasters.'' Hurricane Joan flattened much of Bluefields, a coastal town in the region, in October 1988. Mrs. Chamorro said she will make a campaign trip to Bluefields and Puerto Cabezas, another major town on the coast, next week. ``We're going to win this area,'' she declared. The ethnic vote in the large but sparsely populated Caribbean coast represents about 80,000 people on a nationwide roll of 1.7 million. But it has strong symbolic value because of the Indians' fierce independence. The Indians rebelled against the Sandinistas in 1981, seeking to protect a measure of autonomy against government attempts to impose a leftist system. The strife led to mass relocations of Indians and a guerrilla war in which the Indians, like the Contra rebel movement in central and western Nicaragua, received U.S. support. The Indians agreed to lay down their arms last year. Mrs. Chamorro, who is more conservative than Ramirez, represents a coalition of 14 opposition parties and the support will strengthen her challenge to Ortega in the Feb. 25 election. Clearly stung, Ramirez suggested ``financing'' had something to do with the Yatama desertion and said he had had no disagreements with the Indian leadership. He did not elaborate. Ramirez, considered a moderate, said he did not expect voters to follow the endorsement. ``It doesn't change the political picture in Nicaragua,'' he insisted in an interview. ``Everybody already knows who they are going to vote for. It's too late.'' Mrs. Chamorro, Ortega, Ramirez and seven other contenders square off in the general election. Yatama leader Brooklyn Rivera admitted Indian voters will now have to split their tickets between Mrs. Chamorro at the top and local candidates running under the Social Christian banner further down the ticket. ``We'll be going house to house, community to community,'' he said. Rivera said Yatama had decided to back Mrs. Chamorro because she is sympathetic to the concerns of the underdeveloped, isolated coast and because she's going to win. The people of the coast ``demand something better: a change, freedom and democracy,'' Rivera said. He denied any rupture with Ramirez, saying their alliance had not been formal. The coast region, which represents more than half of Nicaragua's territory, holds economic and strategic importance. Soviet bloc arms shipments and supplies arrive at its ports and the area is considered vital to national security. Former President Jimmy Carter, who will be an observer in the election, personally brokered the agreement between Rivera and the Sandinistas that led to Rivera's return to Nicaragua late last year. The agreement ended a ban on Rivera organizing indigenous political groups.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Recalls 1969 Santa Barbara Disaster
With AM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The oil spill threatening California's coast pales in comparison with the offshore oil well blowout that fouled Santa Barbara beaches in 1969 and helped create the environmental movement. Crews toiled Thursday to clean up more than 290,000 gallons of oil that hovered off the Southern California city of Huntington Beach after being spilled Wednesday by the tanker American Trader. Estimates go as high as 3.25 million gallons for the spill Jan. 28, 1969, that resulted from failure of a well casing on a Union Oil Co. of California platform 5{ miles off Santa Barbara. Perhaps more significant, industry experts and environmentalists alike have said public concern for the environment was focused by nationally televised scenes of birds and beaches drenched with sticky black goo. The spill spurred an eight-year drilling moratorium off Santa Barbara. The blowout ``spewed more than 3.25 million gallons of oil over 800 square miles of water, covered 100 miles of coastline and beaches with a thick, tarry black goo, smothered thousands of birds, fish and other sea life, and helped trigger a new age of environmental awareness,'' the California Coastal Commission said on the spill's 20th anniversary. Even two decades after the Santa Barbara spill, Union Oil _ now renamed Unocal Corp. _ claimed that, at most, 840,000 gallons spilled. But the Western States Petroleum Association has said at least 2.1 million gallons spilled. The spill killed at least 9,000 birds, 8.8 million barnacles, 30,000 mussels and 51,800 limpets, but harm to the fishing industry wasn't proved, according to tallies by biologist Michael Neushul of the University of California, Santa Barbara. Unocal, which ended up paying about $16 million to settle spill-related lawsuits, has argued the spill wasn't an ecological disaster, and that it spurred improvements in drilling technology and training of workers on drilling platforms. Environmentalists contend oil still leaks from the spill site, but Unocal blames natural oil seepage from the ocean floor.

DOC.HEAD: Members Approved for NTSB, FMC, ICC, FCC
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday confirmed the appointments of James L. Kolstad to be chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board and Susan M. Coughlin to be a member. The appointments were approved by unanimous consent, meaning no vote was required. The Senate also approved the appointment of former Maine Senator William D. Hathaway to be a Federal Maritime Commissioner, Edward J. Philbin to the Interstate Commerce Commission and Ervin S. Duggan to the Federal Communications Commission. Kolstad, 50, had been acting chairman of the safety board since May 1987. He replaced James Burnett. Burnett, a former Arkansas judge who as chairman for six years gained a reputation as a strong, independent safety advocate, was forced to relinquish his chairmanship when his term expired and the Senate did not act on his renomination. Coughlin, 43, has been acting administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration since April 1989. She is married to Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa.

DOC.HEAD: Army Tries Gravel Thrower That Fires 600 Stones a Minute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with higher bail for young stone-throwers, details. Picks up 13th, `In political ...
DOC.TEXT: In its latest effort to halt rioting in the occupied territories, the Israeli army has introduced a jeep-mounted gravel thrower that spews out 600 egg-sized rocks a minute, Israel radio said Thursday. It is the latest addition to the army's growing anti-uprising arsenal that includes tear gas and rubber, plastic and metal bullets. Israel has drawn international criticism for firing guns at stone-throwers, most of them children and teen-agers. But army officials say troops use live ammunition only when their lives are in danger. Also on Thursday, a military source said the army will increase bail for Palestinian stone-throwers under the age of 15 from $750 to $2,500. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the money will be returned with interest if the child does not repeat the offense within one year of his arrest. The average Palestinian worker earns $300 to $400 a month. Arab reports said meanwhile that a 20-year-old Palestinian, Salman Mardi El Madani from the Gaza Strip village of Bani Suheila, died Thursday of bullet wounds suffered in a clash with troops a day earlier. The army confirmed the death, but said the circumstances were under investigation. The death brought to 654 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 26-month-old uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 181 Palestinians were killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence. In the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Rafah on the Egyptian border, riots raged for a second day and at least eight Palestinians were wounded by soldiers, Arab reports said. The protests began Wednesday night after soldiers killed an 18-year-old camp activist. Protesters chanted slogans supporting a terrorist raid on a bus in Egypt that killed nine Israeli tourists Sunday, Israel radio said. The driver of the assailants' car lived in the camp before emigrating to Egypt 10 years ago. Israel radio said protests shouted the bus casualty toll and ``Remember what we did to you!'' An army official refused comment Thursday on reports on the gravel thrower. The radio said it was first used in the West Bank town of Ramallah this week. The battery-powered device weighs 66 pounds, can be mounted on a jeep and operated by one soldier. It can throw the egg-sized stones 75 yards, the report said. Previous gravel throwers used by the army were much heavier and less mobile. The commander of the West Bank, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, told the national Itim news agency that as far as Palestinians' throwing stones was concerned, ``The solutions will be high bail, arrests, and the sealing of the homes of stone-throwers.'' The military source said the maximum sentence for throwing stones and damaging a vehicle is 20 years in prison for Palestinians above the age of 15. The sentence can be higher if someone is injured. In political developments, the Palestine Liberation Organization reportedly gave the United States a list of 13 candidates for a Palestinian delegation to hold preliminary peace talks with Israel in Cairo. The list, as published by the Israeli newspaper Maariv, is dominated by backers of PLO chief Yasser Arafat. It also contains two Palestinians from Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem and two Palestinians deported by Israel. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, opposes Palestinians from east Jerusalem and deportees as negotiators, but he has not ruled out a compromise. Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab discounted the list, saying that ``if the PLO was to issue a list, I doubt that an Israeli paper would be the first place where the names would appear.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0758 to make cycle designator BC
MOSCOW: our society.
DOC.TEXT: We exchange opinions here and are summing them up in a difficult debate, and sometimes this injures our pride. Sharp words sound in this hall. But in the end we arrive at the main and, I think, progressive conclusion. We should consolidate actions on the basis of this conclusion. The debate has been held. The decision has been made. The program has been endorsed. There are guidelines for action. We must act instead of recollecting who said what and who this concerns. And we have people inclined to this. We cannot get used to the fact that a normal process of debates is on, that pluralism of opinions is not dissent but democratic centralism understood in a new way. Open debates are held on vital questions of perestroika, when the destiny of the country and, taking into account its importance, the destiny of the whole world is being decided. Is there any room for trying to please one another and for sparing one's pride? All this is gone not to be returned. There is no need to try to guess if this person can be dealt with and the other one cannot. We should all be together, should feel each other's support and act together. We should not start breaking up into clans and groups. This is the road to destroying the party and the country. I wish to mention a debate among Politburo members that broke out here. Meeting miners, I told them the truth that there are no differences that would interfere with effective functioning of the Politburo. It is understandable that there is conflict of opinions, that debates become more acute. I met miners from all over the country and received a wealth of information from them. We get meetings, discuss documents, compare them, there are acute conversations. I would like to say, comrade Malkov, that nobody should think that the Politburo has split, that things are bad. This is not the case and we should be striving that this should not be so. We undergo such trial now in the Central Committee, in the Politburo, in the whole of the party and we should be up to the mark. I liked very much what comrade Alexeyev said. He is a lawyer. And he also has a philosophical approach. A combination of these qualities _ streamlined thinking and scope _ is always effective. I have already said this, describing him thus, when we nominated him to the post of chairman of the constitutional compliance committee. I liked what Sergei Sergeyevich said. We are at the crucial stage, are involved in such events that we can hardly assess in full what we are doing and what consequences this will have. Our drama is that a load of current problems and acute socio-economic are pressing hard on us. We overlooked many things and exacerbated the situation. This is true, but this should not lead us to confusion. We should have scope from which to approach this process. A turn is being made toward world civilization. Renewal processes take place in the socialist world. We must get the bearing in many things, as comrade Shatalin noted. We are placing correct guidelines for the future, but it is important not to err in tactic and fall out. And surely we should not mix things up. If we always appraise events from such a vantage point, this is one kind of approach. But if we start to proceed from considerations how it affects oneself or what will happen to oneself tomorrow, this will be another kind of approach. I have been saying at the Politburo all the time: The question we consider now deserves that we should forget our present posts and should not think what happens to us tomorrow, for the point of the matter is the country and guidelines for its development. We have not yet reached this height. There are many people who want simple solutions, but there are none. We are now at a stage when there are no simple solutions, nor will there be. It is pardonable in a rank-and-file individual, unversed in these matters when he asks for a clear answer where everything is labeled with simple numbers: one, two, three, four. All populists seek to bank on this. The ruling party, expecially in a country like ours, cannot embark on this way. We must see the world and the country in a broad perspective, both today's situation and the prospects for the future. I believe we have not erred in the main thing so far. But we did err in taking required measures, in delaying them or failing to ensure the synchronization of processes, especially in the economic reform. This has complicated the state of affairs, and boomerangs politically. But this does not mean that we should panic and cry `help.' One says, `(you) have wrecked a flourishing state,' another something else of the same kind. True in another breath they will tell you they are not panic-mongers and favor perestroika. But they are panic-mongers. This is defeatism. This has been a major plenum with major results. But all this will only bear fruit if we involve all healthy, reform-oriented forces in the party, on the basis of the new party platform, and will resolutely promote the political ideas and plans that are incorporated in the platform. I want to express confidence and hope that you will support me: we now better understand our responsibility and we are better armed so as to resolutely move ahead and advance our common cause, the cause of perestroika, the cause of renewing socialist society.

DOC.HEAD: Spill Spurs Calls for Tough Shipping Regulation
With AM-Offshore Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Officials and environmentalists on Thursday likened the Huntington Beach oil spill to a rude wake-up call, and urged lawmakers to pass tough legislation to protect fragile shorelines and punish polluters. ``Once again dumb luck has smiled on California. Every good break we could have gotten, we have,'' state Controller Gray Davis told a news conference in Huntington Beach after a helicopter tour over the slick off the coast. Wednesday's 295,000-gallon oil spill from the tanker American Trader threatened miles of beaches and estuaries Thursday. But favorable offshore winds held the slick stationary against an onshore current a mile out to sea, and calm seas eased cleanup efforts. Later, however, the wind reversed direction. Davis, who sits on the California Lands Commission, promised a state investigation. He also said the commission would call on Congress to require tankers be fitted with double hulls, an issue now before Congress. The commission, which regulates oil development in state lands and waters, declared previously unprotected tracts in state waters off-limits to new drilling in December. ``This serves as a wake-up call,'' Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy said at the news conference. He urged the state Assembly to pass pending oil spill prevention and liability legislation. Attorney General John Van de Kamp, speaking to reporters on the beach a short time later, called the spill ``a very fortuitous, beneficial warning'' to state residents and lawmakers. ``We need to do something to make sure this doesn't happen again,'' said Van de Kamp, a Democratic candidate for governor. A U.S. House-Senate conference committee is working on differing House and Senate bills to produce a measure both chambers can approve by the March 24 anniversary of the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound. Davis and McCarthy cited the spill in pushing for passage of a state bill that would require tankers be equipped with booms and other cleanup equipment. The bill would establish a $500 million reserve funded by the oil industry to clean up spills, said Ed Manning, a McCarthy aide who wrote the legislation. Davis said oil companies have indicated they are willing to contribute a total of $10 million to such a fund. The bill also would require each company operating tankers in state waters to meet a $400 million insurance requirement to pay for potential legal costs in the event of a spill, Manning said. Had the bill been law, British Petroleum Co. PLC, which chartered the American Trader, could have been required to pay an estimated $25 million penalty to the state, Davis said. A November ballot initiative that would enact similar prevention and cleanup measures and prohibit new drilling in California waters also was expected to receive a boost from the spill. Some activists said the spill should remind Californians and the rest of the nation about the hazards of reliance on oil as an energy source. ``The whole issue is that every gallon of oil we save is one less gallon of oil that must be pumped and transported and one less gallon that can spill,'' Bob Hattoy, regional director of the Sierra Club of Southern California, said in Huntington Beach. ``The longer we remain addicted to oil, the more we pollute the air we breathe, warm the globe, despoil our landscape _ and run the risk of oil spills,'' Sydney Butler, vice president for conservation at the Wilderness Society, said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Snow In Northwest; Much of Nation Had Mild Weather
DOC.TEXT: Snow hit the mountains of the Northwest on Thursday while rain dampened parts of the Gulf Coast states. Most of the nation east of the Rockies enjoyed mild and dry weather. A storm crossing the Northwest and another approaching the northern Pacific coast brought snow to the mountains in Washington and Oregon. Rain fell in the northern and central Pacific coast region. Heavier rainfall totals for the six-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1.30 inches at Crescent City, Calif., and nearly half an inch at Astoria and North Bend in Oregon. Parts of Montana, Idaho, Wyoming and Colorado had snow and high winds. Wind gusts reached 55 mph at Sheridan, Wyo., and 65 mph around Wheatland. The Colorado Rockies got up to 7 inches of snow overnight Wednesday, and a cold front curving through the southwest brought snow to parts of Arizona. Elsewhere, rain showers developing north of a warm front extended from the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas to Mississippi. Sunny skies prevailed from Southern California to the Dakotas, from the southern Plains to the Great Lakes and over much of the East. A number of cities reported record high temperatures; Charleston, S.C., 74; Flint, Mich., 44; Mansfield, Ohio, 47; Peoria, Ill, 63; Tulsa, Okla., 76. Subfreezing temperatures were confin and an insurance industry group said Thursday that a study of 106 former and current state insurance commissioners showed about half of them obtained jobs with insurance companies after they left office. The study highlights ``the short period of time many commissioners served'' and ``the number of former commissioners who immediately moved to the industry after leaving office,'' said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. The study was released by the Consumer Insurance Interest Group and the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents, which said state insurance commissioners should be prohibited from working directly or indirectly for the industry for one year after leaving office to avoid the reality or appearance of conflict of interest. The survey found that 49 percent of the former commissioners worked for insurance companies or provided legal, accounting or other professional services to the industry after leaving office. ``Their study is incomplete and does not support that sweeping conclusion,'' said Earle Palmeroy, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. ``They've made no conclusion that the regulation of individual commissioners was affected by their later work for the industry,'' said Palmeroy, the North Dakota commissioner. Palmeroy also objected to the group's inclusion of commissioners who later worked for law and accounting firms that had insurance companies as clients. Insurance commissioners are appointed or elected to state boards to regulate insurance rates, allocate insurance premium taxes and carry out other duties. ``This study doesn't contain any evidence of impropriety by insurance commissioners,'' noted Richard Yingling, president of the National Association of Professional Insurance Agents. But ``even the potential for the appearance of conflict can erode the public's confidence in state regulation of insurance,'' he added. The study tracks the employment patterns of 55 former and 51 current commissioners from the 50 states and the District of Columbia who are or have served from 1984 through 1989. Employment information was obtained for 53 of the former commissioners. Twenty-six worked for the insurance industry in some capacity; 13 went to other government positions. Nine entered other industries or practiced non-insurance related law, while five retired. The Consumer Insurance Interest Group is a coalition of three consumer advocacy organizations _ the Consumer Federation of America; Public Citizen, a Ralph-Nader founded group, and the National Insurance Consumer Organization. The National Association of Professional Insurance Agents is a trade associaiton representing 180,000 independent insurance agents who specialize in home, auto and business insurance.

DOC.HEAD: N. David Gross Named Editor of The Jerusalem Post
DOC.TEXT: The Jerusalem Post announced Thursday that N. David Gross, a 40-year veteran of the English-language newspaper, has been named its top editor. Gross, 67, replaced Erwin Frenkel, who submitted his resignation in December in a dispute over editorial freedom with the paper's new management. Frenkel had been editor 14 years. The Post, the nation's only English daily, was purchased last year by the Canadian newspaper chain, Hollinger Inc. The paper has a daily circulation of about 25,000, but is widely read by journalists and diplomats. The Post also prints an overseas edition with a circulation of 75,000. Gross, who joined the Post in 1950, a year after he immigrated to Israel from England, had been named managing editor in January. He earlier served as associate managing editor, chief night editor and news editor and periodically wrote a column. More than 25 reporters quit the newspaper in support of Frankel, and they have said they are seeking investors to establish a new English-language daily.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Politicians Urge Deeper Reforms in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs with Yeltsin's warnings, quotes, in CBS interview.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB11, MOS16
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy reformers from within and outside the Communist Party said Thursday the decision to renounce its legal claim on power is not enough to end political repression and centralized control. ``It is necessary to eliminate (Communist) party organizations in the army, the police, the KGB, the courts, in all the state institutions,'' said Yuri Mityunov, a spokesman for a would-be opposition party, the Democratic Union. Boris N. Yeltsin, who has pressed for greater reform, cast the only vote against the changes Wednesday in the policy-making Central Committee _ because, he said, they did not go far enough. ``I had grounds to vote against, but I think, however, that the platform represents, if not a step then a half-step forward, and that lessens the tension before the (party) congress'' late in June, he said in his office near the Kremlin. A second party should be formed unless the congress removes conservatives from Communist Party leadership, said Yeltsin, who spoke Sunday to the largest pro-democracy rally in decades, at the foot of Red Square. Several hundred thousand people rallied to demand that the party abandon its guaranteed leading role in society. At the Central Committee meeting that ended Wednesday, the party did just that, approving President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's platform of revoking the power monopoly in favor of a multi-party system. ``The discussion was very hot,'' Yeltsin said. ``The proposals were diametrically opposed. It was not easy.'' Mityunov said pressure for reform is moving to the streets, and cited the growing number of angry crowds across the Soviet Union demanding the ouster of hard-line local Communist leaders. Party secretaries in Volgograd, Tyumen, Chernigov and Sverdlovsk were removed in recent weeks, and activists said 6,000 people gathered in front of the party headquarters in Donetsk on Wednesday with a similar demand. Reformers in Saratov plan a rally Sunday to demand removal of their party leaders. Vremya, the main television news program, showed a rally in Donetsk on Thursday where people demanded the resignation of Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, a leading conservative. A commentator said most people at the rally supported Gorbachev. The official news agency Tass said officials of the Baltic merchant fleet decided to return more than 200 Communist political officers on its ships to jobs as mechanics, electricians and navigators, or assign them to shore duty. Yeltsin said the party must reform itself, but the current strength of conservatives in the Central Committee, to which he belongs, complicates the task. He declined to say what percent of the vote he thought the Communist Party would win if there were free elections now. ``The transition to a multiparty system is just a question of time,'' he said. ``It is inevitable and necessary. We should use all chances still to renew the party so that it will have a democratic basis. We should try this chance.'' The party Congress will vote on the party platform and has the power to change the Central Committee. Yeltsin said the platform, which has yet to be made available to the public, contained outdated language and failed to endorse radical measures he said are needed to undo the economic chaos created by seven decades of central planning. ``You talk about approving this program, how can I do it?'' Yeltsin asked. He said the draft still endorses ``democratic centralism,'' the principle used to justify central planning, and fails to favor radical measures need to revive the economy. Yeltsin said the Central Committee rejected his proposal for eliminating the bureaucracy as an instrument of power in favor of self-management in enterprises and said he believed that a market-style economy was desirable as long as workers were protected in the transition. Gorbachev has often lambasted the party apparat as a force blocking perestroika, his plan for economic restructuring. Countries such as Poland and Czechoslovakia that have embraced democratic reforms are finding that digging out the apparat is a major challenge to economic changes. Yeltsin said he favored creating factions within the party, but the Central Committee opposed allowing formal factions to form. ``We should try such a thing as factions that could exist in this transition period, that possibility of discussion and not an atmosphere of unanimity and unity that Ligachev constantly calls for. He (Ligachev) calls for unity, unity for the sake of an idea,'' Yeltsin said. Later Thursday, in an interview with CBS-TV, Yeltsin said, ``If we cannot feed the people right now, if we cannot produce good clothing and if we cannot develop our people spiritually, it doesn't matter what slogans we shout. The people will never respond.'' He also said ``the time for half-measures and compromises is over. We are sitting on a critical mass, a volcano. And within a certain period of time neither Gorbachev nor any other man may be able to lead. Then the people will decide their destiny, like the people of Eastern Europe. ``It would be nice if it's done in a civilized form ... like East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria. But what if it happens like Romania? The bloodshed, the tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey of Low-Income Women Finds Many Anemic in Pregnancy
DOC.TEXT: Many of the nation's lower-income women, especially blacks, are anemic during pregnancy, a condition that can lead to premature delivery or death of the fetus, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. Thirty-eight percent of blacks and 19 percent of whites in the third trimester of pregnancy had hemoglobin levels indicating anemia, in a 1987 survey of lower income women, the CDC reported. During the second trimester, 6 percent of white women and 18 percent of black women were anemic. In the first three months of pregnancy, 4 percent and 13 percent, respectively, were anemic. Nationwide, the CDC said, about 5 percent of non-pregnant, childbearing-age women have anemia. The survey results mean ``many low-income women have poor iron nutrition both before and during pregnancy,'' the CDC said. ``Among pregnant women who receive sufficient iron, (hemoglobin) levels normally decrease early in pregnancy, the increase through the third trimester'' to near pre-pregnancy levels, the Atlanta-based CDC said. For the women in the low-income survey, ``the failure to attain pre-pregnancy levels during the third trimester suggests that many of these women were iron deficient during pregnancy.'' The racial differences ``may be related to a greater risk for iron deficiency in black women,'' the CDC said. But ``the explanation for the difference observed in this analysis is unclear.'' Anemia during pregnancy increases a woman's risk of premature delivery and increases the child's chances of low birth weight and fetal death, the CDC said. The CDC's 1987 Pregnancy Nutrition Surveillance System studied anemia during pregnancy among more than 68,000 lower-income women in 13 states, most of them enrolled in the federal Women, Infants and Children food program.

DOC.HEAD: British Boy Scouts to Admit Girls
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Boy Scouts said Thursday they have decided to break their 83-year tradition and admit girls, who sometimes find the activities in the Girl Guides movement a little too tame. The leader of the Guides, who count Queen Elizabeth II as their most famous former member, was less than thrilled at the announcement and said she hoped the Scouts didn't plan to raid her organization for members. The Boy Scouts of America has allowed girls, ages 6-15, to belong to its Explorer Division for about 19 years, according to national spokesman Lee Sneath. ``The Explorer Posts are co-ed, so it's not like we have a troop of girls and a troop of boys,'' Sneath said in Dallas. ``They're intermingled and they do exactly the same things.'' Chief Scout Garth Morrison said in announcing the British Scouts' decision that local Scout chapters will be able to choose whether to admit girls because some ``want nothing to do with girls.'' Nobody would be forced to have them, he said. ``We are aware that in some places there is a pressing need for it and we are anxious to meet that need. It is an important move and a move in the right direction,'' Morrison said. Nicola Lowes, 14, turned down in October when she and two friends applied to join the Scout group in Wark, northern England, said she would reapply Monday. ``I was in the Guides for a little while but I thought it was really boring,'' she said. ``Scouts seem more active and you get outdoors more. ``I was really upset when I was turned down. I kept asking them why, it just wasn't fair. ``I think the boys will be for it, they treat us just the same as they are.'' Bob Hogarth, Scout leader of the Wark troop, said: ``The three girls have been campaigning strongly, and personally I am in favor of it. We had discussions with the boys in the troop who are aged 10 to 15 and they were in favor of it too.'' Morrison, a former navy lieutenant, said the Scout movement would be opened to girls aged six to 15, with the first girl scouts probably enrolled in 1991. Older girls were allowed to join Britain's Venture Scouts in 1976 and there are 11,000 of them now _ about a quarter of the total membership. Girl Guides' Chief Commissioner June Paterson-Brown said she was ``very angry'' when she learned of the move. The two groups had just finished a two-year joint study on greater cooperation. ``I am extremely disappointed,'' she said, but added, ``I hope we are big enough to say that if the Scouts want this, it's their decision. It really depends if the Scouts target our girls. If they try to poach our girls then it will make things very difficult.'' Morrison said girl and boy scouts would have separate tents, toilets, and washing facilities on camping trips, with men and women leaders. A Scout spokesman said there were 680,000 British Scouts and a lot of pressure had built up by girls eager to join, attracted by the more adventurous activities. Scouts frequently hike and camp out, but Guides don't go camping as often.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Sets of Vietnam War-Era Remains Begin Journey Home
DOC.TEXT: A military honors ceremony was held Thursday morning as eight American servicemen killed during the Vietnam War began their final journey home. The remains, identified by the Army's Central Identification Laboratory here, were placed aboard a military jet at Hickam Air Force Base. The jet was bound for Travis Air Force Base, Calif. Six sets of remains belong to Army soldiers killed in the crash of a South Vietnamese air force CH-34 helicopter in Laos on Nov. 30, 1968. Their remains were recovered in a joint excavation by the governments of the United States and Laos in March 1989, the U.S. Pacific Command said. The dead were identified as: Maj. Samuel K. Toomey III of Independence, Mo.; Capt. Raymond C. Stacks of Memphis, Tenn.; Sgt. 1st Class Arthur E. Bader Jr. of Atlantic City, N.J.; Sgt. 1st Class Gary R. La Bohn of Wixom, Mich.; Sgt. 1st Class Klaus D. Scholz of Amarillo, Texas; and Sgt. 1st Class Michael H. Mein of Cape Vincent, N.Y. Also identified Wednesday were the remains of a serviceman who died on Oct. 2, 1968. His name was withheld at the request of his family. The eighth set of remains was identified in November as Air Force Col. Charles D. Roby of Iowa Park, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Opens With Blast at Government
DOC.TEXT: Authorities hated U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar and considered him an enemy because of his liberal rulings, his attorney said Thursday in the opening shot of his obstruction-of-justice trial. But a prosecutor told a U.S. District Court jury in opening arguments that Aguilar, who is accused of using his office to do favors for convicted felons, engaged in an eight-year ``pattern of criminal activity.'' Aguilar, 58, the fourth federal judge indicted in the last decade, is charged with eight felony counts. Several of the accusations against him are combined in a charge that he used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice, the first such charge against a federal judge. If convicted, he could draw up to 55 years in prison and $2 million in fines. Defense attorney Patrick Hallinan said Aguilar's rulings as a federal judge in San Jose since 1980 had generated consternation among prosecutors and caused some law enforcement officers to ``look upon him as an an enemy.'' Those officers, he said, included FBI agent Thomas Carlon, ``the architect of this indictment'' and a man with a ``distaste for judges of a liberal bent.'' Hallinan also said the government had ignored the disappearance of Aguilar's former legal secretary, Vera Hoff, for nearly a decade until last year, when ``they kidnapped her and intimidated her into testifying.'' Aguilar is accused of helping Mrs. Hoff remain a fugitive in Mexico from a tax evasion sentence by advising her and offering financial help. Hallinan's attempt to say more about Carlon was cut off by U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle, who told him to save his arguments for the end of the trial. But the theme was picked up again by lawyers for Aguilar's co-defendants, Rudy Tham, 66, a convicted embezzler who was once a powerful Teamsters union leader, and Abe Chapman, 83, a self-styled ex-mob gunman with a long prison record who was related to the judge by marriage. The attorneys said Carlon and another FBI agent repeatedly approached U.S. District Judge Stanley Weigel, told him Aguilar was part of a conspiracy to influence his rulings, and tried to get him to tape-record his conversations with Aguilar. ``If there was obstruction of justice, it was by these men here,'' said defense lawyer Doron Weinberg, pointing to the agents sitting alongside the prosecutors. Aguilar is accused of approaching Weigel and another fellow judge on behalf of Tham and Ronald Cloud, an Aguilar creditor and former law client charged with bank fraud; of tipping off Chapman about wiretaps and FBI surveillance; of lying to the FBI; and of telling one of Tham's attorneys to lie to a grand jury. Justice Department prosecutor Ralph Martin said in his opening statement that Aguilar attempted over eight years to interfere with the proper functioning of the judicial system. Martin said Aguilar approached Weigel in Tham's case and U.S. District Judge Samuel Conti in Cloud's. At the time, Martin said, Tham was seeking a hearing before Weigel to overturn his embezzlement conviction, and Cloud was awaiting trial before Conti on bank fraud charges in the sale of a Nevada casino. Tham was denied a hearing, and Cloud was convicted. Martin acknowledged that Weigel interpreted Aguilar's comments as mere inquiries that weren't improper. But the prosecutor said Aguilar showed his intent to help Tham, and thereby interfere with the administration of justice, by giving clandestine advice to Tham's attorneys and boasting of his influence with Weigel. Martin also said Tham helped one of Aguilar's brothers get a job. In Cloud's case, Martin said, Aguilar called Conti and said Cloud was ``an old man, he's from Fresno, and he's a friend of mine.'' Conti considered the comment improper, and Aguilar later made secretive efforts to help Cloud's appeal, Martin said. Hallinan put different interpretations on some of Martin's allegations. The defense lawyer said Aguilar had merely ``shared his expertise'' on legal matters without trying to influence other judges, and that the judge didn't know Mrs. Hoff was a fugitive when he contacted her.

DOC.HEAD: Strongest Quake in 50 Years Rocks Philippines, 25 Hurt
DOC.TEXT: The central Philippines was rocked Thursday by the strongest earthquake in the region in nearly 50 years, injuring at least 25 people, shaking buildings and shattering windows, authorities said. The earthquake was measured at 6.9 on the Richter scale by the U.S. Geological Survey, according to Pat Jorgenson, a public affairs officer at its Menlo Park, Calif., office. Philippine officials measured 20 aftershocks, including one registering 6.6. The quake was centered near Camiguin Island, about 450 miles southeast of Manila, said Bart Bautista of the Philippine Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology. The earthquake also was felt on Cebu and Negros islands, about 140 miles north of Camiguin, and in Cagayan de Oro on the northern tip of Mindanao island, Bautista said. Twenty-two construction workers suffered burns when a vat of hot tar spilled on them at a 16-story building site in Cebu, 350 miles south of here. Doctors said 15 were hospitalized, and that one was in serious condition. Buildings swayed and electricity was cut in Cebu, the major city in the central Visayas islands. Several others were slightly injured when a stampede broke out at one of the largest department stores in Cebu. Traffic stopped as people ran out of homes, offices and schools. A power failure affected large parts of the city. Jorgensen said the earthquake was the strongest in the region since Feb. 4, 1941. The Richter scale measures the magnitude of a quake at its epicenter, according to ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 6 on the Richter scale is considered ``severe,'' a magnitude of 7 a ``major'' earthquake capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Airline Owner Alleged to be Link Between Failed Bank, CIA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `The Post...' to CORRECT spelling of Azima.
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities backed away from investigating an airline owner accused of contributing to the financial failure of a Kansas City bank because he had ties to the CIA, a newspaper reported. Farhad Azima, a native Iranian and owner of Global International Airways, was the fourth-largest shareholder in Indian Springs State Bank of Kansas City, Kan., which failed in 1984, The Houston Post reported. The Post said it was told by federal law enforcement sources, which it did not identify, that the FBI did not investigate Azima's and Global's links to Indian Springs because the CIA said Azima was ``off limits.'' ``I was told by the FBI that Azima had a get-out-of-jail-free card,'' a source in the investigation told The Post in a story published Thursday. The story is one of a series of Post articles suggesting possible links between the CIA, organized crime and the failure of 22 savings and loans, as well as Indian Springs. Global International, based in Kansas City, Mo., started in 1978 shipping cattle to Iran. The fleet grew to 14 Boeing 707 jets. Some federal investigators say Global was owned by the CIA; others say it performed contract work for the agency, The Post said. A cargo plane that the Federal Aviation Administration said was owned by Azima was linked in 1986 to secret shipments of American military supplies to Iran. Azima's attorney said at the time the plane was leased to someone else and Azima didn't know how it had been used. Global filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1983. It owed Indian Springs State Bank about $280,000, according to a list of about $15 million in Global's debts to unsecured creditors. The bank's records indicate Global was overdrawn at the bank by an average of $150,000 a day, The Post said. Indian Springs, with about $27 million in deposits, failed in January, 1984. Azima, who was a director of the bank and owned nearly 10 percent of its shares, was a defendant in a suit filed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. seeking to recover some of the bank's losses. The suit alleged that fraud and negligence on the part of Azima, as a bank official, contributed to the bank's failure, The Post reported. The suit was settled out of court, and no criminal charges were filed against Azima in connection with the failure. Global ``certainly did contribute to the failure of Indian Springs State Bank,'' said Michael Manning, a Kansas City lawyer hired by the FDIC to investigate the bank's failure. Asked about Global's overdrafts at Indians Springs, Azima told the Post, ``I don't get involved in the details of the operations. I have no idea about that.'' Azima, who now lives in London, told The Post in a telephone interview he didn't recall Global doing any work for the CIA, then said ``As a matter of policy we don't comment on questions like this.'' The CIA, in response to a request from the Post under the Freedom of Information Act, said it could neither confirm nor deny that any relationship existed with Azima.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Defends Military Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Bush remarks aboard Air Force One; picks up 8th graf pvs, bgng: As red xxx; DELETES final five grafs pvs to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: Precede OMAHA
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday defended his tour of military bases and tough talk on defense issues at a time of dramatic change in Moscow, saying ``the timing happened to be fortuitous.'' The president, speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One as he returned from a three-day trip that focused on military readiness, said he did not believe his message would be seen as running counter to this week's developments in the Soviet Union. Bush said the message he was seeking to send the Soviet Union was ``one of stability, of reasonableness.''Earlier, the president, Broadcasting from an underground command bunker at Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha, the president told the nation's nuclear-bearing forces to take some credit for the movement toward more democracy within the Soviet Union. Bush's talk to men and women of SAC wrapped up a three-day trip that focused on U.S. military vigilance against what he depicted as an ongoing Soviet threat _ a message played out in contrast to Soviet developments widely seen as encouraging in the West. As Bush was watching war games and giving military speeches, Moscow's Central Committee, the Soviet Communist Party's policy-making body, was concluding a historic meeting at which it endorsed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for an end to the party's constitutional monopoly on power. Bush made little reference to the Soviet developments during his trip, praising Gorbachev's initiatives but saying he didn't want to ``pick winners or losers'' from afar. Some administration officials privately had suggested that the timing of Bush's saber-rattling tour of military installations could have been better. But the president disputed that notion in his in-flight talk with reporters. ``I'm not going to miss an opportunity in arms control. But we're going to keep a strong defense.'' ``And I think that's a stabilizing message, not a militant messsage. And that's why I think the timing happened to be fortuitous,'' Bush added. The president suggested that, by stressing military vigilance through the week and not overreacting to the events in Moscow, ``I hope the message comes through in a balanced way that we are not going to suddenly, drastically change our course away from a reasonable defense program.'' He said he wanted Western European allies to know that the United States is not about abandon them or ``decouple'' from its defense responsibilities there, beyond the troop reductions he has already proposed. ``As long as I'm president, it won't take place,'' Bush said. In his visit to the SAC headquarters in Omaha, Bush, who was a World War II bomber pilot,put on a leather flight jacket and bounded up a ladder into a sleek B-1 bomber to try out the controls. Then, in his business suit, Bush joined two dozen high-ranking military officers in the newly refurbished SAC command post 40 feet beneath the surface of Offutt Air Force Base. As red lights flashed over names of SAC installations on a large screen at the front of the theater-style room, Bush leaned toward the microphone that would carry his voice over SAC's ``primary alerting system.'' ``Good morning. This is the president speaking to you,'' he began. Citing ``a critical need to continue our strategic modernization program,'' Bush hailed the service people who maintain the nation's primary line of nuclear defense. ``I also want to salute your role in shaping history, for the historical changes we are seeing in the Soviet Union are in no small part due to the vigilance and sheer hard work of the men and women of the Strategic Air Command,'' Bush said. ``Your practice of deterrence has kept the peace, and defined the basis for positive change in the Soviet Union,'' he added. But, he continued, echoing a theme he has sounded all week, ``We still live in a time of uncertainty. So as we push for a major new arms agreement with the Soviets, to increase stability we will continue to modernize strategic forces.'' Later, Bush told a Republican fund-raising dinner in Columbus, Ohio _ his last stop before heading home _ that there was ``a new moment of promise'' in the world. But he said any defense cuts must be made ``with a scalpel, not a meat axe.'' And he predicted bitter defense spending battles ahead with the Democratic-controlled Congress. On his proposal to reduce U.S. troops in Europe from 305,000 now to 225,000, which was put forward in the Vienna convention forces negotiations on Thursday, Bush said: ``I am convinced we can do this. The initial reaction from Mr. Gorbachev has been quite positive.'' Referring to the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee meeting, Bush said, ``Now we've seen them take the first steps toward pluralism, multipartyism if you will. He called the events of the past year ``unbelievable, unpredictable change, a triumph of democracy from Prague to Panama.'' In Nebraska, SAC officials said Bush's four-minute transmission was carried to 200 installations around the world, and beamed to war planes in the air and to missile crews at silos in the ground. SAC keeps Air Force surveillance planes and nuclear-armed bombers in flight at all times. Bush joked to intercontinental ballistic missile crews to remember that ``the pointy end is up.'' On Tuesday, Bush attended a simulated tank invasion at war games in California's Mojave desert. On Wednesday, he toured the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory near San Francisco, where the bulk of the government's research on the ``Star Wars'' Strategic Defense Initiative is being conducted. Bush defended his new budget proposal to increase Star Wars spending by $1 billion and to press with modernizing nuclear weapons systems. Bill Harlow, a White House spokesman, said the timing of Bush's trip had nothing to do with the meeting of the Soviet Central Committee _ and that there was no deliberate attempt on the administration's part to send a counterpoint message to Moscow on the state of East-West relations. ``This trip had been planned for a long time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 1st All-Communist Government in Bulgaria; Lukanov Describes Reforms
DOC.TEXT: The country's first all-Communist government was sworn in Thursday after formerly docile allies and other opposition leaders ignored appeals to help run the country until elections in May. As Parliament President Stanko Todorov installed the new 20-member Cabinet, several hundred people protested outside, demanding the resignation of the lawmaking body because it approved the new government. Premier Andrei Lukanov told the National Assembly the economically stagnant country is in ``deep crisis,'' and he pledged to move toward a market economy that favors ``the equality of all property,'' including private and foreign ownership. His comments, broadcast over government radio, appeared to signal determination to institute some of the same reforms already in place by other Warsaw Pact countries further on the road to democracy. Longtime hard-line Communist Party chief Todor Zhivkov was ousted in November, but Parliament did not abolish the party's guaranteed grip on power until Jan. 15. The Cabinet replaces one that resigned last week and included some members of the Agrarian Party, which had been a docile ally of the Communists for decades. In the immediate postwar years, some other parties, later absorbed by the Communists or banned, were also represented in governments. The Communists had called for a new ``government of national concord'' comprising representatives ``from all social forces'' in this Balkan country of about 9 million people. But the opposition Union of Democratic Forces repeatedly rejected the Communists' offer to participate, and the Agrarian Party announced Wednesday that it also would refuse to be part of a Communist-dominated Cabinet. Opposition representatives said they did not want to be in the Cabinet because 67 percent of parliamentary deputies are Communists. They alleged this would substantially slow reforms. Parliament unanimously elected Lukanov premier Saturday after Premier Georgi Atanasov and his Cabinet resigned. Atanasov, a holdover from the era of ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, had been accused of economic mismanagement. The new government will run the country until multiparty elections are held May 5. ``Until the elections, this government will serve national interests, not party interests,'' Lukanov told Parliament. It faces a difficult task. Bulgaria's foreign debt tops $10 billion, labor productivity is low, and private initiative has been stifled by more than four decades of a system of rigid central planning that also ruined agriculture. In addition, the Alternative Socialist Alliance, a group of reform rebels inside the Communist Party, plans to break away at a special congress Feb.11. Lukanov was unable to fill two of the 22 Cabinet posts _ the environment ministry and the culture ministry. He said he would have liked Petar Beron, a senior opposition figure and member of the Ecoglasnost environmentalist group, to be the minister of the environment, but Beron's association with the United Democratic Front made it impossible for him to join the Cabinet. Asked what kind of government he had hoped to form originally, Lukanov said he thought half the ministers would be Communists, while the other half would be members of the United Democratic Front, the Agrarian Party, and independents. In his speech to Parliament, Lukanov pledged ``maximum support'' _ in the form of government subsidies and loans _ to agricultural producers who bring in the highest yield, whether they are paid by the government or farm their own small plots. His comments were seen as a signal that the state was considering ending decades of strict restriction on how much land an individual could work privately. Lukanov announced the Bulgaria planned to seek membership in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade _ the world body of free trade _ the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, in a clear effort to improve the country's moribund trade and debt picture. He also asked foreign creditors for trust and patience.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Executive Who Helped Launch Two New Papers Dies
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Long, chairman of the British weekly newspaper The Sunday Correspondent and co-founder of the daily paper The Independent, has died, his family reported Thursday. He was 65. Long died Wednesday of cancer of the liver at Royal Marsden Hospital after a short illness. Born in London, Long was educated at Wandsworth School in south London. But before he had time to start a career, he was swept up into World War II, serving as a cavalryman in the Indian Army. After the war, he became a reporter and later a feature writer on the now-defunct London newspaper the Daily Graphic. He later worked for the Daily Record in Glasgow, Scotland, and then became Scottish editor of the now-defunct Daily Herald. He subsequently moved to London as chief news editor and feature editor of the Daily Herald. He later became deputy managing director of the Mirror Group of newspapers, whose flagship is the tabloid Daily Mirror, and in 1980 was made deputy chief executive of the group. When publishing tycoon Robert Maxwell bought the Mirror Group in 1984, Long quit to help start up The Independent with Andreas Whittam Smith, the former financial editor of The Daily Telegraph and Matthew Symonds, another former staffer with The Daily Telegraph, among others. The Independent was launched in October 1986 with Whittam Smith as editor and swiftly established itself as a serious and respected newspaper. Long then left The Independent to help launch The Sunday Correspondent, of which he was chairman when it hit the newsstands Sept. 17 last year. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his son Mark, and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Communist Ideology Chief Says, We've Averted Explosion
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Communist Party ideology secretary said Thursday that reform programs have saved the Soviet Union from a ``cataclysmic explosion.'' ``I think we have avoided a really painful resolution,'' Vadim A. Medvedev told a news conference at London's Royal Institute for International Affairs. ``We now have the possibility of controlling the outcome ... but we must not drag our heels.'' Medvedev, a member of the Politburo, arrived from Moscow on Wednesday soon after the vote by the Soviet Communist Party to give up its monopoly on power. He heads a seven-member Soviet delegation invited by British parliamentarians. ``Thanks to the fact that we began perestroika in 1985. ... I think we really have prevented the possibility of a cataclysmic explosion,'' said Medvedev, speaking through an interpreter. ``We have channeled this process into an area of controlled reaction.'' He had been asked if he believed the Soviet Communist Party has avoided the fate of other communist parties swept aside in the pro-democracy upheavals in Eastern Europe. Medvedev said the party will still ``struggle for a leading role ... but by democratic means.'' Medvedev met privately with the House of Commons foreign affairs committee.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Fire Rages Through Brazilian Wildlife Reserve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with fire details, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A forest fire raged out of control through a wildlife reserve for rare animals in southestern Brazil on Thursday and killed some of the reserve's 250 near-extinct golden lion marmosets, officials said. Fire that began Saturday has destroyed more than half of the Poco das Antas Wildlife Reserve 80 miles northeast of Rio, said Vicente Moreira Conti, a spokesman for Ibama, Brazil's environmental protection agency. More than 400 firefighters, police and biologists struggled to put out the blaze and save the animals. Conti said the fire was burning in five areas of the 12,300-acre reserve, the last remaining stronghold for the marmoset and a sanctuary for rare sloths, alligators, monkeys and jaguars. ``The fire has severely burned areas where tamarin families were living. We fear some have died,'' Conti said in a phone interview. Tamarin is another name for the marmoset, a monkey the size of a cat with a lion-like mane and a bushy tail. Conti said droves of animals were fleeing the area but only small numbers of the marmosets had left the reserve. Biologists were losing contact with the marmosets, monitored by means of tiny radio transmitters tied around their necks, he said. Environmentalists are concerned the fire may kill all of the shy, little beasts because they hide in tree holes for warmth and shelter. Conti said firefighters were clearing quarter-mile strips of forest to slow the spread of the fire. But the firefighters were hampered by the 100-degree temperatures of the Southern Hemisphere summer, high wind, difficult access to the mountainous area and a lack of water caused by a long dry spell, he said. A twin-engined Dromader plane was to arrive on Friday from southern Brazil to drop 21,000 gallons of water on critical areas, the equivalent of a month's rainfall in the region, he said. Conti added, ``It's our last hope. We're trying to soak the soil and foilage to halt the spread of the fire.'' But he said it would take several days of heavy rain to extinguish the fire, and no rain was forecast before next week. Manchete TV showed helicopters airlifting firefighters to burning areas and crews battling flames with portable water tanks and rubber mats. Ibama president Fernando Mesquita promised more firefighters and said environmental specialists from northeastern Brazil will arrive Friday to help. The cause of the fire was not known. But officials said unusually dry weather and summer heat could have caused the fire to begin spontaneously. Poco das Antas, which in Portuguese means ``watering hole of the tapirs,'' had become the center of an international crusade to protect the environment. The reserve was founded in 1974 and funded by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, the World Wildlife Fund and the Brazilian and Canadian governments. The Smithsonian said in Washington that two of its employees in the reserve suffered minor injuries fighting the fire, and that Acting Associate Director Ben Beck will leave Sunday to assess the damage. The marmoset was pushed to edge of extinction in 1972 when just 70 remained on Earth after poachers, hunters and ranchers trapped them and cut down their forest habitats. But the animal slowly had been reproducing after naturalists released them in groups from foreign zoos into the Brazilian forest.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Identify Fossil As World's First Known Flower
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have identified a 120-million-year-old fossil barely an inch tall as the world's first known flower. The two Yale University researchers who announced the discovery Thursday offered the fossil as evidence that flowering plants had a more humble beginning than was previously thought. Scientists have long believed that the ancestors of today's flowering plants were magnolia-like shrubs and trees with large showy flowers. But Leo J. Hickey, a geologist, and David W. Taylor, a biologist, advance a new theory of plant evolution in this week's issue of the journal Science which argues that the earliest flowers were impressive neither in size nor color. The new theory may help provide an explanation for what Darwin called the ``abominable mystery'' behind the relatively sudden evolutionary appearance of large flowering plants, the scientists said. Darwin was mystified by the apparent lack of any obvious ancestors to the plants. The fossil that Hickey and Taylor identified as a tiny flowering plant from the middle age of the dinosaur was unearthed about 10 years ago in southeastern Australia, and belongs to the National Museum of Victoria in Melbourne. The fossil had originally been labeled a fern, or nonflowering plant. Taylor said he and Hickey were working on a new theory of the ancestry of flowering plants when he came across a publication in 1988 which featured a picture of the ``fern.'' ``I said, `Ah ha,' that looks like tiny flowers,'' he recalled. Using high-resolution photography, the scientists were able to confirm that the fossil was a portion of a branch from an angiosperm, a class of plant in which the seeds are enclosed in an ovary. The flowers on the plant are less than a tenth of an inch long, and are made up of a modified type of leaf with berries attached, the scientists said. The coloring was believed to be brown or greenish. They said the specimen probably came from a mature plant 6 to 12 inches in height and resembling today's black pepper plant. The discovery means scientists have been ``barking up the wrong tree in their search for the earliest flowers, because it is not a tree at all,'' Hickey said. Fossils of bird feathers, insects and conifers were also uncovered at the site where the plant was found. The Yale researchers said the absence of wood remains from large flowering plants supported their hypothesis. Scientists have found pollen apparently from plants that existed 130 million years ago, but have yet to uncovered any actual remains of flowers from that period. Until their discovery, the Yale scientists said the earliest known flowers were specimens believed to be close to 115 million years old. Peter Crane, an authority on early flowering plants from the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, called the discovery of the 120-million-year-old plant exciting and said he was fundamentally in sympathy with the theory advanced by the Yale scientists. But he said ``a lot of other data has to be counted for'' and that exactly what the first flowers looked like is still ``up for grabs.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Finishes Health Assertions Revisions
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has won White House approval of stricter regulations about health claims by food marketers, permitting only ``truthful and not misleading'' assertions about a narrow range of diseases, an agency official said Thursday. Such claims used to be completely banned, but the agency began allowing them under a new policy announced in 1987. Some members of Congress have said FDA was allowing manufacturers to play ``reckless games'' in making ill-founded claims. The policy revision, to be published in the Federal Register next week, ``is a mid-course correction,'' said the official, who discussed the draft on condition that he not be identified. Though advertising might come under the policy, the agency is most concerned with what is carried on the package label, he said. The Office of Management and Budget, which reviews draft regulations of all executive branch agencies, approved the policy on Wednesday without requesting substantial changes, the official said. The new policy will allow health claims only about these topics: _Fiber and colon cancer. _Fiber and heart disease. _Fats and cancer. _Fats and heart disease. _Sodium and high blood pressure. _Calcium and osteoporosis, a softening of the bones sometimes found in the elderly. Many scientists believe that in some circumstances, fiber might reduce colon cancer and heart disease; fats might increase cancer and heart disease; high concentrations of sodium increase blood pressure and calcium can help prevent osteoporosis. The new policy will require that any claims be: _``Truthful and not misleading,'' in the official's words. _Limited to describing the relationship between a particular food component and a chronic disease. _Consistent with a reasonable diet. _Supported by FDA-approved summaries of the evidence. The agency will make available model summaries for industry to use. Until final adoption of the new policy, which could take a year, the agency will enforce it case by case, considering whether: _The scientific evidence supports a claim. _There are enough benefits to make a claim in the first place. _Whether ``the good outweighs the bad'' in following the seller's advice. The official said this point might, for example, rule out a low-cholesterol food that is high in saturated fats, since scientists believe saturated fats in the diet are more important in forming cholesterol in the blood than diet cholesterol itself. He declined to give examples of current claims the agency could act against under the new policy. However, the agency has said it has serious concerns about cereals containing husks of psyllium, which contain soluble fiber. FDA also has warned the American Heart Association against its new ``Heartguide'' program to label brands it approves as ``heart healthy'' with a prominent mark. The official said the new policy did not directly bear on the heart group's action. He said he understood the association had said it would review the program plans when the new policy was published.

DOC.HEAD: Controlled Destruction of Soviet Ammo Gets Out of Hand
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of grenades and other explosives Soviet troops were to destroy in a controlled operation went off all at once, shattering windows at a nearby village, the official CTK news agency said Wednesday. A ``gross violation of safety regulations'' caused the blast at the Libava base on Tuesday that left the area 180 miles east of Prague blanketed with red dust, CTK quoted Defense Ministry spokesman Stanislav Pohoral as saying. No one was injured, Pohoral said. The troops at the weapons arsenal and military exercise area were destroying 500 anti-tank grenades and 44 pounds of gunpowder with 26 pounds of TNT, CTK said. According to a military report on the investigation carried by CTK, the soldiers dug three holes, seven yards apart, to destroy the grenades and the gunpowder. None of the holes was covered with topsoil, and when the first cache was detonated the others exploded in a chain reaction, the report said. Radiation measurements carried out by Soviet experts, Czech police and citizens' representatives showed no danger for the surrounding population, CTK said, without elaborating on whether the depot actually contained nuclear arms. ``During this morning (Soviet military authorities) have apologized to the concerned citizens and measures were taken to eliminate and compensate the damage. The investigation into the case goes on,'' the CTK report said. Authorities agreed that ammunition would be destroyed in smaller quantities in the future, the agency said. It did not say why the load on Tuesday had to be destroyed, but ammunition is often disposed of in a controlled explosion when it is found to be old or defective. The incident occurred as talks on the withdrawal of about 7O,OOO Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia were to resume this week in Moscow. Since the democratic revolution in November, the Czechoslovak side has demanded withdrawal of the entire Soviet military contingent by the end of 199O. Thousands of citizens demanding the pullout demonstrated in Prague on Tuesday, accusing Soviet military of occupying the country since the 1968 invasion that crushed a reform movement.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Drug Use Debated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-15, `Superior Court ...,' with 8 grafs to UPDATE with judge saying he may rule defense can use theory of government negligence; picks up 16th graf, `Madson said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two Coast Guard ship traffic monitors tested positive for alcohol and marijuana use after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, but a prosecutor argued Thursday that jurors shouldn't hear about it. Defense attorneys in the trial of Joseph Hazelwood, the former tanker skipper accused of causing the nation's worst oil spill, said such evidence is relevant and could show that blame for the disaster lies elsewhere. The dispute arose just before one of the Coast Guard employees took the stand to tell how he and others watched the Exxon Valdez' progress through the Valdez Narrows and into Prince William Sound the night it ran aground. The tanker ran onto Bligh Reef early March 24, spewing more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude. The spill killed thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife and blackened hundreds of miles of shoreline. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is being tried on a felony charge of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, he faces up to seven years and three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole said the drug tests were irrelevant because some were administered 15 hours after the grounding and others were conducted three days later.
