Documents filed in the case showed that Bruce Blandford, the monitor on duty when the tanker went aground, showed a blood alcohol level of .203 15 hours later. Cole said Blandford went home after the accident and began drinking. ``There is aboslutely no evidence that Mr. Blandford was under the influence of intoxicating liquor at any time during his shift,'' said Cole, conceding that in a later urine test Blandford also showed a trace of morphine. Gordon Taylor, who tracked the ship until shortly before it ran aground, was tested March 26 and showed a small amount of marijuana in his system. Cole said the amount was consistent with being in a room where marijauna was being smoked by others or with use far removed from the day of testing. He said there wasn't any evidence Taylor was under the influence of marijuana at the time of the crash. Cole argued that the tests were irrelevant also because the Coast Guard isn't being accused of negligence in the trial. ``This is not a civil negligence case,'' Cole told Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. ``We have an attempt by the defense to turn it into (that) by trying to spread out the blame.'' Johnstone refused to admit evidence of the marijuana, saying defense lawyers had failed to show sufficient reason to explore the issue. He put off a ruling on whether the alcohol evidence regarding Blandford would be admitted. Johnstone ruled the defense couldn't use a theory of government negligence, but later said he may reverse himself. ``What the defense seems to be saying,'' said Johnstone, ``is, `We're not reckless. We didn't create the problem. The government created the problem.' The more I think about it the more I think the defense should be able to show they didn't create it; the government did. I'm reconsidering it.'' Defense attorneys said the traffic monitors were responsible for alerting the Exxon Valdez' crew if they spotted trouble on their radar screen. ``Blandford may well have been under the influence of alcohol while on duty at the Vessel Traffic Control Center,'' a defense motion said. ``His possible intoxication may have been a contributing factor in the grounding.'' Madson said in his opening statement to jurors that there was never a warning from the radar station that the 987-foot tanker was approaching Bligh Reef and was about to run aground. He also said he would show that no one was watching the screen at the time of the accident. In testimony Thursday, shipping agent Patricia Caples told the jury she saw Hazelwood moments before the Exxon Valdez left port. She said he seemed to be in a good mood, and suspected he might been drinking only because he seemed so jolly. Otherwise, the agent said, the captain seemed unchanged from his normal demeanor and was ``very businesslike.'' The prosecution contends that Hazelwood's alleged drunkeness contributed to the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Disney To Ban Ads In Theaters Showing Its Movies
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. announced Thursday it will prohibit paid screen advertising in all movie theaters showing the company's films. The policy will begin in March with Disney's release of the film ``Pretty Woman.'' ``Our patrons don't dislike screen advertising, they hate it,'' said Richard Cook, president of Disney's Buena Vista Pictures Distribution. Audiences, he said, ``do not come to experience the mundane. They come to escape it. We must not so insult our paying guests (with commercials) and we won't.'' Disney plans to enforce the anti-ad policy by revoking a theater's license to show Disney movies if it shows advertisements. Cook said the action was essential to the continued financial health of the exhibition of motion pictures in movie theaters. ``We have been told repeatedly by moviegoers that they do not want and will not tolerate commercial intrusions in movie theaters,'' Cook said in remarks given at the 1990 convention of the National Association of Theater Owners. The Disney announcement was greeted by some groans. A number of theater owners depend on paid advertising to generate extra income. Terry Laughren, president of Screenvision Cinema Network, the nation's leading cinema advertising company, said such advertisements bring theater owners millions of dollars annually. ``It's real money. It's not pocket change,'' said Laughren, whose company has placed ads in about 35 percent of the nation's 17,500 first-run movie theaters. Cook said Disney won't demand that theaters break existing contracts with advertisers, but the company will encourage the theater owners to get out of such contracts. Disney defines screen advertisements as commercials for goods and services projected on the screen in the same theater where Disney films are shown. Previews of upcoming attractions, slides projected for products during intermission and approved charitable advertisements are not affected by the ban, Disney said.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Applies for Membership to Council of Europe
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia applied Wednesday for membership in the Council of Europe, becoming the third Eastern European country to try to join the parliamentary institution. Consul General Milutin Simic of Yugoslavia formally made the application to Gaetano Adinolfi, assistant secretary general of the 23-nation Council, which has its headquarters in Strasbourg, eastern France. In the past four months, Poland and Hungary have also asked for membership in the Council, an advisory body best-known for promoting human rights and parliamentary democracy. The three countries and the Soviet Union already enjoy ``special guest status,'' which allows them to address the body but not participate in decisions. Simic's letter declared that ``membership for Yugoslavia results naturally from the development of relations between Yugoslavia and the Council of Europe.'' The application will be considered by the executive Committee of Ministers, the Council said in a statement. It gave no indication when a decision might be rendered. As a consultative and advisory body, the Council has no actual powers over the governments of its members, but it can influence them on political and moral issues. The 40-year-old Council groups all West European democracies except Finland. Its best-known institution is the European Court of Human Rights, which accepts individual cases and makes binding decisions on states agreeing to acquiesce.

DOC.HEAD: Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes Shown at Orsay Museum
DOC.TEXT: Heads, shoulders, knees and toes sculpted by some of the world's greatest artists are on display at the Musee d'Orsay, illustrating that fragments are often more powerful than the whole. The muscled torso of a man falling over backward, the curled fingers of a tensed hand and the blood-soaked head of a revolutionary martyr are part of a major retrospective on fragmented human forms sculpted over the centuries. The exhibit, titled ``The Body in Pieces,'' is here through June 3 when it travels to Frankfurt, West Germany. It is a comprehensive look at how artists from Michaelangelo to Rodin have been fascinated with buttocks, breasts and biceps, heads, hands and haunches. Some of the works are simply the remnants of things past, the whole having been lost long ago. Other works, such as Rodin's study of praying hands, were conceived as fragments from the start. ``Fragmenting the human form reinforces our perception of what remains,'' wrote Ann Pingeot in the 343-page exhibition catalogue. The show features hundreds of pieces of sculpture by Rodin, Aristide Maillol, Emile-Antoine Bourdelle and photographs, drawings and even a tree of waxen hands. A major highlight is Lorenzo da Mugiano's Torso of Louis XII dating from 1508. The hands and head were tacked on from 1798 to 1790 when scholars believed that broken was not beautiful. Today, art critics are delighted that the armless Venus de Milo did not suffer the same fate. Bourdelle, a French sculptor, wrote in 1937: ``It's so sad to think that there are people still searching for the Venus de Milo's gesture and who, instead of appreciating it as it is _ if they were capable of seeing it _ want to find out at all cost what action the statue represented.'' Fragments became fashionable in the 20th century as a genre reflecting the philosophy that less is more. Michaelangelo was the first to conceive of an incomplete statue as a finished work. Rodin followed in that tradition three centuries later and made fragments the cornerstone of his composition. The exhibition features dozens of his works, which have long been considered as ``experimental'' and which are virtually unknown to the general public.

DOC.HEAD: Deal Could Gain Onassis Title To Indian's Ancestral Land
DOC.TEXT: Most of the Wampanoag Indians involved in a 10-year battle with Jacqueline Onassis over beachfront property on Martha's Vineyard agreed to sell her the land in return for money and another tract, officials said. According to Wampanoag legend, Chief Moshup and his wife, Squant, are buried in the disputed land, a 264-foot stretch of property in the Gay Head section of the resort island. Paul Sulla, a Boston attorney representing some of the Indians, said an agreement had been reached among 95 percent of the parties involved. Under the agreement, Onassis will gain ownership of the site in return for money and another piece of property, said a clerk in Dukes County probate court on the island who refused to give his name. Sulla would not disclose the specific terms of the agreement, which would have to be approved by the court. The case was continued to March 7 to allow four Indians, who have partial title to the land but did not show up for negotiations, a chance to participate, Sulla said. ``The ten years have definitely been worth it. I can say I am comfortable with what they've offered us,'' said Thelma Weissberg, a Wampanoag Indian who is named in legal action on the issue. Onassis' 380-acre private estate surrounds the property. Onassis, the widow of President Kennedy, bought a 17 percent interest in the land in 1980 from a Wampanoag family. The Indians have retained a right of access to the site. Onassis has brought a series of legal actions in an attempt to clear the title on the land.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Gov't Denies Nuncio's Accusation It's a New Dictatorship
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday denied the papal nuncio's allegation that it is a new dictatorship and said Panama is living in a democratic system. Monsignor Sebastian Laboa's comment Sunday that Panama had passed ``from one dictatorship to another'' with the U.S. overthrow of Manuel Antonio Noriega was the lead story in the Panama City newspaper La Estrella de Panama. The newspaper's majority owners were close associates of Noriega and backed the general until his ouster Dec. 20. Noriega took temporary refuge at the Vatican Embassy. On Tuesday, Laboa denied in television interviews having made the statement when he spoke with an Associated Press reporter at the Panama City airport. He did not elaborate. The denial was carried by other newspapers and radio and TV stations. One radio station criticized Laboa for making the allegation and recalled that in January he had defended Eliezer Gaytan, Noriega's chief bodyguard, who remains in the Vatican Embassy. Gaytan has been accused of taking part in assassinations of military officers who tried unsuccessfully to overthrow Noriega Oct 3. Laboa said Gaytan could not be blamed because he was only obeying orders. Julio Harris, minister of the presidency, said Wednesday that justice was being applied in the country and that the justice system, like other branches of government, was independent. ``This country is today living a really democratic system,'' he said. ``It is not our fault that the Panamanian people, in their rejection of those who governed them and abused their confidence, may be seeking justice for many of them, while at the same time others are relegated to an obscure and anonymous life,'' he said. Laboa, in the comments at the airport, had said the new government's prosecution of former officials in the Noriega dictatorship for crimes ranging from homicide to robbery and abuse of power was ``craziness.'' More than 100 officials of the Noriega regime have been arrested and the government, on radio, television and newspaper ads, has invited the public to file complaints against them. After eluding invading U.S. troops for four days, Noriega took refuge at the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve and remained there until Jan. 3. Under pressure from church officials to leave, he turned himself in to U.S. troops.

DOC.HEAD: INS Spending to Increase on Border Due to Alien Flow
DOC.TEXT: A ``blitz'' of the Texas border has been launched by immigration officials worried about an increase in the number of Central American illegal aliens, the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced Wednesday. ``We're not going to allow border crashing,'' said INS Commissioner Gene McNary, outlining plans to spend an additional $11 million on the crackdown. Six large tents, such as those used for revival meetings, have been erected at the 347-acre detention camp near Bayview, raising its capacity to 2,500. McNary said the INS will build tents to hold 10,000 detainees if needed. The Bayview camp held 998 detainees Wednesday. An additional 632 Central Americans were held at five other INS sites in south Texas. When the INS was overwhelmed with more than 500 Central Americans applying for political asylum daily last February, the agency reduced the time it took to make asylum decisions to just one day. Those denied asylum were held in the detention camps pending deportation proceedings. That action reduced the flow of aliens seeking asylum at Bayview to less than 10 a day, and it stayed that way for months. In October, however, apprehension of aliens from countries other than Mexico rose to 829 in the INS sector covering Bayview. By January, the figure had risen to 1,860, mostly Central Americans, said INS spokesman Duke Austin. Increased tensions in Central America and an INS decision to release asylum-seekers on their own recognizance may have spurred the new flow of aliens, officials said. To save money, the INS last month decided to lower the camp's population below 700 and allowed the asylum-seekers to travel to join relatives elsewhere in the United States while their cases progressed. ``Since that time, I'm convinced that because of the gradual increase in people coming across the border that we need to put on a blitz,'' McNary said. McNary said the new crackdown is intended to remind Central Americans that those who come to the United States unable to show a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' will be denied asylum, detained and deported. McNary refused to say how long the crackdown would last, but said INS personnel will be shifted from other sectors to help out. An activist group called the Rio Grande Defense Committee protested the new INS action. ``Last year, these tents became a symbol of injustice, of summary asylum denials and coercive, illegal conditions of confinement,'' the group said in a statement. Several members of the group handed out leaflets protesting the INS' move during McNary's visit. Political asylum is granted to those able to show they are fleeing a country for political rather than economic reasons.

DOC.HEAD: President Warns of Impending Clashes if States Continue Feuding
DOC.TEXT: President Janez Drnovsek on Wednesday said relations between quarrelsome republics in the country have deteriorated to the point where ``the most radical clashes'' are possible. The feuds ``between our republics and peoples have worsened to the extreme,'' Drnovsek told a joint session of Parliament. ``This negative process must be stopped as it has reached a dangerous point.'' He also said the reformist Communist leadership will support ``Yugoslavia's full-scale movement toward the European Community. . .. We expect that the effective implementation of our reforms will successfully pave the way to our membership in the EC.'' In another turn to the West, Yugoslavia applied Wednesday for membership in the Council of Europe, becoming the third Eastern European country after Poland and Hungary to seek to join the Strasbourg, France-based advisory body best known for promoting human rights and parliamentary democracy. Relations among the five constituent republics of Yugoslavia's fragile federation, already strained due to deep rifts between conservatives and reformers, have taken a sharp turn for the worse the past year. The Communist leadership and partisan press in Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia have lashed out against the liberal northern regions of Slovenia and Croatia, accusing them of ``treason'' for criticizing Serbia's policies in the ethnically troubled Kosovo province. At least 26 people of Albanian origin died in clashes with riot police during a rash of demonstrations that shook the province last week. The ethnic Albanian majority is demanding an end to a yearlong state of emergency and greater autonomy for the province, which Serbia controls. The two northern republics object to human rights violations they allege are being committed by Serbian authorities in efforts to control the unrest. In December, Serbia broke off all official and trade ties with Slovenia after authorities there banned a rally by Serbs seeking to oust the Slovenian leadership. Unspecified retaliatory measures against Croatia, the second-largest of Yugoslavia's five states, have also been threatened by Serbia's media. Drnovsek itemized a seven-point ``approach to the solving of the Kosovo problem,'' including the start of talks ``because problems cannot be solved by force'' and the lifting of the state of emergency ``as soon as the situation there calms down.'' Drnovsek also reiterated the presidency's support for the sweeping changes instituted by the reformist government of Prime Minister Ante Markovic. These include the establishment of a multiparty parliamentary system and the transformation of Yugoslavia's government-run economy into a free market system.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 1,000 Rally To Keep Open Long Beach Shipyard
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 union workers chanting ``Save the Shipyard'' rallied Wednesday to keep their jobs at the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, targeted for closure by the Pentagon. ``What we're trying to do is get our congressmen and senators to understand that this is really a bad move. There is no economic sense to it, no sense from a defense point of view,'' said electrical engineer Darrell Meft. Meft is one of about 4,100 shipyard workers, most of them union members, who stand to lose their jobs if Congress allows the shipyard to close to cut costs at the Defense Department. The shipyard is one of 72 military installations slated for closings or cutbacks. In addition to the rally, workers from 13 labor unions have been preparing leaflets, faxing letters to Washington and urging employees to write and telephone their lawmakers. The unions argue that the shipyard is one of the most efficient in the country, with projects last year coming in $20 million under budget.

DOC.HEAD: EDITORS: EMBARGOED for release at noon EST.
DOC.TEXT: Laundering money from cocaine sales and a host of other criminal activities represents a $300 billion worldwide business each year but could prove the drug trade's key area of vulnerability, a Senate report said today. ``Because money laundering is principally accomplished through the use of legitimate financial institutions, money laundering is the potential Achilles heel of the illegal drug business,'' said the report from two Senate panels. The report released by Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., was based on testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations and Banking Committees last fall. It attributed to Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore Martoche the estimate that worldwide drug revenues total $300 billion annually, including $110 billion generated in the United States. It said laundering all of this cash presents tough problems for criminals.
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old girl died four days after becoming the world's first recipient of an experimental lung-assist device, leaving behind a grieving hometown but hope that similar implants will help others. Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey, 16, of Arthur City, Texas, who suffered from adult respiratory distress syndrome, died Wednesday of ``worsening pulmonary failure,'' said Tim Madden, spokesman at LDS Hospital. Mimi had received an IntraVascular Oxygenator, or IVOX, during a two-hour operation Friday. The device is a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes about as fine as human hair, with walls so thin that oxygen and carbon dioxide can pass through. ``There were no clinical complications from the use of the device, which added oxygen to and removed carbon dioxide from the patient's blood,'' Madden said.

Oscar-winning songwriter Jimmy Van Heusen, who wrote such tunes as ``All the Way,'' ``Love and Marriage'' and ``High Hopes,'' was remembered upon his death as one of pop music's most important composers. Van Heusen died of a stroke Tuesday night at his desert home east of Los Angeles, according to a spokesman at the Riverside County Coroner's Office. He was 77. Van Heusen collaborated with such lyricists as Johnny Mercer, Johnny Burke, Eddie DeLange and most notably, Sammy Cahn. He also wrote for Bing Crosby and Frank Sinatra. ``Jimmy Van Heusen was an architect of melody,'' Cahn said Wednesday. ``When we were writing together, if I would ask him to add even a grace note to the song, he would sit down and write a whole new melody.''

Question: If you call a person who speaks two languages bilingual, what do you call a person who speaks one language? An American, says Rep. George Sangmeister, D-Ill. He is introducing legislation today that authorizes $58 million in federal funds over five years and matching grants to states for instruction in foreign studies, language and geography. ``We live in an increasingly global society. We can no longer afford a generation of children uneducated and uninterested in the world outside the United States,'' said Sangmeister. ``We must spark that interest and ability early so that our students become proficient in foreign language by high school or college.''

DOC.HEAD: East German City Now Exposed as Environmental Catastrophe
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: This smoky, smelly city is classified by ecologists as an environmental catastrophe hidden until now by the Iron Curtain. The word is out that its pollution is killing its people. With the collapse of the Iron Curtain across Eastern Europe, Bitterfeld has become exposed to the outside world: deadly chemical canals bubble past homes, smokestacks spew sickening yellow and black toxic emissions above a poisoned wasteland. The Rev. Peter Heyroth, a Lutheran pastor, prays the city about 75 miles southwest of Berlin can be saved. ``For years, the seriousness of the environmental damage was kept secret,'' he said. ``Only now are we beginning to find out how frightening the situation is.'' Ecologists call Bitterfeld a chemical bomb with a shortened fuse _ one of Europe's most dangerously polluted cities. East Germany is one of Europe's most dangerously polluted countries. Its emissions of some toxic substances _ like forest-killing sulphur dioxide _ exceed those of all other European nations, scientists say. About two-thirds of East Germany's lakes and rivers are believed to be badly or moderately contaminated, and large parts of its forests are dying as well. West German companies plan to help clean up areas in East Germany like Bitterfeld, but the task will cost billions and require years to complete. The Bitterfeld area, with its huge chemical complexes and smoke-spewing coal-fired power plants, is a major contributor to East Germany's ominous ecological woes. The 60,000 people in the greater Bitterfeld area live in the toxic shadow of two giant state-owned combines _ the CKB and FKC chemical-producing complexes, and several coal-burning power plants whose emissions include sulphur dioxide. Black coal soot lies in layers on the city's homes and businesses. Noxious odors waft from several ponds filled with chemical wastes, and vast stretches of the area's three rivers are totally devoid of life. On windy days, the chemical stench in parts of Bitterfeld and neighboring Wolfen is so bad that people shutter their windows in often futile attempts to keep the fumes out. Open coal pits the size of large villages have created a wasteland outside the residential areas, adding to the toxic grimness. Hans Zimmermann, a local ecologist, said liquid chemical wastes, without the rigid cleansing treatments usual in the West, have badly contaminated the soil and groundwater. West German scientists have expressed shock that Bitterfeld area residents drink the milk of cows that graze on pastureland that could be contaminated by toxic substances. Zimmermann said the most frightening thing for him is that no one knows for sure what the long-term health dangers might be but suspects the wastewater includes highly hazardous dioxins. Once-secret documents show the chemical wastewaters are also laced with sulphates, huge amounts of chlorine, mercury and other highly toxic substances, according to the Jan. 8 issue of the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel. Bitterfeld has been the site of at least one major chemical accident. In 1968, a huge explosion at CKB killed about 70 people, Zimmermann said. He added that over the past few years a number of smaller accidents have occurred at CKB, a major producer of a wide range of chemical products including herbicides, pesticides and paints. But information about the accidents was always kept ``in-house,'' said Zimmermann. Area residents suffer from a variety of ailments including lung diseases, cancer and slow bone development among children, experts and residents say. Recent Western tests found that Bitterfeld's residents have an average life span at least five years shorter than that of other East German citizens. ``Of those people who die early here, I bury more who have perished from cancer than anything else,'' Pastor Heyroth said. In Wolfen, Luisi Schmidt points to a giant pond filled with liquid chemical wastes next to her home. Signs reading ``Danger, Life-Endangering, Do Not Enter'' surround the pond. ``It stinks like the devil here sometimes,'' said Ms. Schmidt, who looks much older than her 51 years and has sores at her hairline and on her face. ``A young woman died of cancer not so long ago,'' she added. ``She was only 35. It was that stinking cesspool.'' Zimmermann and Heyroth say one of the main problems in Bitterfeld is that East Germany's former Stalinist leaders never bothered to modernize the chemical-production factories and power plants. They also decided it was more important to pursue chemical production at a breakneck pace regardless of the possible health hazards. East Germany's ecological problems are widespread and there seem to be at least two reasons people have tolerated it for so long: the communists' refusal to say exactly what the dangers were, and the lure of salaries up to three times as high for chemical plant workers than for other citizens. ``This city has been totally subjugated by these gigantic chemical complexes,'' ecologist Zimmermann said, ``and in the process it has died.''

DOC.HEAD: Phone Computers: One Ringie Dingie, Two Ringie Dingies
DOC.TEXT: In the brave new world of the telephone company, it's no longer enough to listen to computers. Now you have to talk to them. ``At the tone, please say your name,'' electronic operators are telling collect callers around the country. The machines then ask customers at the other end if they'll pay the charges: ``Please say yes or no.'' The system, years in the works and just now arriving, marks a new tier in telephone technology: a computer that not only delivers messages or directs callers to hit buttons, but responds to the human voice. ``It understands when you say yes or no,'' said Preston Peek, spokesman for Northern Telecom Inc., a leading developer of computer systems that can discern spoken words. ``It asks what you want to do, and you just tell it.'' And it's probably coming to a phone company near you. Three of the seven regional phone companies _ Ameritech, BellSouth and NYNEX _ have ``voice recognition'' systems for collect and third-party calls in some areas now. Two more, Pacific Telesis and Bell Atlantic, will soon. The phone companies, eyeing lower costs and a bigger market, love the technology. They say even smarter computer systems _ ones that can make out numbers, even city names _ are near. ``It's inevitable that everyone's going to go to computerized voices,'' said AT&T spokesman Bryant Steele. ``It's cost-saving. It's more efficient.'' But that delight is not universally shared. ``After some initial grousing, people will eventually go ahead and live with it,'' said Dr. Kenyon DeGreene, an expert in human-machine relationships. ``However, a price eventually has to be paid.'' That price, said DeGreene, a psychologist and professor of systems management at the University of Southern California, is the burgeoning impersonality of society. When a computer demands specific words from a telephone caller, control seems to rest with the machine, DeGreene said. And because many people don't understand the workings of technology, ``there's an implied threat there.'' ``The person senses that he cannot use free-flowing speech. He's being constrained. The computer is controlling him. It can be simply frustrating,'' he said. ``People adapt to it, but only by filing it away subconsciously as another annoyance of living in our technological world.'' There are other problems. Because of interference, background noise or other glitches, the computers do not always recognize words; they eventually switch to a human operator, but only after several tries. For now, they recognize only English. And callers, once familiar with the system, still have to listen to the computer's spiel before answering. There is an out, however: Callers can ignore the computer's instructions and just hit ``O'' to get a human operator. If speaking to a computer is annoying, it's also fascinating. For its first trick _ asking the collect caller's name _ the system simply records the answer and plays it back to the call recipient after announcing the call is collect. The next part is harder. After asking if the recipient will accept the call, the system compares the ``yes'' or ``no'' response to a sound-wave matrix based on recordings of tens of thousands of people uttering those words. ``It makes its best guess as to whether you said `yes' or `no,''' said Candice Kamm, a specialist in speech recognition at Bell Comunications Research Inc. in Livingston, N.J. The computer guesses right about 98 percent of the time, she said, ``provided the person does what they're supposed to do.'' She predicts customers will adjust, noting that phone users grew accustomed to answering machines and, later, to the computerized voices providing numbers to directory assistance callers. Michigan Bell gave the Northern Telecom system its first tryout, starting in June in Grand Rapids; now it's expanding computerized operators to Detroit, Pontiac and then across the state. The system is newly arrived in Florida, Ohio and New York. Nationally, U.S. telephone callers placed 579 million collect and third-party calls in 1988. ``Multiply that by the amount of seconds each operator spends handling one of those calls, and you'll get an idea of the savings,'' said Peek, the Northern Telecom spokesman. Further savings are ahead. Half the nation's telephones are rotary rather than touch-tone models, and those callers cannot punch in credit card numbers. But when the computers can recognize spoken numbers, operators won't be needed to handle those credit-card calls. Rotary phones also will become compatible with systems that now require touch-tone responses _ to reach an extension, for example, or to hear a recorded train schedule. And when the systems can understand city names, directory assistance callers will find themselves queried for that information by the computer before an operator completes the service _ again, cutting operator time. US Sprint, the nation's No. 3. long-distance phone company, says by June it will start a voice-activated dialing system in which callers can say their names and a password instead of punching in their account codes. Callers also will be able to dial preregistered numbers with spoken orders, such as ``call home.'' Sprint's long-distance competitors, AT&T and MCI Communications Corp., are studying voice-activated services. AT&T has said some services could begin this year; MCI has no such plans now. Two of the regional phone companies, US West and Southwestern Bell, have no immediate plans to implement voice-activated services, but they're looking into it. ``We consider it's better customer service to have live operators,'' said US West spokesman Stephen Holder. ``And we don't believe the technology performs well enough yet.'' Spokesmen for Michigan Bell and New York Telephone Co. reported few customer complaints, and said they were not laying off operators. But they said the savings should enable them to handle increasing demand without hiring more workers. New England Telephone, which is starting the service this month, said it might reduce some operators' hours. Linda Meltzer, a phone company analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, predicted layoffs down the line, saying, ``They'll need less employees as they become automated.'' ``Companies will push technology whenever they can as long as there's an economic advantage to it,'' said DeGreene, the USC professor. While staff reductions save money for a company, ``It precipitates all kinds of social problems,'' he said. ``It puts the company's problem out into society in general. What will we do with these people who are no longer employed by the telephone company?''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs, Feb. 12

DOC.HEAD: Impressions and Numbers Are At Odds
DOC.TEXT: If there is a collapse of housing prices it is a mysterious one, because it hasn't shown up in the statistics. The most reliable national numbers obtainable show existing-home prices are higher than they were last year. Affordability measurements are fair to good. Mortgage costs, though higher recently, are below year-ago levels. It's a picture not of deterioration but of stability, but somehow it isn't painted that way. Discovering the reason why isn't easy, any more than it is easy to explain how the media can carry so many stories about layoffs and plant shutdowns while the jobless rate remains stuck at 5.3 percent since last summer. One possible clue relates to the importance people place on jobs and homes. Few things are more important, so it is possible that any suggestion of bad news becomes exaggerated out of proportion. Perhaps. Norman Flynn of Madison, Wis., president of the National Association of Realtors, offers another idea. Speaking of condominium sales, he commented recently that ``because of its large share of condos and co-ops, when the Northeast condo market has slight tremors, the rest of the country experiences an earthquake.'' That inference fits into a larger one involving not just housing but politics and economics. It is the Eastern Establishment effect, or the egocentric tendency for ideas and events in that area to be maximized. But oddly, even in the Northeast, where in some localities apartment co-ops and condos have sat empty for a year, prices overall have held. In 1988, the median price was $110,600, according to the NAR; last year it was $110,800. Other statistics offer little more evidence of a collapse. Sales of existing single-family homes last year totaled 3.59 million units, which indeed was down, by 4.6 percent, from the previous year. But that previous year was the strongest of the entire decade of the 1980s. In prices, there is even less evidence of problems. The national median price for existing single-family homes in December was $92,500, or 4.3 percent above the year-earlier median of $88,700. Even in the Northeast, where economies have slowed from boom times, the median price for 1989 rose to $145,200 from $143,000. The only clue to resolving the mystery might lie in sales figures for the Northeast. They fell. In 1989, existing single-family sales were 585,000, down 88,000 units from the year before, and the lowest since 1984. Moreover, last year's sales decline was the third in a row since the decade's peak sales of 703,000 units in 1986. Much of the decline was in the larger, more prominent cities, where change could become magnified. In certain local areas throughout the Northeast, both building and selling activity all but came to a halt. In some communities near New York City, for example, the average selling time was close to 250 days. Three years ago, it was not uncommon for houses to generate bids in the first week of listing. There's a random assortment of other clues to account for the impression of a housing debacle, among them: _ Homebuilding did decline. For all 1989, total residential permits fell 7.9 percent to 1.340,600, lowest since 1982, according to U.S. Housing Markets, a national survey published by Lomas Mortgage USA. The decline was steepest in the Northeast, 18.6 percent, and the South, 11.3 percent. _ Commercial building also declined. In addition, many owners of existing buildings, and their bankers, ran into highly publicized financial problems. But very few of these disasters involved single-family housing. _ The days of putting tags on houses far beyond the existing market level, in hopes that buyers would chase prices, ended abruptly. As a result, asking prices did fall, but not necessarily below prices of a year earlier. Generally speaking, numbers often confirm impressions. This time they are at odds. It just doesn't add up, as they say.

DOC.HEAD: Valentine's: Red Letter Day for Roses and Chocolate
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Oh, St. Valentine! How to capture the rapture? Does confection affirm affection? Do flowers floor? Or will it take a gold mine to get you to be mine? Valentine's Day _ colored rose red, punctuated with arrows from Cupid's bow, sweet as a bon bon and pretty as a bouquet _ actually has its roots in blood, gore, guts and gluttony. Historians say Valentine's Day began in the third century, when two Christian saints, both named Valentine, were executed. Because the martyrs' feast day, Feb. 14, was around the time of a pagan Roman festival called the Lupercalia, which celebrated fertility, St. Valentine was popularly designated the patron saint of lovers. It's been 1,720 years since the heathens had their way _ today, we shower our sweeties with perfume, jewelry, lingerie, candy and flowers. We'll also buy them pajamas, stuffed animals in all shapes, acrylic legs filled with German chocolate _ at $98 a limb at Macy's _ and Vietnamese potbellied pigs. Americans will give their Valentines $611 million worth of candy this year, about $2.50 in sweets for every man, woman and child, says Richard O'Connell, president of the National Confectioners Association. If that $611 million were translated into chocolate kisses at the New York City price of $5 a pound, about 93 kisses, it would buy 122.2 million pounds. If all those kisses were laid end to end, the chain of chocolate would circle the globe 6.4 times. If you don't want to make your baby a blimp, merchants have a few suggestions. Bloomingdale's has some ``really fun boxer shorts with hearts on them,'' said spokeswoman Jennifer Conner. They also have T-shirts with ``big red lips'' on them. The apparel will set you back about $20. Victoria's Secret, the mildly racy lingerie chain, offers toiletries for those who don't feel their relationships are up to intimate underthings. But business is still brisk in undies, said spokeswoman Laura Holbrook. ``Oversized satin T-shirts, silk camisoles and pants in rich gem colors like emerald, ruby, safire will be big,'' she said. A little more upscale, Bergdorf Goodman has red silk pajamas for $375, a matching robe for $375 and bath oil for $63 _ a mere $813 to get your sweetheart clean and ready for bed. Macy's Estate Jewelry department offers atomizers with cranberry-colored glass and sterling silver trim for $950. Always popular is the romantic staple _ a simple red rose. Seventy million roses will be sold for Valentine's Day, the biggest day of the year for rose sales, the Society of American Florists predicts. Eighty percent will be red, the rest mostly pink and yellow. The other Valentine tradition _ exchanging cards _ is booming, said Leslee Parsons, a spokeswoman for the American Greeting Corp. They expect more than 1 billion valentines to be given this year. School children give the most cards, she said. But back to the chocolate. The National Confectioner's Association says Americans' increasing health consciousness is actually boosting the industry. ``Americans are treating themselves to confections and sweets, but because they are more health conscious and working out, they don't feel as guilty,'' said spokesman Brian Muloney. ``In fact, there's more working out and pigging out.'' And there are some who will literally pig out. Paradise Pigs, which sells the latest trendy pet, Vietnamese potbellied pigs, says it has received orders for Valentine's Day pigs, which cost from $1,500 to $2,500 for males and about $5,000 for females. The pigs are prized because they stay small, ranging from 25 pounds to 150 pounds, and have sunny dispositions. ``For a lot of our customers, it's like having a kid,'' said Paradise Pig's owner, Kris Bryant. ``Husbands are buying them for their wives, men are buying them for their girlfriends.'' Bryant said her pigs try to knock the phone from her hand when they think she's been talking long enough; that might make them a good buy for parents of teen-agers. Be it a dozen roses or a porcine bundle of joy, most people will wonder about their Valentine's Day gift: Was it given sincerely or was it just an obligatory gesture? ``People spend a good deal of time wondering if a gift is sincere,'' said sociologist Hy Mariampolski. And givers also worry whether their presents will be enjoyed, he said. ``People are very insecure about gifts being appreciated so they fall into patterns of safe gift giving,'' said Mariampolski, who studies gift-giving habits for QualiData Research Inc. in New York. One way to make sure your gift is well-regarded is to personalize it, he said. ``It may be a bouquet of flowers,'' he said, ``but if a guy has it delivered to his girlfriend's doorstep by a strolling musician, it's going to be very special.''

DOC.HEAD: Will the Real St. Valentine Please Stand Up?
With AM-Valentine's Day, b0359
DOC.TEXT: The identity of the first St. Valentine is about as mysterious as love itself. Historians say Valentine's Day has its origins in the third century, when two Christian martyrs, both named Valentine, were executed. A pagan festival to fertility, called the Lupercalia, was still being celebrated at that time, and because it fell around the martyrs' Feb. 14 feast day, St. Valentine became the protector of lovers. The people of Terni, Italy, a steel-making town between Rome and Perugia, insist their St. Valentine was the one who started the annual day of love. The town's patron saint was beheaded Feb. 14 in the year 270, after having been imprisoned and whipped. Legend has it that Valentine had a garden where he let children play and lovers meet. While imprisoned, Valentine tied the keys of the garden gate to two pigeons with a message inviting the children to return to the garden. A version of the Terni story has Valentine, in his 76 years as bishop, giving lovers flowers from the garden. One couple who encountered the bishop enjoyed such a happy marriage that every couple wanted his blessing. The story is complicated by a second St. Valentine, also beheaded in the third century, in Rome, and who also has a feast day Feb. 14. But ``Valentine 2'' may not have been a saint at all. Some scholars say a church built on Rome's Via Flaminia by a man named Valentine somehow became known as St. Valentine's church, starting a legend about a non-existent saint. The Roman Catholic Church takes a neutral stance and designates no patron saint of lovers. The Vatican Congregation for the Causes of Saints says 17 Valentines are listed in the official encyclopedia of saints, including ones from Italy, France, Spain and Germany. Terni's bishop, Franco Gualdrini, also refuses to claim his town's saint as the definitive champion of love. ``It is a popular tradition,'' Gualdrini once said of the adulation St. Valentine now receives. ``Some things are proclaimed from above, some are proclaimed from below.''

DOC.HEAD: Documentarian Offers First Big-Screen Look at U.S. Moon Shots
DOC.TEXT: Calling your film a documentary is like a politician today admitting that he's a liberal, laments Texas documentary maker Al Reinert. ``It's a sure way to run off the studio people,'' he said. The times may be a-changing. Thanks to Michael Moore's laceratingly funny ``Roger and Me,'' the documentary may be escaping Rodney Dangerfield status and gaining some respect. Moore was able to win a Warner Bros. release, and his $260,000 investment has already sold more than $3 million worth of tickets in theaters. Reinert hopes he can match Moore's achievement with ``For All Mankind.'' It's the first big-screen look at the achievements of U.S. astronauts who adventured to the moon from December 1968 to November 1972. Like Moore, Reinert had no experience as a filmmaker when he visited NASA headquarters in Houston on a magazine assignment 10 years ago. He learned that 6 million feet of film languished in the Apollo and Gemini archives. ``I thought it was big-screen material,'' Reinert said. ``Trying to tell this story on television was like publishing `War and Peace' in a newspaper. It's too big for the medium.'' He figures his ignorance of filmmaking was an advantage. ``I saw this wonderful film and I knew it was a great story. I thought, `This is an easy movie to make; they've done all the hard work.' To my surprise, I discovered there was still an enormous amount of work to do. ``I was amazed nobody had made this movie before. Looking back on it 10 years later, I can understand why nobody made it before.'' He began by reviewing the millions of feet of film and interviewing many of the astronauts, whose memories provide the soundtrack. Transferring the film to 35mm stock was a tedious process, and the enterprise repeatedly ran out of money. Reinert had to cease operations and hustle for contributions. ``For All Mankind'' has won high praise at film festivals and in test screenings in a few cities. The battle is not over; the film still hasn't attracted a distributor. An Academy Award nomination might help. The greatest impact of ``For All Mankind'' comes not from the moon walks but from looks back at the Earth, Reinert observes. ``For the astronauts, looking at the moon was secondary to leaving the Earth,'' he says. ``The moon is just the first place you can stop. What happened was that these people would look back over their shoulders with their noses to the window staring at the Earth for days and days as it went from the size of a beach ball to a basketball to a softball, and finally to the point where you could cover it up with your thumb. ``That's the way to put not only your life but human life in perspective and really develop an appreciation for this magical, delicate place where we live. I learned that from the astronauts, and also I fell in love with the images of the planet Earth. The most beautiful pictures ever taken are of the Earth.'' Reinert sees hope for the long-neglected documentary to make a dent on the movie market. ``Look at what's happened with writing. It was only 20 years ago that non-fiction writing was considered very much of a sub-genre. Serious writers were expected to write fiction. Non-fiction books sold very poorly relative to fiction,'' he said. ``Nowadays, non-fiction books are right up there (on best-seller lists) with fiction. Good writers go right back and forth between fiction and non-fiction. The same thing might prove to be the case with filmmakers.''

DOC.HEAD: A Marx Brothers Fan? You Bet Your Life
LaserPhoto PX2 of Feb. 6
DOC.TEXT: This must be Freedonia. That's Freedonia, with two e's, not to be confused with Fredonia, N.Y., probably to be confused with the mythical land of the Marx movie ``Duck Soup,'' and the home of current ``Marxist'' thought, The Freedonia Gazette magazine. A bedroom, a bathroom, a living room and dining area is all there is, but seemingly every square inch of Paul Wesolowski's poster-plastered condo is a memorial to the work of the Marx Brothers. Movie posters in the entry staircase make clear his commitment to Groucho, Harpo and Chico. And Zeppo. And don't forget Gummo. Oh, yes, there's also Manfred, who died at age 3. You come to learn such things during a visit with Wesolowski. Drop by and half expect Groucho to come shuffling through as Hugo Z. Hackenbush or Otis B. Driftwood, cigar in hand. Of course he won't, but there are enough Groucho glasses _ frame, nose, eyebrows and mustache _ lining Wesolowski's bedroom ceiling to satisfy a crowd of Groucho wanna-bes. ``I was flabbergasted,'' said Maxine Marx, Chico's daughter. Oh sure, she keeps albums, but her trip to Wesolowski's Marx Brothers shrine in 1988 was another matter. ``I said, `This is my family, and this would drive me bonkers,' '' she recalls. Wesolowski's interest in the Marx Brothers so impressed Groucho biographer Hector Arce that it led to a 10-day visit with the comedian _ who picked up the tab _ eight months before he died in 1977 at age 86. ``Physically he was an old man. He walked very slowly. His speech was slurred,'' Wesolowski said. ``But mentally, he was still sharp.'' When Arce told Marx he would show Wesolowski and a friend around the Beverly Hills house, Groucho quipped: ``Good, show 'em the servants' entrance. Better yet, show 'em the servants' exit.'' What had caught Arce's eye was Wesolowski's research. So drawn was Wesolowski to the Marx Brothers after seeing ``Duck Soup'' on television in 1974 that he left his tracks in libraries across the country. ``I stayed up and I watched it and thought it was the funniest movie I'd ever seen,'' Wesolowski said. When he could find free time from his accounting studies at St. Joseph's University, he looked up Marx Brothers information. He and a friend celebrated graduation in 1978 by spending a month visiting libraries in cities where the brothers performed. He kept filing material away, not really sure what he'd do with it. The result is research and a collection Wesolowski bills as ``the most complete Marx Brothers research facility on this planet.'' He did at least wait several years to see if he'd run across something close. ``In the past couple of years I've decided that there is nobody else,'' he said. He's received calls from magazines and quiz shows to verify Marx facts or quotes. He's not afraid to correct even Maxine Marx, who remembers his admonishment after she gave a lecture. ``He said, `You gave a wrong date.''' Even if Wesolowski can find evidence of his admitted obsession behind the couch (where more old movie posters await a chance for display), a fellow Marx fan sealed it with a chance meeting in London, of all places. There, after searching through book stores for Marx Brothers books, he came upon a cinema book store that had not only the books he wanted, but also another customer asking the shopkeeper if a Marx Brothers expert from Pennsylvania named Paul Wesolowski had ever come in the store. The customer turned out to be a Freedonia Gazette subscriber in Great Britain. ``I said, `He's in your store right now,''' Wesolowski said. ``That was the most bizarre coincidence of my life. That's what I'm talking about when I talk about the fun of collecting.'' Marx Brothers movie posters and lobby cards line Wesolowski's apartment, wall to wall, floor to ceiling. In varying sizes and colors and languages, they bill ``Animal Crackers,'' ``A Night in Casablanca,'' ``Love Happy,'' ``A Day at the Races'' and other films. ``It makes it real easy when I want to rearrange the furniture,'' Wesolowski said. These items don't include Groucho's personal brass cufflinks (a gift to Wesolowski from Groucho's sister-in-law), the Groucho clock with eyes swinging back and forth like a pendulum, the Groucho hat rack, puppets and wooden and ceramic figurines or the red Marx Brothers ``At the Circus'' sleeping bag from France. He also had street signs made, with names of the brothers and characters from their movies. Now he has Hugo Z. Hackenbush Expressway running through the living room, which shows off his time and effort. ``Spending 10 days with Groucho made it all worthwhile,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: The Magical World of Margot Fonteyn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Friday in 6th graf is Feb. 16.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Dame Margot Fonteyn's importance in the history of ballet can hardly be exaggerated. She was the first ballerina of international status to be developed by a British school and company. And, to audiences thrilled by her dancing during a 45-year career, she always seemed like a nice person, too. Personality is conveyed across the footlights, Dame Margot said during a recent visit to New York. ``It shows through your movement and your dancing,'' she said. ``I think if your personality doesn't come through, then you're a little immature as an artist. I think that's part of being an artist. It is not just doing the steps. It is part of yourself that is conveyed through your dancing. ``In `The Sleeping Beauty,' which was supposed to be my best role, I'm smiling, happy, optimistic, cheerful.'' Television audiences will have a chance to meet Dame Margot and see for themselves Friday, when ``The Margot Fonteyn Story'' is shown on PBS's ``Great Performances'' series from 9 to 10:30 p.m. EST. British producer-director Patricia Foy says she nagged Dame Margot for five years after her career ended a decade ago at age 60 to consider the project. Dame Margot's personal story is told on the show, as well as her dancing story. She met Roberto Arias, son of the president of Panama, in Cambridge, England, during the summer of 1937 when the Sadler's Wells Ballet was performing there and he was in college. They saw each other in 1938 and '39 and then not again for 14 years. In the interim, he had married and she had come close to marriage. They were married in 1955 and he was made Panamanian ambassador to Britain. In 1964, when he was running for office in Panama, bullets from an assassination attempt left him paralyzed. Dame Margot was interviewed for the TV show in 1988 at the cattle ranch in Panama where they lived after she retired. ``People asked if I was going to teach when I stopped dancing. I said, `I imagine I'll sit by my husband and be fat and happy.''' She was happy and enjoyed Panama's warm weather, but didn't gain weight. She lives there now, since his death last November, trying to continue his cattle breeding plans. ``I don't know if I can really manage, but I'm going to try anyway because that's what I'd rather do than anything else,'' she says. He had three children, each of whom has a son and daughter, and Dame Margot was visiting one family here. During her interview with The Associated Press, she graciously invited a young Arias grandson named Roberto Brillembourg into the living room to sing ``I was taken by surprise by a pair of penguin eyes,'' which will accompany a penguin dance he's rehearsing for school. Instead of memorizing what she said for TV, or reading from a teleprompter, which seemed stilted, Dame Margot says she concentrated on areas to talk about. In 1983, she was host of the six-part series ``Magic of Dance'' and became used to that technique. When she first started ballet lessons, her name was Peggy Hookham. ``Everybody thought it should be changed,'' she said. ``In those days everybody changed their name and now almost nobody changes their name. Fonteyn came from the Brazilian side of my family, Fontes, sort of a near approach. There are one or two programs where I'm Margot Fontes. Then I became Fonteyn. When I was first in the corps de ballet, I don't know what the name was.'' During World War II, the Sadler's Wells Ballet performed seven, eight or nine times a week. ``I would be in not less than seven _ one got very tired. There were two steps in `Swan Lake' and `Giselle' that were similar. At some point I decided I would do the same step in both ballets because I would get tired to the point it would worry me a bit to know which I was doing. ``At one point I got so exhausted that my main concern when I was doing a variation was that I wouldn't run off the stage before the end. I was frightened I wouldn't have control over what I was doing,'' she said. ``Occasionally I see the step wrong in the second act of `Swan Lake,' the way I changed it long ago. It's a tiny little detail.'' She was in New York to coach ``Birthday Offering,'' in which she was one of the original seven ballerinas, for American Ballet Theater. Sir Frederick Ashton created it for the 25th birthday of the Sadler's Wells, which became Britain's Royal Ballet in 1956. She doesn't often coach for ballet companies but enjoys it now. ``New dancers come into the cast. There are always some little details and things that get lost. I think I can help in small ways,'' she said. Last year, she coached for three weeks in Houston and for three weeks with the Royal Ballet. Dame Margot's first major creation was in an Ashton ballet in 1935 and, though the years, she did many. Interestingly, Sir Frederick recalls on television what he thought of her in 1933 and includes the words inadequate and stubborn. The TV show begins with a ``Swan Lake'' staged by Rudolf Nureyev for the Vienna Opera. He and Dame Margot were filmed dancing in it in 1964. Earlier, Dame Margot danced with Robert Helpmann, which she says helped her develop stage presence. ``If he was playing the title role in `Coppelia,' and you were Swanilda (the doll), you didn't have a hope,'' she said. ``Nobody was ever going to look at anybody else while he was there. He was a genius, so funny. ``If you're on the stage with somebody who has this tremendous magnetism and charisma, if you're there beside him, you have to try to do something. Otherwise, you're going to be a nonentity. Working with him greatly helped me to develop as a stage performer so that people might see me as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Celica GT-S: Sporty, Peppy Redesign for Sleekest Model Yet
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Anyone familiar with Toyota probably knows the Celica name. It is Toyota's second-oldest nameplate in this country after the Corolla. This year, two decades after the first Celica crossed American shores, Toyota makes the popular Celica sleeker and more aerodynamic than ever. The redesigned 1990 Celica line includes its first four-wheel-drive model and offers a larger selection of engines. The 2.2-liter, 16-valve, electronic fuel-injected four-cylinder model that powered the Celica GT-S test car seemed ready and able to take on more than just that car's 2,800 pounds. This marks the fifth major redesign of the Celica. In the two months following last fall's introduction, Toyota sold more than 12,800 Celicas, outperforming its primary import competitors, the Honda Prelude and the Nissan 240SX, said Toyota spokesman Mike Michels. The company would not estimate sales for the entire 1990 model year. Over its history, sales of the Celica have tended to rise when the car is redesigned. In 1986, for example, sales went up to 106,731 from 80,482 in 1985 after a redesigned 1986 model arrived in showrooms. Since then, sales have dropped each year, to 79,333 in 1987, to 66,053 in 1988 and to 61,936 in 1989. The 1990 Celica's new sporty look appeals to women _ two-thirds of recent buyers were female _ with a median age of 30. Two-thirds of recent buyers are single, and 69 percent are college graduates, Toyota said. The bright red GT-S test car reminded me of the Mazda Miata in outside styling. The Celica is eye-catching, with its low, rounded front, slightly flared fenders and quarter panels, and built-in, color-matched bumpers. The metal was clean, devoid of metal strips and trim. The only protrusion was the rear spoiler. You'll have to lift items up and into the cargo area, given the design of the rear hatchback. And the spare tire creates a slightly raised circle in the middle, so trunk space is not flat. The rear seats fold down for additional space. Fit and finish were admirable inside and out, not surprising considering Toyota's reputation for quality cars. The Celica has ranked much better than average in Consumer Reports magazine's owner trouble index for the 1984-88 model years. But the test car's rear seat area was cramped. Only two adults can sit there, and they had best be short and thin. Even at 5-feet-4, I found my head smacking into the Celica's sloping roofline in the back seat. And since the rear seats are sculpted, there was pitifully little hiproom for heftier passengers. The front seats, complete with articulated headrests, were far more comfortable. The test car had the optional seven-way adjustable driver seat with lumbar support, which made for easy positioning. Toyota did a masterful job of gathering and organizing the car's gauges and instruments around the cockpit-style dashboard. All are within easy reach of the driver and have good-sized buttons and knobs. A handy cup holder pops out from under the radio. The premium radio system, by the way, was superb, with 10 speakers, including a little, round one at the window near the outside side mirror. The test car's standard engine didn't act like a little four-cylinder at all. In fact, the GT-S, with a five-speed transmission, had so much power that the front tires often grabbed aggressively at the road when I tried to accelerate quickly from a stop. Unfortunately, on wet and slick surfaces, they weren't always successful, and it was also tricky keeping this sporty car steady on roads lightly dusted with snow. Celica competitors include lower-priced cars such as the Plymouth Laser, which starts around $11,000, and the Laser turbocharged model starting at $14,000. The base price of the Nissan 240SX is about $13,250. Celicas begin at $12,268, although the GT-S test car was base priced at $4,000 more because of its engine and other standard features.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Movie `Challenger' Looks at Astronauts and Safety Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf to say shuttle exploded Jan. 28 sted Jan. 27. Movie airs Feb. 25.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Barry Bostwick says he didn't encounter any objections within the space community to the ABC movie ``Challenger,'' which explores the lives of the seven astronauts killed in the shuttle explosion. ``I think everyone had a wait-and-see attitude,'' said the actor, who plays mission commander Francis R. ``Dick'' Scobee. ``We were scratching around a wound that hadn't quite healed. What I got from the NASA people was that it was a certain catharsis working with us.'' ``Challenger,'' which airs Sunday, also examines the debate over the safety of the shuttle's solid rocket boosters. The three-hour movie _ which ends with liftoff, just before the shuttle exploded on Jan. 28, 1986 _ stars Karen Allen as Christa McAuliffe, the New Hampshire schoolteacher chosen by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to join the shuttle crew. The other five astronaut roles: Julie Fulton as Dr. Judith A. Resnick; Richard Jenkins as Gregory B. Jarvis; Brian Kerwin as Capt. Michael J. Smith; Keone Young as Lt. Col. Ellison Onizuka; and Joe Morton as Dr. Ronald E. McNair. Lane Smith, as Larry Mulloy of NASA, and Peter Boyle, as engineer Roger Boisjoly of Morton-Thiokol Co., carry on the debate over the safety of the O-ring joints sealing the solid rocket boosters. Boisjoly feared the freezing temperatures at the Cape could cause the seals to fail. ``Challenger'' was filmed on location at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``We had so much input from NASA and the families,'' Bostwick said. ``I think the feeling was that somebody was going to do this story, with or without their help, and it was best to see that it was told right. ``These jobs only come along once in a few years,'' he said. ``Being an actor allows you to explore other worlds. I was allowed to go through the whole NASA experience and work with such excellent people and train on the same equipment the astronauts use.'' Bostwick described Scobee as ``a straight-ahead guy.'' ``He was chosen as commander because he was solid and steady,'' the actor said. ``He wasn't a hotshot. I talked to a lot of his friends after I got to Houston. I looked at some training films so I could observe him in action, see how he took control.'' George Englund's screenplay, despite an occasional tendency toward boosterism, presents the astronauts, their families and NASA officials as real human beings, rather than stick figures in a docudrama. Director Glenn Jordan invests it with a dramatic tension that holds interest even though the world knows the conclusion. Bostwick is now at work on a musical version of ``Aladdin'' for the Disney Channel in which he plays the genie. It's part of a package, similar to Showtime's ``Faerie Tale Theatre,'' put together by Martin Tahse from children's musicals done by the Prince Street Theater. Mickey Dolenz of the Monkees is directing. ``It's my first musical since `The Pirates of Penzance' seven years ago,'' Bostwick said. ``But I still sing at least once a year. I sang at the White House last year. The year before that, I did an `Evening at Carnegie Hall.' I'm also in discussions for a musical based on `The Thin Man' called `Nick and Nora.''' Bostwick is avoiding any commitment to a new TV series after stints in two short-lived ones, ``Foul Play'' and ``Dads.'' He's certainly done his share of miniseries, nearly rivaling Richard Chamberlain as the king of the long form. Among his miniseries credits: ``Scruples,'' ``Deceptions,'' ``George Washington,'' ``George Washington II: The Forging of a Nation,'' ``A Woman of Substance'' and ``War and Remembrance.'' ``Doing an hour show can shorten your life,'' he said. ``The hours and the stress are too much. Work has never been an all-consuming thing for me anyway. I'm the kind of person who has a lot of hobbies.'' Bostwick has planted 80 varieties of fruit trees at his hillside home, including many exotic fruits, and is attempting to raise orchids. ``I've been looking into some alternate professions, something to keep my interest up and tide me over if ABC's not doing miniseries this year,'' he said. ``I went to Belize with a friend a few weeks ago to look into some agricultural and aquaculture investments. We looked at five or six shrimp farms and found they were all for sale.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombia, Peru, Bolivia Each Has Own Problems in Drug Fight
With BC-Drugs-Bush's War, b0543
DOC.TEXT: Colombian officials battle a cocaine establishment so ruthless and powerful that their best hope is to ship its leaders _ when they can be caught _ to the United States. The Peruvian government encounters not entrenched, highly successful businessmen but peasants whose livelihood is the coca crop and leftist guerrillas who battle the government in the name of the poor. In Bolivia, impoverished farmers eagerly accept government payments in return for destroying coca crops on which they spend more money than they make. But the government wonders what the peasants will do with themselves if they're not growing the raw material for cocaine. The leaders of these nations will meet with President Bush on Thursday to coordinate their efforts in what they say will be an ``unstoppable assault on drug traffickers.'' But each faces his own reality and must approach the war on drugs in his own way. Here is the situation in the three Andean countries, which together account for most of the world's cocaine production:

Over the years, Colombian traffickers, led by the Medellin and Cali cartels, have murdered thousands of their countrymen and turned entire regions into cocaine-production centers. So strong are the cartels' ringleaders that President Virgilio Barco, fearful that his nation's judicial system is not up to the task, has made hunting down and extraditing the nation's top traffickers his first priority in the war on drugs. Plainly, he feels justice has a better chance of prevailing in the United States _ where 80 percent of the cocaine supply comes from the two cartels _ than in Colombia. ``Colombian police have been going hog wild on locating Colombians for extradition,'' said a knowledgeable U.S. official, adding, ``but they haven't been able to go after the cocaine labs at the same time.'' The government's focus has indeed shifted in the six months of the extradition campaign from targeting the jungle labs that process raw coca leaves from Peru and Bolivia to focusing on the men who call the shots. There's a downside to Barco's efforts. The U.S. official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that the supply of cocaine leaving Colombia, after taking a sharp dive in the weeks after the campaign began, has rebounded nearly to its earlier level. The official said independent traffickers not associated with any organization have filled in the gaps torn in the cartels by the government offensive. Despite its failure to make a lasting dent in cocaine output, the Colombian crackdown has shown some results: _The government reported recently that authorities have taken over 777 of the traffickers' properties worth millions of dollars. _Fourteen drug suspects have been sent to the United States and one leader of the Medellin cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was killed in a Dec. 15 gunfight. _Authorities last year seized nearly 2.7 million gallons of imported industrial chemicals used to process coca into cocaine. The year before, less than 1 million gallons of such chemicals were confiscated. ``The jump was astounding and proved to the world that Colombia was serious about fighting cocaine trafficking,'' said the U.S. official. The acting chief of the national police, Gen. Carlos Arturo Casadiego, put it this way in a recent interview: ``This war will continue until there are no more drug traffickers walking freely in Colombia. That is our goal. It is not negotiable.''

Since September, 30 or so U.S. drug agents, contract pilots and mechanics have been launching raids with Peruvian police against jungle drug laboratories and clandestine airstrips. But rebel activity in the Upper Huallaga valley, where most of the country's coca crop is grown, has kept the agents from operating freely. Last year they pulled out of the valley for seven months after an American helicopter pilot was wounded by gunfire. Maoist Shining Path guerrillas controlling much of the valley offer protection to drug traffickers in exchange for a share of the profits. The rebels also make sure the traffickers do not cheat the peasant coca growers. Peru accounts for 60 percent of the world's coca leaf crop.

In Bolivia, where drug-related violence is much less of a problem than in Colombia or Peru, the government has made some gains against coca growing in recent months with a crop-eradication program that pays farmers to destroy their coca fields. In December and January, farmers voluntarily destroyed a record 512 acres of coca in Chapare, the region where 80 percent of the country's coca plants are found. Farmers get the equivalent of $800 for every acre they destroy. Peasants are lining up for the money because 100 pounds of coca leaf now sells for $5 to $7 _ but costs about $30 to grow. ``In the last few months the Jaime Paz Zamora government has made significant progress in law enforcement, eradication, interdiction and crop substitution programs,'' U.S. Ambassador Robert S. Gelbard said in a recent interview. But he added that Colombia's war against traffickers was partially responsible for the Bolivian success. The Colombian crackdown lowered the price paid for coca because demand for the leaf fell when traffickers dropped out of sight. Bolivia accounts for one-third of international coca leaf production. Bolivian authorities worry, as do those in Peru, what peasants will do with themselves if the eradication program is a thoroughgoing success. An estimated 300,000 peasants in Chapare depend on coca production for their livlihood. Many have complained that the government is eradicating the crop without offering an alternative and that they benefited little from $40 million provided by the United States for crop substitution last year. The government in Peru says as many as 200,000 Peruvians make their living by growing the coca bush. President Alan Garcia has resisted eradication programs such as the one in Bolivia because he does not want to drive displaced coca farmers into the hands of the Maoist guerrillas. The approach to the drug fight may vary, but one thing all three nations agree on is the need to gain more economic assistance from the United States in return for their participation. The Bush administration has earmarked $270 million this year for Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, but some foreign officials say all three countries will likely ask for more.

DOC.HEAD: Everybody Has Wish List as 1990 Farm Bill Debate Moves Ahead
DOC.TEXT: Congress has its starting point on a 1990 farm bill, and the Bush administration has one, too. Exactly where the legislative route will lead and what the trip will cost taxpayers is unknown. Months of dickering and bickering remain, and scores of pressure groups want a slice of the action. Budget constraints hover, but if recent history is any guide, the 1990 edition will not be cheap. The current law, the Food Security Act of 1985, expires at the end of the 1990 crop season, meaning most of the farm commodity costs will spill over into the 1991 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Since passage of the 1985 law, federal spending on commodity programs has totaled an estimated $79.4 billion, a record amount for a five-year period. During the period, however, the amount went down each year. According to the Agriculture Department's budget office, net outlays by the Commodity Credit Corp. have decreased from a record $25.8 billion in fiscal 1986 to $22.4 billion in 1987, $12.5 billion in 1988, $10.5 billion in 1989 and an estimated $8.2 billion in 1990. Farm commodity costs at USDA now run a distant second to food stamps and other consumer services, which total about $23.4 billion this year. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter last week issued a long wish list for Congress to consider, but he evaded cost issues. Yeutter said those will be worked out with lawmakers when the time comes. That did not sit well with some lawmakers who say it is time for the administration to speak more plainly. But the administration's 1990 farm proposals still were ``not a bad opening gambit'' as Congress bears down on the legislation, said Don Lipton of the American Farm Bureau Federation. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, had an opening gambit, too. As chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, he and the ranking minority member, Rep. Edward R. Madigan, R-Ill., introduced their own Food and Agricultural Resources Act of 1990, serving notice on the Bush people that the committee would begin with or without them. De la Garza said the measure ``continues the policies we hammered out'' in the 1985 act and its subsequent amendments. ``It continues the combination of market-oriented polices and farm income protection which has helped American agriculture recover from its economic crisis of the 1980s.'' Madigan said the bill, based on the 1985 law, ``will serve as an excellent starting point for our committee deliberations.'' One of the features of the House bill is a freeze on target prices for wheat and feed grains at their 1990 level. Minimum target prices for cotton and rice would be extended for 1991 through 1995 crops. Soybean price support loan rates would be extended through 1995 at 75 percent of an annual average for the previous five years, excluding the high and low years. The target prices and price support mechanisms would be potential targets for reduction under the Bush administration's plan, although Yeutter did not spell out any details. A keystone of the administration's strategy involves added ``flexibility'' for commodity programs so that farmers can basically plant what they want without losing base acreage credit or suffering other penalties. The House bill did not include a flexibility provision, but de la Garza said the administration's proposals ``may have an impact as we deliberate our bill. There are no items in our bill and the administration proposals that cannot be worked out.'' But there are a few potential sticking points: _Environmental and health issues, including water quality, food safety and global changes are expected to produce some of the most heated debate. The Bush administration says USDA ``should take an active role in research and education'' on environmental issues, but Congress may insist on more. _While the House bill introduced by de la Garza and Madigan would continue minimum price support loan rates for cotton and rice, the Bush plan seeks their elimination. That would make the loan rate formula for cotton and rice the same as for wheat and feed grains. The minimum for soybeans, however, would be maintained under both plans. _Peanuts are one of the few commodities whose supports are tied to production costs. The House bill would continue the practice. But the Bush proposal says the cost-of-production escalator should be eliminated, along with the sale and lease of peanut quotas. _The House bill would extend the minimum sugar support level of 18 cents per pound through 1995 crops of sugar cane. The sugar beet level would have to be at a ``fair and reasonable'' level relative to cane. The Bush proposals do not spell out what the administration has in mind for sugar, although there is pressure within the government to reduce sugar supports sharply. _The Bush plan calls for elimination of federal crop insurance and the formation of a permanent disaster relief program, although Yeutter said the administration is open to discussion if Congress opts for a complete overhaul of crop insurance. _Under the Bush plan, the Farmers Home Administration would ``provide for better targeting'' of farm operating and farm ownership loans and would ``curb certain program abuses'' involved in the restructuring of heavy debt loads. Further shifts to FmHA loan guarantees to private lenders are recommended.
