DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 12th graf, In an open ... voters' time., to make it Sangamon sted Sangamo; SUBs 14th graf, In his ... Sangamon River., to clarify family's moves; CORRECTS 17th graf, Elected to . .. fellow Whig., to make it Mexican War sted Mexico; CORRECTS 37th graf (18th graf of 1st add), On April ... following morning., to make it Ford's sted Ford and Tyrannis sted Tyranus.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY303 of Feb. 6
DOC.TEXT: ``Every man is said to have his peculiar ambition. Whether it be true or not, I can say for one that I have no other so great as that of being truly esteemed of my fellow man, by rendering myself worthy of their esteem.'' _ Abraham Lincoln.

When Abraham Lincoln received the Republican Party's nomination for president in 1860, the New York Herald dismissed him as a ``fourth-rate lecturer, who cannot speak good grammar, and who, to raise the wind, delivers his hackneyed, illiterate compositions at $200 apiece.'' The man later compared to Mark Twain for his gift with the English language was nicknamed Ignoramus Abe, Old Scoundrel and Filthy Story-Teller. ``I have endured a great deal of ridicule without much malice and received a great deal of kindness not quite free of ridicule,'' Lincoln once said, referring to the condescending treatment his homespun style received even from friends. But historians have seen him differently, finding richness in the language of a poor, country lawyer. The Library of America, which has previously published the works of Twain, Henry James and other celebrated writers, is honoring Lincoln with a two-volume, $35 publication of his speeches and letters: ``Lincoln: Speeches and Writings 1832-1858'' and ``Lincoln: Speeches and Writings 1859-1865.'' ``How do we define literature?'' asked editor Don E. Fehrenbacher, author of ``Lincoln in Text and Context: Collected Essays,'' and ``The Dred Scott Case: Its Significance in American Law and Politics,'' which won the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1979. ``He is able to write in such a way as to express deep emotion under artistic control. That's what we look for in a (Ernest) Hemingway or in a Henry James, and that's what we get in Lincoln's best works. ``That combination of something fundamental to say that goes beyond mere intellect. There is artistry in his letters, that ear for the English language.'' The author of the Gettysburg Address composed all his own speeches despite spending only 12 months in school. He was part philosopher, part politician, part poet. His influences included Shakespeare, the King James version of the Bible and long-time Speaker of the House Henry Clay, whose dealmaking earned him the nickname ``The Great Compromiser.'' Lincoln was a progressive pragmatist. He staked his political career on opposition to slavery, but tempered that with assurances that blacks would be better off living in their own country once freed. ``I have no desire to own a slave or to marry one'' was how he summed up his position. He first presented himself as lagging sadly behind _ a reluctant, almost embarrassed public servant, more familiar with the straight path back to his Kentucky log cabin on Nolan Creek than the winding, uphill climb to the White House. In an open letter to the people of Illinois' Sangamon County, published March 9, 1832, Lincoln offered sincere, cut-and-dry analyses of local issues as he urged consideration for election to the Illinois General Assembly and concluded with a near apology for taking up the voters' time. He was born Feb. 12, 1809, the second child of pioneer farmer and carpenter Thomas Lincoln and Nancy Hanks Lincoln. He was just 2 when his family moved out of the log cabin to a 230-acre farm on Knob Creek, 11 miles northeast of Hodgenville, Ky. In his early 20s, after the family moved to Indiana and then to Illinois, Lincoln made his home outside Decatur, Ill., and gave his first known political speech in 1830, favoring improved navigation on the Sangamon River. In 1834, a year after he was appointed postmaster of New Salem, he was elected as a Whig to the Illinois House of Representatives and served four terms. During that time, he received a license to practice law and began his public opposition to slavery. ``The main routes upwards for men who were not well born were law and politics,'' Fehrenbacher explained. ``There weren't that many openings, and politics were much more central in those days. The crowds came out and listened for hours.'' Elected to Congress in 1846, Lincoln served just one term, bitterly questioning President James K. Polk's use of troops in the Mexican War. He left Washington after failing to receive an appointment from the administration of President Zachary Taylor, a fellow Whig. His life in politics seemingly over, Lincoln practiced law in Springfield, where he lived with his wife, the former Mary Todd, whom he married in 1842, and three sons, Robert Todd, Tad and Willie (a fourth son, Edward, died at age 3). The slavery issue had apparantly been settled in 1820 when Clay helped craft the Missouri Compromise, which allowed the South to keep slaves but required abolition in a large section of territories in the Midwest. The agreement, however, fell apart in 1854 when Congress passed the Kansas-Nebraska Act, which repealed the anti-slavery language of the Missouri Compromise in favor of ``local sovereignty.'' An enraged Lincoln, insisting that ``the spirit of '76'' and ``the spirit of Nebraska, are utter antagonisms,'' cut back on his promising legal work and set his sights on the U.S. Senate. Thus was born the most famous political rivalry of the time: Lincoln, the gangly, moody proponent of abolition, and Illinois Sen. Stephen Douglas, the squat, gregarious author of the Kansas-Nebraska Act and a powerful Northern Democrat. In 1856, Lincoln helped found the Republican Party of Illinois, which opposed slavery. He warned two years later that ``a house divided against itself cannot stand,'' anticipating that the United States could not remain intact with conflicting laws. Fehrenbacher said the Lincoln-Douglas debates, included in their entirety in the two-volume compilation, made Lincoln a national figure. Thousands attended each of the seven confrontations, all held outdoors, and frequently interrupted the speeches with loud applause and cries of encouragement. The format was broken into three parts: a one-hour opening statement, a 1{-hour reply and a half-hour rejoinder. Slavery was virtually the only issue. Douglas made overtly racist appeals and insisted the government was ``made for the benefit of white men and their posterity for ever.'' Said Lincoln: ``You say it must not be opposed in the free States, because slavery is not here; it must not be opposed in the slaves States, because it is there; it must not be opposed in politics, because that will make a fuss; it must not be opposed in the pulpit, because it is not religion. Then where is the place to oppose it?'' Douglas won the election, but Lincoln was pleased enough with the debates to have them published the following year. In the 1860 presidential campaign, with the Democrats badly splintered, the election broke down into two regional campaigns: Lincoln vs. Douglas in the North, and John C. Breckinridge vs. John Bell in the South.

DOC.HEAD: Symbolism Wins Out Over Security in Bush Trip to Colombia
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Balancing the risks of narco-tourism against the symbolism of drug diplomacy inside Colombia, President Bush is heading into potentially dangerous territory on Thursday for a cocaine-fighting summit. He is not the first president to decide that a mission and a message should override security concerns. Bush has heard all about it, from aides and from worried constituents, in the two months since he accepted the invitation to go to Cartagena, despite Colombian drug violence, terrorism and reports the cocaine cartel would target him. The question of his safety was raised at a speech in San Francisco on Wednesday, at a barbecue in Texas weeks ago, in telephone calls to the White House switchboard. The president's reply: He won't be reckless; he doesn't want to be in harm's way, but he is determined to go to Cartagena to show his support and solidarity with Colombian President Virgilio Barco. At their brief summit, Bush and the leaders of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru are to sign an agreement to cooperate in drug-fighting efforts, with U.S. aid for crop substitution as part of the plan. But that agenda has been overshadowed by the site of the conference. By going to Colombia, even for a few hours, Bush dramatizes his anti-drug campaign. ``I am not going to do something stupid or macho,'' he said in San Francisco. ``The guy they used to call timid is now ``macho man'' or something? ... It has nothing to do with that. ``It has a lot to do with the support for a courageous leader in Colombia,'' Bush said. He said he believes he can be kept secure for a summit at a naval base, just as Barco is protected in his own home. ``I don't want to send a signal, on your behalf or my behalf, that the United States says to this great president, `Look, our president can't come there, even though we think the security can be granted _ be guaranteed.''' Bush said that could push the Colombian leader toward ``a kind of deal that he has resisted making with the narco-traffickers'' who have said they would stop smuggling drugs in exchange for immunity from prosecution. Other presidents have ventured into war zones, waved off security concerns at home, insisted on appearing where their bodyguards wish they wouldn't go. Bush will travel with all the security the Secret Service, the Air Force and other military escorts can muster during the single-day trip. The four presidents will meet at a secured, sealed naval base on the Caribbean. The tight security is being advertised in advance, as a deterrent, because the secrecy that was part of the shield for earlier presidents in danger zones was impossible this time, with both date and destination disclosed long in advance. There will be escorts, probably decoys and other steps to guard Air Force One and the presidential helicopter. The White House and the Colombian embassy both discounted reports that the drug traffickers were plotting to attack the presidential aircraft with surface-to-air missiles. There also have been reports the cartel had put up a huge bounty on Bush; the president scoffed at that. There are political and personal components to presidential decisions to travel to foreign trouble spots or to overrule security concerns at home. Twice during his presidency, Lyndon B. Johnson flew secretly to South Vietnam. In October 1966, and just before Christmas in 1967, Air Force One flew into the war zone, landing at Cam Ranh Bay, a secure U.S. base about 200 miles from Saigon. His trips were not disclosed until they were over. So, too, when Dwight D. Eisenhower, as president-elect, kept a campaign promise by going to Korea in December 1952 while war raged there. He did not go to the front, although he was at times within artillery range. The trip was announced while Eisenhower was flying home. Franklin D. Roosevelt was the first president to travel overseas in wartime, traveling to Casablanca in 1943 for a summit with World War II allies. Those modern travels into potential danger passed without incident. When Abraham Lincoln went to a Civil War battle front on the outskirts of Washington in 1864, a Union soldier was killed three feet from where the president stood. ``Get down, you fool,'' Lt. Col. Oliver Wendell Holmes is said to have shouted, and Lincoln took cover. Nobody has been that blunt about the drug summit. Bush accepted the invitation on Oct. 10, before the site or the exact date had been set. Cartagena quickly came up as a possible location, and there was a report, never confirmed, that the Secret Service had advised against it. Cartagena it was, with Bush's decision to go there announced in Bogota on Dec. 12 and by the White House a day later. Expressing a thought common to many of his predecessors, Bush said: ``I'm not going to live in a cocoon.''

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Government Warns Pension Case Could Lead to Taxpayer Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The future of the government program that insures millions of Americans' pensions is at stake in a Supreme Court case that will be argued this month, with federal officials warning that an adverse ruling could eventually force a huge taxpayer bailout. At issue is whether LTV Steel Co. will succeed in dumping billions of dollars in pension costs onto the government's Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, setting a precedent that could lead to similar maneuvers by other companies. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole says the case ``will have far-reaching ramifications for the retirement security of workers and pensioners'' across the country. The court must decide whether the PBGC acted properly in ordering LTV Steel, a subsidiary of the Dallas-based LTV Corp., to reassume responsibility for three pension plans. A federal appeals court already has ruled against the PBGC. The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear the arguments Feb. 27. LTV, faced with a declining steel market, declared bankrupcy in 1986 and notified the PBGC it could not pay into its pension plans, which were underfinanced by $2.3 billion. The burden then fell to the national pension insurance agency, which collects premiums from the companies that hold pension plans for 30 million American workers. LTV then worked out an agreement with the United Steelworkers of America calling for the company to return benefits to their previous levels by paying the difference on top of what the PBGC paid. PBGC describes the manuever as an ``abusive follow-on plan,'' which essentially shunts billions of dollars in pension obligations onto the government. In September 1987, the PBGC argued that the steel industry had rebounded and ordered LTV to take full responsibility for its pension obligations to 100,000 participants. LTV objected. ``The steel industry did have a recovery. But it did not recover to the extent that we could take back the pensions,'' Charles Palmer, LTV's director of corporate communications, said in an interview. ``PBGC, in our view, made an arbitrary, capricious decision.'' The pension insurance agency argues otherwise. ``If the decision of the court of appeals is not reversed, other companies will follow LTV's example and use pension insurance as a subsidy to reduce costs and gain a competitive edge,'' the PBGC says in a brief to the Supreme Court. ``The result will be a fundamental transformation of the PBGC's role and a dramatic increase in the PBGC's liabilities that could lead to a financial crisis similar to that currently facing the FSLIC.'' FSLIC was the federal agency that went bust last year after paying out all its premiums to make up for losses in the savings and loan industry. The liability then fell to the taxpayers, who will pay at least $150 billion over the next 10 years under President Bush's bailout plan. ``Like the federal savings and loan insurance program, the pension termination insurance program is in dire financial condition,'' the Justice Department said in a brief backing PBGC's claims. The PBGC already has a more than $1 billion deficit and says the LTV claims would more than double that figure. Backing the government's position in the high court case are several steel companies that say LTV, thanks to the pension maneuver, now enjoys unfair advantages which stifle competition in the industry. A court brief submitted jointly by Armco, Bethlehem Steel Corp., Inland Steel Industries Inc., National Steel Corp. and USX Corp. says LTV has gained an ``artifical competitive advantage'' that was never envisioned under laws governing the pension insurance program. LTV, however, argues that the PBGC's charges of abuse are ``fundamentally inconsistent'' with the agency's duties under the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act, which protects pensioners' rights. ``This explicit scare reference to the unrelated S&L problem totally confounds common sense, the unambiguous record in this case, and all known experience,'' LTV said in a court brief. Palmer says LTV simply does not have the wherewithal to pay into the pension plans. Even if PBGC wins the case, he said, ``we wouldn't have the money'' and the pension expenses would bounce right back to the government. The state of Ohio, with 9,800 LTV Steel workers, and Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corp., another steelmaker that went into bankruptcy, have filed briefs supporting LTV's position. ``Congress (in 1986) addressed the PBGC's concerns not by banning follow-on plans designed to help the pension recipients that ERISA is intended to protect,'' Wheeling Pittsburgh said.

DOC.HEAD: Plastic Surgery in Your Future? Buyer, Beware!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: D.Ann, 22nd graf, is cq with no space.
DOC.TEXT: Looking for a present for the valentine who has more than everything? How about an eyelid tuck, or liposuction? But at anywhere from $600 to $8,000, cosmetic surgery may be too pricey, so how does $85 a month sound for the woman, or man, of your dreams? Buyer, beware! ``It really is a medical procedure and all surgery has problems. It's not buying a fur coat,'' warns Dr. R. Barrett Noone, a director of the American Board of Plastic Surgeons, which certifies doctors in the speciality. ``Don't bother,'' Lee Goldsmith, a physician and practicing lawyer, says to those thinking of cosmetic surgery. ``It's an abused, unnecessary procedure.'' Goldsmith only sees the failures in his New York-area law practice, such as the a woman who came in after an implant with ``one breast going up and one going down and the surgeon was going to charge her to do it over.'' But successes outnumber horror stories in the multibillion-dollar industry _ an estimated 1 million to 3 million ``image enhancement'' procedures a year in the United States. Cher had her nose ``refined'' several years ago. ``It looked too big onscreen and bothered me. Hey, if I need cosmetic surgery, the moment I need it I'm getting it. OK?'' she told People magazine. Angela Lansbury went public last year: Periodic cosmetic surgery dating to 1966 has helped keep her a leading lady. The star of the TV series ``Murder, She Wrote,'' said she decided to talk about it because ``cosmetic surgery shouldn't be just the secret of actresses and socialites now that it's available to anyone who wants it and can afford it.'' Supporters call that accessibility democratic. Critics call it a problem. ``Medicine goes Madison Avenue ... with the kind of advertising previously reserved for the ABCs _ automobiles, beer and cigarettes,'' says the staff of a House subcommittee preparing a bill to set some standards on how doctors can advertise such procedures and where they can perform the operations. Cosmetic surgery is ``a dangerously under-regulated medical field,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., who chaired hearings last spring that prompted his panel of the Small Business Committee to draft the regulations. The panel found that cosmetic surgery is often performed by unqualified doctors in underequipped facilities. The staff report estimated that 3 million cosmetic operations are perfomed a year, 95 percent of them in doctors' offices where crucial emergency equipment is often lacking. Some say the 3 million figure is way too high, but there's no way to know for sure. Men accounted for nearly 30 percent of the 1988 patients for doctors in the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery, and 22 percent of facial surgery by those in the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons. Earpinnings, or croppings, are big with males, who had 53 percent of those procedures reported for 1988 by the Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons group; a further breakdown shows that 53 percent of the total ear procedures was done on children age 12 or younger. Men had 23 percent of the eyelid surgery, 12 percent of the facelifts and 13 percent of the liposuction _ fat removal. The consumer's dilemma _ and everyone seems to agree the consumer can get caught in the middle _ is that any licensed physician can do cosmetic surgery. Or brain surgery, for that matter, but the demand doesn't seem to be so high. ``Physicians have responded to the demand, not created it,'' says Dr. Richard Caleel, president of the American Academy of Cosmetic Surgery. The demand, or the money, has induced doctors who are certified in gynecology, ear, nose and throat, or whatever to turn to the more lucrative work. A top plastic surgeon can do 16 operations a week at ``$3,000 to $4,000 a pop,'' Goldsmith says. Doctors can legally advertise, perform operations any place they choose and call themselves board certified without designating the speciality. This has set up a feud involving doctors trained in plastic and reconstructive surgery and those trained in some other specialty who turned to cosmetic work, those who square off for or against advertising, and those who, like Goldsmith, say the risks of such elective surgery are just too great. Pity the poor consumer! ``There are some very serious abuses going on out there,'' says D.Ann Murphy, a staff investigator for Wyden's committee. ``People being blinded, lost limbs, serious scarring.'' It goes ``well beyond a turf battle'' among the various medical groups, she says, and blames a big part of the problem on people ``lured'' into doctor's offices by ads suggesting they need something they didn't know they wanted. Goldsmith is ``upset by the ads, to put it mildly. There is a tremendous selling of plastic surgery going on and much of it is being done by individuals who don't have the necessary skills.'' Advertising lets people know that techniques have improved, that a hospital stay isn't necessary, that face fixes are affordable, that it's not just for the rich and famous and, quite frequently, that one can charge it. Profiles & Contours, with clinics in New York and Connecticut, runs full-page ads with the headline: ``Look like a million for a couple of thousand.'' It goes on to say you can get liposuction or breast enlargement for as little as $85 a month. The group's 18-page booklet, with the picture of a young model on the cover, says cosmetic surgery is not about vanity or self-indulgence, it's about feeling better about yourself. ``As plastic surgery grows in awareness and acceptance it will gradually become as common as eyeglasses, braces, and hearing aids and be just as useful,'' it says. The booklet has a section on choosing a plastic surgeon that includes tips supporters and critics can agree on: Interview surgeons, check out the hospitals they're affiliated with, make sure they have the proper credentials. Those on the center's mailing list got a letter recently offering ``an interest rate that's just 12 percent. ... We can also help you by deferring your first payment till after the holidays.'' Costs range from $600 to $8,000. ``I call that seduction. That's not the way medicine should be practiced,'' Noone says of ads that promise facelifts for a small monthly payment. People need to know what's available, says Caleel, who practices in Chicago and is a professor of surgery at the Chicago College of Osteopathic Medicine. ``If a child is born with protruberant ears, having those ears repositioned can be very beneficial. They can be a type of stigma in our society,'' he said. ``It's very rewarding to see a woman in her 50s get her first short haircut,'' because she finally had surgery to correct large ears she'd been ashamed of.

DOC.HEAD: World's First Heart-Liver Transplant Patient Has Stormy Year
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, saved by the world's first heart-liver transplant on Valentine's Day 1984, has her own remedy for dealing with the exasperating health problems that seem to multiply with every passing year. She reads. ``That always helps me put my worries and frustrations away,'' said the 12-year-old mystery buff. ``I know my liver problem is never going away and I know my heart problem is never going to go away. So I don't worry about it too much.'' She also writes. ``I feel better when I write my thoughts down.'' In many ways, Stormie is much like any other adolescent girl, said her mother, Lois Purcell, 33. ``We're into boys and a different kind of music than mom listens to, makeup, the whole nine yards. ``If somebody says, `Hey, we're having a slumber party,' I let her go. She goes skating. Now she wants to go to the mall and get her ears pierced.'' More than any other year since her historic operation, though, the past one has been tough for one of transplantation's most celebrated patients. Stormie was doing ``super good'' and leading a fairly normal life in White Settlement, Texas, until October 1988, when she was re-admitted to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh for possible organ rejection, Mrs. Purcell said. She improved the next month after surgeons removed a bile duct obstruction. She was back again in January 1989 because of elevated enzyme levels that interfered with her anti-rejection medication, cyclosporine. She started losing liver function in November and returned again. Dr. Thomas E. Starzl replaced her cyclosporine with an experimental Japanese drug, FK-506, believed to be 50 to 100 times more powerful with fewer side effects. She takes a pill every day, and will for the rest of her life. The setback prompted Mrs. Purcell to remove the sixth-grader from school this year and rehire her home tutor. Stormie returned to Children's Hospital on Jan. 6 with more liver problems. Tests showed no evidence of organ rejection, but rather a non-infectious form of hepatitis. She was discharged six days later and sent home to recuperate. Airlines generally pick up the travel expenses; insurance covers most of the medical costs. Now her doctors in Texas want to draw blood once instead of twice a week because her veins are collapsing from so many tests, but they can't because of her rising enzyme levels. ``It's to the point where it's getting kind of frustrating. We don't really know what's going on,'' said Mrs. Purcell. ``If I remember, they told me after the first five years you're over the hump. They didn't tell me it went downhill.'' Stormie is just as bewildered as her mother. ``She's to the point where it's really bothering her,'' Mrs. Purcell said. ``If her liver is in rejection one more time, she's going to tell Dr. Starzl she wants a new liver. That's getting pretty desperate when you don't want to try the new medication. It's something I never thought I'd hear her say.'' Starzl doesn't intend to give Stormie another liver. And her heart won't need to be replaced even if her liver does. ``Her heart is doing perfectly in all this,'' he said. ``The liver is doing quite well. We think we'll keep that liver for the foreseeable future.'' Stormie suffered from a rare congenital disease that increased the cholesterol in her blood to nearly 10 times normal; the imbalance was caused by a faulty liver. She had two heart attacks, two triple coronary bypasses and a heart-valve replacement before Starzl decided in January 1984 to replace her heart and liver. On Feb. 14, 1984, during 16 hours of surgery, Stormie received the heart and liver of a 4-year-old New York girl killed in a car accident. She was discharged as an outpatient that March and sent home in May. Encouraged by her progress, surgeons did two more heart-liver transplants during the next year in Pittsburgh, the world's leading transplant center, but both patients died within a few days of surgery. Those were the sole attempts in America at replacing heart and liver in a simultaneous operation until Dec. 3, when Pittsburgh surgeons did the world's first heart-liver-kidney transplant. Cindy Martin, 26, of Archbald, Pa., was still in intensive care at Presbyterian-University Hospital in mid-February. She was receiving FK-506 and had experienced no organ rejection. Starzl, who heads transplantation at the University of Pittsburgh-affiliated hospitals, remains confident and willing to attempt more combination transplants, especially with the availability of FK-506. No matter what happens, Mrs. Purcell has no regrets about having subjected Stormie to the experimental surgery. She, like her daughter, is chronicling Stormie's story with hopes of having it published as a book. ``I'm definitely glad we went through it. If it came to it ... I could do it again because I'm a selfish person. I want her with me.''

DOC.HEAD: Captive Breeding Seen as Key to Panther's Survival
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ten Florida panthers are about to be chosen for a new life that may have extraordinary consequences for the survival of the species. A captive breeding program has been approved by federal and state officials to boost the declining population from an estimated 30 to 50 in the wild. ``There are certain purists that say, `Let them die a natural death out in the wild,' '' said John Christian of the Fish and Wildlife Service. ``We need to consider their views, but on the other hand we are charged with preventing the extinction of the species and moving toward its recovery.'' Wildlife managers say the panther is in nowhere near the danger of the California condor or the black-footed ferret when their entire populations were rounded up for breeding, but Dennis Jordan, the Fish and Wildlife Service's panther coordinator, said, ``It's no question the population is stressed. ``When you get down to a total population numbering 30 to 50 animals, you get into a situation of facing the brink of extinction. We consider we have one viable sustaining population now in South Florida and none anywhere else.'' The nocturnal cougar subspecies, growing to 60 to 130 pounds, is smaller and darker than most cougars and has a distinctive tail crook and a cowlick in the middle of its back. It's a solitary hunter favoring deer and small game and needs lots of room _ at least 40 square miles for a female and more than 200 square miles for each male, with little overlap. The panther once ranged from Louisiana to South Carolina, but hunting and development have pushed it into the Everglades and undeveloped South Florida interior. Without intervention, experts say it will vanish within 40 years. The goal of the program is 500 breeding adults in captivity and three wild colonies in 20 years using high-tech influences, such as radio-telemetry collars and possibly even in vitro fertilization and embryo implants. With captive breeding, four founders _ adults at the top of distinct family trees _ and six kittens chosen for their bloodlines will be captured and sent to Miami's MetroZoo, the private White Oak Plantation, Tampa's Lowrey Park Zoo or the Jacksonville zoo in March or April. Big cats in captivity tend to be prolific breeders, but researchers have no solid experience with panthers. Panthers will be captured for six years. Descendants of the first batch captured could be freed to the wild in three to seven years through a ``halfway house'' that would teach them to hunt again. A team of state wildlife workers already checks about 15 cats equipped with radio collars each year. Once the cats are chosen, they will be chased up a tree and tranquilized. The sedated cat will then be roped and lowered to the ground, cushioned against injury by an air bag. During medical exams, the cats will be kept under a tent to protect them from the sun. The breeding cats then will be taken to a central station for evaluation and eventually to their new zoo homes. ``Everybody has philosophical views about these kinds of things. I'm sure everyone would like to see the cat do well in the wild,'' said Larry Thompson, Southeast regional vice president of the National Audubon Society. ``But short of that, what we're going to have to do is bring some of the cats in and carry through with this phase of planning.'' Captive breeding is only one step in a wide-ranging program to revitalize the panther population. A National Cancer Institute researcher is doing genetic kinship studies; the National Zoo is experimenting with in vitro fertilization in domestic cats; state guidelines for oil and gas development and hunting regulations have been modified to protect the panther; culverts have been built under Interstate 75 to keep the cats off the road across the Everglades; and intense monitoring of the wild population will continue. ``The uniqueness of this plan for panthers is we still have this wild population,'' said Tom Logan, the state wildlife research program coordinator. ``This is not a situation where we have to do it or we're going to lose them in the next year or two, in other words a last-step effort. ``We're a step ahead of the game.''

DOC.HEAD: Obstacles to Guinea Worm Eradication Money, Politics
DOC.TEXT: The barriers to eliminating guinea worm disease _ a disabling infection that strikes 10 million people a year, mostly in Africa _ are political and financial, not technical, U.S. health officials say. In addition, there's a failure to ``recognize the opportunity'' that exists to get rid of the disease, the Centers for Disease Control says. Guinea worm disease, dracunculiasis, occurs in 16 African countries, India and Pakistan and is transmitted through drinking water contaminated with larvae of the guinea worm. Nigeria alone reported more than 650,000 cases in 1988, the last year for which statistics are available. When ingested, larvae can mature in the stomach or intestinal tract, becoming worms up to 47 inches long. After incubation of about a year, they emerge through the skin, usually in the legs. The result is intense pain and incapacitattion for up to three months. Although recovery is usually complete, some patients can be left permanently disabled if joints are affected by the worm or associated infections. The disease can be prevented by filtering, boiling or chemically treating water. The major thrust of eradication is to teach people how to treat their water, not trying to overhaul the Third World's sanitation systems overnight, said Dr. Robert Kaiser, head of the CDC Division of Parasitic Diseases. ``The approach in the long term is providing safe and adequate supplies to everyone _ but this is a costly, long-term kind of goal,'' he said. ``There are more immediate and easier approaches to the problem that are less costly.''
DOC.HEAD: AIDS Risk Found Even in Clean-Looking Needles Shared By Drug Abusers
DOC.TEXT: Evidence of AIDS contamination appears even in clean-looking needles collected from ``shooting galleries,'' researchers report. Shooting galleries are places where addicts rent syringes and needles and inject drugs. People who use them risk AIDS virus infection from sharing contaminated needles. Antibody to the AIDS virus appeared in 15 of 148 needle-syringe combinations, or ``works,'' collected from three of the largest and most frequented galleries in South Florida, researchers reported in the February issue of the American Journal of Public Health. The antibody, a protein found in blood of people exposed to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome virus, showed up in 20 percent of ``works'' that contained visible amounts of blood. It also appeared in 5 percent of those without visible blood. The researchers were from the University of Miami School of Medicine, the University of Delaware, Andrews University in Barrien, Mich., and Florida International University.

DOC.HEAD: Salt Is a Tough Habit to Kick
DOC.TEXT: Most people are not born with a taste for salt, but by adulthood, it's hard to imagine eating without it. It tastes good, and it makes food taste better by enhancing other flavors. It also is hard to avoid since half the salt many people eat is hidden in processed foods. If you have already been diagnosed as having high blood pressure, you probably have been told to watch your salt intake. Not everyone is affected by salt, and even eliminating it won't eliminate the threat of high blood pressure. But it can't hurt to back off a little from the salt shaker. Table salt is 40 percent sodium and 60 percent chloride. The National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences suggests that a daily intake of one to three grams of sodium is a ``safe and adequate'' range for adults. That's one to 1{ teaspoons of salt. The average daily consumption now is estimated at four to six grams. It is difficult to eat a diet resulting in a sodium deficiency. Most people can function normally and indefinitely with less than two grams, the American Heart Association says. Just four ounces of corn chips and a large sour pickle would fill the bill. Sodium is needed to attract water into the blood vessels and it helps maintain normal blood volume and pressure. We get most of our sodium from sodium chloride, or table salt, with some from souces such as monosodium glutamate, MSG, and sodium bicarbonate. Water and some foods also naturally contain small amounts of sodium. It's easiest to reduce salt intake gradually, and many people find that once they grow accustomed to less salt, their taste for it diminishes. Some steps are fairly easy: Make the food taste good, so you don't feel the urge to add salt. Always taste food before adding salt. A dash of vinegar sometimes can make up for salt in soups or main dishes. Try lemon juice instead of salt in water for cooking pasta. Be aggressive with herbs and spices. Leave the salt out when making hot cereal. Use unsalted butter or margarine. Make stock without salt, and even if you add some when making soup, it's controlled. Read labels at the supermarket. Consumers will find sodium, used as a preservative as well as for flavor, in canned soups and vegetables, processed meats and cheeses, frozen and canned main dishes, many condiments and other foods. An item labeled as ``no salt added'' is not necessarily salt-free. _ ``Sodium-free'' means an item has less than 5 mg of sodium per serving. ``Very low sodium'' means less than 35 mg. _ ``Low sodium'' means 140 mg sodium or less per serving. _ ``Reduced sodium'' means the usual sodium level has been reduced by 75 percent through processing.

This herb mixture can be used in place of salt. Herb Seasoning, American Heart Association Low-Fat, Low-Cholesterol Cookbook, Scott Grundy, editor, published by Times Books, a division of Random House Inc. { teaspoon cayenne pepper 1 tablespoon garlic powder 1 teaspoon dried basil 1 teaspoon dried marjoram 1 teaspoon dried thyme 1 teaspoon dried parsely 1 teaspoon dried savory 1 teaspoon mace 1 teaspoon onion powder 1 teasppon freshly ground black pepper 1 teaspoon powdered sage
Combine all ingredients. Toss gently with a spoon. Store in an airtight container in a cool, dry, dark place for up to six months. Makes about one-third cup.

DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union will open talks here next week aiming to remove trade barriers between the two superpowers by next June's scheduled summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, in announcing Wednesday the opening round of negotiations here next Monday, said the administration hopes to complete work on a bilateral trade accord by early May.

The Midwest had the most affordable existing homes as 1989 ended, while the most expensive existing housing was found on both coasts, a real estate trade group reported. Peoria, Ill., had the lowest median price, $47,200, of the 83 metropolitan areas surveyed by the National Association of Realtors, the group said Wednesday. That was $233,700 below the median cost of a home in Honolulu, the most expensive area in the survey.

Negotiations to relieve the crushing debt burden on Third World countries should progress more smoothly now that Mexico and its creditor banks have signed a debt reduction agreement, a senior Bush administration official predicted. ``The strengthened debt strategy is very much alive and well,'' Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford, architect of the administration debt plan, said Wednesday to the House Banking subcommittee on international development.

The insurance industry called for federal help in the wake of last fall's California earthquake, saying it would be unable to bear the costs of a major tremor. ``Insurers cannot finance a catastrophic earthquake,'' Franklin W. Nutter, chairman of an insurance industry coalition on quake dangers, told a House Banking subcommittee on insurance on Wednesaday.

Companies that provide telephone operator services for travelers were warned they may face stiff government regulation because of widespread complaints they are picking the pockets of unwary callers. Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., said Wednesday the Federal Communications Commission, which last year issued rules to govern alternative operator services companies, is receiving 150 complaints a month from angry callers who feel they're being overcharged or not being allowed to use the long-distance carrier of their choice. The operator companies contract with hotels, hospitals, airports and other public institutions to handle ``dial O'' calls on long-distance lines leased from a major carrier. The operator companies pay a commission to the premises owner.

Actor Lloyd Bridges settled a lawsuit alleging he misrepresented investment products in television ads, ending a case his lawyers contend will have a chilling effect on the use of celebrity spokespeople. Although no trial ever was held, a judge's ruling on a pre-trial motion and a similar ruling by a judge in a related case indicated celebrities could be held liable for misrepresentations when endorsing a product or service. The Bridges settlement Wednesday concluded a lawsuit that also pitted actor George Hamilton and a Detroit advertising agency against investors allegedly bilked by two Michigan-based mortgage companies, A.J. Obie & Associates and its parent, Diamond Mortgage Inc.

Analysts generally welcomed a report on the imminent departure of Jean-Louis Gassee, Apple Computer Inc.'s flamboyant new-product developer, who was touted as the visionary for the personal computer maker. Gassee once was considered a possible successor to John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer. The reports Wednesday of his resignation comes during a tumultuous reorganization of the company, which has suffered declining sales for a year.

Major airlines had their worst on-time performance in a year and a record number of mishandled baggage problems but complaints declined to their lowest level in 12 months, the government reported. On-time performance for December dipped to 70.2 percent from the 78 percent reported in November, the report said Wednesday. The worst previous showing was in January 1988 when 69.2 percent of flights were reported on time.

G. Heileman Brewing Co. announced it plans to sell two smaller breweries in Minnesota and Michigan as part of its long-range plan to concentrate on its major brands. Heileman President Murray Cutbush said Wednesday the Jacob Schmidt brewery in St. Paul, Minn., and another brewery in Frankenmuth, Mich., have been put up for sale and the company will seek deals that will package certain brands along with the facilities.

The stock market surged Wednesday after recovering from an early slump prompted by concerns about the Treasury's refunding auction. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 33.78 points to 2,640.09. Bond prices rose as the second leg of the government's quarterly refunding auction went well. The dollar closed higher against major currencies in domestic trading. Soybean futures prices rose moderately; most grain futures also advanced; gold futures retreated; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: The Go Very Fast and Cost a Lot; But Why?
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Aeromotive in lead is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Vector Aeromotive Corp. is trying to define a new segment of the American automobile market. The company's chief says they include Ferraris, Lamborhinis and his very own Vector W-2. ``Performance collectables'' is what Gerald A. Weigert, president and chief executive officer of Wilmington, Calif.-based Vector, calls these hyper-powered cars. They're not for everybody. Indeed, some people wonder why anyone would buy them. ``These are California types who want to have something nobody else has,'' said auto analyst Kathleen Heaney of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York City. ``I don't place much stock in these people who buy it just to have it,'' she said. But people do buy them, and they pay handsomely for the privilege. Makers of the cars are proud of their products. Folks who go to the Chicago Auto Show, which opens Saturday, will have a chance to take a look at the $250,000 Vector W-2 and the Lamborghini Diablo, which will go for a little less when it's available in the spring. Put those two cars on the starting line along with a Ferrari Testarossa, each poised to roar off to 60 mph within 5 seconds, and they'd make the stuff car buffs dream about. These are not cars for pre-school shuttles or a swing by the market for a gallon of milk. Hence the collectable angle, says Weigert. ``This automobile is not a consumer product,'' he said. ``It is an experts product.'' The specifications on the Vector, Testarossa and Diablo can awe some auto enthusiasts, although they may be mind-numbing for average drivers: _ Zero to 60 mph in less than 5 seconds means that from a standing start, the cars can be breaking the law on most U.S. highways in less time than it takes most phones to ring three times. _ A 600-horsepower rating, as in Vector's case, is about 50 percent more than in the biggest semi-trailer tractor Ford Motor Co. sells. Those are the kinds of facts that draw buyers, ready to put down tens of thousands of dollars, rarely with financing help from the dealer, for a car that can reach its potential only on tracks in the United States or the autobahns of West Germany. Greg Berner is general manager of Lake Forest Sports Cars Ltd. in suburban Chicago and sells Ferrari, Aston Martin, Maserati and Saab cars. ``We have guys who truly understand the cars, who want them for what they do,'' he said. Those kinds of buyers make up most of his customers. ``Then there are the guys who stand at a cocktail paty and say, `Yeah, I've got a Ferarri.''' Manufacturers and sellers of exotic cars have been increasingly conscious about the potential for disaster when someone gets behind the wheel of one of their cars. Porsche, the West German automaker, offers a driving school to buyers, and Berner runs a twice-a-year driving clinic at Black Hawk Farms north of Rockford, Ill., near the Wisconsin border. For about $100 each, owners of exotic cars gather to learn about high-speed driving in the morning and, in the afternoon, tool around a two-mile, seven-turn course at speeds that would test a state trooper's radar gun. ``Every once in a while, someone tries to slip a Porsche in,'' Berner said. ``We frown on that. We don't deal in Porsches.''

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys: Bridges Case Could Chill Use of Celebrity Spokespeople
DOC.TEXT: As scuba diver Mike Nelson on television's ``Sea Hunt,'' actor Lloyd Bridges wore a wet suit to ward off the ocean's chill. More than 25 years later, Bridges' role in an investment-fraud lawsuit is bringing predictions of a chill in the use of celebrity endorsements. The actor's lawyers on Wednesday announced the settlement of a case in which, although he denied any liability, Bridges was cast as potentially liable for claims against an investment company that he represented in television commercials. No trial was held, but a judge's ruling on a pre-trial motion and a similar ruling by a judge in a related case indicated celebrities could be held liable for misrepresentations when endorsing a product or service. ``The fact that a celebrity is merely reading a script may no longer be an excuse,'' said Dan Formeller, one of the lawyers who represented Bridges. Another Bridges attorney, Jacqueline Criswell, said the willingness of the courts to hold celebrities and ad agencies liable in such cases ``will have a chilling effect.'' ``In the end, the risk associated with celebrity endorsements may not be justified by the rewards,'' she said. But at least one advertising expert predicted that holding celebrities accountable for the integrity of products they endorse could encourage companies to use more celebrity spokespeople because consumers will be more likely to trust them. ``Too many viewers today don't believe celebrities because they think that if you pay a guy a million dollars he'll say anything,'' said Al Ries, chairman of the marketing consulting firm Trout & Ries in Greenwich, Conn. ``This is making the game honest,'' Ries said. The Bridges settlement concluded a lawsuit that also pitted actor George Hamilton and a Detroit advertising agency against investors allegedly bilked by two Michigan-based mortgage companies, A.J. Obie & Associates and its parent, Diamond Mortgage Inc. Bridges was a television spokesman for Obie, and Hamilton represented Diamond in television ads in the early 1980s. Both companies declared bankruptcy in 1986 and two of their executives were sentenced to prison in 1988 in Michigan after pleading either guilty or no contest to fraud charges. Terms of Wednesday's settlement with 11 investors were not disclosed. The investors lost hundreds of thousands of dollars and will be getting a portion of their money back, said lawyer Stephanie Canwit, whose firm represented the plaintiffs in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here. Bridges' lawyers said the actor was not available for comment. Bridges denied any liability, as did Hamilton and Yaffe & Co., the advertising firm that created the ads, in previous settlements. But during the 3{-year course of the case, Judge Robert Ginsburg denied the defendants' motion for dismissal, indicating in his ruling that celebrities could be held liable for misrepresentations when pitching a product or service. The judge said celebrity endorsers must take reasonable steps to ascertain that their statements in an advertisement are true. Ginsburg based his decision on an August 1987 ruling by U.S. District Court Judge Milton Shadur of Chicago, who rendered a similar opinion in a related case against the same defendants _ which also was settled before trial. Stephanie Canwit, a lawyer for the investors, called the lawsuit ``a groundbreaking case'' that established new law in the area of fair advertising. ``It's the principle of advertising substantiation,'' she said. ``You have to look before you leap.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Holder Committees Chosen for Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied retailing chains hope to find out this week whether they can draw on $700 million in bank loans after a federal bankruptcy judge refused to delay hearings on the financing. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said he'd consider a proposal today for Federated to borrow $400 million, and tomorrow for Allied to borrow $300 million to keep their stores operating while the companies reorganize under the court's protection. Some creditors had petitioned for a delay, saying they hadn't had time to prepare. But Aug declined, saying a delay could force Federated and Allied to miss bank-imposed deadlines of next Wednesday to cement the financing. Also Wednesday, U.S. Trustee Conrad Morgenstern announced the composition of committees that will represent all bondhonders in bankruptcy court proceedings. He said he was swamped by bondholders who wanted to be on the committees. ``There has been such unusual and enormous interest in this case,'' Morgenstern said. ``We were still receiving statements of willingness to serve on the bond holders committee this morning.'' The Federated Department Stores Inc. bondholders committee consists of Michael C. Johnson of First Boston Corp., J.T. Atkins of Painewebber Funding Inc., Keenan L. Wolens of Columbia Savings & Loan, Leonard F. Cutugno of Capital Life Insurance Co., and Neil Cohen of Dillon, Read Interfunding Inc. William E. Schumacker of the Fifth Third Bank will be an ex officio member. The Allied Stores Corp. bondholders committee is composed of Talton R. Embry of Magten Asset Management Corp., Nelson R. Jantzen of Equitable Capital Management Co., Robert Cox of Fidelity Investments, Lawrence Guske of PS Group Inc., and Phillip Siegel of Presidential Life Insurance Co. Gerard F. Ganey of U.S. Trust Co. will be an ex officio member. In its Chapter 11 filings Jan. 15, Federated and Allied listed more than 50,000 creditors. ``We have attempted to appoint a diverse cross-section,'' Morgenstern said. ``Each committee represents a special constituency.'' Morgenstern said William E. Beebe of Crystal Brands Inc. had been chosen by the Allied unsecured creditors committee as its chairman. Additions to that committee include Peter Griesback of Farberware Inc. and W. Cornish of Cosmair Inc. P. Scott Oberdorf of the CIT Group has been chosen by the Federated unsecured creditors committee as its chairman, Morgenstern said. Additional members include Gerald Bright of the Masco Group and Sharon Bryan of Reebok International Ltd. Barbara J. Hillmans, representing the United Food and Commercial Workers and several other unions, will be an ex officio member. Federated and Allied are divisions of Federated Stores Inc., the U.S. retail subsidary of the Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Their Chapter 11 filings listing debts of $7.5 billion were the largest U.S. retailing bankruptcy protection filings in history. Federated and Allied's nine store groups operate 260 stores under the names Abraham and Straus and Bloomindale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati, Rich's of Atlanta, The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa, and Stern's of Paramus, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Owners Eye Oakland, Saying Hockey Team Can't Make a Buck in Minnesota
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Carrolyn in 17th graf is CQ
DOC.TEXT: In hockey-crazed Minnesota, where television rights to the state high school tournament cost $1.5 million, making money with a professional team would seem as easy as shooting into an empty net. But after wading in red ink for nine of the past 12 seasons, Minnesota North Stars owners Gordon and George Gund are ready to move the National Hockey League club _ to California. ``It's hard to figure,'' said John Bartz, associate director of the Minnesota State High School League, which oversees competition among 143 varsity hockey teams. ``I think Minnesota has been regarded as one of the premier hockey states and not to have a professional hockey team would be a real disaster.'' But it may be close to being reality. The Gunds say they have a tentative agreement to move to Oakland and also have been invited to move rent-free to a $100 million arena being built in San Jose for the 1992-93 season. The Gunds say a move is imminent unless the public commission that controls the Met Center, the team's home since joining the NHL in 1967, spends $15 million to add skyboxes and other revenue-generating facilities. In addition, the Gunds are demanding better corporate support _ to the tune of an additional 6,000 season tickets. ``I think it's closer to a move than not moving,'' North Stars coach Pierre Page said Wednesday. ``There's no smoke in the air. It's not a threat.'' Bill Lester, executive director of the Metropolitan Sports Facilities Commission, said his staff is exploring options to keep the North Stars. But he has called the Gunds' Feb. 21 deadline ``unrealistic'' and has said the commission has no more than $1 million to spend on the Met Center. Gordon Gund says the issue is simple: The North Stars need better facilities at the 23-year-old arena in suburban Bloomington and a larger season-ticket base to compete against the red-hot Minnesota Timberwolves of the National Basketball Association. The Timberwolves have only 10 wins in their maiden season, but they lead the NBA with an average attendance of 24,600 and have 14,800 season-ticket holders. The North Stars, in contrast, sold just 3,800 season passes and are drawing an average of only 11,000 people a game, more than 3,500 under the NHL average. ``A lot of the corporate community has turned its attention to supporting an NBA team, and in the process they weren't paying as much attention to us,'' Gund said. More irksome to Gund is the commission's penchant for spending money on the downtown Metrodome, where the baseball Twins, football Vikings, the Timberwolves and University of Minnesota football teams play. Among other items, the commission has earmarked $6 million to expand press facilities at the dome for the 1992 Super Bowl and NCAA basketball Final Four. ``The commission hasn't put a dime into Met Center,'' Gund said. ``We've spent $20 million and we're through putting money into it.'' The commission hasn't invested much in the Met Center because it gets little in return, says Carrolyn Anderson, a commission member. Besides paying less than $170,000 a year in rent, the North Stars control all revenue from parking, concessions and special events. ``I don't think the sorts of improvements they are talking about are going to make or break the hockey team,'' Anderson said. ``The overall trend indicates that if you have a fairly good hockey team you're going to have good attendance.'' That's been a problem for the North Stars, who made it to the Stanley Cup finals in 1981 and haven't been close since. After a hot start this season, they're 24-29-3 and fighting to hold onto a playoff berth. They've failed to make the playoffs in two of their last three seasons and posted losing records in four of the past five. Attendance has fallen in all but two of the past 10 seasons, leaving the North Stars in poor position in the Twin Cities market, a seven-county area of about 1.8 million people that has four major pro sports franchises. ``This certainly raises a big issue in everybody's mind,'' said Larry Wipf, an economist at Minneapolis-based Norwest Bank. ``Just how many discretionary dollars are out there?'' ``That's a big question and we need to know the answer right away,'' Gund said. ``It would be very hard for us to leave, but the Oakland area is hungry for professional hockey and it's a much bigger market,'' with about 5 million people. A move to Oakland would complete a circle for the Gunds and the North Stars. The Gunds were minority owners of the Oakland-based California Seals in the early '70s. The Seals, who lost millions in nine seasons in Oakland, moved to Cleveland in 1976 _ with the Gunds bailing out owner Mel Swig a year later. The Gunds wound up with a controlling interest in the North Stars when the two teams were merged in 1978.
