DOC.HEAD: Money Laundering Called $300 Billion Annual Business
DOC.TEXT: Laundering money from cocaine sales and a host of other criminal activities represents a $300 billion worldwide business each year but could prove the drug trade's key area of vulnerability, a Senate report said today. ``Because money laundering is principally accomplished through the use of legitimate financial institutions, money laundering is the potential Achilles heel of the illegal drug business,'' said the report from two Senate panels. The report released by Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., was based on testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations and Banking Committees last fall. It attributed to Assistant Treasury Secretary Salvatore Martoche the estimate that worldwide drug revenues total $300 billion annually, including $110 billion generated in the United States. It said laundering all of this cash presents tough problems for criminals. For example, $100 billion in $20 bills, a denomination often used in drug transactions, would weigh 26 million pounds, the report said. ``A money laundering operation in New York shut down earlier this year required a tractor-trailer to haul away $19 million in small bills,'' it said. It said the 1970 Bank Secrecy Act is working as a deterrent to money laundering through American financial institutions. The measure requires the institutions to report cash deposits of $10,000 or more. The report said, however, that drug traffickers ``continue to use foreign banks and foreign branches of U.S. banks to launder U.S. drug profits.'' It said Switzerland, Canada, the Bahamas, Luxembourg, Panama and Hong Kong are among the main countries where money is laundered. It also said criminals are pushing to develop money laundering centers in a number of tiny countries, ranging from Andorra to Vanuatu. The report said illicit funds are sometimes accepted in large cash deposits by corrupt bank employees. It said funds sometimes are laundered through seemingly legitimate businesses that appear to generate substantial amounts of cash. And often they are transferred to foreign banks that are not overly curious about the source, it said. After the money has gone through one or more ``wash cycles,'' it can be transferred into a legitimate American business, the report said. The report said part of the scandals that have shaken the savings and loan industry in the United States involved thefts by organized crime organizations. ``Significant funds generated from S&L theft have been laundered beyond U.S. borders through offshore bank secrecy havens,'' the report declared. ``These funds now represent an enormous endowment devoted to the support of organized crime.'' It said the success of efforts to stem money laundering through American banks has turned launderers toward unregulated financial institutions, such as money transmitters, check-cashing stores and currency exchanges. The report said the government currently has no policy on control of international electronic transfers of U.S. funds. ``As a consequence, money launderers retain a choice of methods to conceal their laundered funds through international wire transfers, including informal channels involving fax machines, telex, personal computer networks and ordinary telephone instructions which do not leave the paper trail which would allow investigators to follow the flow of funds,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Legislation Tightens Credit for Builders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A well-intended change aimed at curbing reckless and dishonest savings and loans is also choking off credit to some builders, industry representatives complain. S&L bailout legislation enacted in August sharply reduced the limit on how much an institution can lend to one borrower, from 100 percent of net worth to 15 percent. The provision took effect immediately with no transition period. ``The availability of thrift funds for housing has been abruptly curtailed,'' Martin Perlman, president of the National Association of Home Builders, said Wednesday. ``Many builders in the final stages of preparation for a project have been left without funds to start while others have been left in limbo about whether an existing loan will be renewed,'' he told the House Banking oversight subcommittee. He said 31 percent of the builders surveyed at the groups' annual convention in Atlanta last month reported receiving notice that their S&L was cutting back on future loans. Banks cope with the limit by selling off pieces of large loans to other banks, but S&Ls are inexperienced at the technique and developers say they are being turned down for loans at S&Ls that for years have been reliables sources of funds. Members of the panel and officials from banking agencies and the Department of Housing and Urban Development offered sympathy, but little prospect for relief. ``We are seeing healthy home builders around the country being turned away by healthy savings associations. ... We in Congress created a Catch-22 situation that threatens the survival of solvent thrifts and of thriving home builders,'' said Rep. Carroll Hubbard, D-Ky., chairman of the subcommittee. Hubbard said analysts indicate 500,000 units of new housing could go unbuilt over the next five years. He said in some cases builders will get the loans, but at a higher interest rate, a cost that will be passed on to consumers. However, the chairmen of both the Senate Banking Committee and the House Banking Committee have said they oppose overhauling the S&L bill this year. And Hubbard said, ``I am not proposing to amend'' the S&L law. Housing and Urban Development Under Secretary Alfred A. Dellibovi said his department has been trying to ease the strain on builders by having secondary mortgage market agencies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, buy development and construction loans from S&Ls. But, he said, any relief will be limited and he urged S&Ls to develop networks of other institutions to participate in big loans. Officials of both the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates S&Ls, and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates nationally-chartered banks, said the law leaves them with no discretion to delay the effective date of the new standard.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Working on Spring Trade Pact With Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The administration hopes to complete by early May a U.S.-Soviet trade pact that Presidents Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev can sign at their scheduled summit meeting a month later. The first round of talks on what would be the first attempt for an economic accord with the Soviets since the early 1970s will open here Monday, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said. ``Through these negotiations we hope to encourage economic reform within the Soviet Union as it moves toward a more market-driven economy,'' Mrs. Hills told the Senate Finance Committee Wednesday. The panel's chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, warned Mrs. Hills any accord reached with the Soviets could run into trouble on Capitol Hill if lawmakers aren't consulted along the way. Bentsen expressed anger he was not advised beforehand by administration officials that Bush would promise Gorbachev a new round of trade talks at their Malta summit meeting in December. President Nixon signed a trade agreement with the Soviets in 1972 but it was never ratified by the Senate. ``If the Nixon administration had consulted with Congress ..., I don't think the Bush administration would have the kind of limitations it has on it now,'' Bentsen said. ``I'm deeply concerned that we don't see a repetition of that.'' The talks follow mutual pledges by Bush and Gorbachev to accelerate a normalization of U.S.-Soviet trade and economic relations in response to the wave of democratic reforms sweeping the Soviet Bloc. As part of the accord, which has to be approved by Congress, the United States would waive the 1974 Jackson-Vanik provisions that now require the Soviets to pay several times the normal tariffs charged most other countries on their exports to U.S. markets. ``A successful agreement will also create opportunities for U.S. businesses to expand trade and commercial activity with the Soviet Union,'' Mrs. Hills said. The U.S. negotiating team will be led by deputy U.S. Trade Representative Julies Katz. The head of the Soviet team is Yuriy Chumakov, deputy minister of foreign economic relations. Administration officials envision the accord removing a $300 million ceiling on loans and loan guarantees from the U.S. Export-Import Bank to finance Soviet purchases of American exports. Other expected provisions include relaxing restrictions on high-tech exports and reversing U.S. opposition to loans and loan guarantees from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. In addition, U.S. capital investments in the Soviet Union could become eligible for the first time for insurance protection from the Overseas Private Investment Corp. Similar OPIC restrictions on Hungary and Poland were lifted as part of an aid bill last fall. Mrs. Hills said the administration will ``seek protections for U.S. businesses'' in the accord, including safeguards from import surges, protection of intellectual property rights such as patents and copyrights and greater freedom to do business in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies in European trading today. Gold was lower. In Tokyo, the dollar opened and closed at 145.50 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's 145.10-yen finish. Later in London, the dollar retreated to 145.25 yen. Much of today's activity in Tokyo involved sales of the mark for profit-taking after the West German currency's overnight surge on overseas markets, and sales of other European currencies for yen, said a trader with Mitsui Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. The mark, rather than the dollar, has been the focus of recent trading because reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are expected to benefit the West German economy, traders said. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6665 West German marks, up from 1.6545; 1.4885 Swiss francs, up from 1.4805; 5.6690 French francs, up from 5.6335; 1.8775 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8650; 1,241.00 Italian lire, up from 1,234.00; and 1.1990 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1932. The British pound traded at $1.6880, compared with $1.6995 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $418.50 per troy ounce at mid-morning today, compared to Wednesday's late price of $423 per ounce. In Zurich, the bid price was $418.20, down from $422.25 bid late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped the equivalent of $1.29 an ounce today, to close at $416.46. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.35 a troy ounce, compared to Wednesday's $5.38 per ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up, Dollar Also Gains
DOC.TEXT: Buying by foreign securities firms boosted the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index today, while the dollar gained against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average climbed 214.37 points, or 0.57 percent, closing at 37,516.24. The index, which fell 364.96 points on Wednesday, fell another 120 points this morning before turning upward on foreign firms' purchases of shares linked to the index, said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. Such purchases by Morgan Stanley boosted the index by more than 100 points in the last 20 minutes of afternoon trading, Yano added. But most investors were awaiting developments, including the auction of 30-year U.S. government bonds later today and elections for Japan's lower house of Parliament on Feb. 18, dealers said. The Nikkei closed 1989 with a series of record highs but then lost more than 2,000 points in early January due to plunges in Japanese government bond prices resulting from the yen's weakness. It since has made up about half of the January losses. Today's trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 400 million shares. In currency dealings, the dollar opened and closed at 145.50 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's 145.10-yen finish. In between, it stayed in a narrow range of 145.40 yen to 145.62 yen. Much of today's activity involved sales of the mark for profit-taking after the West German currency's overnight surge on overseas markets, and sales of other European currencies for yen, said a trader with Mitsui Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. The mark, rather than the dollar, has been the focus of recent trading because reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are expected to benefit the West German economy, traders said. The mark had climbed as investors grew confident in the outcome of the three-day Soviet Communist Party Central Committee meeting that started Monday. On Wednesday, Communist Party leaders accepted a proposal by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to give up the the party's monopoly on power. Some $5.54 billion changed hands in spot trading.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Coin Counterfeit Probe Extending to Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs with police statement, editing changes; picks up 12th graf, Still the ...
DOC.TEXT: Police officials said today they plan to send investigators to Europe next week to try to trace the source of bogus Japanese gold coins with a face value of $71 million, Japan's biggest counterfeiting case ever. A police spokesman, however, declined to reveak the investigators' destination. Japan's Kyodo News Service said the investigators would go to Switzerland, from which Japanese coin dealers had imported 103,000 gold coins, all believed to be fakes, since March 1988. The counterfeit coins were first discovered late last month when a company tried to deposit a batch with a bank, police said. More fake coins have been found since then, including a cache found in the vault of the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, The New York Times reported today. The counterfeits are of a 100,000-yen, or $687, coin issued by Japan in 1986 and 1987 to commemorate the 60th year of Emperor Hirohito's reign. Hirohito died in January 1989. The fake coins, like the real commemorative ones, are made of gold. But because the commemorative issue sells for almost 2{ times the value of the gold content in the coins, counterfeiting could prove lucrative. ``The huge number of the commemorative coins issued is another factor,'' said Koichiro Ishihara, managing director of the monthly Coin Magazine, published in Tokyo. ``It would make a challenging job for the authorities to find the fakes among millions of coins in circulation.'' The Bank of Japan issued 10 million of the commemorative coins in 1986 and an additional 1 million coins the following year. A Bank of Japan official said the fakes, like the genuine coins, each contain 20 grams, or two-thirds of an ounce, of pure gold worth about 40,000 yen, or $278, based on open market prices for gold. Gold closed at $418.10 an ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange Wednesday. Still, the price of the commemorative coins remains set at 100,000 yen. The first counterfeits were found on Jan. 29 when Taisei Stamp and Coin Co. of Tokyo presented 1,000 coins for deposit at a branch of Fuji Bank in downtown Tokyo. Taisei executives told police that the company had imported the coins through Paul Davis, 38, a British coin dealder based in London, for 98,000 yen each. Police investigators then found that RimPac Gold Co. and Daruma International Galleries, both of Tokyo, had imported a total of 102,000 such coins through Davis and another European coin dealer between March 1988 and January this year. ``We suspect all these coins to be bogus,'' the police spokesman said, adding that the authorities have yet to verify that. Police have said some 8,000 of the 103,000 coins were checked last week and all were found to be bogus. The forged coins had slight flaws on both surfaces, visible only by microscope, they said. A Fuji Bank official said last week he felt the fake coins were lighter in color than genuine ones. Otherwise, he said, they looked and weighed the same as real coins. It was not known immediately how many of the imported coins have been sold to private investors in Japan. Davis came to Tokyo last Friday to answer police questions. Police officials said Wednesday Davis maintains that he only acted as a middleman and he still believes the coins are genuine.

DOC.HEAD: City Sues Exxon in Arthur Kill Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: New York City has filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against Exxon Corp. over a 567,000-gallon oil spill from a pipeline into the Arthur Kill waterway, Mayor David Dinkins said. ``The Exxon oil spill is a disaster that could have been prevented, should have never happened and has permanently scarred the environmental landscape,'' Dinkins said Wednesday. The lawsuit filed in state court seeks a $10 million fine, reimbursement to the city for cleanup costs, and full restoration of the kill _ a waterway between Staten Island and New Jersey _ and adjacent wetlands. The lawsuit also alleges fraud on the part of Exxon at least once every three months from Jan. 1, 1984, through the third quarter of last year for submitting reports to the Fire Department that an oil pipeline and leak detection system were working properly, said Corporation Counsel Victor Kovner. ``Exxon has admitted publicly that for approximately the last 12 years, the ... leak detection system has frequently signaled a leak when none existed,'' the lawsuit said. It said Exxon's repeated prior claims that it had been successfully tested suggests that ``Exxon had a policy and practice of disregarding the truth.'' Exxon spokesman Douglas Walt said the company was disappointed because it has been participating with 10 city, state and federal agencies, in negotiations aimed at addressing the concerns outlined in the city's lawsuit. ``We continue to hope that these discussions will result in the development of a mutually agreeable plan that will eliminate the need for the lawsuit and, in no way are we `backing away' from this effort,'' Walt said in a statement. ``We have provided a definitive study plan and have been waiting for a response. '' Dinkins had indicated early last month that he hoped the city would not have to sue Exxon, which he called New York's ``corporate neighbor'' and that the company would commit itself to reimbursing the city for its costs. Kovner said Wednesday that Exxon had assured the state it would pay for costs for which it was liable, but that it did not make a clear commitment to pay for damages to the city. The lawsuit said the spill continues to contaminate the waters of the Arthur Kill, adjacent Kill Van Kull and other streams, creeks and rivers and caused the death of an increasing number of waterfowl.

DOC.HEAD: Delta, Northwest and TWA Complete Merger of Reservations Systems
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines announced the completion of an agreement to form a new company that will operate a global computer reservations system. The three airlines announced plans to establish the system last September. Joe Krovisky, spokesman for the antitrust division of the U.S. Justice Department in Washington, said Wednesday the division notified all parties on Tuesday that it did not intend to challenge the deal. The agreement will merge Delta's DATAS II reservations system with the PARS system jointly owned by TWA and Northwest. Delta also is paying TWA $48 million for a 6 2-3 percent portion of PARS, giving it the largest share of the new company. Delta will own 40 percent of the new company, Northwest will own 33 1-3 percent and TWA will hold the remaining 26 2-3 percent, the companies said in a statement. Krovisky said he did not have information on what distinguished this deal from one last June proposed by American Airlines and Delta to merge their reservation systems. The department said then an American-Delta deal would substantially lessen competition and that the government would sue to block it. The two airlines then dropped the idea. American and Delta claimed at the time they were blindsided by the Justice Department after crafting their deal to meet possible antitrust concerns _ for instance, they had planned to sell up to half the equity in the venture to other carriers. American was said to have 41 percent of the market and $445 million in revenue in 1988 for its SABRE reservations system while Delta had 7 percent and $68 million in revenue for DATAS II, the smallest airline reservation system. A 1986 regulation says airlines must not favor their own flights in computer displays but the department said travel agents tend to sell a disproportionately high number of tickets on the sponsoring airline.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Opens British Financial Planning Service
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. on Thursday launched a British financial planning service called Acuma Ltd., which it hopes will serve as a springboard for similar operations across Europe. Acuma Chief Executive Officer Frank Skillern said the company is planning 50 branches in Britain by 1992, however, it does not yet have a timetable for further expansion in Europe. The company is targeting its planning and investment services to households with an annual income of at least $34,000. Acuma, American Express's first investment services operation outside the United States, is modeled after IDS Financial Services Inc., a U.S.-based sister company.

DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were nearly unchanged in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Volume was light amid a lack of significant supply-and-demand developments. Continued strength in European soybean meal markets _ a factor that contributed to Wednesday's moderate rally _ was having little effect on U.S. soybean futures this morning. Forecasts for precipitation next week in the nation's midsection put some pressure on grain prices, but selling was offset by buying linked to signs of increased foreign demand for U.S. crops. DOC.HEAD: Grand Met Puts Alpo Pet Food Subsidiary on the Block
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, the huge British food and liquor company, said Thursday it plans to sell its Alpo pet foods subsidiary. The company did not disclose a target price. Grand Met Chairman Allen Sheppard said that after a careful review of all its activities, the company decided the Alpo business did not fit into its strategy of becoming an international branded foods, drinks and retailing giant. The British company acquired the Allentown, Pennsylvania-based Alpo through its 1980 takeover of U.S.-based Liggett Group Inc. Grant Met has sold off most of Liggett's diverse interests which included tobacco, soft drink bottling, and fitness equipment. Alpo is the sixth-largest pet food maker in the United States, where its business is principally located, Grand Met said. It had pretax profit of $45 million on sales of $400 million in the year ended Sept. 30. A figure for aftertax profit was not available, said a company spokesman, who was not identified in accordance with British custom.

DOC.HEAD: Happiness: Researcher Says Feeling Good May Make You Sick
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK _ Getting a promotion or finding a sweetheart may make you happy now, but it could make you feel sick later on, a researcher says. The problem may be that good fortune can be stressful for people with low self-esteem, he said. Slug AM-Happiness Disease. New, should stand. About 600 words. By Science Writer Malcolm Ritter.

DOC.HEAD: Colgate-Palmolive Reports Quarterly, Annual Income
DOC.TEXT: Colgate-Palmolive Co. on Thursday reported its fourth-quarter net income fell 50 percent and 1989 earnings slipped 12 percent over the previous year, when the company profited from the sale of its Kendall health care subsidiary. However, without the one-time gain the consumer products giant said its results far surpassed those of 1988. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Colgate-Palmolive netted $62.51 million, or 87 cents a share, on sales of $1.29 billion. That compared with earnings of $126.71 million, or $1.85 a share, and $1.21 billion in sales in the 1988 quarter. Colgate-Palmolive's 1989 net income totaled $280.03 million, or $3.97 a share, down from $317.80 million, or $4.64, in 1988. Sales rose 6 percent to $5.04 billion from $4.73 billion. Last year's results included a $13.5 million gain from the sale of property in New Jersey and England. The 1988 results included a $125 million net gain from the Kendall sale and a $42 million net charge for the renegotiation of a service agreement at its Hill's Pet Products unit. Excluding them, Colgate-Palmolive earned $43.71 million, or 64 cents a share, in the 1988 fourth quarter, and $234.80 million, or $3.43, for all of 1988. In a statement, Chairman Reuben Mark said Colgate-Palmolive ``achieved important successes in 1989.'' ``Profitability increased as we improved manufacturing and increased global marketing effectiveness,'' he said. ``Our strong momentum means Colgate is well positioned for continuing profit growth in 1990.'' Growth was reported throughout the company's global consumer products businesses, with particular strength in domestic and Western Hemisphere units and Hill's Pet Products. Colgate-Palmolive said it introduced 175 new products in various countries. Based in New York, Colgate-Palmolive markets its products under such brand names as Ajax, Fab and Irish Spring, in addition to Colgate and Palmolive.

DOC.HEAD: Toymakers, Still Fearful of Video Curse, Aren't Offering New Ideas
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Baby dolls that dirty their diapers and a 30-something Barbie show toymakers aren't taking many chances this year with costly creations that must compete with video games in a notoriously fickle industry. Analysts and executives say the multibillion dollar business is largely sticking with the tried and true while supplementing lineups with new additions that have built-in insurance, because they are based on film characters, entertainers or existing toys with proven popularity. ``There are people in the industry who are saying that creativity is going down,'' says Gerald V. Cleary, president of the Tonka products division of Tonka Corp. ``To some degree there may be some truth to that. I think the reason for it is the risk associated with product launches.'' The old classics and newcomers will be competing for attention when the toy industry hosts its annual bash beginning Monday. The 10-day extravaganza draws buyers worldwide who hope to spot the next big craze _ or at least the probable sellers. Familiar faces in the form of Barbie, G.I. Joe plus other widely known dolls and action figures will get prominent billing. Old-timers Life and Monopoly will share the game spotlight with newer entries, such as one that made a splash last year, Shark Attack. Hype ranging from a Fifth Avene parade of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles to appearances by real-life superstars are some of the weapons toymakers are using to outdo each other in generating publicity. Despite the high jinks and hyperbole, industry analysts predict a ho-hum year in toyland. Sales in the $13 billion industry _ excluding the wildly successful video game segment _ rose about 5 percent in 1989, says the Toy Manufacturers of America Inc., sponsor of the 87th Annual American International Toy Fair. The trade group will release official figures the first day of the show, which features more than 1,100 exhibitors. ``I think 1990 will continue the trend that began in 1987 of conservatism,'' said Gary M. Jacobson, a toy analyst at Kidder Peabody & Co. ``I think industry revenues will be up modestly in 1990. I look to 1991 and the decline of video to free up some dollars for traditional toys.'' Nintendo still reigns among systems that turn televisions into game screens. But a more sophisticated and expensive machine, Genesis from rival Sega, did well over the holidays, indicating the market hasn't peaked. New software titles will be introduced aimed at keeping the video game business booming. Sega provided previews of one starring Michael Jackson that inserts slick dance moves into a game plot. Analyst Paul Valentine of Standard & Poor's Corp. says themes of recent years will be repeated and embellished. Miniatures, dolls, stuffed animals, and video-game accessories are categories of concentration. Toys for preschoolers _ too young for Nintendo _ will be emphasized. Dolls will proliferate. They'll range from high-tech babies who eat and cry to Hasbro Inc.'s Baby Uh-Oh, who wets herself after a bottle-feeding and even suffers simulated diaper rash. High-fashion model dolls resemble the real thing. Matchbox Toys' bevy of Christie Brinkley, Cheryl Tiegs and Beverly Johnson dolls may put a few worry wrinkles in 31-year-old Barbie's brow. A strong 1990 contender could be Tyco Toys Inc.'s $45 My Pretty Ballerina, said to be capable of toe dancing, even executing an arabesque or pirouette. Tyco's Oopsie Daisy crawled and stumbled her way to stardom last year. Small has been beautiful for the balance sheets of some manufacturers, particularly Lewis Galoob Toys Inc. which is extending its Mico Machines line that has been racing ahead of Mattel Inc.'s Hot Wheels and Matchbox's vehicles. Galoob's success with miniatures has inspired others to downsize their toys. Hasbro, for example, has decided to offer petite versions of its famous My Little Pony herd. Some toymakers are banking on licensing agreements as tickets to financial rewards. Hasbro, the country's biggest toy company, already announced its agreement with the pop music group New Kids on the Block. The quintet teeny-bopper sensation is spawning dolls, puzzles and other items. By going after a deal with a hot group, Hasbro showed gumption _ something the toy industry must have more of if it intends to regain market share gobbled up by video games and other competitors for toy dollars, analysts say. ``I think the traditional U.S. manufacturers are going to have to become aggressive to make inroads against video and to stimulate sales,'' Jacobson of Kidder Peabody says. Lawrence Bernstein, president of Hasbro's toy division, says the company is pursuing a new strategy: ``We will be far more aggressive in our approach to new products than we have been in the past.'' For years, toy manufacturers have been criticized for playing it too safe while waiting for the videogame fad to fade, which in some respects seems to be a self-perpetuating problem. The rising cost of creating new offerings and plugging them with expensive TV commercials has made toymakers conservative. But retailers, who obviously want to stock winners, typically prefer to order toys promoted on TV. Nonetheless, companies willing to take risks can make a killing if their toys catch on. Playmates Toys Inc. proved that with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, the third hottest selling toy in 1989 after Nintendo and Mattel's Barbie. About two dozen more turtles, new enemies and accessories will come out in 1990 and probably will get a boost this Easter from the film starring live actors. Playmates, a subsidiary of Hong Kong-based Playmates Holdings Ltd., has done so well with the turtles, which are based on a comic, that it was able to land what is expected to be a lucrative license. It won the rights to action figures based on the Dick Tracy movie from Walt Disney Studios starring Warren Beatty and Madonna. The film opens June 15. Richard Sallis, senior vice president for Playmates, recalls that when the idea for the turtle figures came up the company jumped on it despite the risk of a flop. ``I looked at the market four years ago and felt a lot of people weren't doing anything. They weren't taking any chances,'' he said. ``When people aren't doing anything there are a lot of opportunities.''

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Rise Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Prices rose sharply on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, propelled higher by a bullish start on Wall Street and a stronger showing on the stock index futures market. Early gains in London were the result of the Dow Jones industrial average's good Wednesday showing, and London's afternoon advances were made after the bullish start in New York on Thursday, dealers said. Traders said they carefully would watch the auction of U.S. 30-year Treasury bonds later Thursday, but said they were not anticipating any hitches after Wednesday's successful 10-year note sale. By the close of the European day, the Dow Jones average was up 21.84 points at 2,661.93, after a 34-point advance Wednesday. At London's close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 23.6 points, or 1 percent, at 2,331.0. It was just below its session peak of 2,331.2 and way above its minimum of 2,321.0. Volume came to 456.3 million shares, compared with 368.5 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Fight Oil Spill; Tanker May Have Been Gashed By its Anchor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with booms placed, birds dying, quote from volunteer; DELETES 9th graf pvs, `British Petroleum ...,' removing disputed reference to BP accepting responsibility; PICKS UP 13th graf pvs, `A Coast Guard ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SAN1, LA1,3; LaserGraphic NY9
DOC.TEXT: Crews floated containment booms into place today to protect a wildlife preserve and beaches from a slick of more than 290,000 gallons of oil spilled from a tanker that may have gashed itself on its anchor. The 811-foot American Trader, fully loaded with 21 million gallons of heavy Alaskan crude, tore a 3-foot hole in a compartment Wednesday as it was mooring at an offshore pipeline terminal 1{ miles from shore, the Coast Guard said. The spill occurred just off Huntington Beach, a city about 30 miles south of Los Angeles long popular with surfers and sunbathers and often the scene for movies and TV shows featuring surfing. The slick hovered about a mile from several beaches and a marsh this morning, but desert winds condensed it from a four-mile-long plume into a roundish, mile-long blob and were pushing it away from shore, officials said. ``It's good, because it's a smaller area for us to corral,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Mark Kennedy. ``But the farther it gets offshore, the harder it will be to get it out of the water.'' Calm seas worked to the advantage of cleanup crews, who worked under spotlights overnight using oil-containment booms and skimmer boats. A dozen oil-fouled birds found on the beach were taken to a cleaning station, but half died, officials said. ``They were completely drenched in the oil. You'd pick them up and drops would come off,'' said Christina Amato, a volunteer. ``Those wetlands and wildlife preserves are so very precious,'' said Dorothy Green, president of Heal the Bay, a local environmental group. A diver found a hole in the bottom of a forward compartment that held more than 1 million gallons of crude, said Coast Guard Capt. James Card. No other damage was found on the vessel, which was operated by American Trading Transportation Co. of New York and leased by British Petroleum Oil Shipping Co. USA. The Coast Guard initially reported the tanker had struck a submerged pipeline, but American Trading president Sanford Schmidt said the captain speculated that the vessel was punctured by one of its anchors as it was maneuvering at less than 1 mph. Schmidt said the ship, sitting 40 feet deep in the water, had dropped two anchors off the bow and eased backward into a nest of buoys. But he said there was speculation that a swell caused the front of the ship to lift up and one of the anchors to swing loose. Coast Guard Cmdr. Scott Porter, assistant chief of marine safety, couldn't confirm the account. He said the cause of the spill remained under investigation. The tanker captain, Robert Laware, and the first mate were tested for alcohol and drugs, but results were not immediately available, officials said. Oil containment booms were set around the tanker. Protective booms were set at the Bolsa Chica wildlife preserve, Alamitos Bay, Anaheim Bay, Santa Ana River and upper Newport Bay, Coast Guard Lt. Vince Campos said. Coast Guard officials expected the crude would foul Huntington City Beach, Huntington State Beach, Bolsa Chica State Beach. ``We can't boom all the beaches off, but we'll at least key those key areas,'' Campos said. The crude was the same type that fouled Alaska's Prince William Sound last year when more than 10 million gallons spilled from the Exxon Valdez, Porter said. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., and other political leaders seized the accident as evidence of the need for stricter regulation of oil industry operations in coastal waters. Wilson noted that the spill was much smaller than the Exxon Valdez spill, but he added: ``The difference is that here it's going to impact an enormous audience. You've got a densely populated coastline and, incidentally, one that is environmentally sensitive.''

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Inn Headquarters Moving to Atlanta, New Owner Says
DOC.TEXT: Bass PLC completed its $2.2 billion acquisition of Holiday Inns Thursday and said the motel chain's headquarters would be established in Atlanta. Bryan D. Langton, chairman of the Bass hotels and restaurants division, will become chairman and chief executive officer of Holiday Inns Inc. and move from Great Britain to Atlanta, Bass said in a statement. The current Holiday Inn headquarters in Memphis, Tenn., will operate as an office of Holiday Inn, USA. The chain began there in 1952. Shareholders of Holiday Corp., the parent of Holiday Inns, last month approved the sale of the chain to the British company that also brews Bass, Carling Black Label and other beers. Langton said he would review the company's business over the next three months. Bass bought the rights to Holiday Inns outside North America in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Banks Squeezed by Higher Interest Rates, LDC Debt
DOC.TEXT: Japanese banks may have a lion's share of the international banking business, but they now must come to grips with the same problems that hammered many big U.S. banks in the last decade: bad Third World loans, rising interest rates and a potential downturn in their domestic real estate market. ``It's clear the Japanese banks will be pressured to take on a more philanthropic role,'' Simon Smithson, an analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities, said of Japan's Third World debt exposure. ``Some hard decisions will have to be made.'' Japanese banks now constitute the world's 10 biggest on basis of assets, partly due to growth stemming from the booming Japanese economy of the 1980s and the rise of the yen against the dollar. As they grew so did their international business, including in such areas as developing country loans that now are seen as potential trouble spots. In recent years, U.S. banks have restructured a significant portion of their loans to many Latin American countries while beefing up reserves for covering bad loans and writing down the value of some credits. Those actions directly reduced profits. Japanese banks generally have a lower overall exposure to Third World debt than do U.S. banks, with Latin American loans accounting for an estimated 3 percent to 6 percent of commercial banks' outstanding loans. However, their reserves for covering bad loans also are relatively small. Major American and British banks have reserves to cover as much as 80 percent of their outstanding Third World loans. Japanese banks are just now raising their reserves to 25 percent from 15 percent by the end of March. Japanese banks also are set to take an earnings hit by writing off a portion of their medium- and long-term loans to Mexico following a recently approved debt restructuring agreement between Mexico and 450 creditor banks. Japan also has potential loan problems on the domestic front. Smithson said trust banks' loans to corporations and commercial banks' loans to individuals for real estate could be hit hard by a major downturn in the overheated Japanese property market. ``Many of the loans those banks make are ultimately for real estate and could become irrecoverable,'' he said. Concern over Tokyo's inflated land prices reaches into many sectors of the economy. The rate of increase has slowed since 1987, when land prices grew 70 percent, to 24 percent in 1988 and 2.7 percent in the first six months of 1989 _leading some analysts to conclude that prices could soften or fall. Reflecting uncertainty over Japan's overheated property market Moody's Investors Service Inc. this week downgraded its credit ratings for Japan's three largest trust banks _ Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp., Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co., and Mitsui Trust and Banking Co. Land in Tokyo's highest-priced residential area actually did fall in the first half of last year, by 4.4 percent from a year earlier, the National Land Agency reported. In an average-priced Tokyo neighborhood, a square foot of residential land costs $630, according to a survey last spring by the Association of Real Estate Appraisal. But Tokyo's commercial land prices continued to edge up last year. The most expensive commercial property cost $23,600 a square foot last year, up from $22,500 the previous year, the National Land Agency said. Land prices in less-developed suburbs also continued rising, it said. Richard Koo, senior economist at Nomura Research Institute, said falling land prices right now would have limited impact on bank assets. ``Japanese banks use extremely conservative accounting methods sometimes (using) the actual acquisition price from 20 years ago, so even a 30 percent decline in land prices wouldn't do that much damage,'' he said. Analysts say a more immediate danger lies in rising interest rates, which have begun to cut into banks' already slim profit margins. Japan's central bank raised its discount rate, or the interest it charges to commercial banks, three times last year, to 4.25 percent from 2.5 percent. The rate hikes helped push other interest rates higher. Higher rates discourage real estate investment by making borrowing more expensive. They also reduce the differential between lending and borrowing rates that constitutes a bank's profit.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Loss in 4th Qtr, Higher Profit for Year
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times Co. reported Thursday it lost $19 million in the fourth quarter, citing regional economic weakness and previously-disclosed charges involving its forest products investment and costs of staffing reductions. For the year, the media concern said its profit climbed 59 percent, principally because of a big gain on the sale of its cable television system. The company said its loss in the fourth quarter amounted to 24 cents a share in contrast to earnings of $50.4 million, or 64 cents per share, in 1988. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 4.4 percent to $470.2 million from $450.0 million a year earlier. The company said the weak New York regional economy reduced advertising lineage by 5.6 percent for the quarter at The New York Times, its flagship newspaper. The latest results also reflected a charge of 57 cents a share for the establishment of a valuation reserve against the company's investment in its forest products group and costs of voluntary staff reductions at the Times. The fourth-quarter results also were reduced by 11 cents a share in the quarter due to structuring costs associated with its recent acquisitions of McCall's, Golf World (U.S.) and Sailing World magazines and by 3 cents a share as a result of a legal settlement with independent home delivery dealers. The company said that excluding the special factors, earnings per share would have been 47 cents in the fourth quarter. Operating profit for the newspaper group which includes the New York Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in the International Herald Tribune fell 63 percent to $25.1 million for the quarter, reflecting decreased ad linage at the Times and the staff reduction and delivery dealer charges. The magazine group had an operating loss of $12.6 million in the latest quarter in contrast to an operating profit of $5.3 million a year earlier. The loss was due to the structuring charge, higher subscription promotion expenses and single copy circulation softness in the first quarter at Family Circle. The broadcasting and information services group had an operating profit of $2.9 million in the quarter compared with $4 million a year earlier, reflecting a writedown of firm and syndication rights. The company had an equity loss of $25.1 million on its investment in its forest products group as a result of the charge for the valuation reserve. It had equity earnings of $8.1 million in the same quarter a year ago. For the year, the company earned $266.6 million, or $3.39 a share, up from $167.7 million, or $2.08 a share, a year earlier. The results included a gain of $193.3 million after taxes on the sale of its cable TV system. Revenue for the year rose 4 percent to $1.8 billion from $1.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Borden Loses Battle of Plastic Lemons
DOC.TEXT: Britain's highest court of appeal ruled against Borden's Inc. Thursday in a battle over the right to sell lemon juice in squeezable containers. The Law Lords, Britain's highest judiciary body, upheld a previous High Court ruling that bars Borden from selling its plastic lemons filled with reconstituted lemon juice in Britain because shoppers could confuse Borden's ReaLemon with a similar British product, JIF. Borden issued a statement from its headquarters in New York saying the firm disagreed with the decision but would abide by it. JIF's manufacturer, Reckitt and Colman, won an injunction three years ago barring Borden from marketing ReaLemon ``in any container so nearly resembling the Jif lemon-shaped container.'' Borden had argued that it would be impossible to compete without causing initial confusion because JIF was the only product of its kind in the British market. The judge disagreed and said that if the Borden product were packaged differently _ put in a box or shaped like a lemon segment _ the problem would be solved. ``It's unfortunate that U.K. consumers will not be able to make their choice in the marketplace based on price and quality of competitive and conspicuously labeled products,'' Borden's statement said. The three-year legal battle is believed to have cost the two companies $2.5 million in legal fees. Lord Bridge, one of the five judges who heard the case, said Reckitt and Colman had been given a de facto monopoly in natural-sized plastic lemons. ``A trader selling plastic lemons would never be permitted to register a lemon as his trade mark, but Reckitt and Colman have achieved the result indirectly that a container designed to look like a real lemon is to be treated, per se, as distinctive of their goods,'' he said. Bridge said he would have liked to avoid this result, but he could not fault the legal reasoning and agreed with the other judges in dismissing Borden's appeal. Another law lord, Lord Jauncey, said he did not believe that JIF's makers were being given a monopoly. The ruling, he said, merely meant that Borden had not taken adequate steps to differentiate its package from that of Reckitt and Colman so consumers would not be deceived. Borden said it would continue to sell its lemon product in bottles in Britain and throughout Europe and its lemon-shaped containers in France and Norway.

DOC.HEAD: Tenneco Posts Fourth Quarter, Year Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Tenneco Inc., a diversified energy company, said Thursday its fourth-quarter earnings fell 65.7 percent from the final quarter of 1988, when the company had a $775 million one-time gain from the sale of its oil and gas businesses. The Houston-based company recorded earnings of $205 million, or $1.58 per share, on revenue of $3.9 billion for the 1989 fourth quarter. During the year-earlier period, Tenneco had an operating loss of $177 million, but with the gain from the sale of its oil and gas businesses, the company ended with earnings of $598 million, or $4.23 per share, on revenue of $3.6 billion. For all of 1989, Tenneco posted a net income of $584 million, or $4.46 per share, on revenue of $14.1 billion, a 29 percent decline in earnings of $822 million, or $5.48 per share, on revenue of $13.2 billion reported in 1988. Earnings for 1988 included a $892 million gain on the oil and gas business sale. ``1989 was a great first year for the new, restructured Tenneco,'' said James L. Ketelsen, Tenneco's chairman and chief executive officer. ``Three key factors contributed to the overall improvement in results _ a sizeable increase in operating income contributed by nearly all of our divisions, the full benefit of our reduced debt and our share repurchase program,'' Ketelsen said. Among the company's divisions, the natural gas pipeline segment posted fourth quarter operating income of $86 million, compared with a loss of $101 million in 1988. For the year, the division had operating income of $325 million vs. the $114 million recorded in 1988, when the division had a $190 million special charge. The J I Case farm and construction equipment business recorded operating income of $99 million for the quarter compared with an operating loss of $39 million in 1988. For the year, J I Case had operating income of $228 million compared with a loss of $142 million in 1988. Newport News Shipbuilding reported operating earnings of $95 million for the quarter, up from $49 million a year earlier. For the year, Newport News reported operating income of $200 million, up from $25 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Settled At Ford's Chihuahua Plant
DOC.TEXT: Autoworkers ended a week-old strike at Ford Motor Co.'s plant in the northern border state of Chihuahua after the company agreed to a more than 27 percent pay hike, Ford said Thursday. The wage increase ranks among the largest obtained in collective bargaining contract negotiations in the country, said Fidel Velazquez, head of the Mexican Labor Federation. Company and union negotiators for the plant's 800 hourly employees reached a contract agreement late Wednesday, said Ford spokesman Al Chambers in Detroit. ``They are back at work,'' Chambers said. The workers' contract expired Jan. 31 and the union went on strike Feb. 1 when the company refused to change its offer of a 12 percent increase. The plant produces 1,300 four-cylinder engines daily for export to U.S. and Canadian markets. In another labor dispute at Cuautitlan near Mexico City, Ford sent out about 400 layoff notices Wednesday to workers who refused to answer a back-to-work order, according to the newspaper Excelsior. Ford has announced it will fire 2,200 Cuautitlan union dissidents for failing to return to their jobs. The company closed the plant a month ago after more than 150 thugs beat and shot workers. One union dissident was killed and nine were injured in the violence, which Ford said stemmed from an intra-union dispute. Authorities have issued a warrant for the arrest of Cuautitlan official union head Hector Uriarte, alleging that he masterminded the violence. The dissidents, saying that Uriarte was imposed on their union by Velazquez' federation, have picketed the plant continuously since the violence. They said they would not go back to work unless free union elections could be held and Ford could guarantee plant security. The dissidents charged that the union acted in cahoots with the company in the labor conflict. Velazquez promised elections after unionists return to work, saying that his federation would not try to block detention of Uriarte. Ford's Cuautitlan facility produces 450 cars and trucks daily for the Mexican market under normal conditions. Over 1,000 workers are on the job, making possible the production of only about 40 vehicles a day, Ford says.

Advancing issues outnumbered declines by a narrow margin among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 769 up, 695 down and 492 unchanged. The NYSE's composite index fell 0.22 to 184.09.

DOC.HEAD: January Savings Bond Sales Up
DOC.TEXT: Sales of U.S. savings bonds totaled $826 million in January, up 39 percent from December, the Treasury Department reported Thursday. January's sales, a 2 percent increase from January 1989, brought the total value of bonds held by the public to $118.2 billion, the first time it topped $118 billion. Savings bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.

DOC.HEAD: Several Airlines Postponing Fuel Surcharges
DOC.TEXT: Several major U.S. airlines said Thursday they are postponing for a week special fuel surcharges originally due to take effect Friday. United Airlines, leading the move, said it deferred the surcharges in order ``to keep its fare levels fully competitive with all major carriers.'' Spokesmen for American Airlines, Trans World Airlines and Northwest Airlines said those carriers were matching United's initiative. The surcharges _ $6 for a one-way ticket and $12 round trip for travel within the United States _ will be deferred until Feb. 16. Last month, several big airlines added special surcharges to the price of domestic tickets to help cover the surging cost of jet fuel. They also applied for foreign government approval of the surcharge for international flights. Other carriers raised fares 4 percent to absorb fuel costs.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $2.73 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `The average ...,' to CORRECT that average maturity was up, sted down. Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 495 money market mutual funds rose $2.73 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The increase to a record $387.39 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a revised $1.60 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 244 general purpose funds rose $1.02 billion to $130.87 billion, assets of 101 broker-dealer funds increased $1.31 billion to $164.42 billion, and assets of 150 institutional funds rose $401.9 million to $92.11 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday fell to 7.66 percent from 7.70 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.71 percent from 7.75 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, up from 42 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts stood at 6.30 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW account 2{-year CDs, uLercent from 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.88 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.95 percent on 1-year CDs, unchanged; 7.95 percent on 2{-year CDs, uL. Good, chairwoman of the National Science Board, a foundation group that produced the report, said cooperative action between government, industry and academia is required if the United States is to maintain its leadership position. The report said: _Growth rates have slowed in both research and development and in the training of scientists and engineers. _Science and mathematics education in U.S. schools has shown little improvement despite major reform efforts. _Fewer college and university freshmen are choosing science and mathematics fields, which means there will be fewer degrees in technical fields in the coming years. _The number of foreign students earning advanced degrees in U.S. schools continues to increase while the number of advanced degrees to Americans continues to decline. _The U.S. growth in research and development was 6 percent annually from 1975 to 1985, but slowed to 2 percent annually from 1986 to 1989. _The United States spends more on research and development than the United Kingdom, Japan, France and West Germany combined, but Japan and West Germany spend a greater portion of their gross national product on research and development than the United States. ``While the U.S. continues to be the world's foremost supplier of high-tech products, its lead is shrinking,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Up
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly higher Thursday as the soaring West German mark ran out of steam due to profit-taking and concerns about a possible monetary union between the two German states. Gold prices rose slightly after falling overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $418.60 a troy ounce, up 50 cents from Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $418.70 an ounce, up 60 cents. Ronald H. Holzer, chief currency dealer for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the dollar continues to shadow the mark in foreign exchange, as recent reforms in East Germany and the Soviet Union are expected to benefit the West German economy. But concerns about the implications of a proposal to unify the two German monetary systems, along with profit-taking, helped push the mark lower Thursday, dealers said. That, in turn, helped support the dollar, they said. Fear that taking over East Germany's nearly bankrupt system would endanger the West German economy also helped drive down prices of West German bonds Thursday for the third straight day. The dollar traded at 1.6665 marks in New York, up from 1.6580 Wednesday, and at 1.68872 marks in Europe, up from 1.6545. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to 145.50 Japanese yen from 145.10 yen Wednesday. It traded at 145.05 yen in London, and at 145.315 yen in New York, down from 145.60. The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6885 in London, cheaper than $1.6995 Wednesday, and $1.69435 in New York, down from $1.6960. Other late dollar rates in New York compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.4890 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6660 French francs, up from 5.6420; 1,240.25 Italian lire, up from 1,236.50; and 1.19465 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19455. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Wednesday: 1.4905 Swiss francs, up from 1.4805; 5.6725 French francs, up from 5.6335; 1.8810 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8650; 1,241.50 Italian lire, up from 1,234.50; and 1.1970 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1932. Gold fell in London to $417.75 an ounce from $423, and in Zurich, to $417.75 an ounce from $422.25. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $418.15 an ounce, down from $419.65. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.324 a troy ounce, up from $5.311. Silver fell in London to $5.32 an ounce from $5.38.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Rise As Supply Fears Mount
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures prices rose Thursday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid mounting supply fears exacerbated by the threat of a dockworkers strike next week in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer. On other commodity markets, oil futures were mixed; precious metals advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Coffee futures settled .15 cent to .43 cent higher on heavy trading volume with the contract for delivery in March at 82.09 cents a pound, the highest close in about a month. Brazilian dockworkers are scheduled to vote Saturday on whether to strike, which would add to an already existing problem of shipping delays. Bert Ruiz, a vice president of the commodities brokerage Balfour Maclaine Corp., said a vote to strike would be unlikely given Brazil's current political climate, with a new president scheduled to take office next month. But, he added, ``there's a policy in Brazil _ expect the unexpected.'' So roasters were heavy buyers, seeking to lock in prices now. Coffee futures prices have been working higher since mid-October, the start of the annual peak consumption period, after collapsing to 14-year-lows of less than 70 cents a pound early in October. Last year's plunge was triggered by the failure of the 74-nation International Coffee Organization to agree on new export quotas to support prices. With no agreement, coffee-producing nations battled for market share by offering coffee at lower and lower prices, clearing out much of their stocks in the process. Analysts say the tightening of supplies is one factor underpinning the market's recent strength. Others include suspected damage to the Central American crop from a Christmastime freeze; a spell of hot, dry weather in Brazil that threatens the quality of the crop there; and President Bush's upcoming visit to Colombia, the second-largest coffee producer, where prospects for a new International Coffee Agreement are expected to be discussed. Crude oil for near-term delivery sank for the third time in the last four days on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid growing supply pressure. Heating oil futures retreated while gasoline futures advanced. Domestic supplies of crude oil are at their highest mid-February levels in several years, said Jim Ritterbusch, vice president of trading and research at Carson Petroleum Co., a Chicago-area petroleum distributor. He said cash prices of refined products such as gasoline and heating oil have recently been falling at a faster rate than crude, reducing refiners' profit margins and subsequently slowing their demand for crude. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled .23 cent lower to .12 cent higher with March at $22.09 a barrel; heating oil futures were unchanged to .57 cent lower with March at 55.32 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .03 cent lower to 1.4 cents higher with March at 61.17 cents a gallon. Precious metals edged higher on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold futures finished 20 cents to 60 cents higher with February at $418.70 a troy ounce; silver was 0.6 cent to 1.3 cents higher with March at $5.343 a troy ounce. Soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slackening foreign demand and improved weather for the South American crop. Grain futures also finished mostly lower. Wheat futures settled { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $3.82{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $1.37 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with March at $5.64} a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures ended .18 cent lower to .05 cent higher with February at 79.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .23 cent lower with March at 82.42 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .18 cent higher with February at 49.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 50.65 cents a pound.
