DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Hopes to Get Trade Agreement with Soviets By Summer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version focusing on the president's visit to Strategic Air Command headquarters is moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: OMAHA, Neb. _ President Bush told a corn-country audience Thursday that he hopes a trade agreement with the Soviet Union can be negotiated by the time of his summer summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ``expanding markets for American exports'' and helping the Soviet Union. Bush talked of his hopes for a trade agreement, a goal he and Gorbachev set in their meeting at Malta last December, in a state keenly interested in selling grain to the Soviets. ``This will relax trade barriers between East and West, expanding markets for American exports,'' he said in remarks to a $1,000-a-plate fundraising breakfast for Republican Gov. Kay Orr. ``I feel strongly that selling our grain to the Soviet Union is in America's interest as well as theirs,'' he told more than 500 people attending the breakfast. Bush also said he will push for a farm bill this year that emphasizes ``market-oriented farm policies'' that would give farmers more flexibility over what crops they grow. ``What's good for agriculture is good for America,'' he said. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Wednesday the administration hoped to complete by early May a U.S.-Soviet trade pact that Bush and Gorbachev could sign at their scheduled summit meeting a month later. The opening round of talks on what would be the first attempt for an economic accord with the Soviets since the early 1970s will begin in Washington Monday, Mrs. Hills told the Senate Finance Committee. A new trade agreement would help remove obstacles to granting the Soviet Union most-favored-nation trade status, a move that could ease the economic straits under which the Soviets are living. When Bush and Gorbachev agreed at their Malta summit to seek a new trade partnership, they set no date. Their next summit is scheduled in Washington in late June. In a political sidelight to a barnstorming trip aimed at building support for his defense policies, Bush told Orr's supporters, ``I need her ... to support the work of our administration. For we want to make America a kinder, gentler place.'' Bush later toured the underground command center of Strategic Air Command headquarters, capping a trip in defense of his $292 billion military budget. He also addressed by radio the SAC forces deployed around the world on ground alert.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW final 3 grafs to UPDATE with data on monetary base, edit to conform; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The three leading measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Jan. 29, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,233.9 billion from $3,225.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,049.4 billion from $4,044.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $796.9 billion from $794.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.2 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,211.0 billion, a 7.2 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,036.4 billion, up 3.3 percent, while M1 rose 6.0 percent to an average of $793.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $852 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $813 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $303.0 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, up from $299.4 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Modifies Rebate Plan
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. began a new incentive program Thursday offering consumers a combination of a cash rebate and low-interest financing on Escort and Tracer subcompact cars. In the past, automakers have offered car buyers a choice of either cash or low interest rates. In the new program, buyers of 1989 and 1990 Escorts and Tracers may choose a combination of either $750 or $1,000 in cash, depending on the model, and 6.9 percent financing. Alternately, customers may choose to take a cash rebate, with no low-interest financing, of $1,500 on the Tracer or $1,000 on the Escort. While varying the interest and rebate packages available on various models, Ford isn't greatly changing the amount it spends on buyer incentives, spokesman Jim McCraw said. ``Overall, they tend to remain approximately the same.'' In all, 22 Lincoln, Mercury and Ford products are covered in the new program, which expires April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices finished mixed Thursday in fairly sluggish trading as warm weather continued to depress heating oil prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 23 cents to $22.09 per 42-gallon barrel, adding to a 19-cent drop Wednesday. Crude contracts for delivery in April and May also declined, but later months rose. Among refined products traded on the New York Merc, No. 2 heating oil for delivery in March declined 0.57 cent to 55.32 cents a gallon on top of a 0.30-cent loss in the previous session. Later contracts also ended lower. Analysts said springlike weather in the Northeast continued to lower the demand for heating oil. The March contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline dipped 0.03 cent to 61.17 cents a gallon. Contracts after March finished higher after word spread through the markets that some refiners would be doing seasonal overhauls next month. The annual maintenance normally slows the production of gasoline for a short period and impacts supplies with about a four-week lag time. Conversely, oil analysts said word of the refinery slowdown helped depress crude oil prices. ``The demand for crude oil is going to be reduced because refiners won't be using as much,'' said Randall Rothenberg, an energy broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Recommends Continental Get Houston-Toyko Route
DOC.TEXT: An administrative law judge recommended Thursday that Continental Airlines be awarded a daily Houston-to-Toyko route, choosing the Houston-based carrier over five other applicants. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner has 90 days to either accept Judge Ronnie A. Yoder's recommendation or send it back for reconsideration. Continental, a subsidiary of Texas Air Corp., had proposed providing daily Boeing 747 jet service between Houston and Toyko via Honolulu. The other carriers seeking the route were Delta Air Lines, which proposed flying out of San Diego, Calif., through Honolulu; Hawaiian Airlines, from Los Angeles through Honolulu five days a week and from American Samoa, through Hawaii, two days a week; American Airlines, from Boston through San Jose, Calif.; Aloha Airlines, from Los Angeles through Honolulu; America West Airlines, from Phoenix, Ariz., through Honolulu, returning via Las Vegas and Phoenix. Members of the Texas congressional delegation, in a letter Wednesday to Skinner, said the route would provide ``enormous benefits to the state and nation.'' Houston is the largest mainland community without direct service to Japan and other points in the Far East, the Texans told Skinner. ``Houston is our nation's fourth-largest city and the largest city in the South and Southwest region,'' the congressmen said. ``Houston's economic and social links to Japan are more significant than any non-gateway city and, in fact, greater than many gateway cities.'' Japan already tops the list of Houston's trading partners, with the value of imports and exports between Houston and Japan exceeding $2.2 billion in 1988, the congressmen said. There are 104 Japanese companies with offices in Houston and 2,500 Japanese nationals live in the city, which also has an Asian population exceeding 120,000, they said. The Houston-Tokyo route opened when courier Federal Express acquired Flying Tigers. Continental also is asking the Department of Transportation to allow it to provide additional passenger-cargo service between the United States and Japan. Nine other airlines also are seeking the ``gateway'' service. Up to three cities and three carriers will be selected.

DOC.HEAD: Editors:
DOC.TEXT:
U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. says the hearing over operating plans for the Federated and Allied department store chains will continue for another 2-3 hours. An AMs story will move shortly, to be led with further developments as warranted.
AP Business News

DOC.HEAD: Judge Makes It Easier For Georgia-Pacific To Oust Great Northern Board
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge handed Georgia-Pacific Corp. a victory in its bid to buy Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., ruling Thursday that it will take just a two-thirds vote by Great Northern shareholders to oust the paper company's directors. Great Northern's bylaws called for a three-fourths vote, but U.S. District Judge Gene Carter agreed with Georgia-Pacific that the higher number ran afoul of Maine corporate law. The judge also struck down two other portions of Great Northern's bylaws, which allowed outgoing directors to name a new board and called for a 90-day nomination period for new directors. ``We're disappointed, and we certainly are going to study what he had to say, and then we'll decide how to react to it,'' Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said from his office in Norwalk, Conn., where the company is based. It is incorporated in Maine. Great Northern's board has been fighting the $3.8 billion takeover attempt, but Georgia-Pacific succeeded in forcing a special shareholders meeting, scheduled for March 2 in Portland, at which the Great Northern directors could be thrown out. Hill declined to predict whether Great Northern's directors would be able to survive the shareholders meeting. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific contends that Great Northern's directors are resisting the takeover offer so they can hold onto their high-paying jobs at the expense of shareholders. Despite Thursday's setback for Great Northern, the company still hopes to persuade Carter to block Georgia-Pacific's effort to oust the Great Northern board. The judge plans to hear oral arguments Monday on that motion by Great Northern, which also hopes to block the hostile tender offer on grounds that include allegations that Georgia-Pacific has violated federal securities laws by covering up plans to sell Maine assets should the deal go through. T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia-Pacific's chairman and chief executive officer, issued a statement hailing the ruling. ``This is one more important advance in bringing Georgia-Pacific closer to completing this acquisition, which we believe is best for Great Northern shareholders, employees and communities in which they operate,'' Hahn said. Georgia-Pacific has denied Great Northern's allegations that it broke the law by covering up plans to sell Maine assets, saying that it has no such plans.

DOC.HEAD: Money Manager Acquires 7.1 Percent of Immunex
DOC.TEXT: New York money manager George Soros disclosed Thursday that he controls a 7.1 percent stake in Immunex Corp. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Soros said he and a mutual fund he advises, Quantum Fund, purchased 479,000 shares of the Seattle-based biotechnology company from Oct. 24 to Dec. 16. Quantum Fund, based on the Caribbean island of Curacao in the Netherlands Antilles, and Lupa Family Partners, a limited partnerhip controlled by Soros, paid $12 to $20.75 per share for the stock, according to the filing. The filing said the purchases were for investment purposes.

DOC.HEAD: Philips, Chrysler Units Negotiating Auto Electronics Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Subsidiaries of Chrysler Corp. and electronics giant NV Philips of the Netherlands are negotiating a joint venture to make car radios and other auto electronics products, the companies said Thursday. The Philips unit, Philips Car Stereo International GmbH of West Germany, would hold a majority interest in the venture with Chrysler's parts subsidiary, Acustar Inc., the companies said. Terms are being negotiated. The companies signed a letter of intent late Wednesday and expect to reach a final agreement later this year, Acustar spokesman A.J. Malta said. The venture would make items such as vehicle audio and video entertainment systems, navigation and communication systems, trip computers and driver-information systems. Philips Car Stereo International has facilities in West Germany, France, the Netherlands and Singapore and produces more than 3.5 million car radios annually. Acustar makes about 1.8 million radios a year and a line of other auto electronic products at a plant in Huntsville, Ala. The two subsidiaries don't report revenues separately from their parent companies. NV Philips is a $30 billion-a-year conglomerate, while Chrysler Corp. had 1988 revenue of $9.69 billion. Acustar Chairman Thomas T. Stallkamp said the alliance would enhance Acustar's technological capabilities and markets. Bert Snijders, managing director of Philips Car Stereo International, said the companies would complement one another in technology and marketing. ``Philips has a worldwide presence we seem to lack, and we have a presence in the United States Philips seems to lack,'' Malta said.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Reverses Policy On ``White Knight'' Broadcast License Applicants
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday reversed a year-old policy allowing ``white knight'' applicants to gain broadcast licenses, saying such 11th-hour resolutions encourage sham applications. An attorney representing a group that challenged the commission's Dec. 23, 1988, decision to approve a settlement agreement for a new FM station in Marco, Fla., said Thursday's action suggests a more aggressive regulatory posture under new FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes. ``This is an absolute U-turn on a policy adopted by the Reagan-era FCC a year ago,'' said Andrew Schwartzman, executive director of the Media Access Project. Schwartzman's group appealed the FCC's approval of a pact in which Rowland Gulf Radio Inc., which was not an original applicant for the new station license, paid off one of the applicants, Affirmative Broadcasting, to substitute Rowland's name on the application. In return, Rowland paid off the other six competing applicants, the FCC said. The rationale behind the ``white knight'' approach, which the commission first adopted in the Marco case during the chairmanship of Dennis R. Patrick, was to avoid lengthy and costly comparative application hearings in which a number of competing parties try to prove they're the most worthy applicant. The FCC said the white knight approach could get stations on the air more quickly, thus better serving the public interest. But the FCC said it was granting reconsideration of its own motion, disapproving the Marco agreement and re-opening the license proceeding because it was ``concerned that approval would encourage the filing of sham applications conceived only for the purpose of entering into profitable settlement agreements.'' The commission said it found that although approval of the Marco settlement would expedite service to the public, ``this was outweighed by the fact that approving the Marco agreement would create an economic incentive for individuals with no real interest in building and operating broadcast stations to file sham applications in future cases.'' Schwartzman said Thursday's decision was ``a very important policy reversal that will impact a very substantial number of pending cases around the country. ... It signals again that the Sikes commission is going to take a much more aggressive stance on regulatory issues.'' Schwartzman, who had appealed to the FCC on behalf of the United Church of Christ's office of communications and two Florida residents, said the white knight method amounted to a ``private auction.'' ``It enables the least qualified possible applicant to get the station as long as they're rich enough to buy off the better qualified applicants,'' Schwartzman said. The FCC in the early 1980s legalized unlimited payoffs between competing applicants, which critics said led to a flood of frivolous and sham applications by parties not really interested in operating stations. In March 1989, in a move designed to reduce the number of nuisance applications from profiteers, the FCC banned all settlement payments prior to an initial licensing decision by the commission and limited payments after a license hearing to legitimate expenses incurred by the withdrawing applicant. The applicants for the Florida license were: Rebecca Radio of Marco; Emerald Sea Broadcasting Inc.; Affirmative Broadcasting Corp.; Showcase Communications Inc.; Marco Minority Associates; Susan G. and William R. Gaston; and Marco Skywave Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT Amex close to a rise sted decline.
DOC.TEXT: Blue-chip stock prices posted some small gains Thursday, but prices finished narrowly mixed in the broader market as a strong morning rally eroded in the afternoon. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which was up 33.78 points on Wednesday, rose another 4.28 to close at 2,644.37. The market's best-known index had been up more than 22 points shortly before noontime. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by a narrow margin in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 768 up, 696 down and 505 unchanged. The NYSE's composite index fell 0.22 to 184.09. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 176.24 million shares, down from 186.71 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 210.72 million shares. Stock prices moved higher for most of the morning, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 22.30 points as of 11:30 a.m. EST. But profit-taking drove prices steadily lower in the afternoon, and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped below Wednesday's closing level in the final hour of trading before rallying once again at the close. Some analysts said the market is still showing the scars of a big selloff in January which saw the Dow drop from a peak of more 2,800 early in the month to about 2,543 on Jan. 30. In the seven sessions since then, the market has recovered more than 100 points as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. ``The market was ready to get off its back and was able to get up on one knee, but it was not ready to jog around,'' said Bill Raftery, a vice president in the technial research department at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The stock market has been preoccupied this week by the Treasury's $30 billion auction of new securities and its potential impact on interest rates. Rising interest rates hurt stocks because they make yields more competitive on fixed-income securities and raise the costs of borrowing to buy stocks. Bidding was strong for the first two phases of the auction, which involved sales of $10 billion each in three-year and 10-year notes. But Thursday's auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds, the last part opf the three-stage auction, failed to go as well. The bond were sold for an average yield of 8.50 percent, and there were fewer than $2 in bids for every $1 in bonds sold. Some stock market watchers said the end of the borrowing spree may bode well for stocks no matter how the last stage of the auction went. Gene Jay Seagle, vice president and director of technical research at Gruntal Financial Inc. in Stamford, Conn., said the market is headed up to 2,700 on the Dow Jones industrial average. ``We are running into a little profit-taking here,'' he said. ``But I think the market is entitled to some kind of hesitation. With the bond refunding program out of the way after today ... the market won't have that obstacle in its way and we can test above the 2,700 level.'' Leading the NYSE's active list was Varity, which fell [ to 3\. Philips Petroleum was the second most active stock, rising ] to 26{. Oil stocks as a group were strong. Atlantic Richfield added } to 112], Chevron gained 2] to 70\, Pennzoil rose 1 to 85{ and Texaco was up 1\ to 59|. Among blue-chip issues, IBM fell ] to 102}, American Telephone & Telegraph was up ] to 40\ and Philip Morris was up ] at 39]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market slipped $1.345 billion, or 0.04 percent, in value. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 0.40 to 384.99, and S&P's 500-stock composite index lost 0.79 to 332.96. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.53 to 427.32. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.33 to 357.68.

DOC.HEAD: Some Burdines, Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh Stores May Close
With AM-Federated-Allied
DOC.TEXT: Some Burdines and Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh department stores may close as their parent organization tries to recover from a bankruptcy filing, the new head of Campeau Corp.'s retailing empire said. ``If you have businesses that have not done well over time, it makes sense to get out of these and reinvest in other more profitable areas,'' Allen I. Questrom was quoted as saying in The Miami Herald Wednesday. He wouldn't say which stores might be targeted. Questrom recently was named chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., which filed for Chapter 11 bankuptcy protection last month. ``We have looked at stores, but at this point, we have no plans to close any,'' said Carey Watson, senior vice president of advertising for Burdines, which has 28 outlets in Florida. Thirty-seven of the 39 Maas Brothers-Jordan Marsh stores are in Florida. Senior vice president Tom Ford said there are no plans to close any of them.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Announces Recylcing Plan For Disposable Cameras
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. has announced it will begin recycling some of its disposable cameras, including one that made a consumer group's hit list of unnecessary throwaway products. Kodak said Wednesday it will begin a recycling program this year for its ``Fling,'' ``Stretch'' and ``Weekend'' disposable cameras. ``The program is forecast to reduce solid wastes and is expected to provide long-term resource conservation,'' the company said. But a New York City-based consumer and environmentalist group said ceasing production of disposable cameras would have been a better step toward helping ease the nation's garbage problem. ``It's one step in the right direction but not nearly enough,'' said Steven Romalewski, who wrote a consumer products guide for the New York Public Interest Research Group. The 20-page guide, published last month, singled out products for what NYPIRG said were the worst examples of disposable, overpackaged and none-recyclable consumer products. Kodak's Fling was included in the guide's ``Top 10'' list. ``We are committed to finding acceptable ways to reduce the amount of waste either incinerated or going into landfills,'' Peter M. Palermo, Kodak's vice present and general manager of the consumer imaging division, said in a news release. The recycling program will be extended to Europe and other parts of the world next year, Kodak said. Late last year the photography giant announced a recycling plan for the plastic canisters in which 35mm film is packaged.

DOC.HEAD: Unused Refinery, Shipping and Storage Operation To Be Sold to Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. will sell an unused refinery and an operating shipping and storage facility in the Bahamas to Venezuela's state-owned oil company, Chevron announced Thursday. No terms were disclosed for the mostly cash deal with Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., which owns the Citgo oil company. The deal must be approved by the governments of the Bahamas and Venezuela. The 500,000-barrel-per-day refinery was shut in 1985, but storage facilities for 20 million barrels and marine facilities that can accommodate ships carrying up to 500,000 tons have been used almost continuously since the entire facility was opened by Chevron in 1970. The operation in Freeport on Grand Bahama Island was run by Chevron as the Bahamas Oil Refining Co. Besides cash, Chevron will receive a long-term contract for future storage services at the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Hears Federated's Request
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped after end of hearing, expected about 8 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. treasurer Mark Kennedy told a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge Thursday that $400 million in bank credit is needed to prevent the retailer's collapse. Kennedy said Federated did not have enough cash to keep operating another 30 days. He said Federated had been rejected by other lending institutions and that the loan arranged through a Citibank-led syndicate is needed to keep the company functioning. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., in a day-long hearing that continued into Thursday evening, heard Federated officials testify in support of the company's petition for the financing. Federated and Allied Stores Corp., the U.S. department store chains held by Toronto-based Campeau Corp., are operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors while they attempt to work out a plan to pay their huge debts. The bankruptcy judge must approve major company expenditures or other business deals. Aug has scheduled a similar hearing Friday to consider approval for a $300 million loan Allied negotiated with a group led by New York-based Chemical Bank. Federated's lawyers said the Citibank-promised loan agreement will not be available if approval is not obtained by the Feb. 14 deadline imposed by the banks. About 100 banks are participating in the syndicate and more than half of them are foreign institutions, lawyers for the banks have said. The Federated unsecured creditors' committee opposes the loan. The committee says Federated does not need the money and has enough cash on hand. The creditors say the borrowing would only increase the corporation's interest payments. Kennedy testified Federated officials believe that if approval of the credit is denied, they will lose the little leverage they have to negotiate a loan. Kennedy testified, ``I think it's absolutely critical. The existence of the loan is mandatory to re-establish our credibility in the eyes of our creditors ... A headline which says `Federated DIP Rejected' would have a disastrous effect,'' referring to the so-called debtor-in-possession financing. Federated and its fellow Campeau Corp. retailing subsidiary, Allied Stores Corp., filed Chapter 11 reorganization petitions Jan. 15 to obtain Bankruptcy Court protection from creditors while financing plans are developed. In filing for Chapter 11 protection, Federated listed $7.7 billion in debts, amassed when Campeau bought the retailers, both headquartered in Cincinnati. Allied and Federated operate 260 stores and employ a combined 100,000 people. Under cross examination Thursday, Kennedy said Federated has $250 million cash on hand. But he said that would disappear and the company would likely fail if it were forced to spend all its cash to buy merchandise. Creditors contended there is no need for some of Federated's profitable store chains to be included in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy case. Lawyers for the creditors' committee provided statements at Thursday's hearing showing that New York-based Bloomingdale's, Miami-based Burdines and Atlanta-based Rich's all had net worths of more than $1 billion. ``Our concern is long-term ... When the debtors reach a point when they need to build substantial inventories in the fall and winter, the vendor community will not be inclined to meet the substantial needs of the debtor,'' said Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer for the creditors' committee.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Hears About Protecting Small Investors
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators are exploring what to do about a kind of investment scheme known as a ``blank check blind pool'' that often victimizes small investors, a Senate panel was told Thursday. Blank check blind pools are public stock offerings in which the issuer doesn't spell out how it plans to use the money raised. Critics of such pools charge they are often sham corporations brought to the marketplace as vehicles for shady purposes. They were discussed by several witnesses testifying before the securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, which is looking at ways to protect small investors from penny stock fraud and other scams. ``We need more tools to combat the problem,'' Susan E. Bryant, administrator of the Oklahoma Securities Department told the panel, which was chaired by Sen. Richard H. Bryan, D-Nev. Last week Bryan introduced a bill to protect small investors. The bill, which would allow the Securities and Exchange Commission to bar such blank check blind pools from registering their securities, contained provisions sought by the SEC to beef up their enforcement powers. Last week SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said he wanted the ability to to issue cease and desist orders against suspected wrongdoers without having to go to courtm first. Breeden also said Congress should affirm federal judges' rights to bar repeat securities law offenders from serving as officers or director of public companies. On the blank check blind pool, Richard Ketchum, head of the SEC's Division of Market Regulation, conceded ``it is a vehicle that has been used for fraudulent activity, particularly the penny stock market more and more frquently.'' But he and Joseph I. Goldstein, head of the SEC's Penny Stock Task Force, cautioned that clearer definitions were needed. Goldstein said he has asked the SEC Division of Economic Analysis to study the issue ``to see if further regulatory steps should be taken.'' Fraud involving penny stocks _ low-cost, high-risk securities trading for as little as a penny a share _ is estimated to cost American investors $2 billion a year. ``It's very, very hard to recover it,'' said Goldstein, adding that the ``most effective defense against penny stock fraud is an educated investor.'' Penny stocks, which are usually not listed on any stock exchange or national stock quotation system, are not illegal and often not fraudulent. But the scarcity of information about them and the limited amount of surveillance they come under make them prone to numerous fraud schemes. One victim who managed to recover most of the $17,000 she and her husband lost to a penny stock fraud artist said the experience was devastating. ``Losing the money was terrible. Being lied to and misled by people we thought we could trust was worse,'' said Debra Thomason, a secretary from Elberton, Ga. Her husband Bobby, an electrician, said the senators might wonder how the couple got in such a fix. ``The only thing I can tell you is that we trusted these people. Just the same way you trust your doctor or you would trust your mechanic. If you took your car in and he said you needed brakes, you're not going to sit there and argue with him,'' Thomason said.

DOC.HEAD: Sea Containers Announces $490 Million Recapitalization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Sea Containers Ltd. announced Thursday that its board of directors has decided to recommend to shareholders a recapitalization plan worth as much as $490 million. Sea Containers, which operates ferries in the English Channel, said the plan calls for the company and certain subsidiaries to buy up to 7 million common shares at $70 each in cash. The plan values the entire company, with 13.8 million shares outstanding, at around $966 million. Sea Containers is the target of a $1.04 billion, or $70 a share, hostile bid by Temple Holdings Ltd., a Swedish and British ferry consortium. Sea Containers closed at $63.75 a share Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, down $2.87{ from Wednesday. Temple is owned by Sweden's Stena Holdings AG and Britain's Tiphook PLC. Stena already owns about 8 percent of the stock of Sea Containers, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda. In a statement, Sea Containers said the recapitalization will be subject to completion of previously announced asset sales totaling some $1.1 billion to Tiphook and Stena UK Ltd. Sea Containers shareholders are scheduled to vote on the recapitalization plan, as well as the proposed asset sales, at a meeting on March 15.

DOC.HEAD: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines Orders Up to 15 McDonnell Douglas MD-11s
DOC.TEXT: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ordered 10 McDonnell Douglas MD-11 aircraft worth $1.3 billion, representing the biggest initial order so far for the tri-jet jumbo. The Netherlands' national carrier also took options for another five MD-11s. Deliveries of the first 10 aircraft will begin in December 1993 and continue through November 1995. Delivery schedules for the five option aircraft will be established later. The contract for the 265-seat passenger planes, spare parts and services was worth an estimated $1.3 billion, said McDonnell Douglas spokesman Don Hanson. The aircraft will be assembled in Long Beach. The MD-11s will have a non-stop range in excess of 8,200 miles an speeds reaching 588 mph. KLM will use the aircraft on its long-range routes to South America, the Caribbean, the Middle East and Africa. The airline selected the MD-11 after a competition with the twin-jet Boeing 767 and the four-engine Airbus A340. The first flight of an MD-11 was Jan. 10. The aircraft currently is undergoing certification by the Federal Aviation Administration, a process McDonnell Douglas has said it hopes to complete this year. The company said it has orders and options for 340 of the aircraft to date. In Seattle, meanwhile, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said it received an order worth $450 million for 15 737-300 jets from Varig, the Brazilian airline. The twinjets will seat 132 passengers in a single-class configuration. They will be equipped with CFM56-3B2 engines built by CFM International, a joint venture between General Electric Co. and Snecma of France. Boeing spokesman Tom Cole said the company has delivered or received orders for 928 of the 737-300s since the plane went into service in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Bellcore Says It Has Discovered New Power Source
DOC.TEXT: Researchers said Thursday they have discovered a new electrical power source that could replace traditional rechargeable batteries to supply emergency backup power. The system is a small fuel cell that converts gas to electricity using thin films. Bellcore scientist Christopher Dyer, who discovered the process, compared it to a solar cell, but said it is powered by gases instead of sunlight. He described it as a ``very clean power source'' that is fueled by hydrogen and oxygen, leaving water as the only byproduct. However, the applications are limited until the device can be increased in size. Bellcore, the research arm for several regional telephone companies, is looking for manufacturing partners. The thumb-size laboratory prototype generates electricity when hydrogen or other fuel gases are ``blown'' over two electrodes separated by a thin membrane in the presence of oxygen. ``It could replace batteries if we could make it somewhat bigger than what we have,'' Dyer said, adding that a fuel cell does not need to be recharged like a battery. Fuel cells run as long as there is a constant supply of gas. Dyer said Bellcore acquired a patent for the device last fall. A description of the experiment appears in the Feb. 8, 1990, issue of Nature, a prestigious London science journal. The announcement was made by Bellcore, a research group for the seven `Baby Bell' regional phone companies _ Ameritech, Bell Atlantic, BellSouth, NYNEX, Pacific Bell, Southwestern Bell Corp. and US West _ as well as Cincinnati Bell and the Southern New England Telephone Co.

DOC.HEAD: Experts to Study Generic Approval Process
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `Bolar Pharmaceutical...' to UPDATE with FDA official saying Bolar temporarily suspended distribution of all products Friday. Picks up 9th graf pvs `Jere Goyan ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association said Thursday that it had formed a panel of independent experts to examine the government's drug approval process in the wake of the generic drug fraud and bribery scandal. The seven medical, legal and pharmaceutical experts will make recommendations for changes ``to reassure the American people that generic drugs are properly evaluated and safe and effective,'' said Lewis A. Engman, a Washington lawyer heading the committee. ``There are clearly some bad apples that have been uncovered,'' said Engman, a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission and a former president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. Committee members will talk to people in the generic drug industry and the Food and Drug Administration and others ``to try to get a handle on the scope of these problems,'' he said. The scandal in the $7 billion generic drug industry became public last spring and led to bribery convictions of three generic drug company executives and bribe-taking convictions of three FDA employees. The investigations also uncovered evidence that some drug companies cheated on tests required to win FDA approval and prompted recalls of dozens of generic drugs, including the lower-priced versions of some popular drugs. In one case, recalls of two generic products have left SmithKline Beecham's anti-hypertension drug Dyazide, one of the most widely prescribed drugs in the country, without any generic competition. Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc. last week withdrew its version because it appeared false documents had been used to support the company's claims for the product. Last summer, Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. withdrew its generic from the market last summer after admitting it substituted samples of the brand-name drug for its product in potency tests. In another development Thursday, an FDA source said Bolar temporarily suspended distribution of all products last Friday while company officials discusses with the FDA a list of products the agency wants to audit. The products are ``narrow therapeutic range'' drugs, which work within a smaller range of potency than most drugs, the source said. Bolar officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Jere Goyan, a committee member who headed the FDA from 1979-81 and is now dean of the School of Pharmacy at the University of California in San Francisco, said he does not believe there is a major flaw in the FDA's process for approving generic drugs. ``All of the drugs that have gone through the approval process that haven't been switched have certainly measured up and are therapeutically equivalent to the innovator product,'' he said. The committee hopes to complete its work within six months, he said. The FDA and the Justice Department are continuing their investigations into generic drug approvals, as is a House subcommittee, which uncovered the original evidence of impropriety. A committee within the Department of Health and Human Services, which includes FDA, is conducting review of FDA operations.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 grafs with environmentalists' criticism; Sen. Mitchell's response; Picks up 4th graf pvs: ``We are ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders said Thursday they were close to agreement with the Bush administration on compromise clean air legislation, but environmentalists charged the closed-door talks were weakening the bill too much. Key senators and administration officals have been meeting for more than a week in an attempt to craft an air pollution control package that will avert a divisive floor fight. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said that while the talks ``were making progress'' in key areas differences remained over how much to toughen automobile emissions standards to reduce urban smog. Mitchell, who had hoped a compromise package could be agreed upon this week, said he now has ruled out an agreement before the upcoming weeklong congressional recess. Environmentalists charged that the bill approved by the Environment and Public Works Committee last November was being watered down under intense pressure from the White House. ``They're not talking about any strengthening amendments, only weakening ones,'' said Richard Ayres, executive director of the Clean Air Coalition, an umbrella group of environmental and public health organizations. ``The public health is being negotiated away,'' charged Dan Weiss, who has been following the clean air debate for the Sierra Club. Mitchell said he expected the criticism, but said criticis ``should evaluate the final product against current law.'' The Maine Democrat said substantial progress was being made and that he was optimistic a compromise bill that will greatly tighten federal air pollution controls could be worked out. ``We are making progress,'' agreed Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate minority leader. But Dole said there continued to be deep concerns from some senators over the cost of new pollution controls, especially requirements cutting acid rain, which would hit a string of Midwest states the hardest. ``This is not a partisan measure,'' said Dole, adding that opposition and support of the legislation ``depends on where you live.'' The Senate leaders said that tentative agreements had been reached with the administration over controls of industrial toxic chemical releases and on contols of smog pollutants on businesses and industries in heavily polluted urban centers. But Mitchell said differences continued over provisions that would impose tough pollution controls on automobiles after the year 2003. The administration has called the requirements too expensive and argues that a requiring phasing in alternative fuel cars in heavily polluted urban areas would be cheaper and as effective. Mitchell said the discussions would resume after the Congress returns from its President's Day recess Feb. 20 and that he hoped that floor votes on a compromise bill could begin a few days later. ``We're very close (to an agreement) ... much more than three-fourths agreement,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., the bill's Democratic floor manager. But even if a compromise is reached, neither Mitchell nor Dole said they could rule out attempts by some senators to stall the legislation with a filibuster. A group of senators, largely from the Midwest, have threatened a filibuster if some ``cost sharing'' arrangement cannot be worked out to ease the expense of complying with expensive acid rain provisions, especially in the Midwest where most of the dirtiest plants are located. Both Mitchell and the Bush administration have ruled out a national energy tax or fee to share such costs, although some other form of cost sharing _ such as increased emission credits for the dirtiest electric power plants _ continued to be discussed. ``Cost sharing in the customary sense (of a fee or tax) is dead,'' said Baucus.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Output Growth Plunges In January
DOC.TEXT: China's industrial output fell a sharp 6.1 percent in January from a year earlier following a 10 percent drop in December, according to an official report. The State Statistical Bureau, in a report carried by the official China Daily Friday, attributed the big drop mainly to the Chinese lunar New Year holiday, which was marked in February in 1989 but fell on Jan. 27 this year. The lunar new year is China's biggest holiday and most enterprises shut down for three or four days. But the decline also continued the trend of stagnating economic growth that has persisted since mid-1989, when a tough government austerity program instituted shortly after the June political crackdown began to take effect on the economy. Industrial output rose 6.8 percent in 1989 over the previous year, but fourth-quarter growth was only 0.7 percent, and output in October fell 2.1 percent from the level of October 1988, the first monthly decline in a decade. Economists have estimated that up to a third of Chinese factories have had to suspend or reduce production because tight credit policies have left them without operating funds, and a downturn in demand has led to overstocking and poor sales. The bureau said industrial output totalled 127.8 billion yuan ($27.2 billion) in January, with light industry dropping 8.5 percent to 62 billion yuan ($13.2 billion) and heavy industry falling 3.5 percent to 65.8 billion yuan ($14 billion). State-run enterprises produced 88.4 billion yuan ($18.8 billion), down 6.5 percent, and collectively owned firms 34.1 billion yuan ($7.26 billion), down 7.1 percent. Small private firms produced most of the rest. The bureau also said production of most consumer goods fell as a result of the continued slump in the retail sales market. Refrigerator production was down 58.5 percent from a year earlier, washing machines were down 47.6 percent, color televisions 39.3 percent, bicycles 37.3 percent and automobiles 44.7 percent.
